DOC.HEAD: German Interest High in Bush-Gorbachev Summit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Summit-Bush
DOC.TEXT: Perhaps nowhere in Europe will there be as much interest in this week's summit meeting between George Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev as in the two Germanys _ East and West. With 380,000 Soviet troops stationed in East Germany and 250,000 U.S. troops in West Germany, the two nations that are about to become one have the keenest interest in superpower negotiations to drastically reduce foreign forces stationed on their soil. Along with the troops, some of the world's deadliest weapons are kept on German soil: high-tech jet fighters; nuclear-tipped, short-range rockets; and thousands of atomic artillery shells. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said earlier this month that it was up to Germans to decide ``the internal aspects'' of unification. On troop levels, Baker said outsiders could become involved in the discussions, but here, too, the Germans were in charge of their future. The troop negotiations, being conducted in Vienna, Austria, by NATO and the Warsaw Pact, have been flagging and will be one of the prime topics when Bush and Gorbachev meet for four days in Washington, beginning Thursday. Bush himself said last week that ``the talks haven't gone as far or as fast as I would like to see. ... Maybe we can find some way at the summit, or before the summit, to move CFE (the talks) forward.'' U.S. officials have said they feel Moscow is reluctant to conclude a Conventional Forces in Europe treaty unless there are assurances that the large West Germany army will not pose a threat after unification. One U.S. official, who requested anonymity, said recently that it would be difficult to complete a treaty this year because of the German issue and also because of Soviet concerns about the steadfastness of the East European allies. The day before Bush spoke, however, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said after meeting with his West German counterpart, Hans Dietrich Genscher, that Moscow ``advocates an acceleration in the Vienna negotiations.'' West German officials were quoted in Geneva, where the two men met, as saying the U.S. perception of Soviet hesitancy on the treaty might be a misunderstanding. Shevardnadze himself, asked if could confirm the purported Soviet position on the German military, replied, ``No.'' In December, the two superpowers agreed to slash their central European forces to 195,000 each, with the United States allowed to keep an additional 30,000 troops in Britain and southern Europe. There are now 305,000 U.S. troops and an estimated 565,000 Soviet troops in Europe. Looking toward the summit, Capt. Stefan Lang, a spokesman for the West German Defense Ministry, commented recently, ``We hope important signals in the direction of arms controls come out of the summit, but what exactly they will be we don't know.'' No one is more eager for major superpower cutbacks than the Germans. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government says it wants the eventual complete removal of Soviet and U.S. short-range nuclear weapons from German soil. ``We believe that the Lance (missile) and nuclear artillery have lost most of their significance, and therefore there should be thoughts about how these rockets can be negotiated away,'' Lang told The Associated Press. He stressed, however, that the Lance missiles should be removed only in negotiations, because ``the Soviets still have a huge superiority in this area. This should occur in a balanced way.'' An agreement to reduce conventional forces would open the way to negotiations on the superpowers' nuclear arsenals in Europe. Washington and the other NATO allies have said they are ready for talks with the Soviets on the short-range nuclear weapons, most of which are based in Germany. But NATO has not taken a clear stand on negotiating the numbers of these weapons down to zero. A feud could break out within NATO if attempts are made to replace short-range nuclear weapons in West Germany with air-launched rockets. ``I am warning against a new atomic arms race. New weapons are not needed,'' Genscher said recently. The future of NATO, and of American troops in Europe, could become a bone of contention as well. Some West German politicians, including Genscher, have warmed up to the Soviets' idea of creating new ``European security structures'' to take the place of NATO and the Warsaw Pact. But Washington and other NATO partners say they are vehemently against replacing NATO. The Social Democrats, Kohl's main political rivals, have also said NATO and the Warsaw Pact should be transformed into a new, Europe-wide security arrangement. The Social Democrats are pressing NATO to make major changes that would better reflect the rapid waning of the once-mighty, Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. ``It would be very good if the Americans prepared the way for this with constructive proposals (during the summit),'' Horst Ehmke, disarmament expert for the Social Democrats, said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Who Live Near Nuclear Test Site Meet American Counterparts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: On a windswept hill fragrant with prairie sage, the daughter of a Utah sheep rancher passed photographs of nuclear bomb blasts to the Kazakhs crowded around her. Eyes widened. ``We have seen such mushroom clouds from here, too,'' said a grizzled man in this Central Asia ranch town. Just like Janet Gordon's hometown of Cedar City, Utah, Karaul is 125 miles downwind from the spot where the government routinely tests nuclear bombs underground. Mrs. Gordon, 300 other foreign anti-nuclear activists and the people of Karaul on Sunday shared stories of death and disease they blame on radiation caused by the testing. They were taking part in a four-day conference of anti-nuclear activists from 21 countries. Atmospheric testing was conducted by the Americans and Soviets until it was banned under a bilateral treaty in 1963. Some radiation may have drifted across the border from above-ground testing in China until 1980. ``My father died,'' one Kazakh in an embroidered Moslem cap said to Mrs. Gordon. Under the old man's banner, which read, ``We are nuclear victims, too,'' a young mother grasped her little boy's shoulder. ``My son was sick until he was four years old,'' she said. ``He could not walk without falling down.'' ``I came to Kazahkstan to meet people like you,'' Mrs. Gordon replied. On the Central Asian steppe, similar to areas of Nevada near the U.S. test zone, activists traded fears, research and political strategy with local residents who in just one year have been transformed from silent victims to successful protesters. Soviet activists formed the Nevada-Semipalatinsk anti-nuclear movement, named for test sites in the two countries. They exerted enough pressure that the Soviet government has not conducted an underground nuclear blast at Semipalatinsk since October. Soviet authorities have not agreed to a moratorium. But the activists' meeting apparently had top-level approval, since the zone next to the test range is normally closed to foreigners. But police and security officials kept the group under tight control. ``This is my brother,'' Mrs. Gordon, 53, told the Kazakhs crowded around her photographs. ``He was watching our sheep when the cloud of radiation came over in 1954. He got burns on his arms, and his hair fell out. The sheep died. His horse died.'' Four years later, her teen-age brother had cancer of the pancreas. He died after four years, Mrs. Gordon said. The Kazakhs told stories of relatives crippled, retarded or sickly. In the 1950s, historian Amantai Isin recalled his family lived in a village within the boundaries of the test site. Officials would take them away during a blast but bring them back home the same day. No one ever suggested not drinking the milk from the family cows. After one great blast in 1954, Isin's 5-year-old brother came down with a terrible headache and died. His father and another brother both died in their 30s, he said. Isin is 39. The activists traded grisly statistics. Mrs. Gordon said 13 of 17 children born in one year in the 1950s in Cedar City, Utah had birth defects. Dr. Mayra Zhangelova, director of the Semipalatinsk Medical Institute, said birth defects per 10,000 births in the Soviet areas nearly tripled from 11.8 in 1980 to 29.2 in 1985. Foreign scientists in the group said the evidence of correlation to nuclear testing is strong but cannot be proved because of the time lag. Mrs. Gordon pulled out another photo, showing a plume pouring from the earth in 1970. The Kazakhs were shocked. This was long after both the United States and the Soviet Union agreed to keep all blasts underground. ``It was an accident,'' she explained. ``But accidents can happen.'' ``We also fear this,'' the crowd chimed in. ``Do you think there will be action on this at the summit?'' asked one Kazakh woman, referring to Wednesday's meeting between Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush in Washington. Mrs. Gordon replied that a U.S. ambassador had told her ``no.'' She said she infuriated the official by calling for nuclear tests underneath the Pentagon. ``That's great!'' beamed a Kazakh woman, reaching out to shake her hand.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Find Disturbing Parallels Between 1917 and 1990
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: For some students of history, the sense of deja vu is chilling: weakening central power faces discontent among ethnic groups, disgruntled workers and mutually suspicious intellectuals arrayed in myriad political parties. A cumbersome and ideology-laden bureaucracy finds it easier to stick to its old ways than to reform. With some vital differences, Mikhail S. Gorbachev in 1990 faces many of the same bewildering problems that caused the czarist empire to come crashing down around Nicholas II in the spring of 1917, and the provisional government of Alexander Kerensky to fall to the Bolsheviks that autumn. For Gorbachev, the warning is sounded in the official press, over tea at the kitchen table, and in the Congress of People's Deputies, where 84-year-old scholar Dmitri Likhachev warned against a nationwide presidential election. ``I remember the revolution of February (1917) very well, and I know where emotions can lead,'' Likhachev told parliament in March. ``Understand our conditions. Direct election of the president will lead to civil war.'' Writer Andranik Migranyan said in the weekly Literaturnaya Gazeta: ``Really, you can come to despair from the thought that in this country, everything repeats itself.'' Gorbachev's most stubborn problems are ethnic disputes and economic dislocation, familiar problems for pre-revolutionary leaders. The fringe areas of the Russian Empire that escaped during the turmoil of the revolution only to be patiently gathered in again by Stalin are asserting their independence. Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia are leading the way. The economy is in disarray. Industrial production fell 1.2 percent in the first three months of 1990. Strikes last summer by thousands of coal miners finally broke the long Communist prohibition against job actions. Regardless of legality, 130,000 people were on strike on any given day in the first quarter of the year. Store shelves are empty and people are angry. Strike committees still are active in many cities. At a recent meeting, representatives of about 50 of them declared a lack of confidence in the government's ability to reform the economy. Just as the Bolsheviks agitated for the overthrow of the czarist government and then Kerensky's provisional government, dozens of new political parties now are pressing to push the Communists out of power. The Soviet leader's opponents hark back to 1917 to argue that 72 years of Communist rule has brought the country little but ruin. In 1917, ``All Power to the Soviets'' was the slogan under which Lenin's legions took power. In 1990, protesters march with the same banner, demanding that the Communist Party bureaucracy turn power over to an elected parliament. ``The goal of a new party must not be to work within the system but to break up the system,'' Nikolai Travkin, a former Communist, told supporters of his drive to form an anti-Communist group. Repeating the experience of the past, the new parties often cannot agree on their own program much less a common front. Russian Social Democrats meeting in Moscow in early May spent much of their time debating whether local chapters would have to obey central authority. Such disputes paralyzed the Russian political system before the Bolshevik revolution and gave Lenin's highly disciplined minority the opening it needed to seize power. But there are important differences between 1917 and 1990. Many historians argue that czarist Russia, despite its archaic political system, could have been transformed peacefully if not for World War I, which began in 1914. The Russian economy was expanding rapidly, farm output was growing, and expenditures for education were increasing. The war exposed fatal weaknesses in political and economic administration, which led not only to military losses but severe food shortages in the cities, they argue. Gorbachev has resolutely avoided military conflicts. He has pulled Soviet soldiers out of Afghanistan, concluded arms control agreements with the West and started pulling soldiers out of Eastern Europe in order to spend more of the country's resources on the domestic economy. In contrast to Nicholas II and Kerensky, Gorbachev is a consummate inside politician, master of the system in which he has worked for more than 30 years. He has patiently isolated and eliminated his Communist Party foes and stands alone now atop both the government and party apparatus. Nevertheless, critics charge that he is dangerously late in making key reforms, and that he does not fully understand the country he governs. Vyacheslav Shostakovsky, rector of Moscow's Higher Party School and a leading party reformer, said Gorbachev is isolated by the party's inability to give him a real understanding of what people are feeling. ``His rare trips don't give him the emotional coloring,'' Shostakovsky said in an interview. ``That's why he was shocked by the May 1 events'' when protesters marched past him in a May Day parade and shouted their criticisms. If Gorbachev had understood the mood of the people, he would have been able to anticipate the angry reaction, Shostakovsky said. But Gorbachev consistently has shown a strong streak of realism. In February, less than two months after rejecting the idea, he led the party into accepting a multiparty system. At the same time the party adopted the principle of private property, and a new law going into effect on July 1 will allow Soviet entrepreneurs to hire labor. Speaking to reporters last week at a Moscow parliamentary session, Gorbachev indicated he sees in his reforms a comparison with Lenin in the first years of Soviet power. ``Take any sphere, everywhere we are hindered by complexes,'' he said. ``People are saying, `Chaos, chaos, collapse, collapse.' When Lenin watched a similar revolutionary process, he said, `You know, this chaos will crystallize a new form of life.''' ``We remain committed to the choice made in October 1917, the socialist idea,'' Gorbachev told the Communist Party Central Committee in February. ``But we are moving away from its dogmatic interpretation, refusing to sacrifice the people's real interests to rigid schemes.'' In 1990, once again, the Communists' opponents are split. The 19-million member party is by far the largest and best organized force in the country. It controls most media, has experienced party workers, and owns buildings and bank accounts. But the Communists face a split themselves. Conservatives forming a Russian Communist Party declared in a manifesto published May 13 that ``during the time of perestroika the economic situation in the country has been so aggravated that the existence of socialism, and the sovereignty of our government have been placed under threat.'' Shostakovsky said that unless Gorbachev pushes the party to radically reform itself at its 28th Congress this summer, he and many other progressives will quit. The party's dilemma is largely its own fault, Shostakovsky said in an interview with the newspaper Soyuz. Despite the unpleasant analogy with 1917, the party acts as though times have not changed, he said. The Communist Party ``first and foremost has remained a semi-military organization,'' he said. ``But outside the window, it's not 1917 any more!''

DOC.HEAD: Measure Doubling Gas Tax Tops California Ballot Measures
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Voters in the tax-revolt state are being asked to double gasoline taxes to keep highway traffic moving. California voters face June 5 ballot topics ranging from mountain lion hunting to legislative ethics, with the gas tax hike aimed at raising $18.5 billion topping the list. Proposition 111 would double the 9-cents-a-gallon tax on fuel over five years to finance the largest transportation investment in state history. The $18.5 billion would pay for new highway and railway construction aimed at thwarting freeway gridlock. A companion ballot measure sponsored by Gov. George Deukmejian would authorize a $1 billion bond issue just for rail transit construction. Environmentalists are pressing a similar but more generous measure that would provide $1.99 billion. Also on the ballot: _ a proposal to rewrite ethics guidelines for the Legislature, which has been rocked by a federal corruption probe. Critics call it a lawmakers' pay raise in disguise. _ a proposed mountain lion hunting ban, pushed by environmentalists but criticized by opponents who say the $30 million a year it would set aside for wildlife protection would divert money from more deserving programs. _ a plan to alter state justice system guidelines that critics call an attack on abortion rights. _ a pair of measures that would change how legislative district boundaries are drawn. In all, the seven bond measures on the California ballot total a record $5 billion. In addition to the two rail transit bond issue proposals, voters are being asked to approve bonds for low-income housing, public schools, state universities, and prisons, and to make state and local government buildings earthquake safe. The tax hike, Proposition 111, is backed by a bipartisan coalition of government, business and labor interests who forged the plan to combat deepening transportation woes. With less than two weeks before voting, the tax hike backers' internal polls showed a 7-point lead, compared with a 13-point margin in an independent poll taken in early May, according to published reports. Supporters say the gas tax increase is needed because road and rail construction have lagged in face of rising population. Drivers statewide waste more than 400,000 hours a day because the average urban highway speed has fallen to about 20 mph during commute hours. Planners fear future growth could broaden daily gridlock. In the next decade, the number of licensed drivers is expected to rise 18 percent. Strategists have been cheered by the lack of organized opposition, but the measure asks voters to raise their own taxes in a state that revolted against taxes, beginning with landmark property tax-slashing Proposition 13 in 1978. Proposition 11 is the measure that has been criticized by abortion rights activists. Supporters say it is aimed at limiting the rights of accused criminals to those stipulated by the Constitution. They say it would speed up prosecution and increase punishment powers. But foes say the proposition would erode a woman's right to abortion by eliminating privacy assurances in the state constitution. The state Supreme Court has interpreted the state constitution to give defendants greater rights than those granted in federal courts. Proposition 117 would ban the sport hunting of mountain lions and create a new program, funded with $30 million a year over the next three decades, for buying and restoring wildlife areas. Some environmental groups say it is needed to protect wildlife and wouldn't increase taxes, but opponents, including hunters groups, say the animals aren't in danger and the bill would take money away from existing programs. Propositions 118 and 119 address reapportionment. The boundary remapping is required by the state constitution every 10 years to balance populations among districts. Critics of the existing reapportionment system, in which Legislature-approved plans are submitted for gubernatorial approval, say it has allowed Democrats to maintain their dominance. Democrats counter that the proposals would unfairly enhance Republican interests. Proposition 118 would require that plans approved by the Legislature be submitted to voters. Proposition 119 would require that redistricting plans approved by an independent citizens commission go before the electorate. Proposition 112, the ethics reform law, would form a commission to set lawmakers' salaries, taking that task away from legislators. The measure was prompted in large part by an FBI undercover corruption probe that led to the conviction and resignation of one senator. A former senator remains under indictment. Supporters argue that it would reduce the influence of special interests, but foes say the measure would make it easier for legislators to get a pay raise without voting on it. Propositions rounding out the ballot would give the governor more time to consider bills after legislative sessions, would exempt the severely disabled from property tax increases when they move into a new home, would change chiropractor licensing procedures, and would expand instances in which the death penalty could be imposed for murder of peace officers.

DOC.HEAD: Hugo Instructive for Coastal Residents as Hurricane Season Begins
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Hurricane Season-Stress
DOC.TEXT: People caught by Hurricane Hugo last year might disagree, but forecasters here say the deadly storm may have had a positive side effect _ it got the public's attention. And one forecaster says hurricane seasons may be getting worse. Hugo, which caused an unprecedented $10 billion in damage, killed 28 people in the Lesser Antilles islands and an additional 29 in South Carolina. But it would have been much more deadly if it had hit almost anywhere else, says Bob Sheets, director of the National Hurricane Center. At the advent of the Atlantic hurricane season, which runs from June 1 to Nov. 30, Sheets and other hurricane experts are using Hugo's example to get the attention of complacent coastal residents who've never experienced such fury. ``We'll take advantage of the fact that there was a Hugo last year and raise people's awareness,'' said Sheets. ``The consequences of not being prepared are too great.'' Early warnings about Hugo last September allowed 350,000 people to evacuate safely, and in South Carolina the worst of the hurricane struck the Francis Marion National Forest between Charleston and Myrtle Beach, Sheets said. It heavily damaged the fishing village of McClellanville and several small rural communities, but the population there is sparse. If Hugo had struck a major coastal population center, the destruction would have been greater than most Americans have ever seen, according to computer simulations known as SLOSH models, for Sea, Lake and Overland Surges from Hurricanes. With SLOSH, forecasters can predict the height of the storm surge _ the mass of water piled up by the storm that is a hurricane's most destructive component _ anywhere along the U.S. coast by punching in a storm's speed, size and intensity, Sheets said. ``The population density in South Carolina is a lot different from the Florida coast, New Jersey or Galveston, Texas,'' Sheets said. ``Compare that situation to the Miami-through-Palm Beach area _ all of Dade, Broward and Palm Beach counties would have been ... destroyed.'' Hugo was the worst hurricane to strike the southeastern U.S. coast since Betsy hit the Florida Keys in 1965, killing 74 before it went on to Missisippi and Louisiana. Since then, the population of areas such as south Florida has ballooned and most residents have never directly experienced a hurricane. According to one of the nation's leading hurricane experts, Hugo may have been the first in a new era of killer storms. ``No one knows for sure, but the odds are, Florida and the East Coast are going to get it,'' William Gray, professor of atmospheric science at Colorado State University, told a national conference of weather experts this month. Gray came to this conclusion after his usually accurate predictions for hurricane activity were off the mark last year. He had figured the 1989 season would be relatively mild, with only four hurricanes; instead, seven hurricanes and four tropical storms killed a total of 84 people. ``He blew it pretty bad,'' Sheets said. ``But then he looked at the rainfall over Africa, and found an amazing correlation between rainfall there and hurricane activity over Florida.'' Gray realized the 30-year drought in Africa's Sahel region corresponds almost exactly to the years when no major hurricanes have struck the southeastern coast. ``Whether one causes the other is uncertain. They both may reflect larger-scale events. But the Sahel is now getting up to near-normal rainfall,'' Sheets said. Gray plans to release his predictions for 1990 on June 5. Tropical storms have been recorded in the Atlantic in every month except April, but are rare outside the June 1 to Nov. 30 season. Last week, a preseason tropical depression brought heavy rain to Cuba. A tropical depression becomes a tropical storm and is given a name if its sustained winds reach 39 mph; it becomes a hurricane if winds reach 74 mph. The names for Atlantic hurricanes and tropical storms this year are: Arthur, Bertha, Cesar, Diana, Edouard, Fran, Gustav, Hortense, Isidore, Josephine, Klaus, Lili, Marco, Nana, Omar, Paloma, Rene, Sally, Teddy, Vicky and Wilfred.

DOC.HEAD: Hurricane Season: Anxiety, Bad Memories For Hugo Victims
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Hurricane Season
DOC.TEXT: The start of the Atlantic hurricane season this week is a time of anxiety for many victims of last year's Hurricane Hugo. ``A lot of people are just barely back on their feet, if they are at all, and the thought that something like this could happen again is just frightening to them,'' said Veronique Aniel, a counselor with the statewide Hurricane Hugo Outreach Program. The hurricane season begins Friday and runs through Nov. 30. Hurricane Hugo smashed ashore last Sept. 21 with 135 mph wind and a 19-foot storm surge that caused an estimated $5.9 billion damage and killed 29 people in South Carolina. While most structures in Charleston have been cleaned and repaired, recovery in outlying areas has taken longer. Officials of the state Department of Mental Health, which operates the outreach program, say as many as 20,000 South Carolinians suffering post-traumatic stress syndrome are expected to develop long-term psychological problems as a result of the storm. ``We're anticipating stress because of the anniversary coming up and because of the hurricane season starting,'' said Linda Lane, a counselor in Berkeley County, one of the outlying areas hard-hit by the storm. ``We have children who are having difficulty in school when the rain or wind is blowing more than normal,'' she said. Some people will experience fear when the weather is similar to those before the storm, said Dr. Michael Foxworth, a psychiatrist who is medical director at Charter Hospital of Charleston. ``I think the emotional damage a person suffered in Hugo probably relates ... primarily to the duration of time their lives were totally out of their control,'' he said. ``The person who had time to evacuate and get to a safe place and then pretty quickly returned to their normal environment suffered less psychological impact than those who were totally without resources,'' he said. Foxworth said people will be watching weather reports and tracking hurricanes more closely this year. Before Hugo there was a sense of denial about hurricanes, a feeling that ``it can't happen here,'' he said. ``Now that it has, things swing the other way and it becomes a sense of expectancy that it will happen again ... even though the odds are probably no greater this year than before Hugo,'' he said. Some people say they will leave Charleston and never return if another storm hits, Ms. Aniel said. Others deny another storm could even happen. ``Some people don't even want to talk about it. They want to ignore the fact. If another one comes this way, what will these people do?'' she said. But the fact Charleston has recently been hit by a storm would make a future evacuation easier. ``You've experienced a bad hurricane and it's fresh in people's minds,'' said Mark Zimmer of the National Hurricane Center in Coral Gables, Fla. ``There won't be any difficulty convincing people it's a real threat.''

DOC.HEAD: West Berlin Planning Visas For Poles
DOC.TEXT: West Berlin plans to require visiting Poles to obtain visas in an attempt to curb the city's burgeoning black market, a spokesman for the federal government says. Roland Bachmaier, an Interior Ministry spokesman, said Monday that the Western allies, the West Berlin government and the West German government have been discussing the idea, but no date has been set. On Sunday, the West Berlin Morgenpost newspaper said the requirement would take effect July 1 and also apply to other Eastern Europeans. The paper said West Berlin authorities were concerned about the growing black market in the city, for which they blame visitors from Poland and other East European countries. A large West Berlin supermarket chain last week started restricting sales to Poles, limiting the amount of goods they can buy in each store. About 120,000 Poles flock to West Berlin every week, authorities say, many seeking jobs and trade on the black market. Berliner Morgenpost said Poles and other Eastern Europeans wishing to stay in West Berlin longer than one month would have to give ``convincing reasons'' for their stay and prove they have enough money to fund their visit.

DOC.HEAD: Two Women Dead In Shooting During Exchange of Baby's Custody
DOC.TEXT: A man pulled a handgun from a diaper bag and shot to death his estranged wife and mother-in-law Monday before shooting himself, police said. Dutchess County's second triple shooting in two days occurred about 6 p.m. in a YMCA parking lot during a meeting to transfer custody of a 10-month-old boy, Poughkeepsie police Lt. Arthur Regula said. Regula said two women were dead and the man was taken to Vassar Brothers Hospital in Poughkeepsie following the shooting. The man apparently shot himself, he said. Police said the suspect was seriously wounded. Regula said police probably would not release the victims' or the suspect's names pending notification of next of kin. The child's parents had been separated for about three weeks, police said. Police said the man had taken the child for the holiday and was returning the boy to his mother, who was accompanied by her own mother. Both women were from Wappingers Falls, police said. Capt. John Doherty said the child's mother had asked for a police officer to accompany her to the meeting. He said the officer arrived first and interviewed the man, who was reportedly calm and coherent. The officer then returned to his patrol car to watch the exchange, Doherty said. The man placed the boy in a child's car seat, then returned to his own car for a diaper bag. When he reached the mother's car again, he pulled a .22-caliber handgun from the bag and shot the two women and himself before the police officer could react, Doherty said. The child was unhurt, police said. On Sunday a Hyde Park man shot and killed his wife and wounded a neighbor before killing himself with a 12-gauge shotgun.

DOC.HEAD: Oldest Astronaut to Fly Making Final Flight
DOC.TEXT: He is, at 59, the oldest astronaut to ever fly in space. And that's too old, he says, to get back in line and wait _ hope _ for one more flight. As a result, Vance Brand expects the upcoming mission aboard shuttle Columbia to be his last journey into space. Brand will command the seven-man crew, four of whose members are astronomers and will operate a $150 million observatory called Astro. Liftoff is scheduled for 12:38 a.m. EDT Wednesday. ``I'll probably move on to a management job, a second career if you will, at this late date. But frankly, there isn't anything that beats flying in space,'' Brand said in a recent interview. ``Being an astronaut is a great job. I suppose a lot of people would do it until they were 90 years old if they could. But at the same time, why I've had a lot of enjoyment out of being an astronaut and I've had four flights. So I guess I'll maybe look at some other work.'' The trim, silver-haired Brand was chosen as an astronaut in 1966 after serving in the Marines as a naval aviator and later working as a test pilot. Brand made his first spaceflight in 1975 on the Apollo-Soyuz mission, in which the crews of the American and Soviet spacecraft docked in space. He was commander of the first fully operational flight of the shuttle system in 1982 and returned to space as a crew commander in 1984. His decision to make this flight his last is a matter of practicality. ``The big thing is it would be too long to stand in line to get the next flight,'' he said. NASA has 86 active astronauts, two of whom are older than Brand but have not flown for five or more years and are involved in management _ John Young, 59, and William Thornton, 61. A class of 23 will be added to the rolls this summer. The oldest astronaut to fly prior to Brand was Karl Henize, who was 58 when he flew in 1985 aboard Challenger. He is now a senior scientist at Johnson Space Center in Houston. There is no mandatory retirement age for astronauts. The average age is 41. ``It's about like any other job. It depends on the person's capabilities,'' Brand said. For about a year, Brand served as systems project manager for the proposed space station Freedom at Johnson Space Center. He stepped down last fall to devote all his time to the shuttle mission. That may be one of his roles within the National Aeronautics and Space Administration once Columbia returns to Earth, he said. ``There are a lot of challenges'' in management, Brand said. ``So it's just that I'll have to put one switch off and put another one on.''

DOC.HEAD: NFL Veteran With `Energy to Burn' Running for Congress
DOC.TEXT: Pro football veteran Phil McConkey compares himself to the new presidents of Czechoslovakia and Nicaragua in sizing up his chances of being elected to Congress. Neither Czechoslovakia's Vaclav Havel nor Nicaragua's Violeta Barrios de Chamorro had prior elected experience, says the GOP candidate from New Jersey. ``These people have what it takes to lead their people to better times,'' he says. ``Political experience has nothing to do with it.'' McConkey, who describes himself as ``a skinny street kid from Buffalo,'' is running an outsider's race against two veteran Republicans for the chance to face Democrat Marguerite Chandler in November. They are vying for the House seat being vacated by Republican Rep. Jim Courter, who is retiring. ``I've got energy to burn. I can't be outworked or outhustled by anybody,'' McConkey says. McConkey, 33, began his National Football League career as a wide receiver with the New York Giants, who he helped to a 1986 Super Bowl victory. He most recently was with the San Diego Chargers but has not signed a contract for 1990. He models himself after Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, the onetime Buffalo Bills quarterback and former New York congressman, and puts forth a combination of energy, fiscal conservatism and patriotism. Although Kemp has made no endorsement in the GOP primary, he says he has offered a ``helping hand'' to encourage McConkey's no-new-taxes, right-to-life bid. Polls show McConkey trailing state Assemblyman Rodney Frelinghuysen and state Sen. Richard A. Zimmer in the GOP primary. But Richard Roper, director of the Council on New Jersey Affairs at the Woodrow Wilson School in Princeton, N.J., said it's possible McConkey could win if the other two candidates split the moderate GOP vote. Rutgers University political scientist Steve Salmore was more pessimistic about McConkey's chances, noting that few issues distinguish the three candidates other than abortion, where Frelinghuysen and Zimmer are pro-choice. McConkey, however, is his own cheering squad. ``I'm always the underdog and up against insurmountable odds,'' he said. As an example of his determination, McConkey cites his decision to return to football at age 27 after five years as a Navy helicopter pilot. McConkey, a 1979 graduate of the Naval Academy, proceeds undaunted against Frelinghuysen, whose father once held Courter's House seat, and Zimmer, whose state legislative district dominates the congressional district. ``Pressure is landing a 10-ton helicopter on the back of a rolling, pitching deck at night or standing under a punt in front of 80,000 people in the stands and millions on TV with 11 maniacs foaming at the mouth ready to decapitate you,'' he said. McConkey, who has put $40,000 of his own money into the campaign, has postponed his planned June wedding and is focusing solely on the upcoming primary. ``My life goes from here to June 5. If you start worrying about things that aren't in line with your goal, it's taking away from your energy and enthusiasm,'' he said. McConkey talks about attracting minorities to the party, although Roper describes the congressional district's voters as overwhelmingly white, moderate to middle-income Republicans. ``It's an issue of bringing the party back to a Lincoln party, a party of the people,'' McConkey said. He echoes the ``politics of inclusion'' philosophy of Kemp and former New Jersey GOP Gov. Thomas H. Kean. McConkey won't discuss plans for his pro football career except to say retirement from the Chargers has been on his mind. ``Football is an avocation, not a vocation,'' he said. His campaign has relied heavily on radio and cable television advertising, as well as old-fashioned community campaign appearances. He also involves sports colleagues, including former NFL teammates Lawrence Taylor, Phil Simms and Mark Bavaro. Former New York Knicks guard Earl ``The Pearl'' Monroe joined former Washington Redskins quarterback Joe Theismann in co-hosting McConkey's only Washington fundraiser, a $150-a-person cocktail party last week. Besides his political and athletic pursuits, McConkey also has several business ventures pending. He is part-owner of McConkey's restaurant in his home town of Flemington and also is developing a shopping center and awaiting a patent on an electronics timekeeping device for sporting events.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders See Summit as Chance for Progress on Historic Arms Treaty
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union enter this week's summit with renewed momentum toward clinching a treaty that for the first time would require each side to reduce the number of long-range nuclear weapons. While a treaty won't be ready for formal agreement when President Bush begins four days of meetings with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Thursday, the two men are expected to issue a joint statement this weekend declaring the main provisions of the pact to be settled. The details, on the other hand, could be months away. Bush and Gorbachev are expected to agree to drastically reduce their stockpiles of chemical weapons and to end production of those weapons. In addition, they are expected to call for ratification of two existing pacts limiting nuclear tests. U.S. and Soviet officials met during the weekend in an effort to settle arms control issues. The administration has said Bush also will press Gorbachev for a commitment to speed up NATO-Warsaw Pact negotiations to reduce tanks, troops and other conventional armaments in Europe. Progress in these talks has slowed recently. These will be the main arms control features of the summit, which comes almost exactly eight years after U.S. and Soviet negotiators met in Geneva to begin the Strategic Arms Reduction Talks. Yet to be settled before a START treaty can be formally signed are anti-cheating provisions and the question of whether to limit mobile, land-based missiles such as the Soviet SS-24 and the proposed American Midgetman, plus a number of other, relatively minor, points of disagreement. Aides to Bush and Gorbachev are set to work throughout the summit on disputed START issues and negotiating teams in Geneva plan to press ahead this summer in hopes of pulling the final pieces together in time for a year-end summit signing ceremony. Analysts say the chances of success are high. Bush and Gorbachev are expected to announce an agreement, probably not in the form of a treaty, to destroy all but 5,000 tons of each side's chemical weapons arsenal. This would be intended as a catalyst for concluding a global ban on chemical arms in the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva. Terms for ensuring compliance with the U.S.-Soviet deal have yet to be settled. The summit also is to declare the two sides' agreement on a U.S.-Soviet protocol for verifying compliance with 1974 and 1976 treaties that limit the size of underground nuclear tests. Bush and Gorbachev are expected to say the agreement will permit both sides to push for legislative ratification of the treaties. The proposed START treaty, if completed and ratified, would represent an important step in disarmament. It would require about a one-third reduction in numbers of long-range nuclear weapons and also may lead to follow-up negotiations to cut strategic nuclear forces even further. Previous treaties on strategic arms, including the unratified 1979 SALT II accord, limited the growth of long-range weaponry but did not actually reduce their numbers. The proposed new treaty would reduce the combined U.S. and Soviet strategic nuclear warhead totals from about 23,500 now to about 16,000 by the late 1990s. ``START makes good sense for the United States,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III told reporters last week in defending the administration's negotiating record. Yet the proposed accord is being attacked by critics at both ends of the U.S. political spectrum. Conservatives say it concedes too much to the Soviets while liberals say it doesn't go far enough in forcing a shift away from nuclear confrontation. Baker has come under heavy attack for dropping a longstanding U.S. demand that the START treaty prohibit all Soviet upgrading of its SS-18 land-based intercontinental ballistic missile, the backbone of the Soviet strategic arsenal. ``It's a travesty,'' said Frank J. Gaffney Jr., director of the Center for Security Policy, a Washington think tank. He contends that SS-18 qualitative improvements that may be permitted under START would offset the effects of Moscow's agreement to reduce the number of SS-18s by 50 percent over a seven-year period. The treaty as now drafted would not require such drastic reductions in any element of the U.S. strategic arsenal. The proposed cut in U.S. ballistic missiles would be about 35 percent, while the total number of warheads for strategic forces, including bombers and sea-based weapons, would be 25 percent, according to Stan Norris of the private Natural Resources Defense Council. Norris sees only limited value in the treaty. He argues that it would merely codify arms cuts that both superpowers were planning anyway because of budget pressures and aging systems. ``As with many past treaties, this will be arms control without pain or sacrifice,'' he said. The actual size of the reductions is difficult to calculate because no one is sure what political and financial forces will bear on each country's military between now and the end of the treaty's proposed seven-year implementation period. It's unclear, for example, how many more of the new B-2 stealth bombers the Pentagon will buy at the going rate of $815 million each. Jack Mendelsohn, deputy director of the private Arms Control Association and a former member of the U.S. delegation to the SALT II and START negotiations, calculates that the cut in American strategic nuclear warheads may be as little as 6 percent. He figures the Soviet reduction may be less than 15 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Fifth-Grade Prize Winner Sees `No More Wars Anywhere'
DOC.TEXT: As George Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev meet this week for summit talks that may shape the future, an 11-year-old girl from Aberdeen, Wash., is predicting the world will celebrate ``no more wars anywhere'' in just two decades. Sabrina ``Breezy'' Carter's vision of the future, which won a first prize, $4,000 scholarship in a nationwide essay contest of 16,000 youngsters, includes the election of a female U.S. president, a cure for the common cold and ray guns that will zap the dirt out of laundry. Miss Carter, a fifth-grader at McDermoth School at Aberdeen, will fly to Washington this week to read her essay and accept her prize in the ``Time Capsule Contest'' sponsored by Prodigy Services Co., a personal computer services firm based in White Plains, N.Y. The awards ceremony will take place at the Capital Children's Museum on Thursday, the first day of the Bush-Gorbachev summit. Breezy won first prize among elementary school pupils. Other top winners were Heidi Brewer, 15, of San Diego, in the junior high category, and Loretta Vidos, 17, of Deer Park, Texas, among senior high students. In an essay addressed to her ``yet-to-be-born child,'' Miss Carter gave this upbeat prediction for the year 2010: ``I do not believe you will need to wash and dry clothes in your day. You will probably have a little ray gun that you will point at the clothes and when you pull the trigger, all the dirt will be made to jump right out of the clothes. ``I think there will be only healthy food that will not make us fat or sick. ``In the year 2010, I think there will be a lady president. By this time, I think that people in America will finally have realized that women can do just as good a job as men, and perhaps sometimes, an even better job. ``In your day, I believe there will be two important new holidays, Children's Day and Peace Day. ``People will truly love children. I think people will have to get a license to have children to prove that they will be good parents. This way, children will no longer be abused. ``On Peace Day, the world will celebrate no more wars anywhere. ``As a doctor, you will sit in front of a screen and talk to other doctors, nurses and patients. There will be a huge screen that will show a doctor how a cell is working inside a patient's body. ``In our year, we have several terrible diseases such as cancer, AIDS, allergies and the common cold. In your year of 2010, I think you will have cures for all of these diseases.'' Miss Brewer, the junior high winner, predicted that in two decades an environment-minded world will replace fossil fuels with solar energy and pollution-free automobiles will be powered by hydrogen. Human life expectancy will be 120 years. ``There is more living space available because the population is carefully monitored and controlled by foolproof birth control methods now being devised by the French and which will apply to everyone,'' she wrote. Miss Vidos, the high school winner, forecast a world in which telecommunications advances produced ``an amazing harmony'' among cultures. As a result, she wrote, ``the prejudiced were practically obsolete, for there was no more ignorance about their fellow neighbors.'' In a telephone interview from Aberdeen, Miss Carter said she hopes the Bush-Gorbachev summit will foster her vision of a world without war in 20 years. ``They might,'' she said. ``We'll see. Maybe it will happen, if all the countries talk together, work out their problems and come to an agreement.'' The essay contest was held in cooperation with the Christa McAuliffe Institute for Educational Pioneering, a private, non-profit organization established to honor the Concord, N.H., schoolteacher killed in the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: 1990 Census Can be a Con Artist's Dream
DOC.TEXT: It's a con artist's dream. After years of learning to lock doors and install burglar alarms, Americans are being told it's their patriotic duty to open their homes to strangers. It's the U.S. Census 1990, and some swindlers are taking advantage: _An 80-year-old North Carolina woman was tied up and robbed by two men she thought were census workers. _People claiming to be census employees charged Houston residents $50 after helping them complete their forms. Census officials say such scams have to be expected. ``When you do something this massive, there's someone who will figure an angle to get money from it,'' said Noe Balli of the census' regional office in Dallas. He warned, ``Anybody who wants money, they're obviously not census employees.'' There are 200,000 to 230,000 official census enumerators combing the countryside, knocking on doors of those who failed to complete the form sent out this spring, according to Mark Mangold of census headquarters. Each worker is armed with a red, white and blue badge identifying the holder by name and I.D. number as a ``U.S. Census Enumerator.'' In addition, each worker carries a large black satchel with a red, white and blue patch that says U.S. Census 1990, said Ray Bancroft of the census promotion office. To keep from becoming the victim of an imposter, people should demand to see identification and, if they have questions, they should call the local census office for verification or call the police before allowing the person inside their home, census officials said. Bancroft noted that impersonating a census worker carries a maximum sentence of three years in prison and a $1,000 fine. There have been isolated incidents of con artists during every census, Bancroft said, and this year is no different. However, FBI spokeswoman Kelley Cibulas said there is no reason for panic because the impostors have been few in number. But some people have not been wary enough. In the North Carolina case, the woman initially allowed only one man into her home and was having a ``nice conversation'' with him when the doorbell rang and the man told her it was his partner, said Tom Smith Jr. of the Charlotte, N.C., office. ``They tied her up and commenced taking some valuable things from the house as well as her car,'' Smith said. ``They tied her hands and feet and she sat on the couch and watched them take the things.'' She was not injured, he said. In Houston, people identifying themselves as census workers went to homes and helped the occupants complete the questionnaires. Then they charged them $50 for the help, Balli said. The so-called census workers didn't even have copies of the questionnaire but used those sent to the residents, he said. Another Houston resident complained, meanwhile, that someone identifying himself as a census worker telephoned seeking credit information and credit card numbers, Balli said. In Colorado, a woman identifying herself as a census worker asked an elderly woman resident for money. The request was refused and the elderly woman called officials, said Ron Ritschard of the Denver census office. There were no other reports of similar incidents, he said. Nevada residents complained about a mailing that said ``Official Census Form'' on the envelope but actually was sent by a clothing manufacturer, said Bob Clingman of the regional census office in Seattle. ``There are some innocuous questions, and they say if you send it in on time, you can get a special price on two pairs of our new jeans for only $29.95,'' Clingman said. The case was not pursued because the manufacturer's name was included on the mailing envelope, he said. Not everything that appears to be a scam is a scam, noted B.J. Welborn of the regional census office in Boston. For example, people shouldn't necessarily be suspicious if a person identifying himself as a census worker seeks someone's Social Security number, she said. While the census under way this year does not require the number, it is needed for some surveys being conducted by the Census Bureau. However, Welborn warned people to be alert if the person asks for bank account numbers, as no census survey seeks such information. Sometimes it's the census workers who are victimized, officials said. About two months ago, a fearful homeowner shot an enumerator, who survived, said Balli of Texas. The assailant ``was an elderly gentleman in Mississippi who had been vandalized so many times, and he saw this fellow on his property,'' Balli said. The tires of one census worker's car were slashed in northern New Jersey, said Stephanie Lowe of the bureau's Philadelphia office.

DOC.HEAD: Patient Dies After Surgical Sheets Catch Fire in Operating Room
DOC.TEXT: An auto accident victim died on the operating table after sheets covering her caught fire and filled the room with smoke, officials say. An autopsy was ordered to determine whether Angela Hernandez, 26, died of her accident injuries or was killed by the blaze Monday at UCLA Medical Cener. Engineers checked oxygen lines, electrical circuits and other equipment for the cause of the fire, said Rich Elbaum, a medical center spokesman. No other injuries were reported, but the smoke forced the closing of all 16 operating rooms for the day so they could be sterilized. Ms. Hernandez had been in critical condition with heart and liver injuries after being crushed in an accident late Sunday in Santa Monica, police said. She apparently was trying to warn motorists of her disabled car when another car struck her vehicle, which in turn hit Ms. Hernandez, police said. Surgeons had finished operating on the Los Angeles woman and were about to take her out of the room on a gurney when the sheets and blankets ignited, said Fire Department spokesman Pat Marke. Staff members tried to put out the fire but were forced out of the room by smoke, said campus spokeswoman Vicki Beck. By the time firefighters arrived some five minutes later, the blaze had mostly burned itself out, Marek said. ``The fire wasn't even hot enough to set off the sprinklers in the ceiling,'' said Battalion Chief Chuck Merriman. He estimated damage at $40,000. In 1988, a 15-day-old boy was fatally burned at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center when the spark from a cauterizer _ a pen-like instrument used to stop bleeding from an incision _ ignited the high-oxygen atmosphere in the room. UCLA Medical Center officials declined to say whether doctors Monday had been using a cauterizer. In February, a man described as a disgruntled hospital worker walked into a office at the medical center and fatally shot a co-worker and wounded his boss.

DOC.HEAD: Forecasters See Use of Wheat for Feed Rising Worldwide
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Department forecasters are projecting an increasingly narrow gap between wheat and corn prices that they say could mean a shrinkage of as much as 3 million tons in U.S. corn exports over the year ahead. That is because feed-quality wheat, priced at increasingly competitive levels, is likely to take over some sales from corn. The United States, the European Community, Eastern Europe, Korea and the Soviet Union are all expected to use more wheat for feed, raising the total to 105 million tons worldwide, the department says. USDA's Foreign Agriculture Service is thus forecasting the volume of U.S. corn exports in the 1990-91 trade year down 3 million tons from the current level. The department has been estimating corn exports in the current year at 55 million tons. Lower wheat prices also are likely to send some countries into the market to look for additional wheat, notably the Soviet Union and South Korea, the department said. The main reason for the projected lowering of wheat prices is a sizeable crop in sight for next year, estimated by USDA recently at almost 2.7 billion bushels plus beginning stocks of 442 million bushels. A recent USDA report saw farm prices for wheat falling from a current $3.71 a bushel to the range of $2.90 to $3.30 a bushel. Corn prices were projected to be in the range of $2.25 to $2.65 a bushel.

Red meat and poultry production this year may rise about 2 percent over 1989, according to Agriculture Department economists. USDA's latest Livestock and Poultry Situation and Outlook Report says, however, that poultry meat is expected to be up about 7 percent while red meat production is more likely to drop 1 percent from last year. It said returns would be positive for broilers and eggs, near the break-even point for turkey producers and favorable for pork producers. The report said that corn prices may rise from recent levels of $2.30 to $2.40 a bushel, even with a projected 1990 crop of 8.1 billion bushels. The price of corn is crucial for livestock and poultry producers because it is a prime source of feed. USDA forecasters say broiler production could increase 7 percent this year, reflecting a healthy market over the last three years. Turkey production also could climb in the 7 percent range, the department said. Total egg production was forecast up 1 percent. But USDA economists said commercial pork production is expected to be done about 2 percent this year because of poor returns in 1989. They said beef production may rise slightly.

USDA researchers expect to introduce 30 new varieties of landscape plants over the next three years, including a hybrid elm variety designed to be resistant to Dutch Elm disease. ``These hybrids could mean that American elms reappear on the scene,'' says geneticist Alden M. Townsend of USDA's National Arboretum. The arboretum, splashed with color much of the year and spread across 444 acres in the nation's capital, is a world center for developing trees, shrubs, grass and other ground covers. It has introduced 150 varieties of landscape plants since it was established by Congress 63 years ago, according to an article in the May issue of USDA's Agricultural Research magazine. Arboretum researchers have fanned out across the world in quest of uncataloged varieties. With financing help from the Friends of the National Arboretum, a private group, staffers have visited China, Korea, the British isles and other far-flung spots. The arboretum provides magnificent spectacles _ an array of color-washed gardens and a Great Meadow where visitors can see _ standing against the sky like ancient Grecian ruins _ 24 white sandstone corinthian columns that once graced the East Portico of the Capitol. Replaced with marble columns three decades ago, the huge columns were rescued by Friends of the National Arboretum from the muddy banks of the Anacostia River where they had been deposited in 1973. But the most important task at the arboretum may be breeding new plants. Among its most impressive contributions have been three ornamental pear trees. Former Director John Creech first spotted the Bradford pear _ marked by snowy blossoms and a resistance to fire blight disease _ in the arboretum's Glenn Dale, Md., nursery. A seed collected in China in 1917 by USDA plant hunter Frank Meyer had produced the tree, which had grown largely unnoticed. Over the last 30 years, millions of Bradford pears have been planted across the country, including two placed in front of the White House by Lady Bird Johnson in 1966. When Bradford pears proved too tall to be practical on some city streets, the arboretum developed more compact varieties, the Whitehouse and Capitol.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Tells US Teachers of Education Reform
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: It was in the 10th grade that the unusually outspoken student was sent to the principal's office for arguing about government with his teacher. Even today, Mikhail S. Gorbachev remembers the incident that underscored for him the need for free thought and expression. He told the story with relish to two American educators who visited him at the Kremlin shortly after he became president of the Soviet Union in 1989. ``We agreed that the most important thing is to teach students to think,'' said Mary V. Bicouvaris, a government and international relations teacher from Hampton, Va., and the 1989 Teacher of the Year. ``Students need more than just information and facts, we agreed. He (Gorbachev) said that every time he meets American students he is impressed with their spontaneity,'' Ms. Bicouvaris said. Ms. Bicouvaris and Darlene Pierce, director of the American Association of School Administrators' National Superintendent of the Year program, had been invited to the Soviet Union by a weekly newspaper owned by the Communist Party and circulated to teachers throughout the Soviet Union. The 13-day trip included visits to creative schools, where an interchange of ideas between teachers and students is allowed, and to the more typical schools, where teacher lectures are the rule. ``It was amazing to understand the similarities in our problems: low esteem for teachers, low salaries for teachers, problems getting people to enter the teaching profession,'' Ms. Pierce said. Ms. Bicouvaris added, ``A lot of the schools are in crisis. They have problems with students not studying and just watching television, and students being materialistic.'' The Soviet curriculum, which runs through the 11th grade, has 16 required courses. They are algebra; geometry; physics; physical education; army training; English; English literature; computer literacy, although there are virtually no computers in the schools; interpreting; Russian literature; chemistry; history; biology; geography; ethics and family life; and psychology. The newspaper, Uchitelskaya Gazeta, initiated its own teacher of the year program last year and sought advice on expanding it. Officials pressed for a meeting between Gorbachev and the two Americans to give their program credence. Gorbachev, who Ms. Bicouvaris said ``talked quietly'' with a ``wonderful voice like a southerner,'' told of how he was sent to the principal's office for arguing an idea. ``He would lean back in his chair as if he had nothing to do,'' said Ms. Bicouvaris. ``He talked about his feelings about teachers. He thinks that teachers are important in making changes'' in the Soviet Union's education system. ``He clearly feels that the Soviet system needs to do some changing,'' added Ms. Pierce.

DOC.HEAD: Housewife Collects $11 Million in Donations to Erase Deficit
DOC.TEXT: Kay Fishburn gets some snickers when she asks people to donate money to erase the national debt _ now at more than $3 trillion _ but she claims to have collected nearly $11 million. ``We're people of modest means. But we're getting a phenomenal response for the effort we put forward,'' said Mrs. Fishburn, 50, a suburban Milwaukee housewife who formed Citizens for a Debt-Free America in 1983. Mrs. Fishburn is under no illusions about how much her group can accomplish _ not when the national debt is growing by about $20 million every 34 minutes _ but she said, ``We're planting an idea.'' Paying the debt is a ``matter of honor,'' she said. The loose-knit group has enlisted 600 volunteers nationwide. The donations, which last week neared $11 million, have been forwarded to the U.S. Treasury. Donations included $1 million from former President Reagan, under whose administration the national debt more than tripled. Excess funds were donated from his 1985 inauguration committee. The group's volunteers send out 10,000 invitations annually to addresses taken from telephone books, club rosters and ``Who's Who.'' They receive 800 to 900 gifts each year from housewives to business leaders. The invitation reads: ``You are invited to participate in a historic endeavor. To honor our predecessors, to restore a legacy of liberty and initiative for future generations, citizens of the United States of America have begun to voluntarily retire the public debt of the federal government.'' ``That's the one thing we didn't anticipate was the degree of ridicule we would face,'' Mrs. Fishburn said. ``People say, `They'll spend it faster than we'll send it in.' It's the pervasive cynicism. We call it the snicker factor. We ignore the skeptics. We're going for the others.'' Those include an Ohio man who sends his Social Security checks. Although the average gift is $50,000 and many citizens included the Treasury as a beneficiary in their wills, the fund also receives envelopes containing pennies. ``They get a lot of 2-cent gifts. People putting in their two cents. It's such a cynical, negative thing to do,'' Mrs. Fishburn said. Mrs. Fishburn, who coordinates the effort from her New Berlin home, donates 3 percent of her family's income. The U.S. Treasury manages a Debt Reduction Fund, created by Congress in 1961 after Sara Vaughan Clayton of Texas willed annual income from a $20 million trust fund for use in retiring the national debt. The tax-deductible contributions to Mrs. Fishburn's group are used to pay off Treasury bonds, notes and bills the government sells to finance its debt, Treasury spokesman Pete Hollenbach said. ``By and large, most if the contributions are small. It's a way for many Americans to express their patriotism and the love for the country,'' Hollenbach said. The fund has received more than $17 million, he said. The national debt stood at $3.061 trillion on April 30.

DOC.HEAD: Congress' Only Psychiatrist Doesn't Mind the Jokes
DOC.TEXT: Congress' only psychiatrist hasn't minded the shrink jokes since a political opponent took out a full-page newspaper ad asking voters, ``Do you want a liberal, Seattle psychiatrist to be your next governor?'' ``That was 1980 when Ronald Reagan won, so liberal was not a good tag to have,'' recalls Rep. Jim McDermott, D-Wash. ``And there is always the issue of big city versus small town, so Seattle wasn't a good place to be from. He threw in my profession for good measure. I'm not sure which of the three was the worst.'' McDermott said the voters answered the campaign question with a resounding ``hell, no,'' awarding him only 17 percent of the vote in the 1980 election. Eventually he left his private practice and took his 17 years of state legislative experience to Africa, where he worked as a U.S. State Department psychiatrist in Zaire responsible for the mental health of American officials in 26 embassies. Elected to Congress in 1988, the Chicago native who first entered politics because of his opposition to the Vietnam War has found his colleagues curious about his medical work. ``When people approach me they always tell jokes about psychiatrists. I think they do that in part to get to know me. I usually respond with a joke or humor,'' he said. ``Most people, if they have not had direct contact with a psychiatrist, are a little put off by the idea that you could `read minds' or look into people's thoughts. Some say to me that they have to be careful what they say in front of me. I always tell them I never mix business with pleasure,'' he said. McDermott, 53, said the mind is of great interest to people because it is the most complex of all human aspects. However, he said, Congress and the public continue to shy away from addressing mental health issues. ``Most people would rather think that everything is rational and everything is going to be okay. They like to avoid thinking about it. Because of that, it is a hard issue to get money for. We don't like to think there are a lot of mentally ill people,'' he said. Being in Congress has given McDermott a chance to observe his colleagues. ``If you look at them, they are an amazingly accurate cross-section of the United States. In terms of interests, abilities, reputations and economic status, they are quite reflective of the general population,'' he said. McDermott said during his years in the state legislature he developed a level of trust with his colleagues that would prompt them to share family medical history and talk about family psychological problems. He even made referrals for some. McDermott said he gets the impression that every successful politician has a bit of psychiatrist in him or her. ``A good psychiatrist understands people and that's what this business is, a people business. Every single one of them (Congress members) got elected. For many, they can't explain how they did it. But instinctively they understand people. The only advantage I have over them is I spent a long time studying it.''

DOC.HEAD: Arkansas' Clinton Tries to Avoid Runoff; Mazzoli Rejects Help of PACs
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Bill Clinton hoped to avoid a runoff in today's Democratic primary in Arkansas, and U.S. Rep. Romano Mazzoli of Kentucky sought an 11th term in a bid handicapped by his refusal to accept money from political action committees. Also in Arkansas, blacks were guaranteed greater representation in the Legislature because 31 districts were redrawn. Seats in five of 10 newly created black-majority districts are being sought by only black candidates. Clinton must get more than 50 percent of the vote to win the nomination outright for another term. Otherwise, the top two vote-getters will meet in a runoff. A poll released Friday gave Clinton 55 percent to 22 percent for Tom McRae, former president of a charitable foundation, with 19 percent undecided. Three other contenders had 3 percent or less. Clinton, 43, was the nation's youngest governor when he was first elected in 1978. He was defeated in 1980 but was elected again in 1982, 1984 and 1986, the first year the governorship was made a four-year term. The Republican gubernatorial race pits U.S. Rep. Tommy Robinson, a former police chief and sheriff, against Sheffield Nelson, a former utility executive. Robinson and Nelson may pick up some traditional Democratic voters because they switched parties last year. Arkansas voters may participate in either primary without making a commitment for the November general election. In Kentucky, the closest contest for Congress may be the Democratic primary in Mazzoli's Louisville district. Former TV newsman Jeffrey Hutter, who got 39 percent of the vote against Mazzoli two years ago, is trying again. The other candidate is Louisville Alderman Paul Bather. Mazzoli's opponents have questioned whether he has done enough for Louisville since he was first elected in 1970. Hutter has criticized Mazzoli for voting to repeal the Catastrophic Health Care Act, raise the salaries of members of Congress and severely restrict abortions. But Mazzoli's decision not to accept PACs may be his downfall. As of May 18, Mazzoli said he had raised $133,370 from individual contributors. Hutter had raised $172,550 by May 9, including $40,000 from PACs. Mazzoli, 57, decided in December to set an example by becoming one of only about two dozen members of Congress who reject PAC contributions. PACs had contributed to about half of his past campaigns. ``I've always felt politics belongs to the people, not to the large special interest groups,'' Mazzoli said. ``Instead of leveling the playing field, PACs have become a force to keep incumbents in office.''

DOC.HEAD: National Gallery to Display Rubens Painting
DOC.TEXT: A major early painting by Peter Paul Rubens will go on permanent display at the National Gallery of Art tomorrow, on the 350th anniversary of the death of the 17th century Flemish master of the Baroque. The gallery last year purchased the 3-by-4-foot oil, ``The Fall of Phaeton,'' from a private collection in London for a sum director J. Carter Brown described as in the multimillion-dollar range. The painting, which depicts a dramatic scene from Greek mythology, was cleaned to restore its colors to their original brilliance. It joins the eight other works from Rubens' later period in the National Gallery's permanent collection. Except for its inclusion in an exhibition in Cologne, West Germany, in 1977, before it was cleaned, ``The Fall of the Phaeton'' had never been displayed publicly. Little is known of its ownership since Rubens painted it in 1605 while studying in Italy. Brown and Arthur Wheelock, the gallery's curator of northern Baroque painting, said the painting is important because of what it tells about Rubens in the early, formative stage of his development as the greatest Baroque artist.
DOC.HEAD: House Democrats Ask for More Funds to Investigate S&L Fraud
DOC.TEXT: More than 200 House Democrats are asking President Bush to ask Congress for more money to investigate and prosecute fraud in the worsening savings and loan crisis. The Democrats sent a letter to Bush last Friday saying the $50 million appropriated to the Justice Department to investigate and prosecute S&L fraud isn't enough to handle the backlog of thousands of potential criminal cases. An additional $100 million is needed, said the Democrats, led by Rep. Charles E. Schumer of New York and joined by some lawmakers who last week accused the Justice Department of dragging its feet on prosecuting thrift fraud. Sean Young, a White House spokesman, said over the weekend that Bush had not received the letter yet and would have no immediate comment on it. Bush said last Thursday that the savings and loan crisis ``causes me great concern'' and that policymakers' first priority is protecting depositors against losses. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady last week raised administration estimates of how much new borrowing the government needs to clean up the savings and loan mess from $50 billion forecast a year ago to between $90 billion and $130 billion. Including interest, the cost to taxpayers is expected to exceed $325 billion over the next 30 years. __
DOC.HEAD: Ten Health Groups Agree on Diet Guidelines
DOC.TEXT: Health experts often have disagreed about what are the healthiest foods for a long life. But after holding a ``food summit'' last year, 10 health agencies have now come up with a list of jointly recommended dietary guidelines. The five private and five public agencies call it ``The Healthy American Diet,'' with six general diet principles for everyone over the age of 2: _Eat a nutritionally adequate diet consisting of a variety of foods. _Reduce consumption of fat, especially saturated fat and cholesterol. _Achieve and maintain a reasonable body weight. _Increase consumption of complex carbohydrates and fiber. _Reduce intake of sodium. _Consume alcohol in moderation, if at all. Children, adolescents and pregnant women should abstain. The health organizations, ranging from the American Academy of Pediatrics to the U. S. Department of Agriculture, also recommended that some segments of the population take additional measures. To avoid dental cavities, the groups recommended fluoride in drinking water and limited between-meal snacks containing sugar. Adolescents and young women should eat more high-calcium foods, such as low-fat dairy products. Children, adolescents and women of childbearing age also should include iron-rich foods, such as red meat, fish and cereals, in their diets to avoid anemia. Many of the groups, such as the American Heart Association, already had recommended diets. But the experts' diets often differed slightly from organization to organization. Dr. Alan Chait of the University of Washington in Seattle, who is chairman of the heart association's nutrition committee, said a common message on diet recommendations should help ``reduce confusion among the public.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Benjamin Spock says American society is sick and getting sicker, and one of its worst ailments is ``excessive competitiveness.'' Most children are brought up to believe ``you're in this world to get ahead, kid,'' Spock said in a commencement speech Monday at Yale University's School of Epidemiology and Public Health. Little League baseball should be abolished, he said, because it ``takes the fun out of athletics at an early age.'' ``We ought to raise our children with quite a different spirit _ not primarily to get ahead,'' said Spock, whose landmark 1946 book ``Baby and Child Care'' has sold 32 million copies. He also recommended that teen-agers take part in volunteer activities, from working in hospitals to tutoring children.

Madonna's untamed look once drew stares from classmates at Rochester Adams High School, but today's students at her alma mater seem unimpressed that she's back in town for two concerts. ``The kids that are here and are 14 years old were born the year she graduated,'' said Nancy Ryan-Mitchell, who was Madonna Louise Ciccone's counselor. ``To these kids, though they know she's from the community and the school, it doesn't touch them personally.'' Madonna will perform Thursday and Friday at The Palace in Auburn Hills, a Detroit suburb. Five years ago, when her ``Virgin Tour'' came to Detroit, the students adorned a bulletin board with memorabilia hailing the alumna-turned-pop star. Madonna was an unconventional student in her senior year, drawing attention for wearing little makeup and not shaving her underarms. ``She had a real European kind of attitude, a real cosmopolitan flair,'' said Tim Lentz, Madonna's choir teacher. ``She dared to be different.''

The poetry of Allen Ginsberg and the music of Philip Glass are combined in a new production about ``the decline of the American empire.'' ``The Hydrogen Jukebox,'' which premiered over the weekend at the Spoleto Festival U.S.A., is based on Ginsberg's poems dating to the 1960s. The festival production features six singers and a six-piece orchestra. Each scene is built around a poem; the subjects include the Vietnam War, ecology and cocaine trafficking. ``The Hydrogen Jukebox'' is about the ``decline of the American empire,'' Ginsberg said. ``It's basically an emotional and moral decline,'' he said. ``It's not an angry accusation. It's more of a meditation on the decline of an empire. The biggest decline of empire is we won't face our problems.''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A longer version is moving on the sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: A collapsed lung will keep baseball Hall of Famer Harmon Killebrew hospitalized for at least 10 days, his brother says. Killebrew, 53, underwent surgery Friday at a Phoenix-area hospital, said his brother, Bob. ``The problem was a gastric ulcer that ruptured in his stomach,'' he said. ``The fluid backed up into his chest cavity and collapsed his lung. He's still unable to talk.'' During his 22-year career Killebrew hit 573 home runs, fifth best in major league history. He played for the old Washington Senators, the Minnesota Twins and the Kansas City Royals. The former slugger has a home in Payette, Idaho, and was in Phoenix on business.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,817.67, down 373.94 points, or 1.13 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``You can control it, but when you're talking about eradicating the gypsy moth, there ain't no such animal.'' _ Martin Shapiro, a scientist at USDA's Insect Pathology Laboratory in Beltsville, Md., on an anticipated explosion in the leaf-devouring moth's population.
``It's not our business as the United States to sort out the other person's economic problems. We've got some of our own.'' _ President Bush on Mikhail Gorbachev's difficulties in the Soviet Union.
