``I think sophisticated voyeurism has finally come of age.'' _ Promoter Bill Ridley, of the Nude Night Club in Melbourne, Australia.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says New Rebel Group Controls Main Dam
DOC.TEXT: A new guerrilla movement has emerged in this former Dutch colony and seized a hydroelectric dam, cutting off power to the capital and key bauxite smelters, the government said. Deputy Prime Minister Willy Soemita said Monday that the group sprang to life from breakaway followers of Ronny Brunswijk's Jungle Commando, which had been battling the military in the isolated South American republic since 1986. Soemita said the government received word from the new group that it wanted to meet with President Ramsewak Shankar and armed forces commander Desi Bouterse. He said he didn't know what its demands were but said a government delegation was to meet with the rebels at an unspecified time. He said the group seized control of the Brokondo region in Central Suriname over the weekend and overtook the Afobaka hydroelectric about 60 miles south of the capital. Paramaribo was without power over much of the weekend but most electricity had returned on Monday. The deputy prime minister said he didn't know if the rebels were still controlling the dam. ``The situation is very unclear,'' he said. He said the new leader of the group is Barrabas, as a former notorious leader of the Jungle Commando is known. Bouterse, a former military ruler who came to power in a 1980 coup, had opposed a tentative peace agreement the new civilian government reached last July with the Jungle Commando, saying it gave Brunswijk too much power. Bouterse returned the country to civilian rule in November 1987, but the army still retains the real power in the country. The Jungle Commando is made up mostly of Bush Negroes, descendants of runaway slaves who make up about 60,000 of the country's 400,000 Dutch speaking population.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Bounces Back, Stocks Drop
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rebounded Tuesday against the Japanese yen, and share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange declined after a five-day rise. The dollar closed at 150.70 yen, up 1.25 yen from Monday's close of 149.45 yen. After opening at 149.02 yen, the U.S. currency ranged between 149.00 yen and 150.75 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues fell 373.94 points, or 1.13 percent, to close at 32,817.67. The Nikkei index had gained 397.73 points on Monday and 1,735.44 points, or 5.35 percent, over the previous week. Volume on the first section Tuesday was 800 million shares. In the bond market, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds dropped to 88.89 points p.m. from Monday's close of 88.51. The yield rose to 6.990 percent from 6.865 percent. Dollar-trading was calm Tuesday, and most of the activity in the Tokyo market focused on the West German mark, said Takayuki Nishinaka, a dealer with the Bank of Japan. ``The underlying pressure on the dollar is downward,'' however, he said. ``Everyone is expecting a little more decline.'' Currency markets were closed Monday in New York, London and Hong Kong, but the dollar dipped below 149 yen to hit 148.82 yen Tuesday in Sydney, he said. The stock market's main barometer declined after a five-day rise largely because institutional investors sold shares when the index passed the 33,000 target level, said Wataru Watanabe, a trader with Daiwa Securities. Incentive-backed issues did well early in the session, but by the end of the morning, ``most investors were sidelined,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gravestone Dedicated During Memorial Day Service
DOC.TEXT: A 6-foot-8 granite headstone etched with the words ``Kid of Courage'' and lyrics from songs by Elton John and Michael Jackson has been erected at the grave of AIDS victim Ryan White. The headstone was dedicated on Memorial Day, two months after his death at age 18. Ryan's mother, Jeanne White, said the gravestone was built to represent his dream to be tall. Ryan was less than 5 feet tall. ``He wanted to be big and be like Howie Long,'' she said. The 6-foot-5 pro football player was a pallbearer at Ryan's funeral and helped raise money for the AIDS organization that bears the boy's name. The headstone, designed by Ryan's mother, carries inscriptions front and back telling his story. It also carries a picture of the boy, whose battle for acceptance won hearts and improved public understanding of AIDS. A hemophiliac who contracted AIDS through blood-clotting products, Ryan won a court battle to attend school outside of Kokomo, but ill feelings drove him, his sister and mother to Cicero, 30 miles from Indianapolis. He became a spokesman for AIDS education, and his cause drew support from singers John and Jackson. Lyrics from their songs are on the monument, along with words from Gov. Evan Bayh. ``He was a young man who taught us the meaning of courage and I'm convinced that his life will be remembered for what he taught us about living than the disease that afflicted him,'' Bayh is quoted as saying on the black and white granite _ Ryan's favorite colors. Neighbors, his high school prom date, friends and acquaintances gave testimonials about encounters with him during the dedication. ``I think about him every day _ several, several times,'' his uncle, Tom Hale, said before the approximately 75 people who attended the dedication. ```Don't weep for me, meet me.' That would be his prayer.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev: Nyet to Hoover Institution
DOC.TEXT: The Hoover Institution, a conservative think tank at Stanford University, has been dropped from Mikhail Gorbachev's itinerary. But a visit to a typical middle-class Minneapolis family is still on the agenda _ at least for his wife. Soviet officials decided Gorbachev's schedule ``was just too tight'' for a tour of the Hoover Institution when the Soviet leader visits the university 25 miles from San Francisco next week, Stanford spokesman Bob Freelen said Monday. Gorbachev's tentative plans had included a meeting with scholars at the institution, which was founded by future President Hoover in 1919 and boasts one of the world's biggest collections of material from the Russian Revolution. Gorbachev, after summit talks this week with President Bush, will visit Minnesota on Sunday and the San Francisco Bay area on Sunday and Monday. In Minnesota, Paul Ridgeway, lead advance coordinator for the visit, said Gorbachev will stop at the governor's mansion and meet with Midwest business and agricultural leaders at a hotel. A visit to the home of Steve and Karen Watson also remained in the planning, but probably only Raisa Gorbachev will take part, Ridgeway said. The Gorbachevs have said they would like to visit a typical middle-class family with at least three children and a dog. The Watsons have four children and a dog. Georgiy Markosov, a counselor with the Soviet Embassy, said no proposals by the governor's office had been eliminated. But Ridgeway said Gorbachev will not address the public from the Capitol steps, as Gov. Rudy Perpich wanted. Stops expected to be in the final itinerary include the Cathedral of St. Paul and the Sculpture Garden at Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, Ridgeway said. Perpich has suggested an ecumenical service at the cathedral. In San Francisco, Gorbachev is to meet with former President Reagan for breakfast at the Soviet consulate on June 4. During visit to Stanford, the Soviet leader will deliver a speech, meet with former Secretary of State George Shultz, now a professor of international economics at Stanford, and talk with other faculty members and students. Scholars at the Hoover Institution, a longtime bastion of anti-communism, had planned to show Gorbachev the collection from the Russian Revolution and offer papers suggesting ways of solving the Soviet Union's economic problems. Charles Palm, an associate director of the institution, said he was disappointed by the change in plans. Thousands of items, including mug shots of revolutionaries and secret Czarist police files, are at the institution. Hoover scholars have included Alexander Kerensky, premier of the provisional government that followed the downfall of Czar Nicholas II in the spring of 1917 only to be toppled in the Bolshevik Revolution months later.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanians Support Independence Drive Despite Hardships from Blockade
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian authorities say the Soviet economic embargo has forced sharp cutbacks in electric power to industries and idled 40,000 workers, but a new poll shows the hardships have not weakened support for the republic's independence drive. In neighboring Latvia on Monday, the Parliament approved a resolution rejecting President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's May 14 decree declaring independence moves by Latvia and Estonia to be illegal and unconstitutional. After sharp debate, Latvian legislators approved a resolution on Monday that called Gorbachev's decree ``illegal interference'' in the republic's affairs, the Soviet TV news program ``Vremya'' reported. Anti-independence legislators did not participate in the vote, it reported. The three Baltic republics, forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940, are all seeking to restore independence. While Latvia and Estonia have adopted a more gradual approach, Lithuania declared its independence on March 11. Gorbachev cut off all oil and most natural gas supplies to Lithuania on April 18 for its refusal to rescind pro-independence laws. Electricity is being generated at only two power plants in Lithuania _ a nuclear plant at Ignalina and the oil-burning Elektrenai station, and neither is operating at full capacity, according to Radio Vilnius reporter Audrius Braukyla. Braukyla said homes were unaffected by the power cutbacks. According to a government communique reported Monday by Radio Vilnius, ``power supply to industrial enterprises is being severely limited,'' affecting nearly 200,000 workers at those plants. The Lithuanian news agency ELTA said the power cutback would affect 300 factories and enterprises. The communique said 40,000 workers have become jobless since the Soviet economic embargo was imposed. Nearly 2,000 people have registered at the republic's unemployment office, and 500 have been given new jobs, mostly in the farming sector, Braukyla quoted the communique as saying. He quoted Lithuanian legislator Antanas Karoblis as saying factories under Moscow's control were receiving supplies of oil and raw materials. Braukyla said recent motor traffic seemed greater than early in the oil cutoff. A taxi driver told him Lithuanians are striking deals with residents of the neighboring republic of Byelorussia, who are bringing in hundreds of gallons of gasoline in cars and small trucks. Some were even trading Lithuanian chocolates for gasoline, he added. Despite the hardships, the Lithuanian radio station said a public opinion poll conducted this month of almost 1,000 people in Vilnius, the republic's capital, indicated a strengthening of support for the declaration of independence. Asked ``Do you think the Lithuanian Supreme Council (parliament) should revoke the decision about the restoration of the statehood of Lithuania?'' 72 percent said no and 19 percent said yes, the radio station said. In April, 21 percent said the declaration should be revoked. The poll was conducted by the Lithuanian branch of the All-Union Public Opinion Poll Center, which gave no margin of error.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Bounces Back, Stocks Drop
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rebounded against the yen today, and the weaker Japanese currency helped push down share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange after a five-day rise. The dollar closed at 150.70 yen, up 1.25 yen from Monday's close of 149.45 yen. After opening at 149.02 yen, it ranged between 149.00 yen and 150.75 yen. ``Presumably there was an exhaustion of dollar-bearish sentiment, and people took profits on the downside,'' said Masato Nakamura of Sumitomo Bank. He said the dollar could go back above 151 yen this week. The dollar's turnaround was initiated by the West German mark's rally in cross trading with the yen, he said. The dollar generally has been falling since April 18, when it closed at 159.87, and it fell below 150 yen on Monday for the first time in Tokyo in nearly three months. Today's decline in the yen led to a 1.13 percent decline in the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, said John Courtney, a broker with W.I. Carr. The Nikkei index fell 373.94 points, closing at 32,817.67. ``It's strange, but within the market, it seems to matter more what happens in Germany or the United States than what happens here,'' he said. The market is ``ultrasensitive'' to changes in exchange and interest rates, he said. Profit-taking after a five-day surge contributed to today's decline, brokers said. The Nikkei had gained 1,735.44 points, or 5.35 percent, over the preceding week. Many institutional investors sold shares when the index passed the 33,000 target level, said Wataru Watanabe, a trader with Daiwa Securities. Volume on the first section today was 800 million shares. In the bond market, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds dropped to 87.75 points as of 4 p.m. from Monday's close of 88.51. The yield rose to 7.020 percent from 6.865 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet General Accuses Armenian Authorities Of Aiding Militants
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to raise death toll to 23, ADD details on day of mourning in Yerevan and casualties. Picks up 9th pvs, `In Moscow ...'
DOC.TEXT: The commander of Soviet security forces in Armenia has accused the republic's leaders of openly aiding armed groups of Armenian nationalists who have engaged his troops in bloody clashes. Gen. Yuri Shatalin, head of Interior Ministry troops in the Caucasus republic, made the remarks Monday after two days of clashes between militants and Soviet troops in and around the Armenian capital left 23 people dead. At least 20 of the fatalities were civilians. ``Bloodshed in Yerevan is the result of open connivance of the republican leadership and law enforcement agencies with illegal armed groups,'' the official Tass news agency quoted Shatalin as saying. Shatalin told Tass the situation was ``developing most unpredictably.'' The militants were driving around Yerevan in stolen cars, carrying captured weapons, he said. He said Interior Ministry troops could not interfere without permission from the republic's leaders. Accounts of the fighting varied. Armenian nationalists said Soviet soldiers fired on unarmed civilians. Soviet officials said Armenian militants attacked army patrols. Leaders of the Armenian Communist Party and the republic's government declared today a day of mourning for those slain in the clashes, according to Radio Yerevan and the independent Interfax news service. The streets of Yerevan were quiet today, but a demonstration was planned for later in the day, said Bela Avitisyan, an editor of the official Armenian news agency Armenpress. Armenians marked the day by wearing black ribbons and hanging the red-blue-and-yellow Armenian flag from the windows of buildings and cars, said Ms. Avitisyan, contacted by telephone in Yerevan. The local radio interrupted regular programs to broadcast somber music. Ms. Avitisyan said official reports put the casualties from the two days of clashes at 23 dead and 37 wounded. She did not have a breakdown of how many were killed in the separate incidents, or information about how many casualties there were on each side. Armenian Communist Party leader Vladimir Movsesyan urged calm, a call echoed by leaders of the Armenian National Movement, but militants were disregarding the calls and launching attacks to steal weapons from local police, Tass said. In Moscow, Interior Ministry spokesman Yuri Makarov said six people died early Sunday when soldiers fired on militants who had shot at them in Yerevan's central railroad station. He said 20 soldiers were wounded in the shootout. A duty officer at the Armenian National Movement, who declined to give his name, said the soldiers had opened fire on unarmed civilians at the station. Rafael Popoyan, a leader of the Armenian National Movement, said that after the shootout at the railroad station, about 15 armored personnel carriers headed toward the city center from a nearby base. He said troops they were carrying opened fire on a crowd of people who attempted to block the road with parked cars. Makarov said that according to a preliminary report, 14 civilians were killed and more than 30 injured in the clash at the barricade. Armenian activist Satenik Paramadjan said Soviet soldiers on Monday morning fired on the headquarters of the Armenian National Movement, killing a person sleeping in a car outside. Including that fatality, the death toll for the two days of violence was at least 21. Popoyan said there were several clashes in Yerevan and its outskirts late Sunday and Monday morning. Soviet soldiers, he said, ``just came into the city shooting.'' The Soviet evening television news program ``Vremya'' showed scenes Monday of bullet-scarred walls at the railroad station and bloodstains on seats. It called the militants ``terrorists.'' A mass rally was held Monday by the Armenian National Movement to commemorate Armenia's 1918 declaration of independence, Tass reported, adding without elaboration that ``an ominous shadow'' was cast over the observation. Armenia was annexed by the Soviet Union in 1920. In more than two years, several hundred people have been killed in violence in Armenia and neighboring Azerbaijan. The republics have been locked in a bitter struggle for control of Nagorno-Karabakh, the predominantly ethnic-Armenian enclave inside Azerbaijan. Soviet soldiers have been deployed in both republics to quell the violence. Sunday's violence came three days after militants fired on soldiers at military checkpoints and on patrol in Nagorno-Karabakh. One Soviet serviceman was killed and four were wounded in the attacks.

DOC.HEAD: CNN, NBC Planning Live Shuttle Coverage
DOC.TEXT: CNN and NBC said they will provide live coverage of Wednesday's liftoff of space shuttle Columbia. CBS does not plan to carry the launch live. Chip Garner, an ABC desk assistant, said no one was available Monday to discuss that network's coverage. Columbia is scheduled to lift off at 12:38 a.m. EDT carrying seven astronauts and a $150 million observatory called Astro that will study ultraviolet light and X-rays emitted by stars and other objects. CNN will cover the launch and offer live updates from the space center at Huntsville, Ala., said Cissy Baker, CNN vice president and managing editor. NBC said it will carry the liftoff for five to 10 minutes.

DOC.HEAD: Black Nationalist Leader Undergoes Operation
DOC.TEXT: African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela underwent a minor operation and will remain in the hospital for a couple of days for needed rest, the clinic's director said today. ``Mr. Mandela will be here a couple of days and is resting _ which he needs,'' said Gordon Cohen, director of the Park Lane Clinic, to which the ANC deputy president was admitted Sunday night for a routine physical. He did not specify what type of operation the 71-year-old Mandela underwent. ``He is well on his way to recovery,'' Cohen said, adding that the operation did not involve the prostate, which Mandela had had removed in a 1985 operation. ``The operation was nothing serious, and can't have any long-term consequences,'' Cohen said. ANC spokesman Ahmed Kathrada had said earlier that Mandela was undergoing a routine physical examination and was expected to be released today. Mandela's wife, Winnie, visited him today and told reporters Mandela's planned trip to Europe next week was ``in no way affected and would go ahead,'' the South African Press Association said. Cohen said the operation had occurred on Monday. On Monday night, he had refused to confirm an operation and had told SAPA ``It was a completely minor check-up.'' ANC internal chairman Walter Sisulu, a close friend of Mandela, told SAPA on Monday night that he thought the examination had included a minor operation involving Mandela's prostate. Kathrada said that Mandela's admission to the clinic for a complete physical had been planned for a long time, and would be followed by a week of rest at home before he takes his next trip. Mandela was treated for tuberculosis in 1988. He returned last week from a tour of eight African countries. He also made a trip through Africa and to Britain and Sweden shortly after he was freed Feb. 11 from 27 years in prison, where he was serving a life term for sabotage and plotting the overthrow of the government.

MOSCOW: he needed.
DOC.TEXT: The election gives Yeltsin, 59, a visible platform from which to wage his campaign for accelerating the reforms of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who opposed his election. The burly Siberian stood to applause from the floor of the Russian Congress of People's Deputies when the vote was announced. Yeltsin needed 531 of the 1,060 members to win. His nearest rival, Russian Premier Alexander Vlasov, received 467 votes. It was Yeltsin's third attempt to win the Russian presidency and came after he offered to create a coalition government with his conservative opponents.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
MOSCOW: conservative opponents.
DOC.TEXT: The popular and outspoken Communist renegade had lost the second round of voting in the Russian Congress on Saturday by just 28 votes. He had lost the first round on Friday with 497 ballots to 473 for Krasnodar regional Communist Party chief Ivan Polozkov. He was nominated again on Monday and faced Vlasov, who had Gorbachev's support, and Valentin Tsoy, a little-known businessman from the Soviet Far East, in the race. Last week, Gorbachev spoke against Yeltsin at the congress, opposing his plan to transfer economic and political decision-making from central authorities to the republic. Yeltsin has proposed in broad outlines a more radical market economy plan that would give more freedom to enterprises and entrepreneurs. Russia, by far the largest of the 15 Soviet republics, stretches from the Baltic Sea in the west to the Pacific Ocean in the east and is home to just over one-half the country's population.

DOC.HEAD: Former Boston Mayor Admits Birthday Party Was a Money-Making Scheme
DOC.TEXT: Former Mayor Kevin H. White has acknowledged what prosecutors couldn't prove almost a decade ago _ that a planned birthday party for his wife was a scheme to put money in his pocket. In an interview Sunday on WHDH-TV, White said the party ``was an idea artificially hatched to make up for a problem. The problem was I could barely survive on my salary.'' But he said establishing the fund was not improper. After a great deal of publicity, the 1981 party was canceled and about $122,000 in donations was returned. At the time, White angrily denied allegations of corruption, no evidence was produced to link him to organizing the party and no charges were filed. White did not seek re-election in 1983 after 16 years as mayor. He now teaches at Boston University. The State Ethics Commission and the U.S. Justice Department looked into the birthday party for White's wife, Kathryn, in an attempt to prove it was a scheme to put money in White's personal account. The commission censured White for conflict of interest by using his office to gain unwarranted privileges. The two investigations are closed. ``His position and the position that was expressed for him by his attorneys was that the birthday party was for Kathryn,'' said former Assistant U.S. Attorney Robert J. Cordy, former counsel to the Ethics Commission. ``Now it seems it was a scheme to raise money for himself to supplement his income. That was exactly the danger the Ethics Commission was concerned about.'' ``It's an extraordinary confession,'' said former Assistant U.S. Attorney Daniel I. Small. White's salary was raised by $25,000 to $65,000 less than four months before the party was to take place.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Falls in East, Plains
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell in the eastern half of the nation and in the Upper Plains early today, flooding portions of Ohio. Rain and showers extended from Cleveland to Buffalo to Richmond, Va., and from Casper, Wyo., to Spokane, Wash. Thunderstorms looped down from Kansas to the Georgia coast and up to South Carolina. On Monday, wet, stormy weather advanced across the southeastern quarter of the nation, spinning off at least four tornados. Lightning killed one person in Galveston Island, Texas. Heavy rain overnight flooded parts of eastern and south-central Ohio, leaving many roads impassable. Floodwaters up to 6 feet deep swamped Murray City, forcing the evacuation of at least 50 residents, authorities said. The flooding shoved one building off its foundations, caved in a hillside and swept equipment out of a firehouse. ``The streets are a mess. In 1968 we had a flood, but it was nothing like this,'' said firefighter Bob Koon. ``We got the trucks out, but a lot of the other stuff is gone.'' Tornadoes touched down near Atlanta, southeast of Houma, La., and west of Huntington, W.Va. At Morehead in eastern Kentucky, a twister overturned several light aircraft and a small hangar at Morehead-Rowan County Airport and apparently carried off two other planes, state police said. It also downed power lines, destroyed a small office and damaged two houses. No injuries were reported. Hail fell at Maiden, N.C., Midway, W.Va., Baldwin, Ga., and North Knoxville, Tenn. Today's forecast called for rain in Idaho, Montana and Wyoming and across the Northeast. Storms were expected in Kansas, Oklahoma, northern Texas, northern Florida and along the coasts of Georgia and South Carolina. A high of 73 in Nome, Ark., broke the town's Memorial Day record of 70 degrees that had stood for 27 years. The nation's high was 99 at Beeville, Texas. DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell in calm European trading this morning with most attention focused on the West German mark's advance against the yen in cross-trading. Gold prices rose. Markets were closed Monday in Britain for a bank holiday and in the United States for Memorial Day. ``It all depends on the mark-yen crosses,'' said a dealer at a U.S. bank in Frankfurt. ``The dollar had failed to break out on the upside, and the yen was strong against the mark, but now we have a correction to that.'' Rumors that the Deutsche Bundesbank might raise West German key interest rates at its Thursday meeting of the Central Bank Council contributed to the mark's rise against the yen in East Asian dealings, traders said. A bullish report from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development on West German growth also helped, they said. Traders said the market would be looking ahead to Friday's release of new U.S. unemployment figures for a fresh indication of the dollar's medium-term direction. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 1.25 yen to close at 150.70 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 150.83 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday's European rates: _1.6690 West German marks, down from 1.6790 _1.4100 Swiss francs, down from 1.4215 _5.6290 French francs, down from 5.6565 _1.8810 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8910 _1,227.50 Italian lire, down from 1,233.50 _1.1808 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1828 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.6932, slightly more expensive for buyers than $1.6930 late Monday in continental Europe. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $368.50 an ounce, up from $367.45 late Friday. At midmorning, the city's gold dealers fixed a recommended price of $368.35. In Zurich, the bid price was $368.45, up from $367.50 late Monday. Gold in Hong Kong rose 56 cents to close at a bid $369.48. Silver was quoted in London at a bid price of $5.23 an ounce, unchanged from Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Report: N.Y. Company Eyed For Milk Shipping Fraud
DOC.TEXT: A shipping company hired to supply milk powder to the famine-ravaged Sudan is under federal investigation because the powder was unfit for human consumption, The New York Times reported today. Court papers filed by the government allege that the company, AMG Services, promised to deliver high-quality milk powder to the Sudan but substituted an undrinkable, diluted powder. AMG president Martyn Merritt said the inferior powder was supplied by a Sri Lankan subcontractor. Merritt warned U.S. government officials about the switch but was ignored, he said. ``I didn't want this stuff to get sent off and have people get sick from it,'' he said. Under an Agency for International Development program, the United States buys food for the Sudan, one of the world's poorest countries. AMG received $936,000 to ship hundreds of tons of milk powder in January 1989, the court papers said, but the Sudanese never received a shipment. The cargo apparently got mixed up in Sri Lanka, where an AMG subsidiary was supposed to forward it. Sudanese government investigators went to Sri Lanka, found a substitute shipment of the low-quality milk powder and rejected it. Erwin Shustak, an attorney for Merritt, said he believed AMG was under investigation because of a dispute years ago between Merritt and a government investigator. Prosecutors would not comment.

DOC.HEAD: Jamaican Prime Minister Hospitalized in Miami with Pneumonia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to include full name of hospital.
DOC.TEXT: Doctors are waiting for test results to decide how to treat Jamaican Prime Minister Michael Manley, who was hospitalized with pneumonia, an aide to the prime minister said. Manley, 65, was flown here from Kingston by air ambulance early Monday, according to a statement from Jamaica House in Kingston. Carol Smith, nursing coordinator on duty at the Miami Heart Institute, said early today she had been told Manley's condition was ``unchanged,'' but she was unaware what condition he was in. Mrs. Smith said further information was unavaiable. Hartley Neita, an aide traveling with Manley, said Monday it was unclear how long Manley would be hospitalized. ``He has been undergoing tests and we're waiting now for the results of those tests,'' he said. ``From there on, the doctors will go full blast on treatment. He said Manley watched part of the French Open tennis tournament Monday on television, but spent most of the day resting. Earlier, President Bush sent a message to Manley through the U.S. Embassy in Kingston expressing concern for the prime minister's health. On Sunday, Manley was admitted to Kingston's University Hospital, where the pneumonia was diagnosed. Manley was scheduled to undergo prostate surgery June 5 at Sloane Kettering Cancer Institute in New York, Neita said. But doctors were ``watching his prognosis'' to see if that operation would be postponed, the aide said. A socialist, Manley lost the 1980 elections but returned to office in February 1989 after he moderated his politics. He was prime minister from 1972-1980.

DOC.HEAD: One Dead, Three Injured in Czechoslovak Prison Riot
DOC.TEXT: About 30 riot policemen entered the capital's largest prison to end a five-day uprising that left one prisoner dead and three injured, officials said today. Rioting broke out in Ruzyne Prison on Thursday when four inmates barricaded themselves inside their cell and set it on fire, Frantisek Chaloupka, a senior prison official said today. They were hospitalized and one later died of burns. On Saturday night, 11 inmates climbed onto the prison roof and demanded improved prison conditions and the release of all prisoners awaiting trial. Three inmates were reported injured during the riot. It was not immediately clear how many inmates took part in the uprising or how much of the facility the rebellious prisoners took over. The Ruzyne prison, which can hold 2,000 inmates but which only had 500 when the rioting occurred, contains mostly suspects in serious crimes. After negotiations with government officials failed, 30 riot policemen crushed the protest Monday night. The 11 inmates were removed from the roof by police using helicopters and cranes. One policeman was injured in the process. Police said one prisoner escaped during the confusion.

DOC.HEAD: Banana and Orange Milk Make a Splash
DOC.TEXT: Apple-cinnamon milk got a thumbs down, but milk flavored with banana or orange drew raves from kids in a taste test. ``Tastes like soggy Froot Loops!'' said first-grader Jeremy Foster, licking off the pale mustache from orange milk he chose for lunch. Many of his classmates at North Star Elementary School shared his enthusiasm during taste tests conducted at 13 Denver area schools for the Western Dairy Farmers Promotion Association. Apple-cinnamon milk was a real loser but banana milk made a splash. ``Cinnamon milk was sick,'' said kindergartner A.J. Pierce. ``I want banana back,'' said 7-year-old Tino Garcia.'' One of the new flavors could be offered to schools next fall, in addition to white and chocolate milk, and the occasional strawberry. ``Kids have become much more sophisticated in their taste these days, and there are a variety of juices and other flavors that are available to them,'' said association spokeswoman Faye Asano. ``We want to expand that variety, too.'' Reactions from other schools have closely followed those at North Star, with banana the favorite, orange second and apple-cinnamon the distinct third. Aside from the taste, students and adults complained it didn't look nice. ``It looked like dirty milk,'' said Lila Stafford, the cafeteria manager for Adams City Middle School in Commerce City.

DOC.HEAD: Machines Would Dispense Condoms in Vancouver High Schools
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of committee, category code.
DOC.TEXT: A school board committee has approved the installation of condom dispensing machines in high school bathrooms. A school board committee voted 5-2 Monday in favor of installing the machines in the city's 18 high schools. Installations would not begin until September. ``Some of the communities are uneasy with it but the board has got to be the driving force to say we'll have condom machines in washrooms,'' said committee Chairman Ken Denike. John Blatherwick, city medical health officer, said the step was necessary to help students protect themselves from AIDS. Final approval will be considered at the board's meeting next Monday. Earlier this year, two other British Columbia school districts approved the installation of condom dispensers.

DOC.HEAD: Arafat Asks Arabs To Help Anti-Israel Uprising
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING TO RESTORE PARAGRAPH MARKER BETWEEN 1ST TWO GRAPHS
DOC.TEXT: Moderate leaders at the Arab summit appeared today to have persuaded hard-liners to take a ``balanced and prudent'' approach to the United States, under fire for its support of Israel, conference sources said. But despite their reported acquiescence, PLO chairman Yasser Arafat and Iraqi President Saddam Hussein made belicose speeches against the United States and Israel at Monday's opening session of the two-day summit. In another development today, a senior PLO official said Saddam and President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran could meet in the next few weeks to formally end the Persian Gulf war, which was halted by a cease-fire in 1988. The conference sources said that as the heads of state met for a second day today, moderates headed by Egypt and Saudi Arabia seemed to gain ground, despite often heated debates over taking Washington to task. They said on condition of anonymity that Saddam and King Hussein of Jordan, who have favored a tough anti-U.S. line, agreed to take a more moderate approach. They did not say what instigated the change. ``President Saddam has switched to a balanced and prudent approach that will placate hard-liners and satisfy the moderates,'' said one top Persian Gulf official. ``It's now up to the United States to accord the Arabs due respect and handle the Middle East more maturely and constructively.'' The conference was called as a show of Arab unity against what Saddam has said is a Western and Israeli campaign against Iraq. It was also sought ways to stem the large-scale emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel. The Arab leaders met behind closed doors in Baghdad's heavily guarded conference center today. Sources said they were to complete a memorandum on issues related to the Arab-Israeli conflict that will be sent to the U.S.-Soviet summit, which convenes in Washington on Thursday. Hard-liners such as Libya's leader, Col. Moammar Gadhafi, were maintaining a low profile, sources said. Syria and Lebanon have boycotted the Arab summit, while Morocco, Algeria and Oman sent senior government officials. The turnout was seen as a clear sign of discord between hard-liners and the moderates over how tough a line they should take against the United States. Sources said Arab leaders were incensed by a 16-page U.S. State Department note sent to the 21-member Arab League last week urging Iraq to ``moderate both its action and its rhetoric'' and advising the heads of state to avoid ``excessively ardent language.'' The memorandum also called on the Arabs to recognize Israel and uphold the right of Soviet Jews to emigrate to Israel if they want. The Arabs, particularly the hard-liners, viewed the State Department document as an attempt by Washington to dictate policy. Palestinian officials complained the Bush administration ``is treating us like schoolchildren.'' Many Arabs have been angered by the United States' policy regarding the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel _ expected to reach 750,000 over the next years. They say Washington has driven away many from the United States by tightening American immigration restrictions. Arabs states contend Israel plans to settle many of the Soviet Jews in the Israeli-held West Bank and Gaza Strip, land the Palestinians declared part of a Palestinian state in 1988. The Arabs also say Washington has not done enough to pressure Israel into agreeing to peace talks with Arafat. Speaking to the 15 kings, sheiks and presidents at the summit Monday, Arafat reviled Washington for indirectly encouraging the Soviet Jewish emigres to settle in Israel. ``We are duty bound to use all weapons, including sanctions _ economic boycotts and political and psychological pressures _ against states, establishment and companies that participate in aggression against Arab territory,'' Arafat said. He berated the U.S. Congress for describing Jerusalem as Israel's capital in recent, non-binding House and Senate resolutions. ``This illegitimate declaration amounts to aggression on Arab dignity,'' Arafat shouted. He said Arab sector of Jerusalem, conquered by Israel in 1967, ``is part of the Palestinian territory under Israeli occupation. It is the capital of the state of Palestine.'' Also Monday, Saddam warned again that Iraq will use ``weapons of mass destruction'' against Israel if the Israelis used similar weapons against Iraq or any other Arab country. He did not spell out what weapons he had in mind. But he was apparently referring to Israel's nuclear bombs and Iraq's burgeoning arsenal of long-range missiles and chemical weapons. ``The United States bears a basic and primary responsibility for the policy of aggression and expansion practiced by the Zionist entity against the Arabs,'' Saddam declared.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Not Ruling Out Re-Election Bid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lede to change ``next month'' to ``next week;'' INSERTS new grafs 3-7 with Barry friends saying mayor would consider plea bargain, pretrial hearing scheduled; pickup graf 4 pvs, bgng, ``Barry, 54,...
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry, who faces trial on drug charges next week, isn't ruling out a re-election campaign despite advice that he give up on seeking a fourth term, some mayoral aides say. ``There were meetings this week and everything was very forward-thinking,'' one of Barry's top political aides said Monday. ``Everything hinges on this trial and what we are hearing is that he will make no firm decision or announcement until after that.'' A report published today, however, quoted unnamed Barry friends as saying the mayor would consider a plea agreement provided he was allowed to plead guilty only to misdemeanor charges. The Washington Post report said the friends stressed that no talks were under way and that any deal would have to involve the sealing of all evidence against Barry, including a videotape allegedly showing the mayor smoking crack cocaine. Law enforcement sources told The Associated Press that no talks between prosecutors and Barry had begun. The direction of the legal case should become clearer later today, when a federal judge is scheduled to rule on a defense motion to split the charges against Barry into two trials. The comments by Barry political aides indicating the mayor has not ruled out seeking re-election were at odds with a Monday report on WRC-TV that said Barry has told close advisers he will not seek re-election. Barry, 54, is scheduled to go to trial June 4 for a variety of drug and perjury charges stemming from his Jan. 18 arrest in a FBI sting operation and a separate, 15-month federal probe into this ties to a convicted drug dealer. The mayor, who entered seven weeks of substance abuse treatment following his arrest, faces 10 misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge and three felony charges of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use. If convicted of a felony, Barry would be barred from holding office or running for re-election. However, a Washington Post poll released Friday showed that the mayor has held onto core supporters since his arrest. The survey showed that Barry and city council member John Ray lead a field of six with each receiving 23 percent support. Barry has not publicly disclosed his re-election plans, but has been making a series of campaign-style appearances around the city in recent weeks. In addition, Barry campaign officials on Friday picked up petitions for a potential re-election bid, the first formal step to a possible candidacy. ``The mayor was pleased with the poll, and both he and others have said in he last few days that it (the poll) is another indication that he should keep his options open,'' said a top political aide who met with him in recent days. ``However, there are plenty of people who are urging him not to put himself and the city through this trial and to seek a deal,'' said an aide who spoke on condition of anonymity. Some city officials and personal associates of the mayor's have been encouraging Barry to seek a plea bargain agreement in hopes of preventing their names from coming out during the trial, city government sources said. Many of those urging Barry to avoid court proceedings seek to avoid being put in the position of having to testify on whether they ever saw Barry use drugs or if they were aware of his alleged drug problem, one source said. ``It's a question of loyalty,'' said one city official. ``Regardless of what they may or may not know, they don't want to be put in the position of testifying against their boss.'' For the time being, aides familiar with Barry's campaign plans say that volunteers will concentrate on gaining the 2,000 signatures needed to place his name on the ballot and then wait for the trial. Prosecutors and R. Kenneth Mundy, Barry's attorney, have estimated that the legal proceedings could take at least a month. To run in the city's Sept. 11 Democratic primary, the mayor must submit his petition signatures by July 5.

DOC.HEAD: Three Dade County Mayors Under Suspicion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to recast and add Dade population. Picks up 4th graf, `Some people...'.
DOC.TEXT: Three mayors within one county have fallen under suspicion as a string of corruption allegations have tangled Miami-area politics. The mayor of Hialeah has been indicted on federal racketeering charges, the mayor of Miami Beach is under investigation after the collapse of a savings and loan, and three-quarters of Sweetwater's elected officials _ the mayor included _ face federal extortion charges. All three cities are in Dade County, the densely populated area of about 2 million people that includes Miami. Since his appointment two years ago, U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen, a former Republican state senator from Dade County, has made corruption in public office his No. 1 priority. Some people question his motives. ``There is a major suspicion in this town that Dexter has politicized the U.S. attorney's office,'' said Miami attorney Jeffrey Weiner, vice president of the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers. The scandals in Hialeah and Miami Beach threaten the political careers of two Democratic stars, both coming off landslide re-elections in November. In Hialeah, Raul Martinez, mayor of Florida's fifth-largest city since 1981, was indicted in April on charges of extorting nearly $1 million in cash and real estate from developers for zoning approvals. He was suspended along with a city councilman who allegedly traded his vote for $24,000 in cash. Martinez emerged as a potential challenger to Lehtinen's wife, Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, in last year's U.S. House race. But he stayed out, and Ms. Ros-Lehtinen won the seat for the Republicans. The U.S. attorney's office said Lehtinen disqualified himself from the investigation into Martinez, who has been under federal scrutiny for years. Two other council members in the city of 200,000 have pleaded guilty to federal charges in the last three years. No trial date has been set for Martinez, who faces up to 180 years in prison and $2.25 million in fines if convicted. Martinez, 41, has denied all charges, and his supporters say the case is politically tainted. In Miami Beach, third-term Mayor Alex Daoud has not been charged but is being probed by federal and state authorities and by the Florida Bar. Among items being investigated are $35,000 Daoud received from CenTrust companies before the thrift was taken over by federal regulators, tens of thousands of dollars in renovations to his home and thousands of dollars in gifts from Miami Beach socialites. Daoud, a popular and media-conscious mayor, has become tight-lipped about his troubles except to make periodic denials of any wrongdoing. On Friday, city inspectors found more than $235,000 in improvements to Daoud's Sunset Island home, The Miami Herald reported. Daoud lacked city permits for most of the work, did not pay all required fees, failed to get final inspections and, according to some contractors, refused to pay his bills, the newspaper said. A federal grand jury has subpoenaed thousands of pages of city documents as part of its investigation of Daoud's dealings with David Paul, former head of CenTrust. In Sweetwater, Mayor Irain Gonzalez and five of seven council members were named Jan. 25 in an extortion indictment. Two pleaded guilty, and the mayor and two council members are on trial. Another council member, named as an unindicted co-conspirator, testified against them in a case involving a $10,000 bribe allegedly made by a developer for a zoning variance. Jury deliberations began Friday and were recessed until today. Miami Mayor Xavier Suarez, a lawyer, said the accumulation of scandals doesn't mean that city government in the booming Miami metropolitan area is suddenly for sale. ``I guess it's just circumstance,'' he said. He added, ``One of my partners is from a state in the Northeast where they've had a lot of corruption, and he said some of the stuff that he's been reading about here sounds pretty minor compared to what he was used to.''

DOC.HEAD: Presidents of Iraq and Iran Could Meet Soon to Formally End Gulf War
With PM-Arab Summit
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran could meet in the next few weeks to formally end the Persian Gulf war, a senior PLO official said today. Palestine Liberation Organization chairman Yasser Arafat will fly to Tehran this week in a bid to set up the peace talks, the official said. ``The chairman will go to Tehran immediately after the Arab summit,'' expected to end Wednesday, he said. ``Barring last-minute complications, direct summit talks between Saddam and Rafsanjani will be under way after a month.'' Tehran Radio, monitored in Cyprus, today quoted Iranian Parliament Speaker Mehdi Karrubi as saying Saddam and Rafsanjani may meet, but giving no date. The PLO official said Arafat, attending the Arab meeting in Baghdad, has sent two messages to Iran's spiritual leader, Ali Khamenei, and to Rafsanjani, urging them to respond ``quickly and positively'' to Iraq's offer. Saddam and Rafsanjani have also reportedly exchanged letters recently. Iran-Iraq peace talks began five days after the U.N.-sponsored cease-fire halted the war on Aug. 20, 1988. But they have been deadlocked ever since. The PLO official said he expected a high-level Iran-Iraq meeting in Moscow if Arafat's mission in Tehran was successful, followed by a summit between Saddam and Rafsanjani. Moscow has offered to host any summit, and both leaders have indicated willingness to accept, diplomats said. There have been indications for some time that a breakthrough in the stalled peace negotiations was possible. Iran has quietly dropped demands for huge war reparations and no long insists Iraq should be blamed for starting the war in September 1980. Iraq has reportedly dropped demands that the Shatt-Al-Arab waterway, the southern boundary between the two countries and Iraq's main outlet to the Persian Gulf, be cleared of sunken ships before negotiations proceed.

DOC.HEAD: Melee Erupts at Rap Concert, 11 Injured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, ``Some people...', to CORRECT by deleting reference to sponsor. SUBS 11th graf, `The disturbance...', with three grafs to add comments from sponsor and CORRECT opening act. Picks up 12th graf, `As people...'
DOC.TEXT: A melee punctuated by gunfire erupted among 25,000 hot revelers at an overcrowded outdoor rap concert. At least 11 people were injured, none seriously, and more than 20 arrested, authorities said. Concertgoers hurled bottles, fistfights broke out and a man was stabbed in the leg during the Memorial Day show at Herman Park. Mothers carried screaming babies under their arms as they fled. More than 200 officers on foot, horseback and in helicopters evacuated the area. Police reported more than 20 arrests, including two for gun possession. A 16-year-old boy received stitches after being hit in the head by a baseball bat, said Donna Miller, a nurse at Hermann Hospital. ``Some people apparently started throwing beer bottles and then I heard pop, pop, pop _ someone was shooting _ and then everybody started running,'' said Ron Atkins, a spectator and program director at another station. ``I heard about four gunshots and just started running,'' said George Carver. The concert was canceled and police closed the park. Police will investigate whether concert promotors did everything they could to secure the area, said police spokesman Al Baker. ``The attendance was well over capacity (17,000),'' said Parks Director Don Olson. ``We have been trying to limit the number attending events here.'' Promoters had hired about 30 officers for security, said Joe Libios, promotion director for KHYS, sponsor of the free concert. The concert was delayed for at least two hours as promoters tried to arrange for more security. ``You just can't put on a concert any more without any incidents,'' said Libios. ``One bad apple or two bad apples ruined it for the rest of us.'' The disturbance erupted as the opening band began its second song. Temperatures had reached 93 degrees, and witnesses said several people had begun spraying each other with beer in the hot afternoon sun. As people surged toward the stage, someone threw a bottle into the crowd, and someone apparently angry at the people closing in fired a gun, Olson said. Thomas Martin, 13, said people on a hill overlooking the stage threw bottles at the audience inside the theater, hitting a youth. ``He walked from the front of the theater up the aisle with a T-shirt wrapped around his head and blood running down his arm,'' Martin said. ``I never saw so much happen so fast,'' said Carolyn Smith. ``I was crying, I was so scared.''

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin's Maverick Style Prevails Again
With PM-Yeltsin, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Less than three years ago, Boris N. Yeltsin was reviled in the Soviet press, attacked by top party officials and rebuffed by his former mentor, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Somehow, he turned it all to his advantage. Yeltsin, a burly 59-year-old Siberian, won election today to a powerful and visible post _ the presidency of the Russian Federation, by far the Soviet Union's largest republic. It wasn't a quick and easy victory. It took three strenuous rounds of balloting in the Russian Congress. Gorbachev opposed Yeltsin's candidacy. But once again, Yeltsin showed his talent for overcoming odds, for seizing the moment, for using popular support to get what he wants. And as usual, if powerful higher-ups stood in his way, it only seemed to strengthen him and his populist message of radical economic and political reforms and less power for the central government. In 1985, Yeltsin, a construction engineer by trade, was an obscure official in the Ural Mountains industrial city of Sverdlovsk, not far from his native village of Butka. Then Gorbachev brought him to Moscow to take over the capital city's Communist Party organization, and gave him a non-voting seat on the ruling Communist Party Politburo. It didn't take Yeltsin long to start making waves. He showed little reverence for the party hierarchy. He campaigned in stores and on trolley buses to improve food supplies and public services. He spoke out against special privileges for the government and party elite. The gravelly-voiced, white-haired Yeltsin quickly won a following. ``People identify with Yeltsin,'' the weekly Moscow News wrote last year in a full-page story headlined ``The Boris Yelsin Phenomenon.'' Muscovites were tired of watching their leaders rocket by in sleek limousines while they stood in line to buy soap, sugar and other scarce items. Yeltsin's borshcht-in-every-pot message had immediate appeal. Like millions of other Soviet citizens, Yeltsin became increasingly impatient with the pace of Gorbachev's reforms. Characteristically, he did not hesitate to say so. And characteristically, he went too far. In 1987, he made a stinging speech to a closed meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee, criticizing the slow pace of reforms. That earned him a sharp reprimand from his former mentor Gorbachev and brought vitriolic attacks from the party officials who accused him of dealing a ``stab in the back'' to economic reform. The criticism of Yeltsin was published in the press, he was stripped of his post as Moscow party chief and hospitalized for heart trouble. The word went out that he was finished politically. Gorbachev and Yeltsin never did patch things up, and Yeltsin remained on the outs with top leaders. But he made that rift work for him. The open disdain of the Communist Party apparatus enhanced Yeltsin's populist image and helped him win the backing of millions of supporters. Gorbachev actively campaigned against Yeltsin's bid for the Russian presidency. He told the Russian Congress last week that Yeltsin's call for Russian sovereignty was ``an attempt to cut Russia off from socialism.'' Yeltsin in turn spoke against the Soviet government's program for gradually transforming the country's crippled centrally planned economy to a partial market economy. That program, which will eventually double the cost of food, caused panic-buying in Moscow. Some congressional deputies said Yeltsin's candidacy got a boost from public anxiety over the plan. Although Yeltsin's win today seemed like a sudden triumph, his comeback didn't happen all at once. After his fall from political grace in 1987, he began rebuilding his power base. That led to a landslide victory in March 1989 in direct popular elections to the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies, the national parliament. Yeltsin was swept into office with almost 90 percent of the vote, crushing his apparatus-backed opponent. Later that year, he carried out a deft procedural maneuver to win election to the Supreme Soviet, the national legislature. And early this year, he was elected a deputy of the Russian Federation Congress, which today chose him president. He also remains a member of the party's policy-making Central Committee. Now his image as a man who can take on the system and win is stronger than ever.

DOC.HEAD: Former New Jersey Gov. Robert B. Meyner Dies
DOC.TEXT: Former Gov. Robert B. Meyner, a fiscally conservative Democrat credited with restoring his party in New Jersey in the 1950s, has died after a long illness. He was 81. Meyner, who suffered a stroke four years ago, died in his sleep Sunday at his home in Captiva, Fla., said his wife, Helen. ``He lived a very full, rich life, giving an awful lot to a lot of people,'' said Mrs. Meyner, a congresswoman from 1974 to 1978. Meyner was New Jersey governor from 1954 to 1962, the first New Jersey governor elected to successive four-year terms. State law bars governors from serving three consecutive terms. He sought the post again in 1969 but lost. Meyner won the governorship at a time when Republicans dominated state government. He was New Jersey's first Democratic governor since 1940. Meyney had previously served one term as a state senator. Meyner was credited with keeping a balanced state budget, and ably administering basic state needs such as water supply and land management. He oversaw the completion of the New Jersey Turnpike in the mid-1950s. From 1958 to early 1960, he was considered a candidate for the Democratic nomination for president, but was not nominated. Meyner gave credibility to the governor's office and the state Democratic Party, said former Gov. Brendan Byrne, Meyner's secretary for two years. ``He took a boss-controlled Democratic Party and insisted on a public integrity which remains the standard in New Jersey,'' Byrne, governor from 1974 to 1982, said in a statement Monday. Meyner was born in Easton, Pa., on July 3, 1908, and was raised in Phillipsburg and Paterson. After leaving public office he returned to his law practice and served on the boards of several corporations. In addition to his wife, Meyner is survived by a brother.

DOC.HEAD: Court bars Massachusetts from forcing brokers to make arbitration optional
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today refused to let states require stockbrokers to give investors the option of suing, rather than seeking arbitration, over alleged broker fraud. The justices, without comment, let stand a ruling that barred Massachusetts from requiring brokers to make arbitration clauses optional, not mandatory, in brokerage contracts. The Massachusetts appeal the court acted on today was supported by 30 other states, whose officials said a federal appeals court ruling leaves them ``powerless to protect consumers from being coerced to enter arbitration agreements.'' But the Bush administration told the justices the Massachusetts appeal should be rejected. The 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Boston ruled Aug. 31 that the Massachusetts regulations are pre-empted by federal law. The brokerage industry customarily requires customers to agree to arbitrate all disputes as a condition of opening an account. But in 1987, the justices ruled, by a 5-4 vote, that if such arbitration clauses are in the contracts signed by investors, disputes over alleged fraud are to be resolved in arbitration, not in lawsuits. Massachusetts' secretary of state in 1988 imposed regulations prohibiting brokers from making arbitration agreements non-negotiable conditions for opening accounts. The regulations also required brokers to tell customers about the legal effects of mandatory arbitration clauses. The state's action immediately was challenged by the Securities Industry Association and 10 brokerage firms affiliated with it. A federal judge ruled for the brokers, and the appeals court upheld that ruling. ``The long and short of it is that we can find no evidence of a clear congressional command to override the unambiguous pro-arbitration mandate of the (Federal Arbitration Act) in the securities field,'' the appeals court said. In the state's appeal, Massachusetts Attorney General James M. Shannon said the August ruling ``has national implications for state regulation of mandatory arbitration agreements in banking, health care, (the) automobile and many other industries.'' Shannon said the Federal Arbitration Act does not pre-empt all state regulation of arbitration. Lawyers for the securities industry and the Justice Department urged the justices to reject the state's appeal. Government lawyers said federal law does pre-empt such state regulation. The case is Connolly vs. Securities Industry Association, 89-894.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Appeal by Ku Klux Klan
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS spelling of Hosea in 3rd graf, The civil...; Note language in 6th and 10th grafs
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today rejected an appeal by two Ku Klux Klan groups and four men ordered to pay more than $800,000 for organizing a demonstration that turned into a violent attack on civil rights marchers in Georgia. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the punitive-damages award did not violate the free-speech rights of the KKK and its sympathizers. The civil rights demonstration in Forsyth County, Ga., was led by state legislator Hosea Williams on Jan. 17, 1987, the birthday of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. The KKK staged a counter-demonstration intended to convince blacks to stay out of the county. A half-hour before the civil rights march began, Grand Dragon David Holland of the Southern White Knights of the KKK addressed the counter-demonstrators. Holland, who later denied he was inciting a riot, told his followers, ``We need to let them know that we're going to keep this place white. Let's disperse and go greet those filthy half-ape niggers, brothers.'' The Invisible Empire, Knights of the Ku Klux Klan was the second group helping lead the counter-demonstrators. Klan members and sympathizers climbed fences and headed for the marchers, throwing rocks and bottles and shouting obscenities and racial epithets. As the counter-demonstrators surrounded the marchers and their bus, law enforcement officials loaded the marchers onto the bus to protect them and moved the bus away. The counter-demonstrators pelted the bus with debris as it withdrew. The next day, Holland said in a speech in Raleigh, N.C., ``The Ku Klux Klan sent that nigger Hosea Williams and his busload of race traitors back to Atlanta ... with three or four windows busted out of that bus.'' He said any future march should be met with similar tactics. The marchers sued, and a federal jury decided that the KKK groups and 11 individuals violated the marchers' civil rights. The jury awarded $2,500 in compensatory damages; more than $700,000 in punitive damages against the KKK groups; $43,859 against Holland, and $26,316 each against Edward Stephens, Daniel Carver Sr. and Franklin Shirley. Stephens and Carver were KKK officers, and Shirley said he is a white supremacist. The 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the awards last year. There is ample evidence the KKK groups and the individuals ``plotted not only to avail themselves of the opportunity to express views contrary to those held by the marchers but also to disrupt and stop the brotherhood march by violent means,'' the appeals court said. ``A jury may award punitive damages in a civil rights action upon its determination that the defendant was motivated by an evil motive or intent or where the defendant was recklessly or callously indifferent to federally protected rights,'' the appeals court added. Lawyers for the counter-demonstrators said Holland, in addressing the group prior to the march, was urging his listeners ``to jeer and to verbally abuse'' the marchers but not to attack them. The attorneys also said the size of the punitive-damages awards shows the demonstrators were punished ``for their unpopular political and social views'' in violation of their free-speech rights. The case is Stephens vs. McKinney, 89-1558.

DOC.HEAD: Reward Offer Bringing in Tips in IRA Killing of Australians
LaserPhoto LON1
DOC.TEXT: Dutch police alerted all border guards, offered a reward and investigated dozens of tips today, but they were unable to determine the identity of the IRA killers of two Australian tourists. The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility for Sunday night's shooting of the two Australians, saying it ``tragically mistook'' them for British servicemen. The victims were driving a British-registered car, and the attack took place in a district of this southern Dutch city frequented by British soldiers stationed in nearby West Germany. Investigators said up to 20 people witnessed the shootings, but no one had been able to give them a good description of the killers of Stephen Melrose and Nick Spanos, Australian citizens who lived in London. National Police spokesman Louis Steens said about 40 tips had come in since police offered a $52,000 reward late Monday for information leading to arrests in the slayings. In Australia, Prime Minister Bob Hawke today condemned the killings and denounced the IRA's description of the two as accidental victims of war. ``This sort of warped logic of war casualties adds insult to a mortal injury,'' Hawke said. Although Dutch police immediately alerted border guards, it is only a 10-minute drive from Roermond to the nearest Belgian and West German border crossings, and the Belgian border is virtually unguarded. Steens told reporters at National Police headquarters that investigators believed it was ``sheer coincidence'' that the Australians arrived just as an IRA hit squad was seeking a target. Roermond's cafe district was the site of another IRA attack in 1988. Melrose, 24, was shot as he was preparing to take a picture of the floodlit town hall. Spanos, 28, was shot inside their car. Melrose's wife Lyndal, 29, and Spanos' girlfriend, Vicky Coss, 24, were uninjured. They fled screaming for help, according to eyewitnesses. Steens said the two women had returned to London and ``their condition is still very bad.'' ``They are in heavy shock,'' he said. He refused to provide certain details about the attack, such as the number of bullets fired or the weapons used. Roermond residents laid a wreath and attached white and pink carnations to police fences surrounding the shooting site in their historic market square. A chalk outline of Melrose's body was still visible. There are far more eyewitnesses of the shooting than in 1988, when the IRA killed three off-duty British servicemen in coordinated attacks here and in Nieuwbergen, 30 miles to the north, said Steens. But witnesses to this attack disagree on the number and description of the IRA gunmen, he said. The almost exclusively Catholic Irish Republican Army is fighting to push the British out of Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland, join it with the Republic of Ireland and set up an all-Ireland socialist state.

DOC.HEAD: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Dies in California
DOC.TEXT: Hussein Onn, prime minister of Malaysia from 1976 to 1981, died at a California hospital after suffering a second heart attack in six weeks. He was 68. Hussein died Monday afternoon at Seton Medical Center in suburban San Francisco, where he had been hospitalized for several weeks, said a nursing supervisor. Hussein was admitted to the intensive care unit after suffering a second heart attack in six weeks, said his son-in-law, Yahya Awang, a heart surgeon. Yahya said the Malaysian Embassy in the United States was making arrangements for the body to be flown back to the southeast Asia nation where an official funeral was planned. Hussein was Malaysia's third prime minister. Hussein became prime minister following the death of Abdul Razak in 1976. Hussein was Razak's deputy and his brother-in-law. Hussein was a member of the United Malays National Organization party, which has ruled the country since independence in a coalition with Chinese and Indian parties. He resigned after a heart bypass operation in 1981 because of his health. Hussein selected the present prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, to succeed him in July 1981. But the two broke with each other in 1987-88 when Mahathir sacked Malaysia's highest ranking judge, arrested 106 people and detained them without trial. Mahathir's actions resulted in formation of a rival party. But during the past 18 months, Mahathir and Hussein were said to have reconciled their differences and to have held regular consultations.

DOC.HEAD: Court Expands Government Power to Keep Some Defendants Jailed
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today increased the federal government's power to keep some criminal defendants behind bars while they await trial, even if a key bail law was violated. The justices, by a 6-3 vote, spared the government from having to free on bail some defendants deemed to be dangerous or a risk to flee before trial. The decision reversed a federal appeals court ruling that said pretrial release is required _ even for a defendant who could have been held in custody _ if a pretrial detention hearing is not held the first time that person appears in court. ``The safety of society does not become forfeit to the accident of the non-compliance with statutory time limits where the government is ready and able'' to show release on bail is not feasible, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote for the court. ``Neither the timing requirements nor any other part of the (Bail Reform Act of 1984) can be read to require, or even suggest, that a timing error must result in the release of a person who should otherwise be detained,'' Kennedy said. Justices John Paul Stevens, William J. Brennan and Thurgood Marshall dissented. Writing for the three, Stevens said that in writing the bail law Congress required prosecutors ``to turn square corners.'' ``The court today, however, permits federal prosecutors to violate the law with impunity.'' The justices in 1987 upheld the federal law allowing denial of bail before trial to people deemed dangerous to the community, even if accused of non-violent crimes. Before the 1984 law, pretrial bail generally would be denied only if a judge determined the defendant was likely to flee. In practice, however, federal judges could get around the old law by setting very high bail, ostensibly aimed at guaranteeing the defendant's appearance in court but effectively keeping the accused in custody while awaiting trial. A provision in the 1984 law states that a hearing to determine whether pretrial detention is justified must be held ``immediately upon the person's first appearance before the judicial officer, unless that person or the attorney for the government seeks a continuance.'' A federal trial judge and the 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that the ``first appearance'' provision of the law had been ignored in the case of Guadalupe Montalvo-Murillo, charged with possessing nearly $1 million worth of cocaine. Montalvo-Murillo, a Mexican legally living in this country, was stopped in February 1989 while driving a pickup truck near the Mexican border at Orogrande, N.M. U.S. Customs Service agents found 72 pounds of cocaine, with a wholesale value of almost $1 million in the truck. At a Feb. 16, 1989, proceeding, a federal magistrate put off a detention hearing until Feb. 21. After that hearing, the magistrate decided to release Montalvo-Murillo on $50,000 bail. Government prosecutors appealed to a federal judge, who ruled that Montalvo-Murillo posed both a danger to the community and a risk to flee. But the judge ruled that the New Mexico magistrate, in postponing the detention hearing for five days, violated the federal bail law's ``first appearance'' rule. The judge said the only appropriate remedy was the defendant's release on bail. Montalvo-Murillo was freed on $88,500 bail, and has been a fugitive from justice ever since. He is believed to have fled to Mexico. The case is U.S. vs. Montalvo-Murillo, 89-163.

DOC.HEAD: Man Kills Wife, Mother-in-Law and Himself
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead and UPDATES throughout with identities of victims. Micael and Jefferss are cq. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A man returning his infant son to his estranged wife pulled a gun from a diaper bag and killed her and his mother-in-law, then fatally shot himself in the head, police said. The man, Micael Jefferss, 31, died early today at Vassar Brothers Hospital. Dutchess County's second triple shooting in two days occurred Monday in a YMCA parking lot in a front of a police officer who had accompanied the mother to the meeting to exchange the 10-month-old child, Lt. Arthur Regula said. Jefferss and his wife, Lavonne, 27, had been separated about three weeks, police said. Jefferss normally had custody Fridays and Saturdays, and the child was usually returned in front of the YMCA because it is a public place, said Capt. John Doherty. But the boy's mother complained to police Sunday that her husband had refused to give up the child. Doherty said the mother had guessed Jefferss would show up at the YMCA on Monday and had asked for an officer to accompany her. The officer arrived first and interviewed Jefferss, who was calm and coherent, then returned to his patrol car to watch the exchange, Doherty said. Jefferss placed the boy in a child's car seat, then returned to his own car for a diaper bag. When he reached his wife's car again, he pulled a gun from the bag and shot his wife and mother-in-law, Vivian Shealey, 49, at close range, Doherty said. The officer was drawing his gun when the man shot himself, Doherty said. The child was unhurt. On Sunday a Hyde Park man shot and killed his wife and wounded a neighbor before killing himself with a shotgun.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Democracy Party, Claiming Win, Plans to Set up Constitutional Gov't
DOC.TEXT: Burma's main pro-democracy party is claiming an overwhelming victory in the national election and said today it would start setting up a constitutional government as soon as its win is official. But Kyi Maung of the opposition National League for Democracy said his party would be ``patient'' in seeking the transition to civilian rule. The current military government seized power after a bloody 1988 crackdown on pro-democracy forces. A final official tally in Sunday's vote may take weeks, due to a ng process. In vote-counting so far, the military-backed party had yet to win a single parliamentary seat. Kyi Maung said his party was certain it had won at least 322 seats in the 492-seat national legislature, the Htutlaw. Official results reslow hand-countileased so far indicated victories by wide margins for the National League for Democracy in Burma's first multiparty elections in 30 years. In races already decided, League candidates were winning by an average of 72 percent of the vote to about 15 percent for the pro-military National Unity Party, state radio said. Of the 43 parliamentary races decided, the League won 41, official radio reported. The other two seats went to other pro-democracy parties. The Leas personally responsible for paying the owed taxes. The controversy stemmed from the two types of federal taxes owed by employers _ ``trust fund'' and ``non-trust fund'' taxes _ and the differing consequences of non-payment. Trust fund taxes are those withheld from employees' paychecks, representing those employees' personal income tax, unemployment insurance and Social Security taxes. Should an employer fail to pay any trust fund taxes, the government can collect an equivalent sum directly from the officials who were responsible for collecting and paying them. An employer also may fail to pay its ordinary corporate income taxes or other non-trust fund taxes _ those to be paid directly by the corporation and not withheld or collected from someone else. The government generally cannot impose personal liability on corporate officials if a corporation's non-trust fund taxes go unpaid. A Massachusetts corporation called Energy Resources Co. filed for bankruptcy reorganization in 1983 while owing about $1 million in federal taxes, most of which were trust fund taxes. As part of its court-ordered reorganization, the taxes owed by Energy Resources were to be paid over four years. In making the first payment, the bankruptcy trustee told the Internal Revenue Service to apply it to trust fund taxes owed. But the IRS refused, contending the payment could be applied to the corporation's tax debt as the government agency chose. The same sequence of events occurred after a Rhode Island corporation called Newport Offshore filed for bankruptcy reorganization in 1985. Court documents did not indicate the business in which either corporation was engaged. Federal judges in both states ruled that the IRS had to apply the tax payments as specified, and those rulings were upheld by the Boston-based 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The appeals court acknowledged that having the trust fund taxes paid off first hurts the government's chances of collecting all the money owed. If the reorganized corporation were to run out of money with trust fund debts still owed, the government might collect them from the people who were to collect and pay that money. But if all the trust fund taxes have been paid when a reorganized corporation runs out of money, the government could not go after the corporation's officers. Today's decision upheld the two corporations' legal victories. Writing for the court, Justice Byron R. White said a bankruptcy court ``may order the IRS to apply tax payments to offset trust fund obligations where it concludes that this action is necessary for a reorganization's success.'' Justice Harry A. Blackmun was the court's lone dissenter. His vote was not accompanied by a written opinion. The case is U.S. vs. Energy Resources Co., 89-255.

DOC.HEAD: Court Broadens Protection Against Double Jeopardy in New York Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court, in a ruling broadening the protection against double jeopardy, said today that a motorist who pleads guilty to drunken driving in a fatal accident may not be prosecuted later for homicide. The 5-4 ruling in a case from New York extends so-called double jeopardy protection against multiple prosecutions for some criminal defendants. The court said someone convicted of a relatively minor offense generally may not be retried on more serious charges based on the same alleged conduct. ``Drunk driving is a national tragedy,'' Justice William J. Brennan wrote for the court. ``Prosecutors' offices are often overworked and may not always have the time to monitor seemingly minor cases as they wind through the judicial system. But these facts cannot excuse the need for scrupulous adherence to our constitutional principles.'' The court barred a new prosecution of Thomas J. Corbin in an Oct. 3, 1987, accident on Route 55 in LaGrange, N.Y. Corbin was accused of crossing a double yellow line and striking two other vehicles headed in the opposite driection. Brenda Dirago, who was driving one of the other cars, was killed. Corbin pleaded guilty 24 days later to drunken driving and driving on the wrong side of the road. He was fined and his driver's license was suspended for six months. The local judge who sentenced Corbin apparently was unaware someone had died in the crash.
