No one from the Dutchess County district attorney's office appeared in court when Corbin pleaded guilty or was sentenced for the traffic violations. Two days after the January 1988 sentencing, the district attorney's office learned what happened and won an indictment on various criminal charges, including negligent homicide and reckless assault. The New York State Court of Appeals threw out the indictment and the prosecutors appealed to the Supreme Court. Groups that favor stricter laws against drunken driving had called the appeals court ruling an outrage that tramples on the rights of victims. Brennan said today, ``The Double Jeopardy Clause bars any susbsequent prosecution in which the government, to establish an essential element of an offense charged in that prosecution, will prove conduct that constitutes an offense for which the defendant has already been prosecuted.'' He noted that prosecutors intended to introduce new evidence in trying Corbin on homicide charges. But Brennan said the test of double jeopardy is not whether the evidence at a new trial is different, but whether the alleged offense is based on the same conduct. Joining Brennan were Justices Byron R. White, Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens. Justice Antonin Scalia, in a dissenting opinion, said the ruling could hamstring prosecutors. ``It will require prosecutors to observe a rule we have explicitly rejected in principle: that all charges arising out of a single occurrence must be joined in a single indictment,'' he said. Also dissenting were Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Sandra Day O'Connor and Anthony M. Kennedy. The case is Grady vs. Corbin, 89-474.

DOC.HEAD: Preparing For a New Kind of Baby Boom: The Gypsy Moth's
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-8, `Smaller outbreaks...' with 2 grafs to delete redundancy from pvs writethru.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX1
DOC.TEXT: The leaf-devouring gypsy moth is coming, in numbers never before seen on the continent, scientists and federal officials say. ``You can almost take that to the bank,'' said Charles P. Schwalbe, a U.S. Department of Agriculture expert. In 1981, the last time the gypsy moth population exploded, the pest stripped the leaves from 12 million acres of trees and other plants in the Northeast. Gypsy moth populations rise and fall in cycles averaging about seven years. Now, scientists say, the region is due for another boom _ and a huge one. Since 1981, the moth infestation has been expanding by about 10 miles a year from New England, and the moths now are stripping foliage as far south as Virginia and Maryland and as far west as Ohio and Michigan. Smaller outbreaks also have been spotted in California, Oregon, Washington and Colorado, where the larvae apparently were unwittingly transported by humans on the move, said Schwalbe, director of USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service. Those smaller outbreaks, however, were more easily controlled and are being eliminated, said Vic Mastro, an entomologist with the USDA. The gypsy moth actually is a danger in its caterpillar stage, eating more than a square yard of foliage by the time it matures. The attack against the pest has primarily involved spraying of Baccillus thurigiensis, a bacterium known as Bt that attacks the moth's digestive tract, and use of diflubenzuron, a chemical. But they haven't stopped the pest. Scientists are looking to other methods, including release of sterilized males to interrupt the moth's breeding cycle and use of the pest's natural enemies, including the white-footed mouse and nine kinds of parasitic insects. A Japanese fungus is credited with protecting large sections of western Massachusetts last year. The most promising development, some say, are viruses such as gypchek, which attacks the gypsy moth from the inside. Martin Shapiro, a scientist at USDA's Insect Pathology Laboratory in Beltsville, Md., developed and is testing a virus he nicknamed Abby _ for the town of Abington where it was isolated _ that apparently kills more moths faster. But it works best in a large moth population and loses effectiveness in sunlight. Coming soon, Shapiro said, is the potion that will make Abby the gypsy moth's nightmare. He said laboratory policy bars him from disclosing details. Even with all guns blazing against the gypsy moth, however, humans can hope only for a stalemate, scientists say. ``You can control it, but when you're talking about eradicating the gypsy moth, there ain't no such animal,'' Shapiro said. ``We do a good job with dodo birds and passenger pigeons, but there's virtually no insect that's been eradicated.'' A French political exile, Etienne Leopold Trouvelot, imported the pest from France to produce a disease-resistant strain of silkworm. In 1868 or 1869, the moth escaped into Trouvelot's back yard in Medford. By 1923, the moth had spread throughout New England. The U.S. Forest Service, which fights the largest infestations, has spent since 1979 an average of $6.1 million a year to fight the moth, said Ken Knauer, the agency's assistant director of forest pest management. In the fiscal year ending in September, the Forest Service will spend $13.6 million. Knauer said officials are telling Congress they will need about $15.3 million in the next fiscal year. ``With the expanding area of the gypsy moth, we doubt that ever again will we be spending less than $6 million,'' Knauer said.

DOC.HEAD: President Tells Pinochet to Turn Over Secret Police Files
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with Pinochet saying he doesn't have secret police files, other comment. Pickup 11th graf pvs, `Aylwin also...'
DOC.TEXT: President Patricio Aylwin has ordered former military ruler Augusto Pinochet to hand over records of the disbanded secret police and told the general to keep the army out of politics. After the meeting Monday, Pinochet told reporters he would provide the ``necessary information,'' but later denied holding any such records. ``What files? I don't have any,'' said Pinochet, who still commands the country's 60,000-man army. He was summoned to the government palace Monday and then forced to face taunts from demonstrators and shouts of ``murderer!'' when his armored car was denied entrance at the palace gate and he had to walk inside. Visibly angry, he complained about the treatment to a police guard. There was no immediate explanation of why Pinochet's car was turned away. He met with Aylwin and Defense Minister Patricio Rojas for an hour. A statement issued later by Aylwin's office said he asked Pinochet for details on the dissolving of the National Information Center, a secret police agency that human rights groups say were involved in the torture and killing of dissidents during Pinochet's 16{-year military rule. The right-wing general took power in a 1973 coup and his administration was marked by harsh repression of leftists and accusations of human rights abuse. Aylwin won democratic elections in December and took office March 11. According to the government statement, Aylwin ordered that secret police files ``but put at the government's disposition, to help prevent and combat terrorism.'' The National Information Center was legally disbanded shortly before Pinochet relinquished power. In recent weeks, however, there have been newspaper reports that former secret policemen have been caught conducting surveillance of officials of the new government. The general described the meeting as ``very cordial, very friendly'' and said Aylwin asked for his help in fighting terrorism. The government is hunting for leftist guerrillas involved in the recent shootings of some formerly high-ranking military officers. ``It was such an agreeable meeting that he invited the (army's) generals to dine with him in June,'' Pinochet said, speaking to reporters as he left his offices in the Defense Ministry building. Aylwin also complained about the ``political connotation'' of an army statement that expressed concern about the creation of a special commission to investigate human rights abuse during Pinochet's rule. Aylwin told Pinochet the army had no authority to question the panel's creation and should be trying to cooperate with it, according to the statement. Pinochet replied he didn't mean to question Aylwin's authority, although he had reservations about the investigation, the president's statement said. ``He expressed the army's willingness to cooperate,'' the statement said. Pinochet left the meeting by a private underground exit, avoiding reporters. He told reporters later, however, that the army statement on the human rights panel was not politically motivated. It was the first time Aylwin had summoned Pinochet to a meeting. The two met at the palace three weeks ago at the request of Pinochet, who then complained about the human rights commission. Pinochet called the December elections after a national referendum in 1988 rejected extending his rule to 1997. However, a clause in the 1980 constitution, written by Pinochet's administration, allows him to remain army commander until 1998.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say Woman Shot by Clown Dies
DOC.TEXT: A woman shot at her front door by someone dressed as a clown has died and detectives say they have several leads in the search for her killer. Marlene Warren, 40, died at Palms West Hospital in Loxahatchee, where she had been in critical condition since Saturday's shooting in an exclusive Palm Beach County community, detectives said. She was shot by someone who went to the door of her home carrying a basket of red and white carnations and two balloons floating on ribbons, witnesses told police. One of the balloons was stamped with the words ``You're the Greatest.'' The other bore a picture of Snow White and the seven dwarfs. After the shooting, the assailant left in a white Chrysler LeBaron that witnesses said had no license plate. Sheriff's detectives said they were working on numerous leads in the case but could not discuss details. ``We're still out there going crazy, still plugging away,'' Palm Beach County Sheriff's Detective Lt. Lou Sessa said Monday. Mrs. Warren managed rental apartments her family owned. Her husband, Michael, owns a car dealership in West Palm Beach.

DOC.HEAD: Merry Passengers Rescued; Grounded Cruise Ship Refloated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf and 10th graf, ``Coast Guard,'' to UPDATE with ship heading on to Philadelphia.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XREH5
DOC.TEXT: A luxury liner was refloated from a Delaware Bay sand bar today and headed for port, after passengers were ferried ashore, ending nearly two days of merry-making. The estimated 1,000 passengers on the 642-foot Regent Star were treated to free food and drinks, sang Christmas carols and played ``The Newlywed Game.'' ``I had a beautiful time,'' said Mary Poniatowsky, 66, a Baltimore bar owner. ``A lot of people were partying, but I didn't because I'm not a drinker.'' ``It wasn't a bad party,'' said a woman passenger who was met by friends and family at dockside. The ship had been headed for Philadelphia on the final leg of a seven-day cruise from Jamaica when a small fire early Sunday knocked out power and allowed the vessel to run onto a sand bar a mile off Fortescue, N.J. Aboard were 1,360 people, including about 300 crew members. Nobody was in danger during the two days aground, the Coast Guard said. Efforts to push the ship free with tugboats were halted for fear the vessel would spill fuel, and the passengers were transferred to a ferry that normally runs between Lewes and Cape May, N.J. The cheering passengers were put ashore Monday night 100 miles short of their destination and got on buses to be taken to their cars at airports and bus stations in the Philadelphia, Baltimore-Washington and New York City areas. The ship was finally refloated at high tide with help from tugboats early today and initially was moved to an anchorage off Slaughter Beach, Del., according to the Coast Guard. Coast Guard Lt. James Weakley said officials have not seen any evidence of pollution. Divers were supposed to check the hull of the ship today for leaks or other damage, but he said that plan was scrapped because of the weather and a decision was made to take the ship into Philadelphia. When the lights went out in the disco, passenger Kathleen Hopkins said, ``everybody was singing `Hot, hot hot.''' Later they sang Christmas carols and played an improvised version of ``The Newlywed Game,'' she said. ``People started chanting `Drinks, drinks drinks,''' and free mimosas started flowing, Hopkins said. Another passenger, Barbara Sowden of Wilmington, Del., said by phone: ``It just gave us a great opportunity to party hardy a little longer. We don't need a band, we make our own music.'' Ann Burguieres, a spokeswoman for Regency Cruises, said, ``They're always well stocked. There is always plenty of food and drink on a cruise.'' Ms. Poniatowsky and Dorothy Klausmeyer, 63, a store clerk in the Baltimore area, were the first two passengers off the ferry. ``What could you do? We slept, we took pictures,'' said Ms. Poniatowsky. Ms. Klausmeyer said she ``heard a thud early Sunday morning when the ship ran aground and I started to yell. I didn't know what was happening, then they explained it to us and we were all OK.''

DOC.HEAD: Witnesses: Demonstrators Kill Soldier in Anti-Government Fighting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with witness accounts of fighting, death reported, oil company to resume oil production. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers and anti-government demonstrators battled today for control of this oil-production center, and at least five people were reported injured, including a soldier. Initial reports from witnesses said the soldier died after he was severely beaten by protesters. But, according to later accounts, he was evacuated to Libreville, the capital, in critical condition. Gunfire from soldiers backed by armored cars wounded at least four demonstrators, witnesses said. Automatic rifle fire and explosions of hand grenades could be heard in low-income areas of the city. Soldiers also used tear gas against supporters of the opposition Gabon Progress Party and arrested at least 20 people, including three party leaders trying to negotiate the release of several children. Witnesses said they saw them driven in away in military vehicles. The fighting began last week with the death of an opposition leader, and oil companies drastically cut production. Gabon earns 80 percent of its income from oil and would quickly run out of money without it. President Omar Bongo's government imposed a state of siege Monday night throughout Port Gentil's province and sent troops in today to restore order. In Paris, today, the state-owned oil company Elf-Aquitaine announced it would gradually resume production on its 60 offshore rigs. Production was expected to reach half of the 101,000 barrels normally produced per day, and climb to 80 percent Wednesday, a company spokesman said. Security forces began moving into Port Gentil at dawn, sweeping away barricades set up by protesters. Initially there was no sign of resistance from opposition party supporters, whose leaders urged them to put away their weapons, mostly hunting rifles. The trouble began May 23 with the still-unexplained death of Joseph Rendjambe, secretary-general of the opposition Gabon Progress Party in the capital, Libreville. His party members rioted in several cities and took control of much of Port Gentil, burning the French Consulate and taking some expatriate oil executives hostage for several hours. The French government sent reinforcements to its garrison in the former French colony. When the troops arrived in Port Gentil, the hostages were freed. Bongo's government had been reluctant to use military force against the opposition supporters despite destruction of government and private property. But it acted when Elf Gabon and Shell Gabon shut down oil production. Before the Gabon security forces began their push to take over the city, French soldiers gathered 1,000 expatriate oil workers into special centers where they could be protected or evacuated if necessary. Nearly all wives and children of the workers already had been evacuated, and a further 40 to 60 reportedly were flown out today. Most of the expatriates were French, but their numbers also included British, Belgian, Dutch and American workers. Oil company executives said they had been forced to shut down oil production because of threats from the opposition party supporters. The decision angered Bongo, who threatened to look for other oil companies if production wasn't resumed.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Asks Special Counsel to Expand Pierce Probe
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department today asked the independent counsel investigating former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. to investigate fresh allegations of political favoritism at the agency. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh made the request in a May 25 letter to independent counsel Arlin M. Adams. A copy of the letter was released today by the Justice Department after it was received by Adams. In his letter, Thornburgh asked the court-appointed independent counsel to review allegations of favoritism in the operation of the Department of Housing and Urban Development's Urban Development Action Grant Program and the Secretary's Discretionary Fund for technical assistance and special projects. The request for Adams to broaden his inquiry was based on a review of testimony recently given to a House subcommittee by DuBois Gilliam, former deputy assistant HUD secretary for program policy development and evaluation, according to the letter. Gilliam, who is serving an 18-month sentence for conspiracy and accepting illegal gratuities, told a House subcommittee that Pierce told him on several occasions to award HUD grants to projects that were supported by influential Republicans. Gilliam, who operated the UDAG program, said Pierce ordered him to ordered to approve a $2.3 million grant for an apartment complex and shopping center on land owned by Hampton University, where Pierce was a trustee. Gilliam told the House Government Operations subcommittee in testimony earlier this month that Pierce told him to intervene in projects in Cleveland, Miami and Nashville. Justice Department spokesman Daniel Eramian said Gilliam's testimony about the operation of HUD during the Reagan administration was reviewed by prosecutors in the criminal division. In his letter to Adams, Thornburgh said Gilliam's ``allegations concerning how the funding decisions in these programs were made are related to the allegations you are already investigating concerning HUD's Moderate Rehabilitation Program.'' Adams said in a statement that ``it would appear that in light of Gilliam's testimony, it may be appropriate to redefine the mandate of the independent counsel.'' ``I shall, of course, carefully consider this letter from the attorney general during the next few days and take action promptly,'' said Adams, who noted he received the letter today. Adams was appointed by a special court earlier this year to investigate allegations that Pierce and top aides defrauded the government by awarding Moderate Rehabilitation Program grants on the basis of political favoritism between 1984 and 1988. The narrow jurisdiction was sought by Thornburgh following hearings last year by the same House subcommittee, chaired by Rep. Thomas Lantos, D-Calif. Democrats in Congress have repeatedly asked Thornburgh to expand the scope of Adams's jurisdiction. Gilliam's testimony, given under a grant of limited immunity from prosecution, conflicts with Pierce's sworn assertions to the subcommittee that he never ordered aides to approve specific grants.

DOC.HEAD: Unofficial Election Returns Show Strong Solidarity Showing
DOC.TEXT: Candidates supported by the Solidarity trade union held a strong lead over the Communists in community council elections across the nation, according to unofficial returns reported today. Preliminary results from the national General Election Commission indicated that Solidarity candidates swept 59 of 60 seats in the Baltic port of Gdansk, where the union was founded nearly a decade ago. Candidates backed by the union also were reported to be doing well in the large cities of Warsaw, Krakow, Katowice and Czestochowa in the first free elections for local councils since World War II. There were 52,000 individual races for seats on more than 2,000 councils, and the official results were to be announced Wednesday. During four decades of Communist rule, Poland's ommunity councils were largely under the control of the central government in Warsaw, but the new ones will be autonomous. Despite strong campaign efforts, the reformed Communist Party appeared to have done poorly. The Social Democrats, as the former Communists call themselves, won two seats in the cities of Kielce and Czestochowa, four in Opole, six in Lodz and 15 out of 341 seats in Warsaw, according to the unofficial returns. Voter turnout was only 42 percent, and it appeared many people stayed away because of confusion over the large number of parties running candidates. Nearly 80 new parties have been formed in the last six months, but many have not presented clearly defined programs. The most organized political force in the country is the local Citizens Committees founded a year ago by Solidarity supporters to contest elections. They faced competition in some areas. A group representing ethnic Byelorussians won a majority of the vote in the town of Bialowieza, and about 25 percent of the vote in two other towns in the northeastern province of Bialystok, not far from the Soviet border. The Confederation for an Independent Poland, a small anti-Communist group that has been politically active for a decade, won three council seats in the city of Lublin, one in Katowice and 12 in Lodz. But Leszek Moczulski, the leader of the group, lost his race in Warsaw. Residents of Gdansk province also voted on a referendum on the construction of a nuclear power plant in Zarnowiec, the PAP news agency reported today. It said 80 percent of the voters were against the project.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Indian Tribe May Not Prosecute Members of Other Tribes
DOC.TEXT: An Indian tribe may not prosecute members of other tribes for crimes on its reservation, the Supreme Court ruled today. The court, by a 7-2 ruling, stripped the Salt River Pima-Maricopa Indian Community in Arizona of the authority to prosecute a California man accused of fatally shooting a 14-year-old boy. ``Indian tribes lack jurisdiction over persons who are not tribe members,'' Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote for the court as it extended its 1978 ruling that barred tribes from prosecuting non-Indians for on-reservation crimes. Kennedy said Indian tribes surrendered the sovereign authority to prosecute non-Indians for crimes on reservations when the tribes accepted the federal government's protection. Justices William J. Brennan and Thurgood Marshall dissented. Writing for the two, Brennan said, ``I do not share such a parsimonious view of the sovereignty retained by Indian tribes.'' Albert Duro, a member of the Torres-Martinez Band of Cahuilla Mission Indians in California, was accused of the 1984 killing on the Salt River Indian Reservation near Scottsdale, Ariz. The victim, Phillip Fernando Brown, was a member of a third tribe _ the Gila River Indian Tribe. Duro was living with his girlfriend on the reservation, and was working for PiCopa Construction Co, which the Salt River Pima-Maricopa Indian Community owns. His lawyers said Duro is living in California and denies the tribe's charges. They said he is a fugitive. The case is Duro vs. Reina, 88-6546.

DOC.HEAD: Police Probe Slashed IV Tubes at Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Police were investigating why seven hospital patients had their intravenous tubes slashed over the weekend. None of the patients at University Community Hospital suffered any ill effects, Jim Leljedal, spokesman for the Broward County Sheriff's Office, said Sunday. He said there were no suspects. The hospital has beefed up security since the first incidents were reported early Saturday, spokesman David Margulies said. Six of the seven fourth-floor patients had the tubes sliced sometime before 3 a.m. Saturday, when nurses making routine rounds discovered the cuts. One patient said he remembered a man entering his room about that time, but could recall no other details, Leljedal said. Twelve hours later, another IV line was discovered cut.

DOC.HEAD: East Berlin Mayor Wants 3 West Berlin Officials in His Government
DOC.TEXT: East Berlin's mayor-elect said today he wants three city council members from West Berlin in his government, a move that would strengthen new ties between the long-divided cities. Tino Schwierzina said there were no legal bars to his plans, even though the four victorious World War II allies still have ultimate control over Berlin. The United States, Soviet Union, France and Britain are expected to relinquish that power as the German states proceed with unification plans. Schwierzina's plan would be one of the most significant steps toward reuniting the Berlins since the Berlin Wall was opened on Nov. 9. However, the plan may face trouble in East Berlin, where Schwierzina, a Social Democrat, has agreed on a governing coalition with the conservative Christian Democratic Union. The Christian Democrats are expected to object because Schwierzina wants two officials from West Berlin's Social Democratic Party and one from the leftist Alternative List. The Christian Democrats are the opposition party in West Berlin and have tight links with their counterparts in East Berlin. Likewise, the Social Democrats in both cities also have close ties. Schwierzina named as possible candidates West Berlin Finance Sen. Norbert Meisner, Construction Sen. Wolfgang Nagel and Education Sen. Sybille Volkholz. The three have already said they are ready to work for both city governments, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Boat Accident Kills 23 in India
DOC.TEXT: An overcrowded dinghy sailing between two villages capsized and killed 23 people, authorities said Tuesday. The boat was in the Bhima River in the eastern state of Maharashtra when the accident occurred Monday afternoon. Local authorities said the small craft was carrying 36 people to Takli village when it overturned. Thirteen people swam to shore. Ten were pulled out of the river and another 13 people were missing and believed dead, they said. Many of the dead were children. Boat, bus and train accidents are common in India, which lacks a good transportation infrastructure.

DOC.HEAD: Pacific Bird Seen in England
DOC.TEXT: An ancient murrelet is drawing hundreds of birdwatchers to the Bristol Channel in southwest England, far from its normal habitat. ``This bird has never been recorded outside the northern Pacific Ocean before, and its appearance in Britain is likely to be the bird sighting of 1990,'' Richard Millington, who runs an information service on rare bird visitors, said Tuesday. The visitor was first sighted in Jenny's Cove on Lundy Island in the Bristol Channel. Millington's telephone service, Birdline, provided details of boats for hire in the north Devon coastal town of Bideford to ferry birdwatchers out to the island. One boat alone was hired to take 250 people to the scene. The ancient murrelet is a small member of the auk family of diving birds. Its main breeding grounds are on the Aleutians and other islands off western Alaska. In winter it flies south as far as Korea.

DOC.HEAD: Film Producer Dimitri de Grunwald Dead
DOC.TEXT: Dimitri de Grunwald, who produced the film ``The Millionairess'' with Peter Sellers and Sophia Loren, has died at age 76, a family death notice said Tuesday. De Grunwald died Saturday at his home in Hove on the English south coast. He was the son of a czarist diplomat and was born in St. Petersburg, now Leningrad, in 1914. His family brought him to England when they escaped during the revolution. De Grunwald started his career in a chemical company, then moved to advertising and became a movie producer on his own account after collaborating with his brother, Anatole, in making films, including ``The Way to the Stars,'' ``The Winslow Boy'' and ``The Demi-Paradise.'' After ``The Millionairess'' in 1960, in which Sellers played an Indian doctor, de Grunwald produced ``Shalako'' with Sean Connery and Brigitte Bardot, ``Murphy's War'' with Peter O'Toole and other movies. He started a new career in 1980 as a consultant to a pharmaceutical company. De Grunwald is survived by his wife, Vera, and a son. His brother died in 1967.

DOC.HEAD: Police Charge 18-Year-Old With Murder of Utah Man
DOC.TEXT: An 18-year-old Dublin man has been charged with murdering an American missionary for the Mormon Church, police said Tuesday. Edward Fernconde was in custody and charged with the fatal stabbing of Gale Stanley Critchfield, 20, of Payson, Utah, police said. Critchfield was attacked while walking home late Sunday in Clondalkin, outside Dublin, after making a series of house-to-house calls. Police said Monday a man with a knife had demanded money. With the help of a colleague, Critchfield was able to reach his apartment, where a roommate called an ambulance. He died early Monday in hospital. Critchfield was one of 160 workers with the Mormon Missions in Ireland and had been in the mainly Roman Catholic country since March 1989. Police said Fernconde, who is unemployed, made brief court appearances Monday night and Tuesday morning for the formal filing of the murder charge.

DOC.HEAD: Proposal to Disarm Majority of Police Alarms French Officers
DOC.TEXT: Evoking the image of London's bobbies, the interior minister has suggested that most French police officers do not need to carry guns. Police unions are aghast, saying French crooks don't share the English sense of fair play. ``Why not demand the disarmament of the whole planet?'' asked Bernard Deleplace, leader of the largest police union, at a news conference Tuesday. ``In our Latin countries, the criminals are better-armed than the police,'' he added. Interior Minister Pierre Joxe ignited the controversy Monday with a spontaneous comment during a discussion about proposed legislation affecting France's 10,000 municipal police. Joxe said he not only agreed with a proposal to disarm these officers, but also believed that a vast majority of the 120,000 members of the national police force had no need to carry arms. To back his argument, Joxe cited the example of London, where only 2,552 of the 26,800 police officers are authorized to carry guns. All major police unions responded to the comments with surprise and alarm. ``When the crooks have learned English fair play, then maybe we'll see,'' said a spokesman for a union of detectives. ``Crime isn't going to decrease, and we mustn't disarm the police.'' Roger Chaix, former director of the national intelligence service, rejected Joxe's comparison with London. ``Crime doesn't have the same characteristics in Britain as in France, where unfortunately there is extremely violent crime,'' he told the newspaper Le Figaro. According to union estimates, weapons are carried by most of the 80,000 uniformed officers in the national police force, and 95 percent of them would oppose disarmament.

DOC.HEAD: Ethiopian Rebels, Government Claim Victories
DOC.TEXT: NAIROBI, Kenya _ Ethiopian rebels said Tuesday they ``completely routed'' government troops southeast of Asmara, the besieged capital of Ethiopia's northernmost province. The Eritrean People's Liberation Front said in a clandestine radio broadcast that it began an offensive Monday along what it called the Segeneyti Front, 30 miles from Asmara. The broadcast gave no details, referring only to a ``strong offensive'' that ``also routed enemy soldiers who arrived in support.'' The Eritreans' boast came as newspapers in Addis Ababa claimed a government victory over Tigrean rebels in central Ethiopia. The newspapers said government soldiers killed 1,450 rebels of the Tigre People's Liberation Front in fighting for control of a strategic mountain pass. There was no way to verify either of the claims. The Eritreans seek independence for the northern province of Eritrea, a former Italian colony. They captured the Red Sea port of Massawa on Feb. 8 and cut off all but air access to Asmara. The Tigreans are fighting to oust President Mengistu Haile Mariam and establish a hard-line Marxist government. The newspaper reports Tuesday said government troops battled Tigre rebels around Debre Lebanos, 50 miles north of the capital. ``A large number of terrorist bandits was captured and sizeable caches of heavy and light arms and equipment seized,'' the newspapers said. The reports did not specify when the fighting took place, but sources said the battle was Friday and Saturday. It was in the same area where the Tigreans said they ``annihilated'' two government battalions earlier in the week. Debre Lebanos lies on a pass through a mountain range and controls the main road from Addis Ababa northwest to Gojam, the Horn of Africa nation's main agricultural region.

DOC.HEAD: Harvard University President Resigns After Nearly Two Decades
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to CORRECT year of celebration to 1986 sted 1987, add previous speculation about resignation, delete extra words from penultimate graf.
DOC.TEXT: Derek C. Bok, president of Harvard University since 1971 and one of America's foremost educators, has resigned his post, it was announced today. Peter Costa, a spokesman for the university, could not immediately offer reasons for the resignation or any details of its timing. Bok, a Stanford University graduate, earned a law degree from Harvard in 1954. He joined the Harvard Law School faculty in 1958 and became dean of the school in 1968. Bok, 60, is a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and author of several books, including one on labor law that he wrote with Watergate prosecutor Archibald Cox. During his tenure as Harvard's president, Bok established both the John F. Kennedy School of Government and revived an undergraduate core curriculum based on the study of classics. Bok often made headlines with his conservative views on education and business, including a controversial stand against a movement for total divestment of the university's holdings in stocks of companies doing business in South Africa. Among his challenges, he headed the school during sometimes violent anti-Vietnam War demonstrations, and negotiated with black students and professors arguing over the years for better minority representation. But most of Bok's efforts were low-key as he worked behind the scenes to maintain traditions at Harvard, which celebrated its 350th anniversary in 1986 and has one of the nation's richest endowments. There had been wide speculation in academic circles that Bok would step down following the celebration marking the Cambridge institution's founding in 1636. Bok is the son of a Pennsylvania Supreme Court judge, and his grandmother was the daughter of H.K. Curtis, founder of Curtis Publishing Co., which published the Saturday Evening Post. He married Sissela Myrdal, the daughter of Swedish sociologist Gunnar Myrdal, in 1955. He and his wife, who has a doctorate in philosophy from Harvard and teaches at Brandeis University, have three children.

DOC.HEAD: Giant Tortoise Slower Than Most, Needs Ride
DOC.TEXT: Tortoises tend to move rather slowly, but the Brookfield Zoo's was so slow on its annual trek to its summer quarters that its keepers had to call a cab. The 450-pound tortoise, named Peter, has taken the quarter-mile walk from the reptile house to an outdoor yard every Memorial Day for at least 17 years. Peter and its keepers set out Monday at about 10:30 a.m. But by 12:45 p.m., Peter had covered only about 30 yards, said zoo spokeswoman Hannah Jennings. Some plants distracted him and he stopped to eat them. At 1:15 p.m., the keepers gave up, loaded Peter onto a truck and hauled him the rest of the way. The tortoise, from Aldabra Island in the Indian Ocean, was brought to the zoo as an adult and is estimated to be 40 to 60 years old, said Joyce Peterson, senior keeper at the reptile house.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Elected President Of Russia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Soviet officials seeing benefit for Gorbachev in Yeltsin election. Pickup 7th, `After the...'
DOC.TEXT: Radical reformer Boris N. Yeltsin triumphed over opposition from Mikhail S. Gorbachev to win the presidency of the largest Soviet republic today in what he called ``Russia's social, economic and spiritual rebirth.'' After three hard-fought ballots in the 1,060-member Russian Congress of People's Deputies, Yeltsin won 535, four more than the majority he needed. Russian Premier Alexander Vlasov, received 467 ballots. Yeltsin now poses a substantial challenge to Gorbachev, who retains the two most powerful jobs in the country: president of the Soviet Union and general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party. However, Gennadi Gerasimov, spokesman for the Soviet Foreign Ministry, said Yeltsin's election could strengthen Gorbachev's campaign for economic reforms. ``Yeltsin's victory is an expression of general discontent with how things are going in the Soviet Union's biggest republic,'' Gerasimov told reporters at the United Nations in New York. ``The Soviet Union is a democracy, so we accept what the Russian parliament has decided. It may be a blessing in disguise. President Gorbachev has his critics from both the left and the right, and possibly it is better to have the election of a critic from the left,'' he said. Igor Malashenko, foreign policy advisor to the Communist Party who accompanied Gerasimov at the news conference, agreed. ``This victory of Yeltsin has been misinterpreted as a problem for Gorbachev,'' Malashenko said. ``Yeltsin is also a reformer, although he reflects concepts which are different from Gorbachev. ``In this respect I believe it (the election) can strengthen the cause of reform in the Soviet Union. Today, many people blame Gorbachev for problems and now they have another person to blame.'' After the election result was announced in the Grand Kremlin Palace, the burly 59-year-old Yeltsin, strode to the podium, received warm applause and cheers from fellow lawmakers, and was handed a bouquet of flowers. Yeltsin said he felt ``a certain satisfaction, but at the same time, I have much more a feeling of responsibility at this turning point for Russia and the country.'' ``I pledge not to spare anything _ health or time _ to do everything to get out of this crisis and lead Russia to better times,'' Yeltsin said in his victory speech. He called the day ``the beginning of the road to Russia's social, economic and spiritual rebirth, the way out of the crisis and toward the blossoming of Russia as a sovereign, independent government in the framework of our union.'' Gorbachev actively opposed Yeltsin's election, telling the Russian Congress last week that his platform of moving political and economic power from central to local authorities would lead to a ``breakup of the union.'' The Russian Federation is by far the largest of the 15 Soviet republics, stretching from the Baltic Sea in the west to the Pacific Ocean in the east. It is home to one-half the country's 285 million people and includes Moscow. As the president of Russia, Yeltsin will have a highly visible platform from which to wage his campaign for more radical reforms than those pursued so far by Gorbachev. The victory marks an amazing comeback for Yeltsin. Less than three years ago, he was reviled in the Soviet press, attacked by party officials, rebuffed by his former mentor, Gorbachev, and considered finished politically. Gorbachev had brought Yeltsin to Moscow to head the city's Communist Party, but he was fired in 1987 after showing little reverance for party hierarchy. Yeltsin, however, made his rift with Gorbachev work for him. The popular and outspoken Yeltsin had lost the second round of voting on Saturday by just 28 votes. He lost the first round Friday with 497 ballots to 473 for Krasnodar regional Communist Party chief Ivan Polozkov. He was nominated again Monday and faced Vlasov, who had Gorbachev's support, and Valentin Tsoy, a little-known businessman from the Soviet Far East, who received 11 votes. After his election, Yeltsin walked through the Kremlin grounds with reporters and well-wishers. After passing through the Spassky Gate, he was joined by more supporters. ``Thank you! Thank you for our future!'' one man shouted. Yeltsin mounted the steps of an embankment below the Kremlin wall for an impromptu speech to supporters who rushed across the cobblestone street. To shouts of ``victory!'' Yeltsin pledged to work for a ``renewed Russia.'' The crowd pledged support. ``We're prepared to go together with him into tough times. Everyone says that,'' one crowd member, Nadezda Matveyeva said. During his campaign, Yeltsin called on the Congress to reject the Kremlin's new program for gradually transforming the country's crippled, centrally planned economy to a partial market economy. ``The Congress must take the citizens of Russia under its defense,'' he said. The reform program, which would triple the price of bread on July 1 and double the cost of other foodstuffs starting Jan. 1, caused panic buying that prompted Moscow city authorities to bar sales to non-residents of the capital. Gorbachev, who left Moscow today for a Washington summit, went on national television Sunday night to try to calm fears. But anxiety is high and the list of items being rationed is on the rise. Yeltsin has broadly outlined a plan that would more rapidly seek a transition to a market-based economy, giving more freedom to enterprises and entrepreneurs. Lawmakers said Monday they believed Yeltsin's offer of a coalition government in the republic bolstered his chances to win today's round. Discontent over the government's economic program also boosted Yeltsin's campaign, said one of his backers, lawmaker Leonid Gurevich of Murmansk. Some economists have estimated that up to 40 million people could lose their jobs as a result of the central government's reforms, expected to drive many inefficient businesses into bankruptcy. Under the three-step reform plan, to be implemented through 1995, 60 percent of state enterprises would be sold to the public sector, and controls would be lifted on 60 percent of prices.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Admiral Confirms Nuclear Submarine Incident
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet admiral Tuesday confirmed that a nuclear submarine suffered a mishap near Norway in December, but he denied reports that it leaked radiation. The Soviet youth newspaper Komsomolskaja Pravda reported in February that a MIKE-class submarine spread radioactive contamination after a reactor or atomic missile accident. ``I can confirm that a nuclear submarine was involved in a mechanical failure situation, but it made it to land under its own power. There was no danger for the crew or of a radiation leak,'' said Adm. Aleksi Sorokin at a news conference in the Soviet Embassy. ``Our youth newspapers sometimes sensationalize things,'' said Sorokin, who was in Norway visiting military bases and meeting with government leaders. He said the accident occurred 345 miles from land, ``in an area between the Barents Sea and the Norwegian Sea,'' but gave no details. Norway, a member of the NATO alliance, has complained that the Soviets failed to issue adequate warnings in three other accidents aboard nuclear submarines last year. In the worst previous accident, a Mike-class submarine sank in the Norwegian Sea on April 7, 1989, killing 42 Soviet sailors. Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Sigrid Romundset said the December incident was ``probably not serious enough that we would expect to be informed.''

DOC.HEAD: Historic Section of Cemetery Hit by Vandals
DOC.TEXT: Vandals stole a truck and drove it through a section of Mount Hope Cemetery, damaging monuments near where Susan B. Anthony is buried, officials said. About 20 monuments were discovered damaged Saturday 100 yards from the graves of Anthony, Edward Bausch and Henry Laumb, said Mary Lou Tyndall, manager of the city's division of cemeteries. ``These are literally priceless,'' she said. ``Some of them date back to the last century. It's really almost beside the point what the monetary value is.'' The vandals stole the dump truck after breaking into a maintenance garage, Tyndall said. No arrests have been made.

DOC.HEAD: House Leaders Receives Thousands in Speaking Fees
DOC.TEXT: House Speaker Thomas S. Foley received $32,000 in speaking fees last year, according to House financial disclosure forms made public today. Foley, D-Wash., donated $5,000 of the honoraria to charity. In 1988, when he was House majority leader, Foley accepted $34,750 in speaking fees. Foley also got a healthy boost in salary when he was elected House speaker to succeed Rep. Jim Wright, D-Texas, a year ago after Wright was forced to resign. Foley's salary _ half a year as majority leader and half as speaker _ was $107,034. He also reported receiving $26,462 on the sale of various stocks managed by a blind trust. All House members were required to submit the financial disclosure forms, which listed assets and liabilities as well as income from salaries and outside sources and gifts. Senate financial disclosure forms will be made public Wednesday. The House Democratic leadership last year underwent a traumatic shift as a result of the resignations of Wright and Rep. Tony Coelho, D-Calif., both of whom were caught up in allegations of financial irregularities. But the scandals that brought about the leadership changes prompted no differences in attitudes toward accepting speaking fees from various groups. Rep. Richard Gephardt of Missouri, catapulted into the majority leader's post last year, accepted $34,500 in honoraria and donated $7,500 to charity. But the speaking fees accepted by Foley and Gephardt were dwarfed by their leadership colleague, Rep. William H. Gray III of Pennsylvania, the assistant majority leader. Gray received $164,098 in speaking fees and gave $139,098 to charity. House members are allowed to keep honoraria totalling up to 30 percent of their congressional salaries. The base salary for House members was $89,500. Not all benefits that went to House members came from their speaking ability. Rep. Ben Nighthorse Campbell, D-Colo., received $14,000 in income from designing jewelry, most of it for people in Colorado. Rep. Les Aspin. D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, can see all the baseball games he wants. He received an American League baseball pass from Bud Selig, owner of the Milwaukee Brewers and a National League pass from the late A. Bartlett Giamatti, who was National League commissioner at the time. Among Republican leaders, Rep. Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the assistant minority leader, saw his speaking rise sharply from a total of $28,550 in 1988, to $67,491 last year. Gingrich, who came under criticism last year for the royalty arrangement on a book he wrote, gave $40,704 of his honoraria to charity _ $29,304 of that to the Atlanta Zoo. Minority leader Bob Michel, R-Ill., received $49,300 in speaking fees and donated $21,540 to charity. As usual, Michel, an avid golfer, listed items received from his participation in various charity tournaments, including shoes, golf balls, jackets and shirts. The categories for assets and liabilities were in ranges that made it impossible to precisely calculate the wealth of some members. For example, Amory Houghton Jr., a New York Republican who is an heir to the Corning Glass Works fortune, listed his assets as a range from at least $5,046,937 to more than $7,460,000. But there was no way of estimating how much more than the second figure Houghton was worth. Rep. Julian C. Dixon, D-Calif., chairman of the House Ethics Committee, included the income and holdings of his wife, Betty, in his form. Mrs. Dixon's dividend income was listed as exceeding $100,000 in 1989. It came from her interest in Mir Kanon@Peideau, an airport stores partnership. And the value of her stock was listed as exceeding $250,000. According to previous financial disclosure forms, Dixon's wife invested between $5,000 and $15,000 in the partnership in 1986. Last year, Dixon listed the value of his wife's investment in the partnership at between $100,000 and $250,000. As usual, Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., was one of the leaders in speaking fees. Schroeder reported accepting honoraria on 72 occasions in 1989 for speeches, writings and television appearances. She reported keeping $26,313 of her total honoraria, $500 less than the maximum allowed.

DOC.HEAD: ``Write 'Em Up Ray'' Collects Traffic Excuses
DOC.TEXT: Here's a list that would make David Letterman proud: the best excuses for avoiding traffic tickets. ``One person said he was reaching for his hamster, because the thing got loose in the car. One guy said he couldn't read, so he couldn't read the speed limit sign,'' said police Cpl. Ray Schexnider, known as ``Write 'Em Up Ray'' Schexnider has handed out 10,882 tickets in seven years and keeps his excuse collection in a battered yellow notebook. ``I have the 66 best excuses, but there are some duplications,'' he said. ``The most popular one is, `I'm late for work.' And it doesn't matter what time it is, either.'' Some people want to see how the road works. Others claim their car can't possibly go as fast as the ticket says. One speeder said he was on the way to help a cow give birth. Another was hurrying home to check his motor, because a cat was caught in it. But sometimes Schexnider softens up. Once, he said, a man stopped for speeding said he wanted to get to the hospital before his wife's operation began. Schexnider believed the man and let him go. He later got a letter from the man, saying his wife had died on the operating table and Schexnider had given him the extra minutes he needed to see her.

DOC.HEAD: Freight Train Derails, Spills Fuel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with higher estimate of spill's size, other details. Adds byline.
DOC.TEXT: A freight train derailed near Fairbanks and spilled more than 100,000 gallons of jet and diesel fuel, state officials said. The southbound train with more than 50 cars derailed at about 1:30 p.m. Monday, said Arnold Polanchek, vice president of operations for the state-owned Alaska Railroad Corp. No one was injured in the derailment and the company still was investigating the cause, Polanchek said. Railroad cleanup crews and state Department of Environmental Conservation officials were on the scene, about 40 miles south of Fairbanks near Dunbar Station, Polanchek said. The fuel probably would have run into nearby Goldstream Creek were it not for some beaver dams nearby that held it back, a state environmental official said. There were no immediate reports of whether any beavers or other wildlife were harmed. Polanchek estimated the spill at 60,000 to 80,000 gallons. But Paul Bateman, Fairbanks program manager for the state environmental department, said Tuesday that more than 100,000 gallons was a more accurate estimate. ``We've got cars upside down, sideways, holed on both ends. They're in all shape and condition. It's a mess,'' said Bateman, who spent Monday night at the scene. He said at least 14 cars were leaking. Polanchek earlier had said 18 tank cars left the track and eight or nine were leaking fuel. By early today, pumps and hoses had begun pumping the fuel off the ground, Bateman said. Broken tanker cars were scattered on both sides of the track. A bulldozer was used to build a temporary earthen dike around the spill, Polanchek said. ``It should all be contained. It hasn't gotten to any moving water,'' he said. The fuel was on its way to Anchorage from the Mapco Alaska Petroleum Inc. refinery in the town of North Pole, near Fairbanks. The Alaska Railroad was purchased by the state from the federal government in 1985. It runs one freight train northbound and one train southbound daily. Passenger trains also make the run between Anchorage and Fairbanks, serving the Denali National Park and Preserve, where Mount McKinley is located.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Decide on Sentences in Michigan Drug Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether states may impose mandatory life sentences without possibility of parole for people convicted of possessing large amounts of drugs. The justices said they will study the appeal of Ronald Harmelin, convicted in Oak Park, Mich., of possessing more than 650 grams of cocaine. Harmelin contends that his life sentence without possibility of parole violates the Constitution's ban on ``cruel and unusual punishment.'' Michigan courts rejected that contention. The justices were told Michigan is the only state that imposes such a mandatory sentence. But if the state sentencing law is upheld, other states might follow Michigan's lead in their fight against drug use. Oak Park police stopped Harmelin's car for going through a red light May 12, 1986. Police found more than a pound of cocaine when they searched the car's trunk. The appeal acted on today attacked Harmelin's conviction as well as his sentence, but the justices said they were limiting their review to the sentence. In other words, they left intact Harmelin's conviction. The appeal said: ``There is no other crime in Michigan for which the punishment is mandatory life without parole except for first-degree murder. ``A person with a long criminal record could commit the foulest of atrocities _ hacking off limbs or poking out eyes of children or attempting to assassinate public officials _ without even the possibility of receiving a sentence as high as Ronnie Harmelin,'' the appeal said. The appeal added, ``This mandatory sentence law does nothing to deter the real drug kingpins, nor does it help protect society from drugs.'' But Michigan prosecutors defended the sentence as they urged the justices to reject Harmelin's appeal. ``While the defendant portrays himself as an innocent and misguided individual with no prior record, it is clear that he possessed well over 650 grams of cocaine, some of which was individually packaged for apparent resale,'' the state prosecutors said. They noted that he also possessed other drugs, a gun and a beeper. But Harmelin was not convicted of distributing drugs or of possession of drugs with intention to distribute.

A Michigan appeals court spent two sentences rejecting Harmelin's constitutional challenge to his sentence. ``Defendant's last claim is that the mandatory sentence of life imprisonment is entirely out of proportion to the seriousness of his crime and constitutes a cruel and unusual punishment proscribed by the U.S. Constitution's 8th Amendment and (the state constitution). We disagree,'' the appeals court said. It cited a previous state appeals court ruling for that conclusion. The Michigan Supreme Court refused to hear Harmelin's appeal last Jan. 29. The case is Harmelin vs. Michigan, 89-7272.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting a0604 to fix cycle designation
Court to Review Federal Regulations on Abortion Counseling
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 5-6, with other case.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court agreed today to review federal regulations that bar government-financed family planning clinics from counseling about abortion. Critics of the regulations, issued by the Reagan administration in 1988, allege they violate free-speech and abortion rights. At stake is the future scope of a federal program with a $200 million yearly budget. The program funds over 4,000 clinics serving some 5 million low-income women nationwide. In other action, the court: _ Agreed to decide whether states may impose mandatory life sentences without possibility of parole for people convicted of possessing large amounts of drugs. The justices said they will study the appeal of Ronald Harmelin, convicted in Oak Park, Mich., of possessing more than 650 grams of cocaine. _ Broadened the protection against double jeopardy, saying that a motorist who pleads guilty to drunken driving in a fatal accident may not be prosecuted later for homicide. The 5-4 ruling in a case from New York extends so-called double jeopardy protection against multiple prosecutions for some criminal defendants. The court said someone convicted of a relatively minor offense generally may not be retried on more serious charges based on the same alleged conduct. _ Rejected an appeal by two Ku Klux Klan groups and four men ordered to pay more than $800,000 for organizing a demonstration that turned into a violent attack on civil rights marchers in Georgia. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the punitive-damages award did not violate the free-speech rights of the KKK and its sympathizers. _ Increased the federal government's power to keep some criminal defendants behind bars while they await trial, even if a key bail law was violated. The justices, by a 6-3 vote, spared the government from having to free on bail some defendants deemed to be dangerous or a risk to flee before trial. _ Refused to revive a lawsuit in behalf of a child abused after Illinois officials placed her isn the home of her aunt and uncle. The court, without comment, turned away arguments that public officials should not be shielded from federal suits when they knowingly expose children to abuse in foster homes. A federal appeals court in New York upheld the ban on abortion counseling but other federal courts ruled it is unconstitutional. The high court's decision, expected sometime in 1991, should resolve the conflicting rulings. The family planning program, enacted by Congress as Title X of the Public Health Service Act, pays for creating and operating family planning clinics. The 1982 law forbids clinics to use the federal money to perform abortions, but initial regulations let the clinic staffs tell women about the abortion option. After those regulations drew fire from anti-abortion groups, the government barred clinics from using federal money to advise women that abortion is an option or to refer them to abortion clinics. The newer regulations say federally funded clinics may not ``encourage, promote or advocate abortion as a method of family planning'' or distribute written materials on abortion. The regulations also require a family planning clinic that receives federal money to keep physically and financially separate any abortion clinic it might operate without federal money. If a woman visiting a federally funded family planning clinic asks about abortion, doctors and counselors are barred from saying more than that the program ``does not consider abortion an appropriate method of family planning'' and to offer help in obtaining prenatal care. New York state and New York City officials, the directors of two family planning clinics, Planned Parenthood and other organizations challenged the 1988 regulations in federal court the same day they were issued. The lawsuit contended the regulations go far beyond the restrictions imposed by the 1982 law, and that they impermissibly interfere with freedom of speech and women's choice to obtain abortions. U.S. District Judge Louis L. Stanton in New York City upheld the regulations, and the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals agreed by a 2-1 vote last Nov. 1. After stating that the regulations are consistent with the 1982 law, the appeals court ruled that the regulations do not violate any constitutional right of pregnant women or family planning clinic staff members. ``The government has no constitutional obligation to subsidize an activity merely because the activity is constitutionally protected,'' the appeals court said. ``The government may validly choose to favor childbirth over abortion and to implement that choice by funding medical services relating to childbirth but not those relating to abortion.'' n the appeal acted on today, challengers said the federal regulations represent a kind of ``viewpoint discrimination.'' ``Because these regulations require the provision of misinformation they do more than encourage childbirth. Rather, they constitute a direct interference with a protected activity,'' the appeal said. ``Women who have come to rely on Title X for medically sound advice will be misled. The silence of a trusted doctor on the subject of abortion will lead many women to believe that abortion is not an appropriate or medically indicated option for them,'' the appeal added. Bush administration lawyers, although contending that the 2nd Circuit court was right, urged the justices to review the case to resolve conflicting rulings. The Boston-based 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled last March that the regulations are unconstitutional. So did a federal judge in Colorado. The cases are Rust vs. Sullivan, 89-1391, and New York vs. Sullivan, 89-1392.

DOC.HEAD: Air Accord Ready, Negotiators Still Working on Arms Cuts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with talks resuming, progress on one issue reported, subbing 3 grafs for 4th graf pvs
DOC.TEXT: An agreement to expand _ and possibly quadruple _ commercial air travel between the United States and the Soviet Union is ready for signing at the summit, while negotiators are still working on deeper cuts in nuclear weapons. The agreement, concluded on Sunday, will expand the travel route to involve more carriers and cities and inaugurate regular cargo flights between the two countries. It represents closer ties between the superpowers as Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev tries to get a grip on his troubled economy. In another sign of U.S.-Soviet cooperation, U.S. officials said Monday that the Soviets had informed the Bush administration that they would begin dismantling the long-disputed Krasnoyarsk radar facility in eastern Siberia. The arms negotiations, meanwhile, resumed today at the State Department after more than nine hours of talks over the holiday weekend. They are dealing with projected cutbacks in long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines, as well as a stalemate in negotiations to cut troops, tanks and other conventional weapons in Europe. Any announcement will be withheld until the summit, Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said. However, another U.S. official said none of the strategic arms issues had been settled but there was some progress on methods of verifying cutbacks in conventional weapons. ``That's good news,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. A brief press notice late Monday gave no indication whether any progress was made. Any announcement of a breakthrough is expected to come from President Bush or Secretary of State James A. Baker III. In any event, the two sides already have reached agreement on many of the main points of a new treaty to reduce their strategic nuclear weapons arsenals. A declaration will be issued by Bush and Gorbachev at their four-day summit meeting, which opens in Washington on Thursday. The air travel accord will add four U.S. cities and six Soviet cities to current airliner routes, under an agreement to be signed at the summit. U.S. officials said Monday the agreement could quadruple air travel between the two countries and, for the first time, would provide regular cargo service. It will allow six additional U.S. airlines to operate as well as a planned new Soviet airline to participate in service between the two nations. Only Pan Am and the Soviet airline Aeroflot now fly U.S.-Soviet routes serving New York, Washington, Moscow and Leningrad. Additional U.S. cities to be provided service are Anchorage, Alaska; Chicago, San Francisco and Miami. The new Soviet cities are Kiev, Minsk, Magadan, Khabarovsk, Tbilisi and Riga, in Latvia. In addition, the two sides agreed to allow at least 100 annual charter flights over the North Atlantic route and to consider up to 100 charters across the Pacific. U.S. officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the final details involved a compromise on the percentage of rubles paid by Soviet travelers that Moscow will guarantee to convert into U.S. dollars. The United States originally insisted on 15 percent while the Soviets only wanted to guarantee 6.5 percent. Negotiators settled on a compromise that 8.75 percent of the space on U.S. airliners flying out of the Soviet Union would be purchased with rubles convertible to dollars. A number of U.S. carriers have expressed interest in competing with Pan Am for the expanded service, including Delta, United, Alaska Air and Northwest. The Soviet decision to begin dismantling the Krasnoyarsk radar facility would overcome one obstacle in the way of the strategic arms treaty. Both the Reagan and now the Bush administrations have said they would not sign a strategic arms reduction treaty until the giant radar facility is dismantled. ``We recently saw signs that this is going on,'' said one official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Reagan administration had contended the installation violated the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty which imposes strict limits on radar. After protesting initially, the Soviets eventually relented and said they would dismantle the facility. The two countries' arms control negotiating teams met in three sessions Sunday totaling 6{ hours and then for 2} hours on Monday. The U.S. delegation was headed by Undersecretary Reginald Bartholomew and the Soviet group by Deputy Prime Minister Viktor P. Karpov, an experienced arms control negotiator. Gorbachev sent the negotiators initially to take up a half-dozen unsettled strategic weapons reduction issues. But a U.S. official, declining to be identified, said the talks also dealt with cuts in U.S. and Soviet troops, tanks, artillery and airplanes in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Slum Dwellers of Soviet Central Asia Have Little Faith in Reforms
DOC.TEXT: The people who live in the hillside slums of this Central Asia city have little faith in the latest Kremlin plan to salvage the economy. ``Honestly, I don't believe anyone anymore,'' said Valentina Bludova, 57. She said she was fired from the nearby slaughterhouse after she was struck on the head by a falling piece of machinery and knocked out. Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov last week announced a plan for a painful transition to what he called a ``regulated market,'' in which the state will surrender much of its control over the economy. When Muscovites heard they could expect food prices to double and widespread layoffs, they began buying out the stores. Halfway across the country, in Kazakhstan near the mountains separating the Soviet Union from China, shoppers have not panicked. However, residents expressed little hope in the future. They predicted the government would have a hard time winning support for a program that officials say will entail a two-year recession. ``I don't think it will be any better for me,'' said Tamara Sukhikh, 37, who earns $243 a month as a janitor in a packaging factory. ``I fear higher prices. How can I take care of my family?'' Mrs. Sukhikh lives with her husband and two children in one of many two-room shacks built from wooden scraps and tar paper. The hovels are privately owned, but the land beneath them belongs to the state. The rain pours through plywood ceilings of the home built by Mrs. Sukhikh's parents just after World War II. Half the family sleeps on the floor. A young mechanic lounging along Polezhayeza Street smoked cigarettes with friends in front of his weathered wooden shack that houses his wife, two children, his mother, and three other families. The toilet is outside. Water is hauled from a communal faucet down the steet. Residents say in the nearly 50 years since the shacks were built, the authorities have never even mentioned the possibility of plumbing. The mechanic says he gets ``promises, promises, promises'' when he asks city authorities for an apartment. ``They take our documents and later they give them back,'' he said, refusing to give his name. ``If they would let me buy land, I would build a house and a garden,'' he said. One of the government's announced reforms would allow the people of this slum _ and those in millions of shacks and slums throughout the country _ to buy a building lot. ``I don't believe it,'' the mechanic said. ``The bureaucrats will just take my documents and keep them and do nothing.'' As it is, he doesn't even dare repair the leaky roof of his shack. ``If I did, they would ask `Where did you get the material?' and give me a fine,'' he said. Mrs. Bludova, the former slaughterhouse worker, ran afoul of the bureaucrats when she took the housing situation into her own hands. A widow who says she was abandoned by her second husband when she was unable to bear children, she bought a shack just big enough for a stove and a table. She paid 10,000 rubles. That's $16,600 at the official rate, or roughly six years' salary, not including the land. Scrounging a board here and there, she gradually added 2{ rooms herself. ``I lived well,'' she said proudly. She soon discovered, however, that she needed permission for each improvement. And she found that the woman who had sold her the house, who is now dead, had not transferred the documents into her name. The bureaucrats discovered this and ``yelled and yelled at me, and I broke down in tears and ran away,'' she said. Now, she fears any attempts to better her living conditions will bring her back to the attention of the authorities. After decades of promised reform, the slum dwellers aren't the only ones in Alma Ata who have grave doubts about the government's economic plan. ``If the economists can't make up their minds what to do, how can I decide if their are right?'' asked Murlan Zhanobilov, a lawyer with the Kazakh Supreme Court. Legalization of private land would help, he said, ``but nobody believes that. Without a guarantee that if we build a three-story house, it won't be taken away, nobody will believe it,'' he said, shaking his head. Soviet citizens remember the millions who died in the collectivization drive of the 1930s for the crime of being owners of private farms. In Kazakhstan, memories are fresher. Five million of the republic's 16 million people came to its remote steppes when Stalin forcibly deported whole nationalities in the 1940s, Zhanobilov said. Alma Ata authorities confiscated homes as recently as three years ago, he said. Bureaucrats said it was part the ``campaign against unearned income'' and converted the houses to kindergartens and other institutions, he said. They told residents: ``Prove where you got each brick.'' Since many of the houses were 20 and 30 years old, Zhanobilov said, ``How could they?''

DOC.HEAD: No. 3 CBS Unveils Fall Schedule
DOC.TEXT: CBS' fall schedule features a revamped prime time lineup with seven hours of new programming and a first-run movie package, the network's top entertainment executive said today. ``This is a strong, first step in the process of rebuilding our prime time lineup,'' said Jeff Sagansky, president of CBS Entertainment, introducing his first full schedule since taking over the job last year. CBS has been in third place for three consecutive seasons, but came close to beating front-runner NBC in the just-completed May sweeps _ although it did so with a mix of specials and movies that pre-empted its regular programs. CBS offers four new half-hour situation comedies _ ``family comedies with breakout star potential,'' _ and five hourlong dramas aimed at attacting more family viewing in the 8 p.m. to 9 p.m. time period, Sagansky said. Fox Broadcasting Co. was expected to announce its fall schedule late today. Sagansky said CBS will have new shows in the 8 p.m. to 9 p.m. slots on five nights. The first-run, pre-cable movie package includes such hits as ``Born on the Fourth of July'' and ``Field of Dreams,'' he said. The new sitcoms are the movie spinoff ``Uncle Buck''; the NBC castoff ``Hogan Family''; the blue-collar ``Lenny''; Burt Reynolds in ``Evening Shade,'' as a former pro football star who coaches a high school team; and a widower firefighter raising four children in ``Four Alarm Family.'' The five hourlong series include ``The Flash,'' adventures of the high-speed superhero; ``WIOU,'' about the cutthroat world of local television; ``The Hammersmiths,'' a ``comedic and poignant'' family saga; ``Over My Dead Body,'' a murder mystery with Edward Woodward and Jessica Lundy. There also will be network television's first prime time pro-environment series, ``The Green Machine,'' about a team of experts who right ecological wrongs. Shows getting the ax included ``Tour of Duty,'' ``Falcon Crest,'' ``The Amazing Teddy Z,'' ``City,'' ``Sydney,'' and ``Sugar & Spice,'' but Sagansky said ``Paradise'' may be renewed. ``Wiseguy,'' a crime series, has been relegated to backup status, with Ken Wahl to return in the first few episodes when the show returns to the air, but with a new actor, Stephen Bauer, replacing Wahl as a new undercover agent. CBS' news shows ``60 Minutes'' and ``48 Hours'' return to the fall schedule, along with what was ``Saturday Night with Connie Chung.'' Miss Chung's show was given a new format and shifted to Monday night as ``Face to Face with Connie Chung.'' The show in that incarnation got two test-runs during the May sweeps and scored high ratings. Sagansky played down suggestions that the CBS schedule is not as unconventional as that of its two major rivals, each of which have music-drama shows and, in ABC's case, the return of the quirky cult favorite ``Twin Peaks.'' ``What makes a show unconventional is the way it's executed, not cops singing or whatever is behind `Twin Peaks,''' Sagansky told reporters at a news conference at the CBS Broadcast Center.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Industries Destroying Last European Wilderness
DOC.TEXT: Soviet pollution is choking Finnish Lapland, threatening what is considered Europe's last wilderness, scientists say. Some experts predict ecological death for the pristine pine forests and arctic tundra in a decade unless quick action is taken. ``We are used to drinking water from the lakes and streams in Lapland. But if the pollution continues at current levels, I give the region 10 years,'' said Satu Huttunen, professor of botany at the University of Oulu in north Finland. Finnish Lapland makes up about a third of the country and is largely uninhabited by humans. Home to bears, wolves, moose and other animals, it also provides a recreation area for skiers and canoeists. Finnish officials say the problem begins with large Soviet nickel and apatite plants in the Kola Peninsula that spew out 770,000 tons of sulphur dioxide into the atmosphere each year. Most of it falls into Soviet territory, but foresters in northeast Finland have reported increasing levels of pollutants. ``Some of the sulphur concentrations are three times higher than the vulnerable arctic nature can tolerate. In fact, concentrations in some Finnish cities are lower than in the isolated corner of Lapland,'' Mrs. Huttunen told The Associated Press. Last week, Prime Minister Harri Holkeri visited the Soviet industries in the region with Soviet Deputy Prime Minister Stepan Sitaryan. ``It was just plain devastation. Everywhere you looked for kilometers around, the trees and vegetation were dead. The whole place was polluted, under heavy black dust,'' said Jyrki Myllyvirta, Holkeri's special assistant. Myllyvirta said Sitaryan ``was visibly shocked'' by what he saw, but was unsure how fast the Soviets would begin to clean it up. The two countries have signed an agreement to halve trans-boundary air pollution, measured by 1980 levels, in the next five years. ``But we have experienced in the past that there are many problems in the Soviet Union when it comes to applying new technology,'' Myllyvirta said in an interview. Mrs. Huttunen and other researchers say that to save Lapland, sulphur emissions must be cut by at least 90 percent without delay. ``Otherwise, there is no hope. The pollution levels are much higher than any of us believed,'' said researcher Jaana Reinikainen, who recently returned from northeast Lapland. ``We knew of totally destroyed forest areas of some 10 hectares (25 acres), but now we found areas as big as 400 hectares (1,080 acres) which were badly damaged,'' Mrs. Reinikainen said. The Finnish Outokumpu mining company is negotiating the sale of new flash-smelting technology to the Soviets that it says would reduce sulphur emissions by more than 97 percent. An Outokumpu official said the new technology could be running at full capacity in the Kola Peninsula within three years at a cost of $375 million. Press reports said the Soviets had rejected Outokumpu's technology in favor of their own. Myllyvirta denied the reports.

Here, at a glance, are highlights of actions taken Tuesday by the Supreme Court.
ABORTION COUNSELING
The court agreed to review federal regulations that bar government-financed family planning clinics from counseling about abortion. Critics of the regulations, issued by the Reagan administration in 1988, allege they violate free-speech and abortion rights. At stake is the future scope of a federal program with a $200 million yearly budget. The program funds over 4,000 clinics serving some 5 million low-income women nationwide. The cases are Rust vs. Sullivan, 89-1391, and New York vs. Sullivan, 89-1392.
DRUG SENTENCING
The court agreed to decide whether states may impose mandatory life sentences without possibility of parole for people convicted of possessing large amounts of drugs. The justices said they will study the appeal of Ronald Harmelin, convicted in Oak Park, Mich., of possessing more than 650 grams of cocaine. The case is Harmelin vs. Michigan, 89-7272.
DRUNKEN DRIVING
The court broadened the protection against double jeopardy, saying that a motorist who pleads guilty to drunken driving in a fatal accident may not be prosecuted later for homicide. The 5-4 ruling in a case from New York extends so-called double jeopardy protection against multiple prosecutions for some criminal defendants. The court said someone convicted of a relatively minor offense generally may not be retried on more serious charges based on the same alleged conduct. The case is Grady vs. Corbin, 89-474.
KU KLUX KLAN
The court rejected an appeal by two Ku Klux Klan groups and four men ordered to pay more than $800,000 for organizing a demonstration that turned into a violent attack on civil rights marchers in Georgia. The court, without comment, let stand a ruling that the punitive-damages award did not violate the free-speech rights of the KKK and its sympathizers. The case is Stephens vs. McKinney, 89-1558.
BAIL
The court increased the federal government's power to keep some criminal defendants behind bars while they await trial, even if a key bail law was violated. The justices, by a 6-3 vote, spared the government from having to free on bail some defendants deemed to be dangerous or a risk to flee before trial. The case is U.S. vs. Montalvo-Murillo, 89-163.
CHILD ABUSE
The court refused to revive a lawsuit in behalf of a child abused after Illinois officials placed her isn the home of her aunt and uncle. The court, without comment, turned away arguments that public officials should not be shielded from federal suits when they knowingly expose children to abuse in foster homes. The case is Doe vs. Bobbitt, 89-1218.
TAX DEBTS
The court made it more difficult for the federal government to collect all taxes owed by bankrupt corporations.
