By an 8-1 vote, the court thwarted the government's attempt to hold officials of bankrupt corporations personally responsible for paying the owed taxes. The case is U.S. vs. Energy Resources Co., 89-255.
OVERSEAS BANKS
The court, in a case with potentially billions of dollars at stake, ordered further hearings to decide whether U.S. banks with branch offices overseas must pay depositors after foreign governments freeze those accounts. The court, by an 8-1 vote, set aside a ruling that required Citibank to pay a depositor whose account was frozen by the Philippine government of Ferdinand Marcos. The case is Citibank vs. Wells Fargo, 88-1260.

DOC.HEAD: Jovanovich Resigns From Publishing Company, Former Energy Sec Appointed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 3 grafs with Jovanovich son's role, background on Herrington. A longer version moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: William Jovanovich has resigned as chairman of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. and his successor at the publishing company is former U.S. Energy Secretary John S. Herrington. ``Forty-three years is enough, especially since I now can devote my time to editing books and writing them,'' Jovanovich, 70, said in a statement issued today by the Orlando, Fla.-based company. Jovanovich is the author of several novels and one is scheduled for release in the fall. He edited Mary McCarthy until her death last November and currently edits Diana Trilling. During Jovanovich's tenure, the company's revenue grew from $8 million in the 1950s to $1.3 billion. The company's authors include Alice Walker, Umberto Eco, Mark Helprin and Charles Simic, who won the 1990 Pulitzer Prize for poetry. The company also publishes scientific and medical books and journals and operates a large insurance business as well. Jovanovich arranged an infusion of capital in 1987 that enabled the company to avoid a takeover by British media baron Robert Maxwell. But the resulting heavy debt prompted the company to sell its six theme parks, including four Sea World parks. Herrington has served as a member of the Harcourt board since May 1989. He called Jovanovich ``an American publishing legend, a pioneer in educational technology and an industry giant who built the best independent publishing house in America.'' The company issued a statement that Jovanovich also had submitted his resignation as chairman of the company's executive committee. He will be replaced in that position by his son, Peter Jovanovich, 41, who was named chief executive and president of the company last December. Herrington, 51, served as energy secretary in the Reagan administration from February 1985 to January 1989. He had been assistant secretary of the Navy from 1981 to 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Legislation Would Tie More U.S. Aid to American Purchases
DOC.TEXT: Two Senate committee chairmen on Tuesday proposed revamping U.S. foreign aid to make it more supportive of American business interests overseas. Sens. David Boren, D-Okla., and Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, said a larger portion of U.S. economic aid should be tied to purchases of American goods and services. They proposed legislation to boost the figure from the current 7 percent to 40 percent by 1996. Competitors such as Japan, West Germany and France already make heavy use of such ``tied aid,'' they said. ``More and more, we have come to understand that competition in the world today is primarily economic'' rather than military, Boren said at a news conference. He said polls show Americans are increasingly disenchanted with foreign aid spending. Boren, chairman of the Intelligence Committee, said he and Finance Committee Chairman Bentsen were being joined in the effort by Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., chairman of the Appropriations Committee. Their suggestion is likely to join various ideas for revamping foreign aid as Congress seeks to adapt a decades-old aid system to the new realities of Eastern European democracies and collapsing centrally planned economies. Many of the ideas reflect a need for aid to be aimed less at military security for friendly nations, as it has been through the Cold War era, and more at economic warfare. Boren called it a ``tragic waste'' that the United States gave most of its recent $800 million in aid to Poland in cash, with no strings attached, while West Germany and Japan gave nearly $3 billion that could be spent only to buy goods from those countries. ``I think it is time we adjust to what our economic competitors are doing,'' Boren said. ``We should offer American goods when developing nations are cleaning up their environment and building their infrastructure, transportation systems, communications networks and new plants with new technologies.'' Boren proposed as a safeguard that the shift of aid money not penalize the poorest countries, particularly those in Africa, which now receive direct grants for programs like public health, population control and agricultural development. The proposal also included a 15 percent increase in the ceiling for direct loans by the Export-Import Bank to finance purchases of U.S. goods by overseas buyers, increases in other credit programs tied to purchase of American products, and a new $1 billion loan guarantee program for Eastern Europe to encourage ``an aggressive U.S. presence'' in that new market.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Business Weekly Begin U.S. Publication
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. edition of a private Soviet business weekly is making its debut this week to coincide with the Bush-Gorbachev summit. ``The idea is to give practical information and objective information, which is more or less unusual for the Soviet press,'' said Vladimir Yakovlev, creator and editor-in-chief of Commersant. The paper, aimed at the Soviet and foreign businesses in the Soviet Union, started publishing in Russian and English in January. It has a domestic circulation of 350,000 and the new Soviet-American edition is expected to attract up to 60,000 subscribers at an introductory rate of $165 a year. Commersant covers topics such as the launch and failure of joint ventures, the accurate but unofficial dollar exchange rate and Soviet government decisions affecting business. It was the first to report on the government's planned economic reforms. The paper advises readers about how to start a business, where in the country it is risky to invest, how to attract foreign capital and how to invest rubles. It will also list stock prices when the Soviet Stock Market opens in September. The front page of a special summit issue says Commersant has been ``published since 1908,'' but was ``suspended from 1917 to 1990 for reasons beyond its control.'' One piece in the summit issue of Commersant compares the Soviet economy to a cramped leg _ ``you can move it neither forward nor backward nor can you remain still because of the pain.'' Asked if he had any competitors, Yakovlev laughed and said, ``Not yet.'' But he said he hoped someone would start a daily Soviet business newspaper, allowing him to publish less news and more analysis. Yakovlev, 31, is founder and chairman of FACT, his country's largest business databank. It employs more than 400 people.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules in Cross-Country Divorce Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today effectively extended the long arm of the law in the case of a couple who split up and now live on opposite coasts. The justices, voting 9-0, said New Jersey resident Dennis Burnham must answer to courts in California in a divorce suit by his wife, Francie Burnham. The court ruled that someone who visits a state may be sued there by a state resident even if the visitor has only minimal contacts with that state. The ruling is likely to have significant impact in other divorce and custody cases. Burnham was greeted by a process server in January 1988 when he went to California to spend some time with the couple's children who live with their mother in the San Francisco area. The Supreme Court said today that Burnham's presence in California, although brief, was enough for the California courts to have authority over him in the divorce proceeding. Justice Antonin Scalia, in the court's main opinion, said Burnham's due process rights are not violated by forcing him to contest his wife's divorce claim in California. ``Jurisdiction based on physical presence alone constitutes due process because it is one of the continuing traditions of our legal system that define ... notions of fair play and substantial justice,'' he said. Joining his opinion were Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White and Anthony M. Kennedy. The other five justices agreed that Burnham's rights were not violated but in separate concurring opinions declined to go along with Scalia's reasoning. They supported a case-by-case approach precluded by Scalia's broader pronouncement. The Burnhams were married in 1976 and lived in New Jersey until they separated in July 1987 when Mrs. Burnham took their two children to California. Burnham sued for divorce in 1987 in New Jersey, accusing his wife of desertion. She said the suit violated their agreement that they were splitting up over ``irreconciliable differences.'' When Burnham visited his family in January 1988, he took one of the children on an outing to San Francisco. When he returned to his wife's home in nearby Mill Valley, he was served with a summons and a copy of her divorce petition. The California courts denied his motion to quash the service of process, rejecting arguments that he only had minimum contacts with the state. Court papers did not specify where Burnham lives in New Jersey. The case is Burnham vs. Superior Court of California, 89-44.

DOC.HEAD: Election a Chance for Burma to Heal Old Wounds, Begin Anew
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Nu and Zagana Use Only One Name
DOC.TEXT: Burma's first competitive election in 30 years may have given this impoverished nation a chance to start anew in building a democratic government. But skepticism and anxieties persist about how the powerful military, which has held authoritarian power since 1962, will react to the turn of events. To the surprise of many analysts, the country's leading opposition party, the National League for Democracy, appears to have scored a huge victory over conservative, pro-military forces. Final results from Sunday's general election may not be in for weeks, but in vote-counting through Tuesday, the party backed by the military had yet to win a single seat in the 492-seat parliament. The National League for Democracy had won 41 of the 43 parliamentary seats decided and said it was certain it would hold at least 322 seats when counting was finished. The mood in this city of crumbling, British colonial-era buildings has changed dramatically since the vote. Saturday, people dared not take the leaflets I was handing out. Now they talk freely,'' said a party organizer Tuesday. But the future appears unclear. The military has promised to turn over power after the new parliament writes a constitution and a strong civilian government is in place. There is no indication when this will be achieved. ``It's still a very murky situation. It has never happened before, and I think the army is still scratching it's head and wondering how to handle it,'' said one senior Western diplomat. ``If you look back in history, the army's attitude is not firm. They often change their color _ do you see the point?'' said an official of the National League for Democracy, who requested anonymity. It was the army that killed several thousand, mostly unarmed civilians, when the country rose up against authoritarian rule in 1988. A group of military leaders, led by Gen. Saw Maung, crushed the uprising in September 1988, imposed martial law and carried out widespread arrests. It did call for general elections and for a time allowed relatively free political activity. But when opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi, the charismatic daughter of independence hero Aung San, criticized the military and gathered mass support last summer, she was put under house arrest. The co-leader of the National League for Democracy, Tin Oo, was also jailed. Former Prime Minster Nu also remains under house arrest. Other political prisoners remain in detention, and arrests continued until just before the election. Five days before balloting, Zagana, a popular comedian who took part in the 1988 uprising, was sentenced to five years in prison by a military tribunal. Given this prelude, diplomats, human rights organizations and others branded the elections fraudulent. Yet from all available accounts, including observation by foreign correspondents, the balloting was free and fair. The United States praised the Burmese for the election and said Tuesday that from the early results, ``it is apparent the Burmese people want to return to a multiparty political system.'' Some analysts speculate that the military miscalculated the Burmese people's dissatisfaction with their situation. ``They simply did not realize how deeply unpopular the (pro-military) National Unity Party, and by extension they themselves were,'' said a Rangoon-based Western diplomat. The opposition is taking the election at face value: the military called an election, pro-democracy forces won and now have a mandate from the people. People who until recently did not dare approach foreigners in public are speaking freely, although they do not always want their names printed. ``I'm very happy to see fresh new faces in parliament, and I'm glad to see those old cronies who had devastated the economy leave the scene,'' said one retired civil servant. ``This election has turned a page in Burmese history.'' This is not the first effort at democracy in modern Burmese history. After independence from Great Britain in 1962, a parliamentary democracy was established. It scored some successes. But factionalism, rebellions by ethnic groups, and other problems plagued the fledgling experiment. The army stepped in on several occasions and finally seized power in a 1962 coup led by Gen. Ne Win. Ne Win and his one-party state led the country to economic ruin, isolationism and political stagnation. Ne Win retired in 1988, and some say his withdrawal from the political arena contributed to the election triumph of the League for Democracy. Others believe he is still pulling strings behind the scene.

DOC.HEAD: Precede BOSTON
Thousands Give Former Hostage Hometown Welcome
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with procession held; picks up 8th graf pvs: `Those comments ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX2
DOC.TEXT: A marching band and the cheers of thousands of residents created a rousing homecoming today for Frank Reed, who spent 3{ years as a hostage in Lebanon. The noontime procession officially welcomed Reed back to this suburb just north of Boston, where residents never lost hope during his 44 months of captivity. Reed and his family led the city's high school band through downtown to City Hall to the tune of ``Tie A Yellow Ribbon,'' the song that inspired the idea of festooning trees with yellow ribbons as reminders of U.S. hostages. Reed, 57, was freed by his Shiite Moslem kidnappers April 30. He underwent medical treatment at Andrews Air Force Base, Md., until the holiday weekend, which he spent relaxing with family members in Malden. Later he was to return to Maryland for continued treatment. On Monday, Reed recalled in an interview that fellow hostage Terry Anderson once suggested Reed would get through the experience because he was ``a realistic optimist.'' Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, has been held captive since March 1985. ``I've never been a person to go through super highs or super lows,'' Reed said in an interview. ``I've never been a person to get depressed. That may have sustained me during the whole ordeal.'' Bob Woolf, Reed's spokesman, repeatedly stopped him from answering questions about the six Americans and 10 other Westerners held in Lebanon. On Sunday, Reed said some of the hostages were in ill health, mentioning Anderson, 42, and Thomas Sutherland, 59, but giving no details. Those comments contradicted statements he made at a news conference May 6, when he said Anderson and Sutherland ``look physically wonderful.'' He said he last saw Anderson between a year and 18 months ago and Sutherland 14 months ago. Asked about the contradiction, Reed said, ``There is something to say, and there may be some clarifications to be made,'' before he was stopped by Woolf. Appearing fit and heavier than when he was released, Reed said his anemia is ``moving in the right direction.'' He was prevented from answering detailed questions about his condition, but did say doctors had been surprised by how quickly he had regained his health. He said he had regained almost 20 pounds. ``Everything's supposed to be wrong with me, but the doctors keep saying, `Gee, it ain't there,''' Reed said. ``They keep making up these superlatives to describe my health.'' He attributed his seeming good health to a strong constitution inherited from his 91-year-old mother, Leota Sprague. He saw her for the first time in eight years when he arrived at Boston's Logan International Airport on Sunday. He said he hopes to complete his doctorate, continue his career as an educator and perhaps write a book about his experiences. ``The thing about suddenly being released is, thank God I'm free,'' Reed said. ``Put me anywhere where I can get my life started.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush: `We Have a Better Chance Now for a Lasting World Peace'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates in top 10 grafs with White House briefing, picking up in 6th graf pvs, Most of
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and his advisers went over final preparations today for a U.S.-Soviet summit that a top aide said will tackle ``bare bone essentials'' rather than tallying up agreements to sign. Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will likely issue a statement of progress on nuclear arms reductio as sign various cultural and economic agreements when they meet this week, said a senior admin talks, as wellnistration official who briefed White House reporters. But the official, speaking on condition of anonymity, cast doubt on prospects for a U.S.-Soviet trade agreement before Gorbachev leaves. ``We're in a rather uncertain state about what exactly will happen on the trade agreement,'' the official said, citing U.S. unhappiness over Soviet actions in Lithuania and the Soviets' failure to enact legislation allowing free emigration. Still, the official said, ``This is not a summit devoted to the celebration of agreements that we can sign. It is a summit designed to do the hard work of trying to overcome the remaining obstacles that stand in the way of transforming East-West relations.'' ``We are now dow: Education Program.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Traffic Fatalities Exceed 450 During Holiday Weekend
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE figures, CORRECT to Missouri sted Florida. Picks up 4th graf, `In Illinois...'
DOC.TEXT: California recorded the most traffic deaths during the holiday weekend with 62 of the nation's 451 fatalities. The National Safety Council had estimated 380 to 480 people would die during the counting period, which began at 6 p.m. local time Friday and ended at midnight Monday. Texas recorded 29 deaths, Georgia and Missouri had 24 each, and New York recorded 20 fatalities. In Illinois, 18 people died in traffic accidents. Only Delaware, New Hampshire, Rhode Island and the District of Columbia reported no fatalites over the Memorial Day weekend. Last year, 441 people died and 20,000 were injured over the holiday.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Summit Won't Send Memorandum to Superpower Summit
DOC.TEXT: Arab Leaders Tuesday decided against sending a memorandum on the Middle East conflict to the superpower summit after moderates failed to temper criticism of Washington in the draft. The memorandum, mostly on the influx of Soviet Jews to israel, had become a focus of discord on how hard a line the Arab League summit should take against the United States. ``There will be no letter,'' Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz said as he emerged from a closed-door meeting. He refused to elaborate. The conference was called as a show of Arab unity against what President Saddam Hussein has said is a Western and Israeli campaign against Iraq. It also sought ways to stem the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel. Little unity, however, has been apparent so far in the summit. Syria and Lebanon boycotted the meeting, and Morocco, Algeria and Oman sent senior government officials. In bellicose speeches Monday, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and Palestine Liberation Organization chairman Yasser Arafat blasted the United States and Israel. But moderates, led by Egypt and Saudi Arabia, appeared to have persuaded hard-liners to take a ``more balanced and prudent'' approach on the summit's second day, sources said. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Arab nations were unable to agree on the wording of a memorandum to be sent to the superpower summit, which begins Thursday in Washington. Iraq and the PLO drafted an 18-page document, which focused mainly on the emigration issue and called for economic sanctions against countries that facilitate the influx. It urged Western nations, especially the United States, to absorb Soviet emigrants. But Egypt and Saudi Arabia rejected references to sanctions and the criticism of U.S. policy. ``With the moderate and hard-line blocs arguing over every word in the 18-page draft memorandum, they decided to scratch it altogether,'' a conference source said. About 750,000 Soviet Jews are expected to emigrate to Israel in the next few years, and Arab states contend many will settle in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, land the Palestinians consider their own. Many Arabs are angry at the United States, saying it has added to the influx by tightening immigration restrictions and driving Soviet Jews to Israel. The Arabs also believe Washington has not done enough to pressure Israel into agreeing to direct peace talks with the PLO. At a closed-door session Tuesday, Arafat alleged that Israel was conducting military exercises in the Negev Desert in preparation for an attack against Iraq's military installations. Iraq has often said accusations it was producing chemical weapons and building a so-called super gun were a prelude to a strike similar to the 1981 Israeli air raid on a nuclear reactor near Baghdad. On Monday, Saddam told the conference he would use ``weapons of mass destruction'' against Israel if the Jewish state deployed its nuclear arsenal against any Arab nation. He accused the United States of fostering ``the policy of aggression and expansion practiced by the Zionist entity against the Arabs.'' Iraq is said to have binary chemical weapons. Britain, Italy, Greece and Turkey recently have confiscated Iraq-bound shipments allegedly containing components of a ``super gun.''Arab states claim Israel has 200 nuclear bombs. The Arab summit was originally scheduled to end late Tuesday, but conference sources said the closing session would not be held until Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Abello Sentenced to 30 Years in Prison
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge sentenced a reputed high-ranking member of the Medellin drug cartel to 30 years in prison and fined him $5 million today. Jose Abello Silva was convicted May 19 on one count of conspiracy to import cocaine and marijuana into the United States and one count of conspiracy to possess drugs with the intent to distribute. Abello was extradited to the United States from Colombia last fall. U.S. District Judge Thomas Brett said the extradition treaty provided a maximum sentence of 30 years. Brett sentenced Abello to 30 years on each count but ordered the terms to run concurrently. Abello, who stood with his arms crossed during the hourlong sentencing, maintained his innocence. Abello was indicted and tried in Tulsa because of telephone calls and money exchanges between groups in Oklahoma and Florida that allegedly helped raise money for a man jailed in Tulsa.

DOC.HEAD: Congress: Quirks and Oddities
DOC.TEXT: One congressman's life was saved by a newspaper. A senator's marriage gave some Midwesterners their first look at a Democrat. And a new president rated a unique greeting at the Capitol. While reports of Washington street violence seem to abound lately, it's apparently not a new phenomenon. In 1861, muggers attacked Rep. Charles Van Wyck, R-N.Y., on a street near the Capitol. One assailant tried to stab the congressman but the knife was deflected by the folded pages of a newspaper in Van Wyck's pocket. Van Wyck decked one mugger, then pulled out a pistol to ward off others. Most members of Congress aren't armed these days, and few would expect their lives to be saved by newspapers. But many may find similar experiences in a new book, ``Congressional Chronicles.'' The collection of anecdotes compiled by Anthony S. Pitch was published by Mino Publications of Potomac, Md. In it, Pitch recalls Sen. J. Allen Frear, D-Del., who had what may have been a tense experience. Shortly after his marriage, Frear went to Wisconsin to visit friends and relatives of his wife, Esther, who was from a town where nearly everyone was a Republican. In the middle of the party, Frear was asked to stand in the middle of the room and his father-in-law told those present: ``I want you to see and know what a Democrat is. You probably have never seen one before, but here is one.'' When Ronald Reagan headed for the Capitol after his first inauguration, the new sergeant-at-arms Howard Liebengood asked Majority Leader Howard Baker, R-Tenn., ``How do you greet these people.'' ``Watch Nordy, he knows,'' said Baker, referring to Nordy Hoffman, the retiring sergeant-at-arms. But Hoffman, a 300-pound former tackle on Knut Rockne's 1929 and 1930 Notre Dame football teams, recalled that actor Reagan once portrayed George Gipp, another member of that team. When Reagan's limousine pulled up and the door opened, Hoffman extended a hand and said: ``Hiya, Gipper.'' Many members of Congress admit that their staff wields plenty of influence, getting things done that the members don't have time to supervise. Rep. Norman Dicks, D-Wash., saw the difference when he was elected to the House in 1977 after eight years as an aide to Sen. Warren Magnuson. ``I never thought I'd give up that much power voluntarily,'' Dicks said when asked about his new job. Rebecca Latimer Felton, D-Ga., holds three Senate records set in a very brief 1922 career. Appointed before the winner of a special election was seated, she served the shortest Senate term _ one day. The 87-year-old also was the first woman senator and the oldest person to become a member of that body. Rep. John Taber, R-N.Y., was famous for his impassioned oratory, particularly when it was about saving money, but his voice may also have had some medical applications. Taber reportedly bellowed so loudly one day in the spring of 1940 that Rep. Leonard Schuetz, D-Ill., tottered dazed into the cloakroom. A few minutes later Schuetz recovered his equilibrium and realized that he could hear perfectly, having suddenly recovered from lifelong deafness in his left ear. George Washington Bridges was elected to Congress as a unionist from Tennessee in 1860, but was captured by Confederate troops before he could get to Washington. Bridges eventually escaped and was sworn in just a week before his term expired. A visit to a naval vessel by women is nothing special these days, but it wasn't the case at the close of World War II. Reps. Chase Woodhouse, D-Conn., Reva Bosone, D-Utah, and a female aide, surprised the Pentagon by accepting an invitation for an overnight stay aboard the Aircraft Carrier Midway. Woodhouse asked Adm. William Halsey if the guard posted outside their quarters had been there to protect the women or the crew. ``You've got to know,'' said Halsey, ``that you three are the first ladies who ever spent a night on the ship _ legally.'' Rep. John Allen, D-Miss., joined the House in 1895 and said he was mighty impressed with the other members. ``In a House in which everybody is either a judge or a general or a colonel it is quite a distinction to be a private,'' remarked Allen. From then on he was known as Private John.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Sends Iran Report on Iranians Missing in Beirut
With AM-Hostage Return
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has given Iran information supporting his earlier assertion that four Iranians missing in Lebanon since 1982 are dead, the White House said on Tuesday. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the Swiss government had passed the report on to Tehran. Bush, at a news conference on May 3, promised to provide the information as a ``gesture of goodwill.'' ``We have made a major effort of collecting information,'' Fitzwater said. ``Essentially, the conclusions are the same: the four individuals they are concerned with are dead.'' The four Iranians _ two diplomats, a journalist and a driver _ disappeared from Beirut during the 1982 Israeli invasion of Lebanon. Iran in the past has suggested Lebanese Christian militiamen had a role in the abductions. Fitzwater told reporters he had no new information on the circumstances of the killings or on the identity of the perpetrators. The contents of the report were not disclosed. He said that the United States conferred with the International Red Cross, other countries and ``a lot of private sources that we developed'' in compiling its report to Iran. At his May 3 news conference, Bush said he hoped providing Iran with information on the fate of the four missing Iranians would satisfy Tehran's request for a gesture of thanks for its role in the freeing of two U.S. hostages. At the same time, Bush said he remained firmly against negotiating for the release of the six American hostages still being held in Lebanon. ``We don't put any conditions'' on giving Iran the ``new evidence'' on the fate of the four missing Iranians, Fitzwater said. He said the material was turned over to Iran ``within the last several days.''

DOC.HEAD: Opponents of New Premier Riot, Fight With Police
DOC.TEXT: The legislature confirmed a top general as premier during a raucous session Tuesday, and hundreds of opponents fought in the streets with police, burned buses and tossed firebombs at government buildings. At least 40 people, including 10 officers, were reported injured. Police detained 10 people in the rioting, which paralyzed downtown traffic for more than 12 hours. Two policemen were hospitalized with serious burns from firebombs, police said. At the height of the clashes, about 600 demonstrators, many wearing headbands with the slogan ``oppose military intervention in politics,'' fought roving battles with about 5,000 riot police near the legislative Yuan building. Police used water cannons to try to subdue the protesters, witnesses said. What touched off the unrest was the approval of Defense Minister Hau Pei-tsun as the next premier. Legislators approved him by a vote of 186 to 27. The vote was delayed seven hours as 21 members of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party stormed the podium, kicked their seats in disgust and grabbed microphones from lawmakers of the ruling Nationalist Party. The opposition lawmakers, all wearing vests with Chinese characters reading ``Oppose a soldier leading the Cabinet,'' occupied voting booths for an hour to prevent Nationalist lawmakers from casting ballots. Several voting booths set up as replacements were torn down. At one point, legislature Speaker Liang Su-jung called in 100 police officers to restore order. Hau, 70, the nation's only four-star general, was selected by President Lee Teng-hui earlier this month to head the Cabinet. Opposition politicians and intellectuals called the decision a step backward for democracy on this island. The Nationalists have dominated politics since they fled the Chinese mainland in 1949 after losing a civil war to Communist forces. In recent years, however, the Nationalists have eased their authoritarian grip, lifting martial law and allowing the formation of opposition political parties. Hau has promised to distance himself from the military once he becomes premier, but his critics dismiss the claim. Hau gave up his four-star ranking Saturday. Opposition lawmaker Chen Shui-pien called Tuesday's vote ridiculous and said it ``ran counter to public opinion.'' After the vote, about 200 students staged a sit-in outside the legislative building, witnesses said. The clashes began when about 600 demonstrators tried to break through barricades and a wall of police guarding the building. Police with shields surged into the crowd and beat several demonstrators with clubs before opening up with water cannons, witnesses reported. The crowd dispersed but quickly regrouped and attacked the officers with rocks, they said. Dozens of protesters then attacked the nearby Cabinet building, where a room was destroyed by firebombs, they said. Some protesters ransacked the lobby of the nearby Lai Lai Sheraton Hotel, smashing chandeliers, windows and security monitors and overturning furniture. The hotel closed briefly because of the violence. About 500 protesters later surrounded a police station and demanded the release of the detainees. Witnesses said the protesters smashed windows and that the demonstrators and police threw rocks at each other. About 1,000 riot police marched in to disperse those protesters, but many returned later and burned a bus, the witnesses said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Strafes Bar With AK-47, Killing One And Wounding Five
DOC.TEXT: A man angered because he couldn't take his drink out of a bar drove by the lounge and opened fire with an automatic rifle early Tuesday, killing a woman and wounding five people, police said. The wounded were taken to Jackson Memorial Hospital where they were listed as stable, said police. The trouble started when two men trying to leave the Magic City Lounge three blocks west of the Overtown section were told it was against the law to carry their drinks outside, police said. An argument ensued and the men left. The two drove by in a car and one opened fire with a fully automatic AK-47 assault rifle, police said. One of the bullets went through a 3-inch-thick metal door and fatally wounded Tracy L. Black, a 25-year-old customer inside the bar, police said. ``We're trying to interview some of the victims at the hospital to see if they know anything about these guys,'' police spokesman David Rivero said. ``We lifted fingerprints from some of the glasses. We have very little information. We're going to check all the AK-47s purchased recently.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Hails Colombian Election
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration Tuesday hailed the election of Cesar Gaviria as president of Colombia. Sunday's vote showed ``the people of Colombia were not intimidated'' by drug interests, said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. ``The United States looks forward to working closely with the next president when he takes office,'' Fitzwater said.

DOC.HEAD: Reformer and Gorbachev Rival Wins Presidency of Russian Republic
LaserPhotos MOSB1,3,5
DOC.TEXT: Populist reformer Boris N. Yeltsin won the presidency of the largest Soviet republic Tuesday, overcoming opposition by Mikhail S. Gorbachev and declaring the start of ``Russia's social, economic and spiritual rebirth.'' Yeltsin's election, after three hard-fought ballots in the Congress of People's Deputies of the Russian Federation, poses a substantial challenge to Gorbachev and may spur more radical reforms across the country. Gorbachev, who arrives Wednesday in Washington for a summit, retains the two most powerful jobs in the country: president of the Soviet Union and General Secretary of the Soviet Communist Party. But as president of the largest of 15 Soviet republics, Yeltsin will have a highly visible platform from which to wage his campaign for more radical reforms. Yeltsin and other Soviet officials said they believe his election will help Gorbachev push more radical reforms. ``It may be a blessing in disguise,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov told reporters at the United Nations in New York. ``Gorbachev has his critics from both the left and the right, and possibly it is better to have the election of a critic from the left.'' Yeltsin said: ``At first, President Gorbachev will react very unhappily, but then he'll gradually get used to this inevitability.'' The strapping, white-haired Yeltsin told reporters that he would seek reconciliation with Gorbachev and avoid confrontation with him, so long as it did not hurt Russia's interests. Gorbachev had brought Yeltsin to Moscow to head the city's Communist Party, but the two men had a falling out in 1987 after Yeltsin publicly criticized the pace of Kremlin reforms. They have been at odds since then. After the vote result was announced in the Grand Kremlin Palace, Yeltsin strode to the podium to warm applause and pledged to ``spare nothing _ health or time _ to get out of this crisis and lead Russia to better times.'' His bass voice echoing through the hall, he called the day ``the beginning of the road to Russia's social, economic and spiritual rebirth, the way out of the crisis and toward the blossoming of Russia as a sovereign, independent government in the framework of our union.'' He left through the Kremlin gates later to the tumultuous cheers of a small crowd of well-wishers chanting ``Victory! Victory!'' One man yelled, ``Thank you, thank you for the future!'' Gorbachev strongly opposed Yeltsin's election. He told the Russian Congress last week that Yeltsin's platform of moving political and economic power from central to local authorities would lead to a ``breakup of the union.'' The Russian Federation stretches from the Baltic Sea in the west to the Pacific Ocean in the East. It is home to half the country's 285 million people and includes Moscow, the Soviet capital. As president of the Russian Congress, a newly created body that holds the Russian Federation's highest government authority, Yeltsin acts as chief executive of the republic and took office immediately. As the first president of a newly reorganized legislature, he will play a major role in shaping his powers and duties, which as yet are unclear. After three votes in the 1,060-member Russian Congress, Yeltsin won 535 votes, four more than the majority needed. Russian Premier Alexander Vlasov received 467 votes. Valentin Tsoy, a little-known businessman from the Soviet Far East, received 11 votes. Lawmakers said Tuesday they believed Yeltsin gained the last few votes he needed by offering to form a coalition government with members of the conservative Communist Party bloc and other groups. Yeltsin said he believed he gained several votes because of a last-minute push by Gorbachev to block his election. Gorbachev reportedly urged delegates at a meeting Monday night not to vote for Yeltsin. Russian Deputy Alexander Liubimov, a well-known TV commentator, said Yeltsin's election would force Gorbachev to start dealing with another strong leader instead of ``shadows'' willing to defer to him. ``It will be a lesson for him. Maybe a hard one,'' Liubimov said. Vitaly Churkin, a spokesman for Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, said on NBC that Yeltsin's election ``might actually help Gorbachev because Gorbachev is for radical reform, and he needs more popular support for that.'' Some also said Yeltsin may have benefited from the adverse reaction to the Kremlin's proposed program for making the crippled Soviet economy a partial market economy. The reform program, which would triple the price of bread on July 1 and double the cost of other foodstuffs starting Jan. 1, caused panic buying that prompted Moscow city authorities to bar sales to non-residents of the capital Monday. The national legislature postponed a decision on the reform plan Tuesday, raising the possibility of compromise with Yeltsin and others demanding more radical measures. It also rejected a motion for a no-confidence vote in Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, who presented the reforms last week. Yeltsin has proposed a more rapid transition to a market-based economy that would grant more freedom to enterprises and entrepreneurs.

DOC.HEAD: Broken Silence: Hard Times Bring Out Truth About Suburban Poverty
LaserPhoto BX3
DOC.TEXT: Summertime is tough for Jean Brissette, who longs to give her kids the backyard barbecues and baseball outings she knew while growing up in an affluent suburb. Today, the divorced mother of four is scraping by on $100 a week. Making sure her children have new sneakers means months of scrimping. ``I figured I'd have everything my mother had, the nice home and all that,'' Brissette, 42, said recently. ``But I'm robbing Peter to pay Paul and still barely getting by. How can I hope to get ahead?'' She is part of a suburban secret, 9.5 million poor people scattered among the nation's manicured lawns and backyard basketball hoops. They won't be evident to first ladies Barbara Bush and Raisa Gorbachev, who are coming to this town about 10 miles outside Boston to deliver a commencement address this week at Wellesley College. ``They are the invisible poor,'' said Sheldon Danziger, a University of Michigan poverty researcher. ``They are seldom discussed.'' These people live on the edge of bankruptcy, foreclosure and life on the streets. Many have already been pushed off the precipice by New England's broken-down economy and inflationary cost of living. Like Brissette, fellow Wellesley resident Frank G., who spoke on condition that his family's name not be used, measures his life in checks: paychecks, unemployment checks, checks from relatives lending a hand. Jobs are scarce, so the 31-year-old construction worker and his wife are raising three children on about $600 a month in a town where the median home price is about $340,000. ``I'm two paychecks away from getting thrown out on the streets,'' he said. ``I was treated better in the inner city. At least there you were on the same wavelength.'' His family and Brissette and her children live in Barton Road, a faded housing project for financially strapped families. Frank's wife has to walk two hours round trip, with children in tow, to a supermarket because they have no car and there is no public transportation. Residents of wealthy communities are beginning to face pockets of despair camouflaged by country clubs and in Wellesley's case, a prestigious women's college. Since 1986, suburban welfare cases have jumped 12 percent compared with a 5 percent increase in the number of urban poor. Officials estimate the state has 44,000 suburban welfare cases, just 4,000 fewer than in the cities. More than 28 percent of the 520,000 people living below the poverty line in Massachusetts now reside in suburbia, where about 80 food pantries have sprung up to feed them. ``The poverty has been masked for a long time,'' said Westy Egmont, executive director of the Boston Food Bank. ``But social service providers are documenting the reality.'' Frank found himself homeless after leaving the Navy in 1980. ``We've been dirt poor but we're a family ... and that's what it's all about,'' he said. Frank's family moved to Wellesley from Boston five years ago when their number was called for the low-cost housing project. But the cost hasn't turned out to be that low. Each time Frank gets a decent job, the rent is adjusted upward. It has climbed as high as $700. Jobs have been hard to come by and welfare is not for Frank, who is built like a football player and more than ready to work. He never gives up, but being broke gets him down. ``It's tough when friends say `Let's go to see the Bruins play' and your priority is in diapers,'' said Frank. Living on the edge takes its toll on everyone. But it's perhaps hardest for the children, whose schoolmates are dressed in the best and riding brand new 10-speed bikes. ``Sometimes they say mean things like `Your mother's on welfare,''' said Frank's 10-year-old daughter, Janelle. Brissette, with two young sons still at home, had a stormy marriage that ended in a divorce seven years ago. When the money runs out, she joins the line of people seeking help from the local food bank. Things aren't at all the way she planned. ``It's a story of incredible pain because of the contrast between being poor and living in Wellesley,' said Egmont. ``We can't escape the fact that we are all marginal.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Leader Will Be Closely Guarded on U.S. Visit
DOC.TEXT: A ``big bunch of people with big guns'' will protect Mikhail S. Gorbachev during his summit visit, a Soviet spokesman said Tuesday, saying ethnic protesters could keep the Kremlin leader's guards busy. Dozens of protests, by groups ranging from Lithuanian-American war veterans to Afghans and Turkestanian-Americans, might become ``a headache for Gorbachev's security,'' Soviet press spokesman Vladimir Ustimenko said. Neither the U.S. Secret Service nor the KGB, which will work together on summit security, furnished details of protection arrangements on the eve of Gorbachev's arrival for his second Washington summit. But the Soviet leader's free-wheeling style in public already has been in evidence here, and his security detail wants to be ready. If officials knew of any Gorbachev surprises a day before his arrival, however, they weren't saying so. The last time he was here _ to hold a summit with then-President Ronald Reagan in December 1987 _ Gorbachev halted his motorcade to take an impromptu walk to meet the local citizenry. Then-Vice President George Bush, riding in the same motorcade, jumped from his limousine to join Gorbachev on the busy Washington street corner. The Soviet leader also has been known to wade into crowds of protesters to carry on political discourse _ and there will be plenty of opportunities for that if he chooses to do so. They include protests by those representing people in various Soviet states, as well as people favoring a unified Korea with a South Korean leadership. There also will be Palestinians seeking a homeland, Vietnamese seeking democracy in Vietnam, and those pushing for a cure for AIDS, said Maj. Carl Holmberg of the U.S. Park Police. Other demonstrations are scheduled to follow Gorbachev as he travels to Minneapolis and Northern California on Sunday and Monday. Estonians, Latvians and Lithuanians plan a peaceful show of their flags in Minneapolis. And in Northern California, Armenians and Eritreans plan protests. The latter are fighting for independence from Soviet-backed Ethiopia. The demonstrations have been announced, but details of Gorbachev's stay in Washington still were not in the hands of the Soviet press center or the Secret Service on Tuesday. All of the roughly 500 U.S. Park Police officers in the Washington area were to work through the summit Sunday to ensure control over the myriad protests planned for Lafayette Park and the Ellipse by the White House as well as at the Capitol reflecting pool, Holmberg said. ``No days off _ and extended shifts,'' he added. Holmberg expressed confidence that while Gorbachev might see some protesters, they won't get out of control. ``We've got some groups to keep an eye on, but I don't think they're a grave concern,'' he said. The number of agents was a state secret on both sides. ``It will be a big bunch of people with big guns,'' Ustimenko declared. Richard Adams of the Secret Service, like Ustimenko, had no specifics to give out. ``We have a good idea of what he's going to do,'' but not all of the details, Adams said. ``As far as an impromptu stop, that's not out of the question.'' Any sudden decision by Gorbachev to get out of his limosine to shake hands with the public ``probably works to our advantage,'' Adams said. ``If we don't know and his staff doesn't know where he's going to stop, that means someone meaning him harm won't know either,'' Adams said. ``Impromptu stops are not necessarily a negative thing to us.'' Washington, D.C. has been the nation's murder capital for the past two years, but the Soviet Embassy where Gorbachev will stay is in a relatively safe part of town near the White House. There have been no slayings in recent memory in that area, said Metropolitan Police Department spokeswoman Shannon Cockett. To ensure that no untoward events occur there this week, the entire block will be closed to all traffic through Sunday, she said. U.S. security agents and the KGB apparently are working well together. ``Soviet-American friendship starts with the friendship between the Soviet KGB and the American Secret Service,'' Ustimenko said. ``It's hard sometimes for the folks on the outside to understand this,'' said Adams, ``but from a security point of view, we have the same goal here: the protection of Gorbachev.'' ``We have to work closely with them, so they understand what we're doing and we understand what they're doing,'' Adams said. ``If our president decides to travel to Moscow, we would be asking for the same cooperation from them, and they would provide it.''

DOC.HEAD: Agency Budget Cuts Expected to Restrict Help to Refugees
DOC.TEXT: In a decision that will severely restrict assistance to 15 million refugees worldwide, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees agreed Tuesday to a sharp cut in its 1990 budget. The agency's executive committee agreed that expenditure on general programs should be limited to $341 million in 1990 in order to tackle a financial crisis overwhelming the organization. In a speech on the opening day of the emergency meeting Monday, Deputy High Commissioner Douglas Stafford said a deficit of $82 million was forecast for 1990. He said overall spending needs were estimated at $672 million. Last year's general budget was $389 million, and in October, the executive committee proposed a $414 million budget for 1990. High Commissioner Thorvald Stoltenberg said in an 11-page report to the meeting that the revised budget was a ``reasonable balance'' between the needs of refugees and income expected from donor governments. He said said education and support programs were being slashed as a result of the financial crisis and that 10 percent to 15 percent of the 2,400 agency employees would be cut. Supplies of food, clothing, blankets and fuel are being cut to inadequate levels in many refugee camps, while lack of resources for transport and road repairs is imposing further limits on supplies, according to the report. The report said refugee protection was also suffering. It cited insufficient staff to monitor Vietnamese boat people in Southeast Asian countries, to separate genuine refugees fleeing political persecution from those escaping economic hardship. Stoltenberg said cuts in programs to repatriate refugees or integrate them into local economies meant people would have to remain in camps, at great expense. ``In 1980, UNHCR had twice as many resources for each refugee than it has in 1990,'' Stoltenberg said. The meeting in Geneva was held to fix spending for the rest of 1990 and to make an initial assessment of needs in 1991. All agency money is based on voluntary contributions from governments.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Earthquake Shakes Kodiak Island; No Damage Reported
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake rattled Kodiak Island on Tuesday, but there were no immediate reports of damage or injuries. The 10:31 a.m. temblor was centered about 50 miles southwest of Kodiak, and had a preliminary magnitude reading of 5.8 on the Richter scale, said Bill Zitek, a spokesman at the Alaska Tsunami Warning Center. ``It was felt strongly in Kodiak and at Old Harbor,'' Zitek said. ``I guess a few things fell off shelves.'' Kathy Duda, a communications officer with the Kodiak Police Department, said a few residents of the island, 260 miles southwest of Anchorage, called to report feeling the quake. ``There was no damage, no injuries, no tsunami,'' she said. Tsunamis are tidal waves that can be generated by quakes. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. A magnitude-5 quake can cause considerable damage and a magnitude-6 quake can cause severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: Toxic Fumes Cause Scores to Be Hospitalized
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of people remained hospitalized Tuesday after a cloud of toxic fumes passed through a small farming community, authorities said. A farmer who burned garbage containing an insecticide caused the poisonous cloud Monday in Quebrada Seca, about 280 miles southwest of Caracas, said Civil Defense director Carlos Tovar. He said 33 children were being treated at a local clinic. About 30 adults were being treated at Central Hospital in the state capital of Barinas, Tovar said. Some 120 people were affected by the fumes Monday morning. Authorities identified the burned insecticide as Dixos. Residents of the town of 10,000 suffered fainting spells, dizziness, vomiting and severe stomach pains, Tovar said. ``People would be walking along the streets and all of a sudden they'd collapse,' he said. The farmer who lit the bonfire was among the first to be affected, Tovar said.

DOC.HEAD: Clinton Seeks Nomination in Arkansas; Democrats Make Senate Bid in Kentucky
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Polls close at 6 and 7 p.m. EDT in Kentucky; 8:30 in Arkansas; matter below the dash will stand.
DOC.TEXT: Arkansas Gov. Bill Clinton sought the Democratic nomination for a fifth term Tuesday, and Republicans decided a rancorous gubernatorial primary that pitted a former utility chief against a sheriff-turned-congressman. In Kentucky, former Louisville mayor Harvey Sloane battled state schools Superintendent John Brock for the Democratic nomination to meet Republican Sen. Mitch McConnell. McConnell faced only token opposition in the GOP primary, from perennial candidate Tommy Klein. Long-time Democratic congressmen in both states faced spirited challenges. In the 1st District of northeast Arkansas, Rep. Bill Alexander, a 22-year veteran of Congress, faced Osceola attorney Mike Gibson, a political newcomer with strong business backing. In the Louisville area, 10-term incumbent Rep. Romano Mazzoli campaigned without money from political action committees against former television newsman Jeffrey Hutter and Alderman Paul Bather. Clinton's main challenger, Tom McRae, former president of the Winthrop Rockefeller Foundation, lagged in public polls, and the governor hoped to gain a majority vote and avoid a June 12 runoff. The other Democratic candidates were Joe Holmes of Pine Bluff, Jerry Tolliver of North Little Rock, Cyrus Young of Fayetteville and O.O. ``Woodrow'' Wilson of North Little Rock. The GOP primary featured a bitter rivalry between Rep. Tommy Robinson, former police chief and sheriff from Pulaski County, and Sheffield Nelson, former head of Arkla Inc., the major natural gas utility in Arkansas. Both were Democrats until last year.

Sen. David Pryor, an Arkansas Democrat, had no primary opposition and will face only a write-in foe in November. Arkansas' Republican campaign for governor focused on a business deal between Arkla Inc. and Arkoma Production Co., owned by Nelson's friend Jerry Jones, the Dallas Cowboys owner who grew up with Robinson in North Little Rock. In 1982, Arkla sold a half-interest in gas drilling leases to Arkoma for $15 million. After Arkoma spent $35 million more on drilling and other costs, Arkla bought back its leases in 1986 along with the rest of Arkoma for $174.8 million. Robinson, 48, called the deal sleazy and severed his financial ties and friendship with Jones. Jones' 22-year-old daughter, Charlotte, quit her $60,000 a year job as administrator of Robinson's congressional office after Robinson began criticizing her father. Nelson's feud with his mentor at Arkla, W.R. ``Witt'' Stephens, spilled over into the campaign. Stephens' sister-in-law, Mary Anne Stephens, managed Robinson's campaign. Her husband, Jack Stephens, and Stephens Inc., the investment firm run by the brothers, were major contributors to Robinson's campaign. Clinton, 43, was the nation's youngest governor when he was first elected in 1978. He lost his bid for re-election in 1980, but was elected again in 1982, 1984 and 1986, when the two-year term for governor was doubled. Clinton, frequently mentioned as a potential presidential candidate, became the object of jokes in 1988 because of his meandering speech introducing another candidate for that office _ Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis. Clinton was supposed to talk for 15 minutes but spoke for more than twice that long. In Kentucky, Gov. Wallace Wilkinson backed Brock, but disagreements between the two surfaced last week when Brock decided not to follow Wilkinson's advice to borrow $250,000 for a last-minute television blitz. Wilkinson said that all but dashed Brock's chances and disassociated himself from the campaign. Alexander, 52, claimed that rich landowners in his native Mississippi County and big oil companies bankrolled Gibson' campaign. In a whirlwind push the last two months of the campaign, the incumbent portrayed himself as a ``child of the Delta'' and boasted of bringing $100 million in federal aide to the 24-county district. Gibson, 43, derided what he said was the incumbent's ineffectiveness in Congress. He noted that Alexander had never chaired or co-chaired a major congressional committee. The main issue in Mazzoli's district was whether the incumbent, first elected to the seat in 1970, had done enough for Louisville in his two decades in office. Mazzoli was co-author with Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., of the 1986 immigration reform law.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Hopes Arab Summit Will Contribute to Middle East Peace
With AM-Arab Summit
DOC.TEXT: The United States said Tuesday it hoped any joint statement emerging from the Arab League summit would contribute to peace in the Middle East. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler also said that anti-Israel statements by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein were outrageous. Saddam, repeating an April warning, told the summit in Baghdad that Iraq would use ``weapons of mass destruction'' against Israel if the Israelis used similar weapons against Iraq or any other Arab country. ``Our view of these statements remains as it was several weeks ago. They're irresponsible; they're inflammatory; they're outrageous,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. ``No one should be trumpeting such weapons _ meaning chemical weapons. We should be trumpeting their destruction,'' she said. Repeating messages sent privately and publicly to Arab leaders, Ms. Tutwiler said the United States hoped ``any resolutions coming out of the summit will contribute to peace, not raise tensions further.'' Any summit document should support U.S.-sponsored efforts to bring Israelis and Palestinians to the negotiating table so violence such as that that killed a 72-year-old Jewish man in a Jerusalem explosion Sunday can be stopped, she said. The conference was called as a show of Arab unity against what Hussein has said is a Western and Israeli campaign against Iraq. It also sought ways to stem the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel. But little unity has been apparent so far in the summit, with several Arab states boycotting the gathering and a decision Tuesday by the participants to send a memorandum critical of the United States to the superpower summit in Washington this week.

DOC.HEAD: Iran, Iraq to Hold Talks to Formally End Gulf War, Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: The presidents of Iran and Iraq may hold their first direct meeting in the next few weeks for peace talks to formally end the Iran-Iraq war, a senior PLO official said Tuesday. If the talks take place, they would be the first direct negotiations between the countries since 1988, when a U.N.-sponsored cease-fire halted eight years of fighting. Peace negotiations began five days after the truce took effect in August 1988, but they quickly deadlocked. Arab officials in Baghdad said they believe the threat from Israel perceived by Arab leaders is acting as a catalyst to push the foes toward a peace treaty. The Palestine Liberation Organization official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said PLO chairman Yasser Arafat will fly to Tehran this week in an effort to set up talks between Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani and President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. Tehran Radio, monitored in Cyprus, quoted Iranian Parliament Speaker Mehdi Karrubi also as saying that the two leaders may meet, but Karrubi gave no time estimate. He made the comment after Saddam proposed direct talks in a letter to Tehran. Arafat, in Baghdad for an Arab summit that began Monday, ``will go to Tehran immediately'' after the conference, which is expected to end by Wednesday, the PLO official reported. ``Barring last-minute complications, direct summit talks between Saddam and Rafsanjani will be under way after a month,'' the official added. According to Soviet sources in the Iraqi capital, Saddam sent a letter to Tehran in April suggesting direct talks. Soviet envoy Vladimir Petrovsky carried that letter to Tehran, they said. The PLO official said Arafat had sent two messages to Iranian leaders Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and Rafsanjani in recent days, urging them to respond ``quickly and positively'' to Saddam's offer. Speaking at a news conference in Tehran, Karrubi stressed that any talks between Rafsanjani and Saddam must be within the framework of United Nations Security Council Resolution 598, which resulted in the cease-fire. The resolution calls for the withdrawal of both sides to internationally recognized borders, an exchange of prisoners, and dredging the Shatt-Al-Arab waterway of war debris. The waterway forms the southern boundary between the two countries and is Iraq's main outlet to the Persian Gulf. Iraq's claim over the strategic waterway was the main stumbling block in earlier peace talks. But according to press reports in Tehran and Kuwait, Saddam has now conceded that sovereignty over the Shatt-al-Arab is negotiable. Both leaders are under pressure to formally end their war. Iran needs stability to carry out reconstruction and revitalize its economy. Since Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini died last June, Tehran has quietly dropped its demands for huge war reparations and for an Iraqi admission it started the war. Iraq, meanwhile, needs to reopen its major port at Basra on the Shatt-Al-Arab, which has been closed since the war began. It also is under domestic pressure to get back its 50,000 prisoners of war.

DOC.HEAD: Sources say New Orleans, New York are Finalists for Convention
DOC.TEXT: New Orleans and New York are the finalists in the competition to host the 1992 Democratic National Convention, party sources said Tuesday. The 46-member site selection committee will recommend the two cities Wednesday to party Chairman Ronald H. Brown, who will make the final decision, the sources said. The convention is scheduled to open July 13, 1992, and run for four days. Brown plans to visit both cities, possibly as early as next week, and announce his decision in mid-June. The 1988 Democratic convention was held in Atlanta. New York was the site of the 1976 convention when the Democrats nominated Jimmy Carter for president, the last time the party won a national election. New Orleans hosted the 1988 Republican convention that nominated George Bush. In addition to the two finalists, the site selection committee also considered bids from Cleveland and Houston. While Cleveland impressed committee members with its enthusiastic presentation, the city was unable to overcome its shortage of hotel space. The city planned to house some convention participants on boats docked on Lake Erie. The Democrats insisted on access to the hall for six weeks prior to the opening of the convention and also asked for a commitment of $15 million in support services to include police protection and rental of the facility. Those two requirements proved too much for several cities that were invited to bid but later declined to enter the competition. The convention is expected to attract 35,000 people to the host city and millions of dollars in economic benefits. Atlanta was estimated to have gained about $70 million from the 1988 convention that nominated Michael Dukakis for president. New York made the strongest financial bid of any city, offering the Democrats $22 million in up-front money and services. But Madison Square Garden was regarded as only marginally adequate for the convention. City officials offered a plan to provide additional seating, but several selection committee members were skeptical. In addition, the media workspace in New York would be in the Javits Center, half a mile from the convention site. New Orleans had trouble meeting the financial requirement and is located in a state that is considered a stronghold of the anti-abortion movement, placing it at odds with the prevailing sentiment of the Democratic Party. But its Superdome offered more than enough space for the delegates plus the thousands of news media needing room to work. Both cities were able to guarantee plenty of hotel rooms and are home to some of the nation's best known restaurants. The Republicans also have begun their site selection process and plan to announce the GOP convention site in January.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Look at Government-Financed Family Planning Clinics
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4 and 23 to CORRECT day of the week to Tuesday, sted Monday
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Scotus-Drunken Driving
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court said Tuesday it will decide whether a ban on government-financed family planning clinics counseling patients about abortion violates free-speech and abortion rights. At stake is the future scope of a federal program with a $200 million annual budget. The program funds more than 4,000 clinics serving about 5 million low-income women nationwide. A federal appeals court in New York upheld the counseling ban, but other federal courts ruled it is unconstitutional. The high court's decision, expected sometime in 1991, should resolve the conflicting rulings. In other action Tuesday, the court: _Said it will decide whether states may impose mandatory life sentences without parole for people convicted of possessing large amounts of drugs. The court must determine whether such a Michigan law, the only one of its kind in the nation, amounts to unconstitutionally ``cruel and unusual punishment.'' _Gave criminal defendants new ``double jeopardy'' protection against multiple prosecutions as it voted 5-4 to bar homicide charges against a drunken driver in New York. _Ruled, 7-2, in a Pennsylvania case that convicted criminals may avoid making restitution to their victims by declaring bankruptcy. _Ruled, 7-2, in a case from Arizona that Indian tribes may not prosecute any member of another tribe for crimes committed on their reservations. _Let stand a ruling in an Illinois case that shields public officials from being sued in federal court for placing children in foster homes where they are sexually abused. _Rejected an appeal by two Ku Klux Klan groups and four men ordered to pay more than $800,000 for organizing a demonstration that turned into a violent attack on civil rights marchers in Georgia three years ago. The newest abortion controversy tackled by the court involves a family planning program enacted by Congress as Title X of the Public Health Service Act. It pays for creating and operating family planning clinics. The law forbids clinics to use the federal money to perform abortions, but initial regulations let the clinic staffs tell women about the abortion option. After those regulations drew fire from anti-abortion groups, the Reagan administration in 1988 barred clinics from using federal money to advise women that abortion is an option or to refer them to abortion clinics. The newer regulations say federally funded clinics may not ``encourage, promote or advocate abortion as a method of family planning'' or distribute written materials on abortion. The regulations also require a family planning clinic that receives federal money to keep physically and financially separate any abortion clinic it might operate without federal money. If a woman visiting a federally funded family planning clinic asks about abortion, doctors and counselors are barred from saying more than that the program ``does not consider abortion an appropriate method of family planning'' and to offer help in obtaining prenatal care. New York state and New York City officials, the directors of two family planning clinics, Planned Parenthood and other organizations challenged the 1988 regulations in federal court the same day they were issued. The lawsuit contended the regulations go far beyond the restrictions imposed by the 1982 law, and that they unduly interfere with freedom of speech and women's choice to obtain abortions. U.S. District Judge Louis L. Stanton in New York City upheld the regulations, and the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals agreed by a 2-1 vote Nov. 1. After stating that the regulations are consistent with the 1982 law, the appeals court ruled that the regulations do not violate any constitutional right of pregnant women or family planning clinic staff members. ``The government has no constitutional obligation to subsidize an activity merely because the activity is constitutionally protected,'' the appeals court said. ``The government may validly choose to favor childbirth over abortion and to implement that choice by funding medical services relating to childbirth but not those relating to abortion.'' In the appeal acted on Tuesday, challengers said the federal regulations represent a kind of ``viewpoint discrimination.'' ``We are hopeful the Supreme Court will overturn the appeals court's very harmful ruling,'' said Eve Paul, Planned Parenthood's vice president for legal affairs. ``The regulations would force many clinics to go out of business because they could no longer provide medically ethical advice to their patients. Fewer women would get contraceptive advice, and the result would be more women would seek and obtain abortions,'' she said. Diana Gurieva, president of Planned Parenthood of New York City, said, ``As policy, the regulations are both shortsighted and self-defeating.'' Bush administration lawyers, although contending that the 2nd Circuit court was right, urged the justices to review the case to resolve conflicting rulings. The Boston-based 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in March that the regulations are unconstitutional. So did a federal judge in Colorado.

DOC.HEAD: Advocates Say Health, Education Professionals Must Work Closer
DOC.TEXT: Improved teaching won't mean better schools until curriculum changes are coupled with broader early childhood health screenings, advocates said Tuesday. ``We need to be dealing with the whole child. You're not going to have an educated child until you have a healthy child,'' said Lawton Chiles, a former senator from Florida and chairman of the National Commission to Prevent Infant Mortality. His comments came at a news conference that kicked off a two-day symposium designed to persuade health and education professionals to work more closely. ``Nobody is looking at the whole child,'' said William S. Woodside, a New York City businessman who chairs the board of the Institute for Educational Leadership. ``We've got programs out there, but nobody asks, `How are all these programs dealing with the children?''' The organizations headed by Chiles and Woodside form the National Health-Education Consortium. Chiles said a third of the nation's school-age handicapped children have problems that could have been corrected in their early years. Part of the problem, he said, is that existing programs are under funded and serve too few. ``We're talking about doing something about curriculum, but if you don't do something on the front end, none of that will make any difference,'' he said. While expanded programs might require greater financial commitments from federal, state and local governments, Chiles said the net result is a shifting of costs because children who remain in school are more likely to pay taxes and less likely to need public assistance or end up in prison. Woodside said the long-term savings could be five times as much as the cost. Conference participants discussed how a child's learning potential is affected by factors ranging from premature birth, low birth weight and substance abuse by the expectant mother to perinatal, pre-school and school-age health screenings.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin's Comeback Challenges Gorbachev
With AM-Yeltsin, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Boris N. Yeltsin has embarrassed President Mikhail S. Gorbachev again by transforming popular support into a political office, despite a high-level campaign against him. The prize this time was the presidency of the Soviet Union's largest republic, the Russian Federation. Yeltsin's victory Tuesday in the republic's Congress of People's Deputies presents a formidable political challenge for Gorbachev, who invested his own political clout last week in a rare public browbeating of Yeltsin. The 59-year-old Yeltsin confronted Gorbachev's program of moderate reforms with a sweeping call for a more radical steps, including devolution of political and economic decision-making from central to local authorities. Gorbachev told the Russian parliament last week that Yeltsin's call for Russian sovereignty was ``an attempt to cut Russia off from socialism.'' Those words may have slowed the rise of Yeltsin, who passed the 531-vote majority he needed only after three ballots. But they did not prevent his ascendancy into a leadership position from which Gorbachev cannot fire him. Gorbachev, who retains the top Kremlin jobs of Soviet president and general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, left Moscow on Tuesday for Canada and the United States, where he is to meet President Bush on Wednesday. Yeltsin's victory stood in contrast to Gorbachev's foreign trip, a showcase of the Soviet leader's foreign policy success at a time of sagging popularity at home. His election also coincided with a nationwide wave of panic buying triggered by the government's plan to raise prices in a transition to a partial market economy. Yeltsin was born Feb. 1, 1931 in the village of Butka in the Sverdlovsk region of the Urals. He was educated as a construction engineer. For several years he worked in building organizations in Sverdlovsk. In 1976-1985 he was head of the Sverdlovsk regional party committee. Shortly after Gorbachev came to power in 1985, he summoned Yeltsin from Sverdlovsk to take over the Communist Party organization in Moscow. Gorbachev also gave Yeltsin a non-voting seat on the ruling Communist Party Politburo. Yeltsin's populist style soon won him the affection of Muscovites. He chopped the capital's party apparatus, campaigned in stores, on trolley buses and on television to improve food supplies and public services, and spoke out against special privileges for the government and party elite. For many Muscovites, who watch their leaders rocket by in sleek limousines while they stand in line to buy soap and other scarce items, Yeltsin's borscht-in-every-pot message has immediate appeal. Yeltsin, along with millions of Soviets, became increasingly impatient with Gorbachev's perestroika, or economic reform, program. He called for faster changes and became an outspoken public figure. Then he went too far. In a speech to a closed meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee in 1987, Yeltsin criticized the slow pace of Gorbachev's reforms. He also lashed out at conservative forces led by Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev. That speech brought Yeltsin a scathing reprimand from Gorbachev and vitriolic attacks from other party officials, who accused him of dealing ``a stab in the back'' to economic reform. The criticism of Yeltsin was published in the press. He was stripped of his post as Moscow party chief, then hospitalized for heart trouble. The word went out that the Siberian politician was broken. In his own biography published this year, Yeltsin said he felt demoralized and beaten, but not defeated. Now, after two years, adversity and the open opposition of the Communist Party apparatus has only swelled Yeltsin's reputation. Millions of supporters relish his open battles with party leaders and cheer his calls to ease the brutal grind of Soviet daily life. He carries a simple message in simple style, using his throaty bass to boom out accusations and demands in simple phrases, his square doughy face set in a characteristic snarl, his strapping, erect figure topped by a smooth sweep of silver hair. ``People identify with Yeltsin,'' the weekly Moscow News wrote last year in a full-page story headlined ``The Boris Yelsin Phenomenon.'' ``He's a victim of dislike on the part of higher-ups _ who of us hasn't been in the same position?'' the weekly said. ``And he is being slighted for refusing to seek their approval _ who hasn't dreamed of doing that?'' The first big step in his political comeback was a landslide victory in March 1989 in direct popular elections to the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies, the national parliament. Yeltsin was swept into office with almost 90 percent of the vote, obtaining approval from more than 5 million Muscovites and crushing his apparatus-backed opponent. Later that year, he carried out a deft procedural maneuver to win election to the Supreme Soviet, the national legislature. And early this year, he was elected a deputy of the Rssian Federation Congress, which Tuesday chose him president. He still is a member of the party's policy-making Central Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Presbyterians Tackle Statement of Faith in Utah Meeting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Marj in 6th graf and SalmonCampbell in 9th graf are cq
DOC.TEXT: The Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) is meeting in the Mormon heartland to act on its first statement of faith since a 1983 merger healed a Civil War-era split over slavery. In its first meeting in Salt Lake City, the General Assembly is scheduled to vote on ``A Brief Statement of Faith'' that mixes traditional Christian beliefs with more modern concerns for the environment and sexual equality. Resolutions on the environment, U.S.-Cuban relations and Northern Ireland also have been placed before the chief policy-making body of the 2.9 million-member Protestant denomination. No official dialogue is planned between the Presbyterians and the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, but private meetings are scheduled between Mormon leaders and the Presbyterian Inter-Faith Office. There are 5,000 Presbyterians in Utah, where an estimated 70 percent of the 1.6 million residents are Mormons. Roman Catholics make up the next largest group with an estimated 80,000 members. It is unusual for the denomination to hold its annual assembly in a place where it has so few members, but the church was heeding a call from local Presbyterians who were seeking recognition in Utah, according to church spokeswoman Marj Carpenter. ``They just kind of wanted a little reinforcement,'' she said. The more than 600 commissioners attending the 202nd General Assembly, which opened Tuesday, have their first major business meeting Wednesday when the election of a moderator is scheduled. The meeting runs through June 6. Six candidates, all male, were nominated to succeed the Rev. Joan SalmonCampbell of Philadelphia. The candidates are: Josiah Beeman, 54, clerk of session of Capitol Hill Presbyterian Church in Washington, D.C.; Price Henderson Gwynn III, 67, an elder at Steele Creek Presbyterian Church in Charlotte, N.C.; the Rev.
