M. Douglas Harper Jr., 62, pastor of St. Andrews Presbyterian Church in Houston; the Rev. Allen Maruyama, 63, co-pastor of Montview Boulevard Presbyterian Church in Denver; the Rev. Herbert Meza, 67, pastor of Fort Caroline Presbyterian Church in Jacksonville, Fla.; and the Rev. Fred A. Ryle, 55, pastor of Grace First Presbyterian Church in Weatherford, Texas. Stated Clerk James E. Andrews, the denomination's chief executive, said the proposed statement of faith reflects the theological maturity of the church since the northern and southern branches reunited in 1983, following a 122-year-old split. The 80-line statement upholds centuries-old church teachings that Christ was fully human and fully God, and that he rose from the dead to offer eternal life. Reflecting more recent church developments, it also declares that God calls women and men to all ministries of the church and uses the images of both mother and father in references to God. The statement also calls upon the denomination that was once divided over slavery to proclaim: ``In sovereign love, God created the world good, and makes everyone equally in God's image, male and female, of every race and people, to live as one community.'' If approved, the statement will be sent to the church's 171 presbyteries. If two-thirds of the regional bodies approve the statement, it will come before the 1991 General Assembly for a final review and vote. Among other issues: _In a document titled ``Restoring Creation for Ecology and Justice,'' the Committee on Social Witness Policy recommends the church establish an office on environmental justice and stewardship. It also calls for incorporation of environmental concerns into worship and preaching, education programs and community ministries. _The resolution on normalizing relations with Cuba calls for relaxing trade, travel and currency restrictions and negotiating agreements on issues such as radio and television transmissions, drug trafficking and immigration procedures. _The resolution on Northern Ireland calls for cooperative efforts among U.S. and Irish Presbyterians and Catholics to work toward a non-violent solution to the sectarian conflict. Several presbyteries submitted overtures on abortion and homosexuality, two issues that have continually divided the denomination, but task forces appointed by previous assemblies to study the issues have not finished their work.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Retake Oil City, at Least 15 People Wounded in Fighting
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers sent to take control of this oil production center clashed with anti-government protesters Tuesday, and at least 15 people were wounded by gunfire and grenade attacks, officials said. The troops, backed by armored cars, arrived in the morning and were in control late Tuesday, said witnesses. They described the city as tense but calm in the evening. Witnesses said soldiers used tear gas on supporters of the opposition Gabon Progress Party and arrested at least 20 people, including three party leaders. A girl and a soldier were among the injured, according to witnesses and hospital officials. A Gabonese general said in a news conference that 300 soldiers were used in the operation. The city had been in turmoil since last Wednesday, when a leader of the opposition party was slain. Oil companies drastically cut production because of the unrest. Gabon earns 80 percent of its income from oil and would quickly run out of money without it. President Omar Bongo's government tried to restore order by declaring a state of emergency Monday. When that did not stop the protests, troops were sent in. In Paris, the state-owned oil company Elf-Aquitaine announced it would gradually resume production on its 60 offshore rigs. Production was expected to reach half of the 101,000 barrels normally produced per day, and climb to 80 percent Wednesday, a company spokesman said. Troops began moving into Port Gentil at dawn, sweeping away barricades set up by protesters. Initially there was no sign of resistance from opposition party supporters. Leaders urged them to put away their weapons, mostly hunting rifles. Later, automatic rifle fire and the explosions of hand grenades were heard in low-income areas of the city. At the news conference, the Gabonese general said soldiers hurled grenades over barricades sheltering demonstrators firing rifles. The general's name wasn't immediately known. He appeared at the news conference with Gen. Idriss Ngari, head of the Gabonese armed forces. A spokesman at Paul Igamba hospital in Port Gentil said at least 15 people were wounded by bullets. Most were hit in the upper leg, but one 9-year-old girl was struck in the back. Initial reports from witnesses said one soldier was captured and beaten to death by demonstrators. But, according to later accounts, he was evacuated to Libreville, the capital, in critical condition. The unrest began May 23 with the still-unexplained death of Joseph Rendjambe, secretary-general of the opposition Gabon Progress Party in Libreville. His party members rioted in several cities and took control of much of Port Gentil, burning the French Consulate and taking some expatriate oil executives hostage for several hours. The French government sent reinforcements to its garrison in the former French colony. When the troops arrived in Port Gentil, the hostages were freed. Bongo's government had been reluctant to use military force against the opposition supporters despite destruction of government and private property. But it acted when Elf Gabon and Shell Gabon shut down oil production. Before the Gabon security forces arrived Tuesday, French soldiers gathered 1,000 expatriate oil workers into special centers where they could be protected or evacuated if necessary. Nearly all wives and children of the workers already had been evacuated, and a further 40 to 60 reportedly were flown out Tuesday. Most of the expatriates were French, but they also included British, Belgian, Dutch and American workers.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Hospitalized; De Klerk Postpones U.S. visit
DOC.TEXT: African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela underwent a minor operation and will remain hospitalized for a couple days for a needed rest, the clinic's director said Tuesday. Gordon Cohen, director of the Park Lane Clinic, would not say what the operation involved. Mandela, 71, was admitted to the clinic late Sunday and had surgery Monday, Cohen said. Also Tuesday, President F.W. de Klerk indefinitely postponed his visit to the United States next month. He said an unnecessary controversy had developed over his U.S. visit preceding Mandela's, which is scheduled for late June. ``Mr. Mandela will be here a couple of days and is resting _ which he needs,'' Cohen said. ``The operation was nothing serious, and can't have any long-term consequences.'' ANC internal chairman Walter Sisulu said Monday he thought the operation involved Mandela's prostate, the independent South Africa Press Association reported. But Cohen said the surgery was not related to Mandela's prostate, which was operated on successfully in 1985. Mandela was hospitalized with tuberculosis in 1988, but is believed in generally good health. Mandela's wife, Winnie, visited him Tuesday and said Mandela's planned trip to Europe next week was ``in no way affected and would go ahead,'' the Press Association reported. He has maintained a demanding schedule of public appearances since his release in February after 27 years in prison for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the government. He returned last week from a tour of eight African countries. He also made a trip through Africa and to Britain and Sweden shortly after his release. He is scheduled to visit Europe next week, then return briefly to South Africa before traveling to the United States on June 20. De Klerk said Tuesday he was postponing his visit, which would have been the first to the United States by a South African head of government in more than 30 years. He said he still planned to meet Bush but gave no date. Black American organizations and the ANC office in Washington had said they would not look favorably on President Bush meeting de Klerk before he meets Mandela. ``Due to a controversy that has arisen in the United States as regards the possible timing of my visit in June ... I have decided to postpone my visit,'' de Klerk said in a statement. De Klerk took office in August and has launched a series of reforms, including Mandela's release. He says he wants to dismantle apartheid and negotiate a new constitution that will allow black-white power sharing.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Begins in Italy's Major Banking Scandal
DOC.TEXT: The trial of 35 people for their alleged role in Italy's biggest postwar banking scandal opened Tuesday with some key defendants failing to appear, including Licio Gelli. Gelli, former grandmaster of the supersecret P-2 Masonic Lodge, and several others exercised their right under Italian law and stayed away from the proceedings. They will be tried in abstentia. The defendants are charged with being accessories to the 1982 fraudulent bankruptcy of Banco Ambrosiano, which was Italy's largest private bank. Umberto Ortolani, one of the defendants and former close associate of the late Ambrosiano chairman Roberto Calvi, said allegations of the lodge's involvement with the bank were a ``fantasy.'' Speaking to reporters in the courtroom, he said the charges were ``fabricated.'' The lodge, which is now outlawed, has been linked to right-wing terrorism and other crimes. The opening day was confined to procedural matters. Three minor defendants informed the court they would seek to plea bargain but the prosecution said it would oppose that. The defendants include 15 members of the bank's former board of directors, as well as industrialists and the reputed leaders of the Masonic Lodge. Archbishop Paul C. Marcinkus of Cicero, Ill., and two senior officers of the Vatican bank, originally charged in the case, will not be tried. Italy's highest court ruled two years ago that Italian judges can not interfere in the internal affairs of a foreign state _ the Vatican. The Vatican bank, formally known as the the Institute for Religious Works, was Ambrosiano's largest shareholder. Banco Ambrosiano collapsed after failing to collect $1.3 billion in loans it made to Latin American ``dummy'' companies. The loans were made after the Vatican bank provided letters of assurance. Orazio Bagnasco, a well-known Italian industrialist, and Giuseppe Prisco, a noted lawyer who is vice-president of the soccer club Internazionale, are among the board members charged in the case. Also accused are retired financier Anna Bonomi Bolchini, and the former managing director of the Rizzoli publishing group, Bruno Tassan-Din. P-2 allegedly received funds from Calvi, the secretive chairman of Banco Ambrosiano, who was found hanging from a London bridge in June 1982, a few months before the collapse of his bank. If convicted, defendants could receive jail terms of 3 to 10 years. The trial could last months.

DOC.HEAD: Army to Try to Restore Order in Troubled Sindh Province
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto ordered the army to help restore peace to her troubled home province, where hundreds of people have been killed or wounded in ethnic violence, government sources said Tuesday. Critics, including some within Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party, say she has not done enough to stop a wave of kidnappings, assassinations and sniper attacks that have left more than 250 people dead and 1,000 injured in the past two weeks in Sindh Province. In Karachi, the provincial capital and Pakistan's largest city, 89 people have been killed since Saturday in random shootings and clashes between rival ethnic groups and security forces, officials said. Despite escalating violence, Ms. Bhutto again rejected calls to dismiss the provincial government and declare a state of mergency, according to government sources. ``It has been decided after two days of consultations to call out the army to help the civilian administration restore law and order in the province,'' said one source, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``The army will stay until peace is restored.'' The prime minister called emergency meetings in Karachi with provincial officials. Also attending was Gen. Mirza Aslam Beg, Pakistan's army chief of staff, who cut short a visit to Bangladesh. Ms. Bhutto has accused neighboring India of stirring up much of the trouble in Sindh. New Delhi denies the allegations. ``The country is confronted with civil war,'' said opposition leader Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi, referring to the violence in Sindh. ``How long can the government be ... like the ostrich with its head buried in the sand?' Police blame the current violence on a militant faction of the Mohajir Qami Movement, a small political party representing descendants of Moslem Indians who immigrated to Pakistan during the 1947 partition of the subcontinent. The group is demanding recognition as Pakistan's fifth nationality, along with the Pathans, Punjabis, Baluch and Sindhis. The Mohajir group once backed Ms. Bhutto but withdrew its support last November and forced a no-confidence vote, which she narrowly survived. Tensions have been simmering for years between the Mohajirs and other ethnic groups. Ethnic rivalries erupted anew on May 15 in Hyderabad. By the time the army was deployed to restore order Sunday, at least 180 people had been killed and nearly 500 wounded. The army was deployed in Hyderabad, about 150 miles north of Karachi, after security forces opened fire on a crowd of 10,000 people who defied curfew. They defied the curfew at the urging of Moslem clerics, who told them to take to the streets to demand food and restoration of their water and electricity. Officials said at least 60 people were killed and nearly 300 injured.

DOC.HEAD: US Grateful for Return of Remains of War Dead
DOC.TEXT: The State Department expressed appreciation Tuesday for the return by North Korea of the remains of five American servicemen and said the action was a step toward improved U.S.-North Korean relations. Other measures that could promote an accommodation include a North Korean willingness to engage in constructive talks with South Korea and an end to alleged North Korean sponsorship of terrorist activities, department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said. In addition, she encouraged North Korea to sign a nuclear safeguards agreement with the International Atomic Energy Agency. Ms. Tutwiler also reaffirmed a statement on Feb. 1 by Secretary of State James A. Baker III in which he said the United States is looking for a ``steady, reciprocal process toward better relations both between North and South Korea and between the United States and North Korea.'' She said the return of the remains ``is a step in that direction.'' North Korea turned over the remains of the Americans to eight members of Congress in a ceremony at the truce village of Panmunjom.

DOC.HEAD: Week-old Dock Strike Broadens in Romania
DOC.TEXT: A week-old strike by more than 10,000 shipping and harbor workers widened Tuesday and the nation's largest steel plant said it only had a few hours of fuel, the state news agency Rompres reported. There appeared little chance of a quick settlement to the walkout, which has left hundreds of cargo ships backed up outside seven ports on the Danube River, the agency reported. The government on April 25 agreed to some demands by the shipping union, including a 25 percent salary increase for night shifts, allowances in hard currency and food allocations for the merchant marine. But the Department of Shipping Transport called several later demands unjustified, including a further 50 percent raise and retroactive payment of night shifts for the past three years. ``We just want to be given back what had been taken from us in the dictatorial regime,'' union leader Gheorghe Vrabie was quoted as saying Sunday, referring to Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who was ousted in a popular revolt in December and executed. Dockers in the port of Turnu Severin joined the strike Tuesday, Rompres reported. Sailors, harbor workers and administrators are striking in the Danube ports of Galati, Sulina, Tulcea, Cernavoda, Agigea and Braila, the news agency said. Unions at Romania's largest steel plant, in Galati, said Tuesday the strike had repercussions on the national economy, noting their plant only had enough coal and limestone for a few hours, Rompres said. The union and the transport ministry said Monday night that attempts to start a dialogue between the workers and representatives of the shipping company Navrom had failed. The union said Tuesday it wanted a dialogue with the ministries of transport, labor and national economy. Navrom, which had a profit in 1989, has lost $10.6 million in the first four months of this year and is now on the brink of failure, the transport ministry said in a communique. The department said the strike has caused grave economic problems for the Galati and Calarasi steel factories and called for the establishment of a commission to investigate the losses. The union began the strike May 23 after issuing another 22 demands.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Officials Say Yeltsin Win May Help Reform, Blessing In Disguise
With AM-Yeltsin, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The election Tuesday of populist reformer Boris Yeltsin as president of the Russian Republic was an expression of discontent that could aid reform, Soviet officials said. ``It may be a blessing in disguise,'' said Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov after hearing of Yeltsin's victory. ``President (Mikhail S.) Gorbachev has his critics from both the left and the right and possibly it is better to have the election of a critic from the left,'' he said. Gerasimov and other Soviet officials were at the United Nations to brief reporters before the U.S.-Soviet summit on Wednesday in Washington. Igor Malashenko, foreign policy adviser to the Communist Party, told reporters at the same news conference that ``this victory of Yeltsin has been misinterpreted as a problem for Gorbachev. Yeltsin is also a reformer, although he reflects concepts which are different from Gorbachev. ``In this respect I believe it can strengthen the cause of reform in the Soviet Union. Today many people blame Gorbachev for problems and now they have another person to blame.'' However, Yuri Golik, chairman of the Supreme Soviet Committee on law, said through an interpreter: ``I am not very happy with the election of Mr. Yeltsin, but it is a fact.'' Speaking through an interpreter, he quoted a Russian proverb: ``Only when chicks grow up to be chickens can we see the results ... So, when the autumn comes, we will see the results from Mr. Yeltsin's election.''

DOC.HEAD: World's Newspapers Face Growing Classroom Competition from TV
DOC.TEXT: The world's newspapers trying to battle illiteracy and boost future readership by getting schoolchildren to read papers face growing competition from television, international publishing spokesmen said Tuesday. Even among young readers in Japan, with its low illiteracy rates, ``disenchantment with newspapers is proceeding at a frightening pace,'' said Kazuo Ichiriki, owner of the newspaper Kahoku Shimpo in Sendai. Japanese high school students spend an average of just six minutes a day reading newspapers, and 20 percent of university students don't read newspapers daily, Ichiriki told participants at a international literacy conference sponsored by the American Newspaper Publishers Association Foundation. The conference focused on ANPA's 25-year-old Newspapers In Education program aimed at promoting use of newspapers in schools worldwide to help youngsters develop lifelong reading habits. The international gathering, which drew 165 participants from 20 nations, was a prelude to a three-day conference in New York beginning Wednesday. Among the topics to be discussed later in the week: classroom newscasts by CNN and Channel One by Whittle Communications. Some publishers fear such programming could squeeze newspapers out of the curriculum. ``We are in a war in fighting for resources and recognitiion in schools,'' said Uzal H. Martz Jr., president and publisher of the Pottsville (Pa.) Republican. Japanese publishers began an NIE program 4{ years ago, said Ichiriki, because people from that nation were spending just 30 minutes a day reading and two hours a day watching TV. About 85 percent of Japanese schools now make use of newspapers in classroom lessons. ``But NIE is not just to protect our self-interest (as newspaper publishers) but because the future of Japan could be adversely affected,'' he said. Representatives of several other foreign language newspapers published in the United States and abroad issued similar warnings that newspapers needed to make a more concerted effort to regain students' attention in the face of growing competition from television. In Sweden, newspaper readership among 9-to-14-year-olds recently has declined after a decade of stability, largely because of increased television viewing, said Birgitta Pahlen, Newspapers in Education manager for the Swedish Newspaper Publishers Association in Stockholm. In less developed countries, poverty or indifference pose the larger threat to literacy efforts employing newspapers. In India, for example, with 280 million illiterates, only one NIE effort exists, according to John Ryan, coordinator for UNESCO's International Literacy Year.

DOC.HEAD: Food Price Increases Spur Cuts in Benefits for Women and Youngsters
DOC.TEXT: More than half the states are responding to unexpectedly sharp increases in food prices by cutting back on a federally funded program that provides food for women, infants and children, authorities said Tuesday. ``It means we won't have as many healthy children and mothers as we wanted because all of these people are medically at risk for malnutrition and anemia,'' Rep. Tony P. Hall, D-Ohio, said. ``You've got to be in trouble to be in the program in the first place.'' The changes are being made in the $2.1 billion Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children, known as WIC, which in February provided groceries to an all-time high 4.55 million individuals. Hall, chairman of the House Select Hunger Committee, has been calling for a $150 million increase in the program for each of the next five years. But he said that even with that money in 1991 ``if we stay even, we'll be lucky.'' The program provides needy women and children with vouchers redeemable at the grocery store for food, including milk, infant formula, juice, cheese and cereal. Price increases for milk and to a lesser degree orange juice and cereal have been named as the prime sources of the budgetary strain. The Department of Agriculture's food and nutrition service, which runs the program, had figured on inflation in food prices this year of a little more than 4 percent. But the costs of food staples have risen about double that, straining state programs. Dennis Bach, head of the Iowa program and president of the National Association of WIC directors, said 36 of the 44 states that responded to a recent survey said they were cutting benefits under the program. Hall said a Hunger Committee study found similar results. Only about half of those eligible are receiving benefits, according to Bach. Many states are not able to provide food to individuals who fall into the lowest priority categories. ``There are literally millions of young children who would qualify for WIC who are not getting served,'' Bach said. ``We've talked to the states about the first measure being to find less expensive ways to provide the same nutrition without cutting volume of food or nutritional value of food,'' said F. Philip Shanholtzer, a spokesman for the food and nutritional service. Texas has cut the cereal allowance for 1-year-olds and 2-year-olds from 36 ounces a month to 24 ounces a month and will drop 27,000 program participants. Those receiving benefits reached a peak of 357,000 in January. ``When prices go up on food items, that means our budget won't go as far and we have to serve fewer people,'' said Ray Krzesniak, chief of staff services for the Health Department's bureau of women, infants and children. Texas receives $148 million from USDA under the program as well as $5.5 million in state funds plus a hefty rebate on each can of infant formula. Iowa, which has a much smaller program, is nonetheless planning to end benefits for post-partum women who are not breast feeding, a low priority on the USDA scale. That would drop an estimated 4,000 participants and reduce the total of individuals receiving benefits to 45,000 for a $400,000 savings. California, which currently serves 470,000 individuals, is planning to cut the monthly juice allowance for children three to five years old for an expected savings of $1.2 million. It also is hoping to save $6 million by eliminating vouchers for cheese.

DOC.HEAD: House Hopefuls Disclose Their Financial Dealings
With AM-House Finances, a0657
DOC.TEXT: A former Vietnam War hero, an ex-ambassador and a movie stuntman were among House candidates whose financial disclosure forms were released Tuesday. The disclosures of income, holdings and liabilities are required of challengers as well as for incumbents. Holdings and liabilities are listed in low and high ranges, rather than in exact amounts. Randall H. Cunningham, an ex-fighter pilot who was a Vietnam ``ace'' and an instructor in the Navy's elite ``top gun'' school, is a Republican running for the seat held by Rep. Jim Bates, D-Calif. Cunningham listed $77,666 in income for 1989, while his holdings ranged from a low of $465,008 to more than $820,000. He had no liabilities. Another Republican vying for the seat is Joseph A. Ghougassian, who was the U.S. ambassador to the Persian Gulf nation of Qatar from 1985 to 1989. His entire salary in 1989 was from the State Department, totaling $46,502. He listed unearned income ranging from $30,005 to $90,000. Ghougassian's holdings, however, were extensive, ranging from $680,006 to more than $1.3 million. He also listed $100,000 to $250,000 in liabilities. Bates, who is running for re-election, came under fire last October from the House ethics committee, which found that he had violated a House rule prohibiting sexual harassment and an ethics guideline barring campaign work in a congressional office. Former female staffers of Bates had complained about his behavior. James H. Dingeman Jr., a part-time stunt driver for television ads and for movies, is a Republican challenging Rep. David Bonior, D-Mich., his party's chief deputy whip. Dingeman, who also is an environmental consultant, listed 1989 income of $670,781 _ which included the sale of a his interest in a steel company. He also listed unearned income ranging from $21,008 to $72,500 and holdings from $40,009 to $155,000. He had no liabilities. Walter Dudycz, a Republican state senator and Chicago police detective on leave, is challenging 13-term Chicago Democrat Frank Annunzio. Dudycz listed a 1989 income of $59,660. Dudycz had no unearned income, no holdings and no liabilities last year. Three Democrats are running to unseat House Republican Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia. David Worley, who lost to Gingrich two years ago, did not list any 1989 salary or liabilities, and his only holding was an individual retirement account worth $1 to $1,000. Roger B. Marietta, mayor of Fayetteville, listed $51,752 in earned income last year, and an additional $2 to $2,000 in unearned income. His holdings were $5,000 or less. Liabilities were listed from $5,001 to $15,000. Joe Forrest, a former Eastern Air Lines pilot, earned $33,002 last year, including $16,800 in strike benefits during the pilots' walkout against the airline. His unearned income was $6,007 to $22,500 and his holdings ranged from $5,001 and $15,000. He had no liabilities. Last March, the House ethics committee ordered Gingrich to amend his financial disclosure forms to reflect participation in the purchase, along with his daughter, of her home in Georgia four years ago. The committee also criticized two letters sent on his letterhead in 1986 and 1987, promoting a for-profit senior citizens cruise. However, the committee also decided not to pursue a formal investigation of Gingrich's financial dealings as had been requested by Rep. Bill Alexander, D-Ark. C

DOC.HEAD: Eton Celebrates 550-year Anniversary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 12 `George Orwell' to DELETE reference to Capt. Cook; picks up graf 13 pvs, `The Old ...'
DOC.TEXT: Old Etonians thronged ``ye distant spires, ye antique towers, that crown the wat'ry glade,'' and Queen Elizabeth II came for lunch Tuesday to mark the 550th anniversary of Eton College. The queen praised the school as ``second to none,'' though she sent her three sons to Gordonstoun in Scotland. She told students she had asked the headmaster to give them an extra holiday each October. Why October? Because the actual 550th anniversary of the foundation of Eton College by King Henry VI falls on Oct. 11. Eton celebrated Tuesday, a school official explained, because it was the day before the annual June 4 holiday in honor of King George III _ which Eton chose to celebrate on May 30. Eton's calendar, like its modes of speech and dress, is all its own. The school long ago disposed of top hats, flogging, and the humiliating ``bum freezer'' jackets for its shortest boys, but it remains its own world. Masters are still ``beaks,'' classes are ``divs,'' rowers are ``wet bobs,'' cricketers are ``dry bobs'' and students are either ``tugs'' (King's Scholars) or ``oppidans'' (fee-paying students). Students wear long-tailed black coats, white ties and stiff collars in class. The myth of Eton is that the school, nestled in the shadow of Windsor Castle, inculcates superiority of mind, grace and social status. ``The thing Eton majors in is arrogance _ so deep-rooted it is totally unselfconscious. It's ugly and unappealing, and I've spent the past 30 years trying to unlearn it,'' said Mark Fisher, a Labor Party lawmaker. Lord Longford says he once was interrogated by King George VI about why he, an old Etonian, became a socialist. It came down to ``the conviction that we are all equal in the sight of God,'' Longford said. ``Well, I think Eton stands for something far removed from that.'' Fisher and Longford were among 50 ``old boys'' interviewed by Danny Danziger for his recently published book, ``Eton Voices.'' George Orwell, Percy Bysshe Shelley, Henry Fielding, Aldous Huxley, the economist John Maynard Keynes and the poet Thomas Gray, who wrote about ``ye distant spires,'' all attended Eton. So did a score of prime ministers and three members of the current Cabinet. The Old Etonian Association had hoped to lure 8,000 old boys for the festivities, including fireworks and a ``supper box'' priced at about $105 but sold half that many tickets. John Butterwick, chairman of the Old Etonians, blamed an out of date mailing list, and a computer that couldn't deal with titles or the strings of honors behind some former students' names. Derek Malcolm, film critic of The Guardian newspaper, left Eton feeling equal to any occasion. ``I mean, there's no higher you can go socially,'' he told Danziger. Pish and tosh, says Philip Howard, literary editor of The Times of London. ``You should see some of the diffident, insecure ... boring Etonians I meet, if I don't see them coming first,'' he wrote in the newspaper. ``I do get irritated by people who think that because we look traditional and old-fashioned, the Establishment is hidebound and backward-looking,'' the headmaster, Eric Anderson, told the Daily Express. ``Underneath all that, it's a very modern school.'' Nine out of 10 Etonians go on to universities, a quarter to Oxford or Cambridge. The school has two dozen science labs, a ``beak'' for every 9.5 students and even a golf course among the famous playing fields where, as it's said, the Battle of Waterloo was won. The school has at least three applicants for each of its 1,260 places, and parents pay $14,450 a year for an education, plus those incomparable intangibles. ``Being known as an Etonian is a handicap, because of false expectations of snobbery and wealth it arouses,'' wrote Howard, who said one of his old school companions wound up managing a bus station.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Asks Special Counsel to Expand Pierce Probe
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department on Tuesday asked the special prosecutor investigating former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. to study new allegations of favoritism toward politically connected developers. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh asked independent counsel Arlin M. Adams to review allegations by one of Pierce's former top aides, DuBois L. Gilliam, that politics was an important criteria for awarding grants through two additional programs operated by the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Adams, who is already investigating whether Pierce and top aides illegally dispensed political favors in managing the Moderate Rehabilitation Program, said he would act promptly on Thornburgh's request. ``It would appear that in light of Gilliam's testimony, it may be appropriate to redefine the mandate of the independent counsel,'' Adams said in a statement after the Justice Department released a copy of Thornburgh's letter. Thornburgh based his request on testimony that Gilliam, who is serving an 18-month sentence for corruption, gave a House subcommittee about the operation of the Urban Development Action Grant Program and the Secretary's Discretionary Fund for technical assistance and special projects. ``Mr. Gilliam's allegations concerning how the funding decisions in these programs were made are related to the allegations you are already investigating concerning HUD's Moderate Rehabilitation Program,'' the attorney general said. ``Accordingly, I consider it proper and appropriate to refer those allegations to you for investigation,'' Thornburgh wrote. Justice Department spokesman Dan Eramian said Thornburgh's request for a wider investigation was based on a review of Gilliam's sworn testimony by criminal division prosecutors. Paul Perito, Pierce's attorney, called Gilliam's testimony ``scurrilous allegations'' and denounced the congressional committee that called him as a witness. Pierce, Perito said, has ``nothing to fear by an impartial review ... by a group of dedicated and responsible prosecutors, as opposed to the hysteria and insatiable thirst for publicity of a congressional inquiry gone awry.'' Gilliam testified that during the Reagan administration HUD was ``the best domestic political machine I'd ever seen. We dealt strictly with politics there.'' ``If you were well connected in political circles, your application got strong, strong consideration,'' said Gilliam, who was deputy assistant secretary for policy development and evaluation. Gilliam's testimony, given under a grant of limited immunity from prosecution, contradicts Pierce's own sworn assertions to the same subcommittee last spring that he never ordered aides to approve particular grants. ``I know for a fact the secretary made decisions'' on specific projects, Gilliam said during his congressional testimony earlier this month. In one case, Gilliam said Pierce ordered him to approve a $2.3 million grant for an apartment complex and shopping center on land owned by Hampton University, where Pierce was a trustee. Gilliam said that Pierce ordered the approval of a $5.6 million UDAG grant to a project in Florida because his former executive assistance, Lance H. Wilson, was a private consultant for the developer. Gilliam told the subcommittee that Pierce ordered him to intervene in projects in Nashville, Cleveland and Miami that were supported by influential local Republicans. Adams was appointed by a special court earlier this year to investigate allegations that Pierce and top aides defrauded the government by awarding Moderate Rehabilitation Program grants on the basis of political favoritism from 1984 to 1988. The special prosecutor law allows Adams to accept a broader jurisdiction at the request of the attorney general. The original jurisdiction was defined by Thornburgh in his request to the special court for the appointment of Adams. Democrats on Capitol Hill have repeatedly called for a wider scope of the independent counsel's inquiry. Gilliam, who told lawmakers he took $100,000 in bribes and gratuities while working at HUD from 1984 to 1987, pleaded guilty last year to conspiring to manipulate the award of a grant and accepting $8,000 in illegal gratuities. Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., one of several House Judiciary Committee members who spearheaded the call for an independent counsel last fall, welcomed the move but called for even wider jurisdiction. ``I still do not understand, however, why perjury is not included'' in the independent counsel's jurisdiction. ``It would be best if the attorney general issue a broad mandate and let the independent counsel's investigation go where the evidence warrants,'' Schumer said in a statement. Thornburgh found there was insufficient basis to investigate Pierce for allegedly lying to the subcommittee, saying the former secretary was asked ambiguous questions.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 1st item to CLARIFY that gift to royal couple was naming hospice after them.
DOC.TEXT: There's nothing fashionable about being this late, but no one seemed offended. Prince Charles and Princess Diana finally received a wedding gift from Glasgow, nearly nine years after they were married. The present: naming a hospice after them. It's named the Prince and Princess of Wales Hospice, which took several years to finance and construct, and chatting to patients. The royal couple _ married July 21, 1981 _ officially opened the hospice Tuesday, and spent an hour touring the building and chatting to patients.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Visit Spurs Promotion Of Soviet Vodka
With AM-Summit Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A suburban community is toasting the upcoming visit of Mikhail S. Gorbachev by slashing the price of Soviet vodka _ a libation banned by another municipality when East-West relations weren't so merry. ``We felt it was an opportunity to extend a greeting to the Soviet president,'' said Bob Erickson, city administrator of Lakeville. Erickson said the sale of Stolichnaya vodka by the three municipal liquor stores at 5 percent above the wholesale price _ discounted from $14.99 a liter to $11.65 _ was designed to counteract a now defunct advertising campaign for Minnesota-made Karkov vodka. Before the Karkov campaign was dropped last week, billboards featured the Soviet president as a pitchman beside the caption ``The Party's Over,'' a reference to the Communist Party's problems. The billboards were up before Gorbachev's visit to Minnesota was announced. In their place is a message in Russian toasting his health. Lakeville has advertised its Stolichnaya promotion under the slogan ``The Party's Just Beginning,'' said Judy Perron, Lakeville liquor manager. ``She (Perron) found the Karkov billboards somewhat offensive,'' Erickson said. ``She felt that as a liquor retailer we wanted to counteract that.'' The vodka promotion at the municipal liquor stores began Monday and will continue through Saturday, Perron said. But the drinks haven't always flowed this freely. The small town of Hutchinson, for example, banned the drink from its municipal liquor store in 1983 following the downing of a South Korean jetliner by a Soviet fighter pilot. The ban was lifted in December in recognition of a thaw in the cold war.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Upholds Poindexter Convictions, Says Defense Was Weak
DOC.TEXT: A judge refused Tuesday to overturn John M. Poindexter's five Iran-Contra convictions, ruling that the former national security adviser had presented a weak defense against strong evidence. U.S. District Judge Harold H. Greene denied defense motions for a judgment of acquittal on the five felony convictions of then-President Reagan's national security adviser. ``A review of this evidence reveals that proof of defendant's guilt of the charges is compelling,'' Greene said of the conspiracy, obstruction of Congress and false statement convictions that were returned April 7 by the jury in the case. Jurors found Poindexter guilty of lying to Congress and destroying documents to conceal covert Reagan administration assistance of the Nicaraguan rebels and the U.S. role in a 1985 Israeli shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. The judge, rejecting defense arguments that prosecutors did not prove their case against the retired Navy rear admiral, found that Poindexter's defense ``was neither broad nor particularly convincing.'' ``Other than to attempt to weaken the testimony of the government's witnesses through cross-examination, Poindexter simply did not have a defense of his own,'' the judge said. Poindexter, who did not testify at his trial, is scheduled to be sentenced June 11, when he could be given up to 25 years in prison and fined as much as $1.25 million. The judge noted that neither Reagan, who gave a videotaped deposition that was played to the jury, nor former National Security Council aide Oliver L. North, was ``willing to relieve defendant of culpability'' in their testimony. The judge found that Reagan ``may have helped generate an atmosphere at the White House which led subordinate officials to conclude they were carrying out the president's wishes'' by repeatedly stressing his commitment to freeing U.S. hostages in Lebanon and helping the Nicaraguan rebels after Congress cut off aid. But Greene said ``there is no evidence to contradict the former president's testimony that he warned his subordinates against acting outside the law.'' The judge also dismissed a defense contention that Iran-Contra prosecutor Dan Webb improperly argued to jurors in his final summation that Reagan had lied to the American public when he denied selling arms to Iran for hostages. Poindexter's lawyers argued this was an improper expression of personal opinion not based on the facts. ``While the language regarding a former president of the United States should perhaps have been more delicate, the prosecutor's assertion was nevertheless a fair inference from the evidence,'' Greene said.

DOC.BYLINE: World Bank Approves Big Loan for China ^By CARL HARTMAN
DOC.TEXT: The World Bank approved a $300 million loan for China on Tuesday, the bank's largest loan to China since tanks suppressed the pro-democracy movement there last June. Approval came despite protests in Congress and from Chinese student groups in this country. The United States contributes more than any other country to the bank, which is the biggest source of aid to the Third World. Patrick Coady, the U.S. executive director, is one of the 22 members on the board that met Tuesday and approved the loan behind closed doors. Until last year, China was one of the bank's two biggest borrowers, along with India. It borrowed $1.35 billion in the 12 months that ended last June 30. Since then it has borrowed $140 million. The new loan will go largely for planting trees in 15 Chinese provinces. China can take 40 years to repay it at less than 1 percent interest a year. Within a week after tanks went into Tiananmen Square, bank President Barber Conable delayed loans to China worth $780 million, though he continued disbursing loans granted previously. President Bush then asked that new loans be withheld but later said they should be granted only for basic human needs. Robert Levine, a spokesman for the Treasury, said after Tuesday's board decision that the forestry loan qualified under that definition because it provides jobs, fuel and housing material for low-income farmers. It is part of a $500 million project, for which China itself will provide the other $200 million. Conable has said repeatedly that the bank makes its loans only on economic grounds, with no attention to politics. The bank spokesman, Peter Riddleberger, said another loan _ $150 million for roads and waterways in China _ was indefinitely postponed at Tuesday's meeting. He added that the postponement was asked by one of the 22 executive directors, whom he declined to identify except to say he was not the U.S. representative. The prospect of the two loans brought a sharp protest from congressmen, including Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the House Banking Committee. In a letter last week to Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, Gonzalez said granting the loans would endanger the prospect of new money for World Bank help to the poorest countries, and for eastern Europe. ``We expect that the political atmosphere in the Congress will be poisoned to the point of making thorough analysis and consideration on the merits of these important initiatives extremely difficult,'' Gonzalez wrote. He said that under U.S. law, Coady should vote against the loans and try to persuade other governments' directors to do the same. The letter was also signed by Rep. David R. Obey, D-Wis., who chairs the foreign operations subcommittee of the Appropriations Committee and Delegate Walter Fauntroy, D-D.C., head of Gonzalez' subcommittee on international development bodies.

DOC.HEAD: US Says Reports Indicate Tibetan Prisoners Being Tortured
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said Tuesday it has received numerous reports of torture by Chinese authorities in Tibet, and it called on China to take effective measures to guard against such abuses. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said the reports received by U.S. officials were similar to those contained in a study by Asia Watch, a privatehuman rights group. The report said the incidence of serious torture in Tibet ``is at least as bad as it has been for years, and in some cases worse.'' Some officials have suggested China's decision to lift martial law in Tibet a month ago was aimed at encouraging the Bush administration not to revoke trade privileges for China. Ignoring appeals from some members of Congress, President Bush announced last week that China's most-favored-nation trade status would be retained. About two weeks after martial law was lifted, a U.S. consular official visited Tibet to review the human rights situation there. It was the first visit of its kind since martial law was imposed, and Ms. Tutwiler expressed hope that such visits will be permitted in the future. ``Renewed diplomatic access will enable us to monitor the situation in Tibet more directly and to raise human rights concerns with officials there, she said. The administration also hopes the lifting of martial law ``will lead to further easing of tensions and the release of those imprisoned for peaceful expression of political views,'' she added. The Asia Watch report said there is no indication that the lifting of martial law has led to the release of any political prisoners. China regards Tibet as an integral part of Chinese territory but many Tibetans favor independence.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Guerrilla Killed in South Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: A radical Palestinian guerrilla group said Tuesday one of its fighters was killed in a clash with Israeli-backed militiamen in south Lebanon. In a brief communique released in this southern port, the Palestine Liberation Front said a second fighter was missing after a clash Monday with militiamen of the South Lebanon Army. U.N. soldiers said Monday they believed the guerrilla was killed when Israeli forces attacked a hillside 1\ miles north of Israel's security zone with mortar and helicopter gunship fire. Israel's self-declared security zone is a strip two miles to 10 miles wide that Israel set up after withdrawing the bulk of its invasion forces from Lebanon in 1985. The zone is patrolled by Israeli troops and the estimated 2,500-member Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army militia. The guerrilla communique said the fighters clashed with South Lebanon Army militiamen near the southern town of Bint Jbeil, in the western sector of the security zone. On Saturday, the Israeli-backed militiamen killed four guerrillas from the Marxist Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine who infiltrated into the zone.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms On Plains, Heavy Rain In East
DOC.TEXT: Storms rolled across the Plains on Tuesday, heavy rain was scattered over the upper Ohio Valley and Eastern Seaboard, and frosty air settled around Lake Superior. Showers and thunderstorms washed across the Texas Panhandle, western and central Oklahoma, western and central Kansas, western Nebraska, southwestern South Dakota, southern Wyoming, Colorado and much of New Mexico. Several funnel clouds that did not touch down were reported in east-central New Mexico, the National Weather Service said. One twister did touch down, near the tiny town of Taiban in the rural DeBaca County, but it didn't do any damage, said Kathy West, city clerk at Fort Sumner, N.M. She said the tornado headed toward Taiban, which has only a post office and a few families, but it lifted back up into the clouds before it reached the community. Hail three-quarters of an inch in diameter fell near Milnesand, N.M., the weather service said. Funnel clouds and tornadoes also appeared over metropolitan Denver as a cold, wet storm system crossed Colorado, triggering hail, heavy rainfall and street flooding. But there were no reports of injuries and only minor property damage was reported. Rain also fell across central and southern New England, New York state, Pennsylvania, eastern Ohio, much of West Virginia, Maryland and northern Virginia. Showers and thunderstorms also developed along North Carolina's northern coast and showers were scattered across southern Florida. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 1.73 inches at Wilmington, Del.; 1.63 inches at Dover, Del.; 1.50 inches at Millville, N.J.; 1.45 inches at Atlantic City, N.J.; 1.13 inches at Willow Grove, Pa.; and 1.08 inches at Patuxent River, Md. In the West, rain and showers extended from northeastern Nevada into south-central and western Montana. Overnight temperatures early Tuesday reached the mid 30s near Lake Superior, and an advisory for frost and freezing temperatures into Wednesday morning was issued for Upper Michigan and a section of northern Lower Michigan. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 45 at Yellowstone National Park, Wyo., to 95 at both Avon Park and Daytona Beach, Fla. Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 32 at Flagstaff, Ariz.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Meets With Scholars, Execs in Super Bowl Atmosphere
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites b0482, which moved on May 25 and is for release for Wednesday AMs, to UPDATE with Gorbachev's visit to Hoover canceled. No pickup
DOC.BYLINE: With AM-Summit Rdp, Bjt ^By STEVE WILSTEIN
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev may be eager to play ``Let's Make A Deal'' when he meets with West Coast executives next week, but he's likely to be confronted by plenty of skepticism. Gorbachev, beleaguered at home by rising prices and bare shelves, is going West in search of high-tech products, entrepreneurial expertise and long-term business relations after his summit talks with President Bush. Gorbachev's June 4 luncheon with executives of 150 businesses based in California, Oregon and Washington state is ``more than a public relations gesture,'' said Bill Johnston, Palo Alto-based Hewlett-Packard Co.'s director of international planning and administration. ``He is clearly wooing the West, and certainly this area. He's trying to get his economy squared away and attract U.S. manufacturing expertise to the Soviet Union.'' Hewlett-Packard has had an office in Moscow for 18 years, and last week joined four other U.S. companies in a consortium with three Soviet health and medical research ministries. ``There are a lot of problems,'' Johnston said. ``The currency is a major issue. There is still considerable political and economic uncertainty, and the two are interlocked. They have a mess on their hands.'' But despite worries about doing business in the Soviet Union, Gorbachev's visit has charged the Bay area with a Super Bowl atmosphere, sending corporate executives scrambling for a chance to dine with him at a business luncheon _ some willing to pay thousands of dollars for a ticket. Fifteen companies co-sponsoring the event are paying $2,000 for two seats each, and up to $500 for additional seats. Labor leaders are complaining they may be left out. Phone lines are jammed at the Soviet consulate, Stanford University, the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce and City Hall. T-shirts with Gorbachev's image and tackier souvenirs _ a ``Communist Party Animal'' T-shirt _ already are on sale, and billboards are planned to welcome the Soviet leader in the city and on the highways. ``This may even exceed the Super Bowl,'' predicted Stanford spokesman Joel Shurkin, who said the university had been bombarded with requests by 5,000 reporters to cover Gorbachev's speech at the 1,700-seat Memorial Auditorium. A lottery is planned to determine who gets to go, with preference to Stanford faculty and students. Silicon Valley is experiencing a ``Gorbasm,'' said Mark Muchnik, president of Global Development Corp., who has organized a Soviet Silicon Summit to encourage high-tech trade between the countries. Raisa Gorbachev's planned visit to an Oakland-based program that helps Soviet children doomed by heart defects, and the possibility that she'll visit some of the area's big tourist attractions, has sparked more excitement. ``Lots of people have invited her ... institutions, hospitals, homes,'' said Charlotte Mailliard Swig, San Francisco's chief of protocol. Armenians, Latvians, Estonians and Lithuanians are planning protests, some coming from hundreds of miles away to register complaints about Soviet policies. At Gorbachev's request, the companies at the business luncheon will represent a variety of industries _ telecommunications, computers, agribusiness, food processing, construction, oil, banking, hotels and tourism. Gorbachev's aides chose the companies from a list submitted by the Chamber of Commerce, which is co-host of the luncheon with Mayor Art Agnos and California Gov. George Deukmejian. ``The Soviets have an interest in positioning the Asian part of their country as a Pacific Rim player,'' said Carol Piasente, spokeswoman for the Chamber of Commerce. ``The purpose of this luncheon is to build a relationship between the West Coast companies and the Far Eastern part of the Soviet Union.'' In addition to Hewlett-Packard, other companies with longstanding ties to the Soviet Union who will be represented at the luncheon are AT&T, BankAmerica and Chevron. Rep. Tom Campbell, R-Calif., said the Soviets have ``a desperate need'' for computers, fax machines, modems and other high-tech office equipment that are attracting them to Silicon Valley. And the interest is mutual. ``We are very concerned about losing one of the largest markets we'll ever see,'' said Campbell, who fears European and Asian companies will swoop in on the Soviets if American firms move too slowly. ``I don't see any risk to our defense and I do see economic benefits. One of the great dreams is we'll be so integrated economically that nobody would benefit from an attack,'' he said. At Stanford, Gorbachev had been expected to visit the Hoover Institution, a campus think tank and longtime bastion of anti-communism with ties to the Reagan and Bush administrations. Stanford officials said Tuesday that Gorbachev would skip Hoover because he felt his ``schedule was too tight.'' Others speculated that the visit was simply too controversial. ``The Russian ambassador made it very clear that the president really wanted to spend time with students and faculty,'' and that Gorbachev could not do that if he also stopped at Hoover, said Robert Freelen, Stanford's vice president for public affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Bucharest Mayor Announces Plans to Clear Square, End Protest
DOC.TEXT: The mayor of Bucharest announced Tuesday that authorities would clear the city's main square of anti-Communist protesters by morning. One demonstrator urged friends and relatives to come to the square. About 150 protesters remained in University Square on a cold and rainy night, continuing a 38-day-old protest that demands former high-ranking Communists be banned from holding public office for 10 years. The government, led by President Ion Iliescu, a former Communist official, has rejected the demand. In a statement read on state television, Mayor Dan Predescu said his office decided ``to take due measures to open traffic'' in University Square because the lengthy blocade has blocked one of the city's main thoroughfares and because of the numerous requests from local people. He said the area would be cleared by morning. One protester urged friends and relatives of those remaining to come to square to maintain the blockade. Octavian Radulescu, a member of the Association of Former Political Detainees, said he would use his car to ram the first security vehicle that approaches. The government earlier said it would do everything possible to stop the hunger strike by 11 anti-Communist demonstrators living in a tent camp on the square. Some have been fasting for four weeks. Demonstrators have remained split on ending their occupation. Six key groups in the square, concerned the hunger strikers might die, have decided to switch to weekly protests. The Group for Social Dialogue, Romania's leading intellectuals, backed them saying the demonstrators had won ``a moral victory'' and they didn't want the hunger strikers to suffer any more. But other groups have vowed to remain in the square because the government has rejected their proposed ban on ex-Communists in office. The demonstrators say the first to be banned should be Iliescu, an ex-Communist Party Politburo member, who they accuse of rigging the general election May 20, in which he won a landslide victory. Since the protest started April 22, several attempts to start a dialogue between the protesters and government officials have failed. The government has called the protest unacceptable. Iliescu announced he wanted to clear the square before the election, but Prime Minister Petre Roman later said the demonstrators could remain. Iliescu is leader of the National Salvation Front, a broad group that served as an interim government following the ouster of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu in a popular uprising in December. Iliescu fell from favor with Ceausescu and became a critic of the dictatorship. Ion Neamtiu, president of an association named for the Dec. 16-21 uprising, pledged to keep his members in the square ``until the final victory.'' ``Our democracy is like a frail baby and needs somebody to take care of it,'' he said Sunday. ``Our retreat from the square would mean we are renouncing the fight for a real democracy. I'm asking all the Western governments not to help Romania's new neo-Communist leaders ... (who have) stolen our revolution and the elections.''

DOC.HEAD: Israelis Shout Anti-Arab Chants, Stone Cars After Bomb Attack
DOC.TEXT: Angry Israeli youths shouting ``Death to the Arabs!'' stoned Palestinians' cars Tuesday after the funeral of a 72-year-old Israeli killed in the bombing of a Jerusalem market. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir appealed for calm. Two Palestinian groups claimed responsibility for Monday's bomb attack in telephone calls to news agencies. The stone throwing occurred despite a heavy police presence aimed at preventing anti-Arab violence during the funeral. Police dispersed the protesters after about 90 minutes. About a dozen Arab cars were stoned and some had their windows shattered, but there were no reports of injuries. The stonings began about 15 minutes after a procession of several hundred Israelis went to the cemetery to bury the victim of the pipe bomb attack. Six of the nine Israelis injured in the bombing remain hospitalized, Israel radio said. Shamir, visiting the injured, appealed for calm. ``It has to be a concern of all the people living in this area to see to it that reason prevails,'' he said. One victim, Miriam Dadya, 57, struck in the chest and legs with shrapnel, told Shamir repeatedly, ``I want to see peace, let there be peace.'' Shamir replied: ``So do we all.'' Since the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation began 29 months ago, 712 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis. Forty-four Israelis also have died. In one anonymous call to a Western news agency in Jerusalem, a man who spoke in Arabic claimed responsibility for Monday's bombing in the name of the Islamic Jihad fundamentalist group. The caller said the bombing was in revenge for the May 20 massacre of seven Arab laborers by an Israeli gunman, who authorities said went berserk. ``Israel still doesn't understand any other language except fire and steel,'' the caller said. Islamic Jihad also claimed responsibility for the Feb. 4 attack on a tourist bus in Egypt in which nine Israelis died and 21 were wounded. On Monday, a Syrian-backed Palestinian guerrilla group that broke with the Palestine Liberation Organization also claimed responsibility for the bombing. PLO chairman Yasser Arafat demanded last week that a U.N. force be stationed in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip to protect the 1.7 million Palestinians living there. An Israeli Foreign Ministry official, requesting anonymity, left open the possibility that Israel would allow a U.N. delegation to visit Palestinians in the occupied territories, but only if it did not deal with security issues. Foreign Ministry officials told reporters Monday that Israel had in the past accepted personal envoys of the U.N. secretary-general. ``If there will be a request for a secretary-general envoy who will not deal with security, then it will be judged on its merits,'' said the official. ``We are not saying yes, not saying no.''
