DOC.HEAD: CBS Seeks TV Comeback, Fox Expands Schedule To Five Nights
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 15th graf, `CBS' new ...' to CORRECT title of show to `Four Alarm Family' sted of `Four Alarm Fire.'
DOC.HEAD: With BC-TV-Fall Schedules-List
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: CBS, trying to battle back from three seasons as third in evening TV ratings, said Tuesday it will have nine new series next fall. Fox Broadcasting said it'll go to a five-night-a-week schedule. Fox also said it is moving the hit ``The Simpsons'' to head-on Thursday competition with NBC's ``The Cosby Show.'' And Fox's shows will air on Thursdays-through Mondays. It had been expected to add Wednesdays and Fridays to its current Saturday-through-Monday lineup. Fox, which also said it would air a new Sunday sitcom about an interracial marriage called ``True Colors,'' announced nine new series. To make room, it axed one of its original series, ``21 Jump Street,'' and such others as ``Alien Nation,'' ``Booker,'' and ``The Outsiders.'' CBS' new lineup, which includes a comic-book hero and an action series whose heroes fight polluters, was described by CBS Entertainment president Jeff Sagansky as a starting move in the network's road to ratings recovery. ``This is a strong first step in the process of rebuilding our prime time lineup,'' said Sagansky. The schedule, his first full one since CBS hired him last fall, revamps all nights but Tuesday and Sunday. It also gives CBS four nights of comedies. The goal, he told CBS affiliates in a closed-circuit hookup, is to attract younger viewers and more family viewing in the 8 p.m. EDT time period. Speaking with reporters here later, he discounted suggestions that CBS' new schedule is not as unconventional as ABC's and CBS'. It's the way a show is done, not the idea for it, that makes it succeed, he said: ``What makes a show unconventional is the way it's executed, not cops singing or whatever is behind `Twin Peaks.' '' CBS' roster includes five new hour-long series; four new sitcoms and a comedy once on NBC, ``The Hogan Family.'' It also has a pre-cable movie package of such hits as ``Born on the Fourth of July'' and ``Do The Right Thing.'' The low-rated ``Saturday Night With Connie Chung'' will move to Mondays with a different format and name _ ``Face to Face With Connie Chung.'' Two test runs of the new version got high ratings during the May ratings sweeps. But CBS axed the Vietnam War series ``Tour of Duty,'' the venerable ``Falcon Crest,'' whose demise was announced last week, and such far newer ones as ``The Famous Teddy Z,'' ``City'' and ``Sydney.'' However, Sagansky said ``Paradise'' may be renewed. ``Wiseguy'' now is in backup status, he added, with Ken Wahl to return in the first few episodes, then be succeeded by Stephen Bauer, who would play a new undercover agent. CBS' new sitcoms are the movie spinoff ``Uncle Buck,'' the blue-collar ``Lenny,'' ``Four Alarm Family,'' about a widowed firefighter with four kids, and ``Evening Shade,'' starring Burt Reynolds as an ex-football star who moves his family back to the small Arkansas town of his boyhood. Edward Woodward of CBS' late ``The Equalizer'' will return in the hour-long ``Over My Dead Body'' as a burnt-out novelist paired with a young obituary writer played by Jessica Lundy. CBS' other new hour-long entries are ``The Flash,'' based on the comic book crime-fighter; ``WIOU,'' about the cutthroat world of local TV, and ``The Hammersmiths,'' a family drama with Lucie Arnaz. There also will be ``The Green Machine,'' the first network drama in which the good guys battle those who would harm planet Earth. In addition to ``True Colors,'' Fox's other sitcoms are ``Parker Lewis Can't Lose,'' about high school life; ``Get a Life,'' starring Chris Elliott as a 30-year-old newspaper delivery boy; ``Good Grief,'' about undertaking; and ``Babes,'' about three sisters in a cramped New York apartment. There also is a half-hour serious series, ``American Chronicles,'' by Mark Frost and David Lynch, creators of ``Twin Peaks,'' and an hour series of various video projects, ``Fox Video Hour.'' The other new hour-long series are ``Class of Beverly Hills,'' about a Midwestern family moving to Southern California; ``D.E.A.,'' about exploits of the Drug Enforcement Administration, and ``Against the Law,'' about an unconventional trial lawyer. Fox also added a two-hour Monday movie night, ``Fox Night at the Movies.'' Fox says it has 129 affiliates, compared with the more than 200 each of CBS, NBC and ABC. But it isn't officially considered a network yet by the Federal Communications Commission. Its expansion this fall was made possible by a one-year FCC waiver that lets it broadcast 18{ hours a week of prime-time programming without being subject to restrictions that bar CBS, NBC and ABC from the lucrative syndication business.

DOC.HEAD: Infant Formula Manufacturers Criticized
DOC.TEXT: Three companies use their nearly total control of the infant formula market to keep prices high and rebates to state-run programs for poor children low, two federal lawmakers said Tuesday. Industry officials said their prices were fair. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, accused the companies that control the market of participating in a ``follow-the-leader'' system of matching a competitor's price increases. ``American women may have been paying millions of dollars more than they should for infant formula because there is no price competition,'' he said at a hearing of the antitrust, monopolies and business rights subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee. Mead Johnson, Ross Laboratories and Wyeth Laboratories make about 90 percent of the infant formula sold in the United States. Representatives of state-operated Women, Infants and Children programs, which provide formula for babies of poor women, said most additional federal money meant to add participants is being spent on expensive formula. ``The funds that Congress intended for helping more infants are contributing to healthy profits for manufacturers,'' said Betsy Clarke, director of Oregon's WIC program. WIC mothers receive monthly vouchers to buy a particular brand of formula from a grocery store, which is reimbursed by WIC. The state contracts to receive a rebate from the manufacturer. More than 1.3 million women participate in the 16-year-old program. Advocates complained that the companies are offering lower and lower rebates. But Rolland Eckels of Bristol Myers in Evansville, Ind., whose Mead Johnson subsidiary manufactures Enfamil, said his company paid more than a half-billion dollars in rebates last year. He said companies submit rebate offers in sealed bids based on the state's population and other factors. John Kane, president of Columbus, Ohio-based Ross Laboratories, said he'd like to see additional incentives for breast feeding built into the program and development of ``a number of administrative controls'' to help ensure its effectiveness. Ross markets Similac. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said in a written statement that infant formula price increases over the last 10 years have been 10 times more than increases for groceries. Eckels, whose company was not represented at the hearing, said it's unfair to compare rises in formula and grocery costs. ``Infant formula is manufactured under conditions that are health industry standards,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``Infant formula is not just something that is thrown together.'' Both Kane and Eckels said their companies put much of the profit from formula back into research. He said Ross spent more than $500 million last year on research and product development, with much of the money invested in special formulas for ``extremely premature'' babies and those born with rare metabolism problems. Officials of Wyeth Laboratories did not return calls seeking comment.

DOC.HEAD: House Members Took in Millions for Talking Off the Job in 1989
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with more reports; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: With BC-House Finances-List
DOC.TEXT: Special interests paid nearly $600,000 last year for speeches by a half-dozen top leaders in the House. Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the tax-writing committee, took in the most with $285,000, according to financial disclosure reports made public Tuesday. Rank-and-file members shared in the speechmaking windfall to supplement their $89,500 salaries. All told, House members accepted millions of dollars for speaking and writing, and many got more for talking than the average family earns in a year. The flow of speaking fees, mostly from special interests that ranged from colleges to banks, was hardly slowed by the allegations of financial improprieties that led last year to the resignations of Speaker Jim Wright, D-Texas, and Rep. Tony Coelho, D-Calif., the majority whip. Wright's successor, Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., reported he received $32,000 in honoraria. Coelho's successor, Rep. William Gray, D-Pa., claimed $164,098. Foley's successor as majority leader, Rep. Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., reported $34,500. Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., was the top talk-for-pay lawmaker outside the leadership, with $160,517. House members are allowed to keep honoraria equivalent to 30 percent of their salaries and most give what is left to charity. Rostenkowski traditionally spreads the excess among churches and schools in his hometown of Chicago. Republican Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia handed over $29,304 of his $67,491 in fees to the Atlanta zoo. The disclosure statements of most House members were made public Tuesday, although some lawmakers were granted extensions. Senators' reports will be released Wednesday. Speaking and writing fees were not the only source of outside income for members of the House, which has dozens of millionaires. One of the wealthiest, Rep. Amory Houghton, R-N.Y., an heir to the Corning Glass Works fortune, received $127,000 last year for managing family trusts. Rep. Don Sundquist, R-Tenn., listed dividends of $5,000 to $15,000 from his stake in a popular barbecue restaurant, Red, Hot `n Blue, in Arlington, Va. Rep. Ronald Machtley, R-R.I., earned interest by lending money to his own campaign committee. Rep. Dante Fascell, D-Fla., who heads the Foreign Affairs Committee, pocketed a $24,000 salary from his law firm, $11,913 in Social Security benefits and as much as $15,000 from his stake in a thoroughbred horse breeding operation. Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., who is under investigation by the House ethics committee because of his association with a male prostitute, was paid between $15,000 and $50,000 as an advance on a book he is writing. Rep. Ben Jones, D-Ga., an actor who played on the old ``Dukes of Hazzard'' show, received a $10,625 advance for his autobiography. Another ex-actor, Rep. Fred Grandy, R-Iowa, earned $26,219 in royalties from his tour on the ``Love Boat'' series. Rep. J. Howard Coble, R-N.C., won $600 in a congressional pinball tournament and donated it to charities in his district. Rep. Curtis Weldon, R-Pa., who once helped extinguish a fire in a House office building, was reimbursed for expenses of 19 speaking trips to fire-fighting organizations in 16 states last year. He received no fees for those speeches. Weldon is a founder of the congressional fire-prevention caucus. Rep. Chester Atkins, D-Mass., earned $17,307 as chairman of the Massachusetts State Democratic Committee. Rep. Stan Parris, R-Va., sold a 1948 Chrysler roadster for something between $15,000 and $50,000. Rep. Ben Nighthorse Campbell, D-Colo., earned nearly $14,000 designing Indian jewelry. Rep. Herbert Callahan, D-Ala., was paid $12,000 in director's fees from the Finch Companies. Although Democrats, who control the House, were paid the most for their speechmaking, Republicans shared in the wealth. Republican Leader Robert Michel of Illinois reported $49,300. Rep. Jerry Lewis of California, who heads the House Republican Conference, was paid $31,000. As part of a bill raising their government salaries, House members agreed that 1990 will be the last year they will receive honoraria. Senators will allow themselves lower government salaries than House members after this year but will keep their speaking fees. In addition to their speaking fees and other honoraria, members of Congress and most other federal officials are required to disclose their assets, not including their homes; their investments, most liabilities and gifts. The forms require that values be listed only by broad category. For example, a multimillion-dollar holding is reported only as worth more than $250,000. Some members are more precise. Rep. William Natcher, D-Ky., whose seniority and Appropriations Committee position make him one of the most powerful House members, listed no speaking fees, no gifts, no liabilities, no investment transactions and no membership in any organization. He listed nine properties valued at $144,978 from which he collected $4,200 in rent, and the $4,131 savings account that earned $212 interest. Not all are so lucky in their finances. Rep. Tommy F. Robinson, R-Ark., who switched parties last year, listed among his liabilities more than $250,000 he owes Jerral W. Jones, owner of the Dallas Cowboys. Jones' daughter left a $60,000-a-year job on Robinson's staff last year after the congressman and Jones had a falling out over Robinson's plans to run for governor. Rep. Doug Barnard, D-Ga., reported assets of between zero and $5,000 with no liabilities. On the other hand, Gephardt, who sold rental homes in Missouri last year, had no liabilities but assets of as much as $915,000. Rep. William Green, R-N.Y., an heir to the Grand Union food stores, reported one of the highest 1989 incomes among House members, at least $507,857 and perhaps as much as $1.26 million. His campaign committee returned to him between $100,000 and $250,000 of personal funds he had invested in his 1984 re-election effort.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon: Trident Weapon Meets Safety Standards
DOC.TEXT: The nuclear-tipped Trident II missile designed for the Trident submarine meets safety standards, but a study is under way to determine whether there are ways to make them safer, a Pentagon spokesman said Tuesday. ``The Trident (missile), in its present design, meets all current safety requirements'' of both the Department of Defense and the Department of Energy, Bob Hall told reporters. He was questioned about a report in The Washington Post that said the design of the W-88 warhead on the Trident D-5 missile concerns experts at the three U.S. nuclear weapons laboratories. Only one Trident submarine, the USS Tennessee, has been deployed with the D-5 missiles that carry the W-88 warheads. The report said experts are concerned about a possible missile explosion that could result in the release of plutonium. The experts have been using computer studies to see if their fears have foundation, the report said, but so far their studies have found ``no firm basis for such a possible accident.'' The report said the concern lies in the design of the missile, which has three-stages. The missile contains its most explosive rocket fuel in a cylinder at the center of its uppermost stage, and the fuel is surrounded by eight thermonuclear warheads. Because of the need for continued study, Energy Secretary James Watkins has ordered a special report on the cost and feasibility of redesigning the warhead, the report said. Hall would say only that ``a study of all weapons including the W-88, is being conducted.'' He said the study was ``looking at the safety of all our nuclear warheads.'' ``As technology changes, and there are things you can do to make them safer, you make them safer,'' Hall said.

DOC.HEAD: Lebanese Demonstrate to Demand End to War
DOC.TEXT: More than 100,000 people demonstrated throughout Lebanon on Tuesday, chanting anti-war slogans and demanding an end to the nation's civil strife. Also Tuesday, a major labor union issued an unprecedented call for a strike against warring leaders. In Beirut, tens of thousands of demonstrators waved loaves of bread and Lebanese currency banknotes. They chanted, ``We are hungry, we are thirsty! No, no, no to war!'' In the past two years, bread prices have increased 250 percent while the Lebanese pound has lost more than half its value. Earlier, the warring Christian forces of Gen. Michel Aoun and militia chieftain Samir Geagea fought a two-hour duel with mortars in east Beirut. No casualties were reported. The exchange reflected the fragility of a 12-day-old cease-fire in the confrontation beteen Geagea and Aoun. The two have been fighting four months for control of the Christian enclave northeast of Beirut. The showdown has killed at least 1,035 people and wounded 2,770 since it broke out Jan. 30. It has inflicted an estimated $1 billion damage, adding an extra burden to Lebanon's shattered economy. ``Moslems and Christians starve alike. Moslems and Christians die alike,'' demonstrator chanted as they gathered near the government house in west Beirut. In its first such move since the civil war broke out in 1975, the General Federation of Labor Unions told Lebanese: ``Let's strike against the leaders of this war.'' `It's our natural right to demand an end to the war. We want state authority spread over the whole of Lebanon,'' federation President Antoine Beshara told a demonstration in the Christian port of Jounieh, north of Beirut. The demonstrators applauded and sang the national anthem. Police said demonstrations in Beirut, Jounieh, the southern provincial capital of Sidon, the northern town of Tripoli and the ancient town of Baalbek in the eastern Bekaa Valley ended peacefully. The strike was observed in Moslem regions as well as in Israel's self-proclaimed ``security zone'' of south Lebanon. But the work stoppage was reported in only 60 percent of the enclave controlled by Geagea's militia. Aoun's civil administration agency, the National Coordination Bureau, declared Tuesday ``a normal working day,'' and said the strike was not a positive way to combat soaring prices.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Gives Princesses Equal Right to Throne
DOC.TEXT: Parliament amended the constitution on Tuesday to allow princesses the same rights as princes to inherit the crown, news reports said. The former constitution said a male child should inherit the throne, even if he has an older sister. ``A basic attitude in Norwegian society today is that men and women have equal rights and duties,'' Jan Petersen of the Conservative Party told the NTB news agency. ``I see it as self-evident that this should include the right to inherit the throne,'' he said. The amendment affects children born after 1990. Crown Prince Harald and his son Prince Haakon Magnus will still be able to ascend to the throne, even though they have older sisters.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Postpones U.S. Trip Until After Mandela's
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk said Tuesday that he has delayed his visit to the United States after complaints by black nationalist groups that he would be upstaging Nelson Mandela. Neither the White House nor the South African government had announced a date for the meeting with President Bush, but it had reportedly been set for June 18. The African National Congress and others complained a meeting with de Klerk would be a snub to Mandela, the ANC leader, who is due to arrive in the United States on June 20. De Klerk, in a statement, said: ``Due to a controversy that has arisen in the United States as regards the possible timing of my visit in June, and also because certain important matters would require my personal attention during the next few weeks, I have decided to postpone my visit to the United States.'' In Washington, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said de Klerk notified U.S. officials, who ``are ready to see him whenever he wants.'' He said the change of schedule ``will have no impact'' on Mandela's visit. Fitzwater said he was aware of the controversy over whether de Klerk or Mandela visits first, but said the White House had not ``tried to guide them.'' ``We are willing to see either gentleman, at any time,'' he said. De Klerk and Mandela have said they don't care which one meets with Bush first. But many ANC representatives and some black American leaders have said Bush should not meet with de Klerk at all until South Africa's apartheid system is dismantled. It has been more than 30 years since a South African head of government has visited the United States. In the province of Natal, South African police on Tuesday reported a renewed outbreak of violence. They said 16 people had died the previous 24 hours, including a a 14-year-old girl reported to have been dragged from her home by a mob and raped before being beaten to death. Fighting between black factions in Natal's townships has killed more than 4,000 people since 1986. Mandela has criticized de Klerk's handling of Natal, saying the government has not done enough to stem the violence. The South African president returned Saturday from an 18-day visit to nine European nations, where he met with leaders and explained his plans to end apartheid and give the voteless black majority a voice in running the government.

DOC.HEAD: Negotiators Struggling in Final Hours Before US-Soviet Summit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs before last graf pvs, bgng, On another front xxx etc., to UPDATE with U.S. officials voicing doubt a trade pact will be signed.
DOC.TEXT: Lagging U.S.-Soviet talks to cut troops and tanks in Europe got a pre-summit boost Tuesday but a half-dozen tough strategic weapons issues remained unsettled as negotiators pressed against a fast-approaching deadline. The talks, held for a third day under tight secrecy at the State Department, focused on the two main arms control areas _ U.S. and Soviet conventional forces in Europe and the two superpowers' arsenals of globe-girdling nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines. Two days before opening his summit with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, President Bush met with leaders of the Pentagon, State Department and CIA for an update on deep economic and political troubles in the Soviet Union. The only non-summit appointment on Bush's schedule was the presentation of diplomatic credentials from new ambassadors, including Aleksandr Bessmertnykh of the Soviet Union. Gorbachev, meanwhile, arrived in Ottawa for a 29-hour visit and talks with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. ``This is a time of dramatic change in the world,'' the Soviet president said after escorting his wife, Raisa, from their Ilyushin 62 aircraft. The Soviet leader, appearing tired after a long flight, expressed hope for ``a new level of cooperation.'' Commenting on political developments back home, Gorbachev told reporters he was ``somewhat concerned'' by Boris N. Yeltsin's victory over Gorbachev's own candidate in parliamentary elections for the presidency of Russia. But he also said Yeltsin had had to ``adjust his position quite seriously over the past few days and has adjusted to the better.'' On Capitol Hill in Washington, Senate Republican leader Bob Dole said Gorbachev was in a much weaker position than when he last visited, 2{ years ago. ``Bush has 1,000 points of light, and Gorbachev has 1,000 problems,'' Dole said, alluding to shortages of consumer goods, ethnic unrest and Yeltsin's political ascent. ``We'll be watching closely,'' Dole quipped. ``If Gorbachev brings more than two bags, he may be staying.'' Gorbachev will arrive in Washington Wednesday evening and begin three days of talks on Thursday. Thousands of demonstrators already are on hand, ready to express anger over Soviet coercion of Lithuania and to voice demands for causes ranging from a Palestinian homeland and democracy in Vietnam to a unified Korea and a cure for AIDS. Security forces were beefed up to keep control. ``No days off and extended shifts,'' said Maj. Carl Holmberg of the U.S. Park Police. The number of security agents was kept secret, but Soviet spokesman Vladimir Ustimenko said, ``It will be a big bunch of people with big guns.'' While there was no announcement from the arms negotiations, U.S. officials reported progress on one front and continuing difficulties on the other. The ``good news,'' a U.S. official told The Associated Press, was that the two sides had agreed on definitions for such conventional weapons as tanks and armored personnel carriers. The issue is one of several holding up a treaty to cut most weapons by at least 50 percent and to set new and lower ceilings on U.S. and Soviet troops. The Bush administration had accused the Soviets of foot-dragging before Gorbachev sent Deputy Prime Minister Viktor P. Karpov and other experienced negotiators here for pre-summit talks that began on Sunday. The agreement on defining the weapons not only will facilitate cutting weapons stockpiles but will make it easier to verify that terms of the treaty are carried out, the officials said. On the other hand, the two sides remained in disagreement over several long-range nuclear weapons. The officials said those weapons may be excluded from a declaration Bush and Gorbachev are expected to make. The issues include whether to ban ballistic missiles with multiple warheads and the number of flight tests the Soviets could conduct of their heavy SS-18 missiles. The arsenal of such missiles is to be halved, from 308 to 154, but there is no agreement restricting improvement in the missiles that remain. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, in talks two weeks ago in Moscow, proposed two flight tests a year. But the Soviet negotiators led by Karpov did not accept the quota in their talks with the U.S. group headed by Under Secretary Reginald Bartholomew, the U.S. officials said. The lack of progress in the current talks will not keep Bush and Gorbachev from a declaration at the summit pledging wholesale cutbacks in long-range nuclear arms. Baker's trip to Moscow produced a breakthrough on sea and air-launched cruise missiles, setting the stage for a summit announcement that most major issues had been resolved. Yet, a senior administration official played down the importance of arms agreements, saying the real significance of the meeting would be face-to-face discussions on disputes over Germany unity and Soviet action against Lithuania. ``I'd urge you ... to put away your scorecard on this one about who's winning and who's losing, about what agreements are signed and trying to enumerate them,'' the official told a standing-room-only briefing at the White House. He commented only on condition of anonymity. There were conflicting signals about movement toward the signing of a U.S.-Soviet agreement on trade, a condition for Moscow receiving most-favored-nation trade status. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater refused to rule out the possibility of an accord, although the senior administration official said an agreement was linked to a U.S. demand for a law protecting Jewish emigration, as well as to U.S. unhappiness over Soviet pressure on Lithuania. Details on a new trade agreement were completed last week but Bush may delay signing the accord. ``We would like to go ahead,'' the State Department said in a brief press notice. ``...The situation in Lithuania, however, cannot help but influence the final decision on the subject.'' The statement referred to the partial economic boycott the Soviets have imposed on Lithuania to try to force a slow-down in a drive for independence in the Baltic Republic. On another front, Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said a new commercial air travel agreement was initialed on Monday and could be ready for signing at the summit. It will more than triple air service between the two countries, vastly increasing Soviet ticket purchases, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Moreno to Succeed Hastings in Florida Judgeship
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Tuesday he will nominate Federico A. Moreno, a state circuit judge in Florida, to succeed former U.S. District Judge Alcee L. Hastings of Miami. Hastings was removed from the bench last October after his conviction by the Senate in an impeachment trial on charges of conspiring to obtain a $150,000 payoff and lying about it to a grand jury. He was the first judge ever removed after acquittal in an ordinary criminal trial. Moreno, 38 and a native of Caracas, Venezuela, has served on the Dade County Circuit Court since 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Court Freezes Defendant's Assets
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese court has frozen assets of an engineering company accused of rigging construction bids at a U.S. Navy base in Yokosuka, the Justice Department said Tuesday. The unprecedented order from the Kawasaki District Court freezes $1.6 million in assets of Hosaka Engineering Co., the department said. Under Japanese law, the granting of the order indicates that the U.S. government has shown ``a substantial likelihood'' of winning its civil suit, the department said. ``The application of pre-judgment attachments of assets is a firm and decisive action. We are gratified that the Japanese court was receptive to our request,'' Stuart M. Gerson, assistant attorney general in charge of the civil division, said in a statement. ``Today's action by the court is an important step toward ensuring free and fair trade by making it clear that all nations of the world must be bound by the same international code of business and legal conduct,'' Gerson said. Hosaka is one of 140 Japanese construction companies that had been accused by the Justice Department of rigging 250 contracts at the Yokosuka Navy base. Of those, 124 companies have paid $33.8 million to settle the claims. Hosaka is one of 16 firms that have refused to settle. ``The practice of bid-rigging in Japan has too long been a way of life in their construction industry,'' said James F. Rill, the assistant attorney general for antitrust matters.

DOC.HEAD: Baltic Leaders Say They Will Not Abide by Summit Decisions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf `Gorbachev is' to CORRECT meeting is Thursday, sted Wednesday. Picks up 4th pvs, `We do...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Yeltsin, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the Baltic republics Tuesday challenged Mikhail S. Gorbachev's authority to negotiate their fate during his talks with President Bush and said they would not be bound by decisions made at the summit. Also Tuesday, Lithuania asked Soviet officials to restore fuel supplies to a power station connected to a nuclear power plant, saying the cutoff could lead to an accident at the nuclear plant, Vilnius Radio reported. Gorbachev is scheduled to meet with Bush on Thursday at the White House. ``We do not want anything signed behind our backs or at our expense,'' President Edgar Savisaar of Estonia told a news conference in Stockholm, Sweden. He said the Baltic republics will ``not be bound by the outcome.'' The Baltic foreign ministers announced the same policy after a meeting in the Latvian capital of Riga. They also restated their rejection of the 1939 Soviet-Nazi pact that divided Central Europe into spheres of influence. Their declaration appeared in part to be an effort to ensure that the Baltic issue is not overshadowed at the summit by talks of arms control and Gorbachev's political and economic problems. The declaration, reported by the Lithuanian news service ELTA and by telex from the Baltic foreign ministries, said that as a result of the Soviet-Nazi pact, ``the three Baltic states came under Soviet military occupation during June 15-17, 1940, and subsequently were forcibly incorporated into the U.S.S.R.'' Soviet authorities say Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia violated the Soviet constitution with their steps toward independence, and Gorbachev imposed a partial embargo of oil and natural gas against Lithuania. Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene asked Soviet authorities to restore fuel supplies to a thermal power station or shut down a nuclear power plant to which it is linked, Vilnius Radio reported. She outlined the problem in a letter to Gorbachev and Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, Vilnius Radio said. ``As a result of the Soviet Union's blockade on supplies of petroleum products to Lithuania, reserves of fuel have run out at the Lithuanian thermal power station, which is a component part of the Ignalina nuclear power station,'' she wrote. The Ignalina plant supplies much of Lithuania's electricity and is controlled by Moscow-based ministries. ``The situation at the thermal power station could lead to an accident at the atomic power station. It will therefore be necessary to halt the operation of the atomic power station,'' she said. Lithuanian officials did not say how the thermal plant is connected with Ignalina's safety system. Most nuclear power plants depend on a separate power source to run their control rooms and safety systems in the event the nuclear reactors have to be shut down. Without independent power, operators might not be able to control or monitor the nuclear reactors. A shutdown of Iganlina, Prunskiene said, would cut electricity not only to Lithuania but to Kaliningrad, a region of the Russian republic that can be reached only across Lithuanian territory. Electricity is being generated at only two power plants in Lithuania _ a nuclear plant at Ignalina and the oil-burning Elektrenai station. Neither is operating at full capacity, said Radio Vilnius reporter Audrius Braukyla. He said homes were unaffected by the power cutbacks.

DOC.HEAD: Gaviria Urges Drug Barons, Rebels to Disarm
DOC.TEXT: President-elect Cesar Gaviria urged drug traffickers and leftist guerrillas on Tuesday to lay down their arms and said his election this weekend proved Colombians had rejected violence. In his first news conference, the president-elect said: ``I trust that those responsible for terrorism will understand that theirs is a blind policy, a policy of hate that was rejected by Colombians at the polls.'' Gaviria, 43, made his comments at the presidential palace after a meeting with President Virgilio Barco. Gaviria won Sunday's presidential elections with 47 percent of the vote. His closest rival, Alvaro Gomez of the National Salvation Movement, took 24 percent. The results, reported by the national elections office, are based on a count of 95 percent of the ballots. Of the four major presidential candidates, Gaviria took the toughest line against drug barons, advocating their extradition to the United States. Authorities said the traffickers stepped up terror attacks in the days preceding elections, killing 37 people and injured about 350.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Hong Kong Drug Traffickers Hanged
DOC.TEXT: Malaysia on Wednesday hanged eight Hong Kong residents convicted of drug trafficking _ its highest number of executions in a single day, prison officials said. Authorities rejected humanitarian appeals by British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and the human rights group Amnesty International. They also turned down new court efforts to block the killings of the eight, convicted of smuggling 28 pounds of heroin. Despite widespread criticism, Malaysia has said it would continue a mandatory death penalty for anyone convicted of drug trafficking. Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad says illicit drug use is Malaysia's ``No. 1 enemy'' _ with an estimated 350,000 addicts among Malaysia's 17.8 million people. Since 1975, 250 people have been sentenced to death for trafficking. Of those, 92 have been hanged, while the others are awaiting dates for hanging or appeals. Under Malaysian law, a drug trafficking conviction does not require proof of actual sale. The possession of more than a half-ounce of heroin or 3{ ounces of marijuana is deemed to be trafficking. Two of the eight were hanged in Kajang prison, 18 miles south of Kuala Lumpur, and the remainder in Taiping Prison, 150 miles north of the capital. Among those killed was 32-year-old waitress Han Tsui Ling, the first foreign woman to be hanged. Most of those executed were professionals from the British colony, and they included a company supervisor and the director of an insurance company. Police said the eight were en route to Brussels, Belgium, with the heroin in five suitcases when they were arrested in October 1982 at the Penang International Airport, 180 miles northwest of Kuala Lumpur. They were convicted in 1985, and the Supreme Court rejected their appeals last year. Wednesday's hanging of eight marked the highest number of people executed in Malaysia on the same day, prison officials said.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0695 to capitalize city in dateline
Romania Holds Post-Revolution International Bridge Tournament
DOC.TEXT: More than 200 bridge players shuffled their cards Tuesday at Romania's first international bridge festival since Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu banned the game seven years ago. Over the weekend, about 800 players from Romania, Bulgaria, the Soviet Union, Poland and France are expected to gather at Bucharest's main exhibition hall, scene of the city's annual national fair for the May 26-June 3 festival. Dragos Paun, who helped organize the event said he thinks Ceausescu banned bridge in 1983 because it brought ``Too many smart brains together,'' hinting at the former dictator's fear of opposition of any kind. But bridge referee, Victor Marculetiu, said he thought Ceausescu banned the game to separate his oldest son, Valentin, from other players. ``He used to play a lot and was an intelligent guy. He was OK. I think he does not deserve his fate,'' he said. Valentin, his brother Nicu and sister Zoe were arrested and jailed following the December revolution, in which Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were deposed and executed. Bridge fans founded the Romanian Bridge Federation in January, just weeks after the uprising, and began organizing the first competitions for its almost 4,000 members. Since January, Romanian players have disputed the European championship in Bordeaux, France, placing among the top third. They also played in a tournament of one-time Communist nations in Riga, Soviet Union, and placed second. Marina Alart of France said she came to Bucharest for the festival. ``I have found out that the Romanians play better than the French. They like to attack. Neither the Spanish nor the Belgians are so strong. Only the Germans do better,'' she said. Theodor Chimion, a former Romanian who now lives in France and also came to play said: ``I left the country in 1972. Then, I returned to Romania to work here for an Austrian company until Ceausescu forced me out in 1982. By that time I had already played 100,000 games.'' Organizers said the festival was a dress rehearsal for the National Bridge Festival, which is to resume this summer at Mamaia, on the Black Sea. ``We actually never stopped playing,'' said Marculetiu. ``Even under the ban we had our championships, although we had to meet in the players' homes illegally. We were about 200.''

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Promises New Gov't Dominated by Non-Communists
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslavia soon will form a coalition government dominated by non-Communists, Prime Minister Ante Markovic said in an interview published Tuesday. His comment was a significant step in efforts to resolve a political crisis that has paralyzed the country and eroded the fragile federation that unites its six ethnically and economically diverse republics. The daily Borba also quoted Markovic as saying he might quit the Communist Party, which has ruled Yugoslavia since 1945. Markovic was named prime minister in March 1989 by the one-party, Communist Parliament but now hopes to keep his post in a free ballot. His popularity has grown as his government has moved to halt four-digit annual inflation and make the Yugoslav currency, the dinar, convertible. His suggestions of turning his government team into a separate party have drawn fierce criticism from hard-line Communists in Serbia, Yugoslavia's largest republic, who fear losing their authority if Markovic forms a new power base. Borba quoted Markovic as saying the government will join democratic elections and ``is offering a coalition of all parties.'' Dozens of non-Communist parties have emerged in Yugoslavia in the past two years. The Zagreb daily Vjesnik, commenting Tuesday on Markovic's recent maneuvers, noted the premier has ``shrewdly entered the empty political space which has been created by the definite collapse of the Communist Party.'' The party's authority has deteriorated since the 1980 death of Communist Yugoslavia's founder, Josip Broz Tito, leaving Yugoslavia's diverse ethnic and political groups battling for power. Over the weekend, the Communist Party formally renounced its monopoly on power and agreed to multiparty elections. Borisav Jovic, a hard-line Serbian Communist who recently began a one-year term as president, said Tuesday he is sure democratic parliamentary elections will take place by December. Free elections already have taken place in the northern republics of Slovenia and Croatia, and are scheduled in all republics except Serbia by year's end. Slovenia and Croatia are now dominated by center-right parties, which advocate a looser confederal alliance for Yugoslavia's republics. They threaten to secede altogether if their demands are not met.

DOC.HEAD: Fortune Cookie King Edward Louie Dies at 69
DOC.TEXT: Edward Louie, creator of the fortune cookie folding machine and the popular risque fortune cookie, has died at age 69. Louie returned from visiting his ancestral village in China two days before his death Friday. The trip fulfilled a promise made to his mother long ago, the San Francisco Chronicle reported in Tuesday's editions. The cause of death was not immediately available. Louie gained notoriety after he invented a machine that automatically inserts the paper fortunes into the cookies as they are folded. He created the device in an effort to save his family the labor of folding thousands of cookies by hand every day. Louie was best known, however, for two marketing ploys that were tremendously successful _ the giant fortune cookie and the risque cookie. The giant fortune cookie was six inches wide and was sometimes filled with money or jewels. The risque cookie, of course, contained suggestive fortunes and jokes. Louie's parents, farmers in a village near Canton, China, emigrated to San Francisco when Louie was only 18 months old. Set on opening his own fortune cookie company, Louie opened the Lotus Fortune Cookie Co. in 1946. The entire Louie clan worked at Lotus, flipping and folding the fortune cookies with chopsticks until he invented the folding machine in 1967. The original machine is still operating today, contributing to the company's daily output of 90,000 cookies. ``To this day, nothing breaks down,'' said his son, Gregory Louie. Louie once said his business was successful because, ``nobody can resist reading their fortune, no matter how corny it is.'' Louie had not worked at the Lotus Fortune Cookie for three years. He is survived by his wife, Florence, and his three sons, Gregory, Clarence and Paul, all of San Francisco. Louie is also survived by three grandchildren, three brothers and three sisters.

DOC.HEAD: Eugenia Charles, Caribbean's `Iron Lady,' Wins 3rd Term
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Charles disappointed with narrow victory, plans to carry out development program. Pickup 3rd graf pvs, `The United...'
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Eugenia Charles, the Caribbean's first female leader, expressed disappointment Tuesday after winning a third consecutive term with a sharply reduced parliamentary majority. ``I do not call this a victory,'' the 71-year-old conservative and staunch U.S. ally said in an interview at her home outside the capital of Roseau. ``There is no joy to it.'' Final but unofficial returns from Monday's parliamentary elections gave Charles' Dominica Freedom Party 11 of the 21 elected seats in the House of Assembly _ the minimum required for a majority government. Going into the election, the party had 17 seats. During the campaign, Charles said she hoped to win all 21 parliamentary seats. She said Tuesday she did not know why the party had done so poorly. ``Maybe we did not put in enough (campaign work), that's all,'' she said. Despite her now-slim majority, Charles said she expected to carry out the government's development program, including the planned construction of an international airport to boost tourism and trade. The United Workers Party, formed in 1988 and headed by Edison James, finished a strong second, winning six seats in its first electoral outing. James, a former manager of the Banana Marketing Corp., replaces the Dominica Labor Party's Michael Douglas as parliamentary leader. Labor won four seats, unchanged from the previous election. About 50,800 voters of the 82,000 residents of this 289-square-mile eastern Caribbean island between Guadeloupe and Martinique were eligible to vote. The election focused on personalities, rather than issues. Ms. Charles' opponents accused the prime minister of becoming increasingly authoritarian. The prime minister is a leading proponent of economic and political integration of the English-speaking islands of the Caribbean. Her tough anti-communist stance and allegiance to former President Reagan during the 1983 U.S. invasion of Grenada earned her the nickname ``Iron Lady,'' a reference to British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. She won her first five-year term in 1980 and was re-elected, with an increased parliamentary majority, in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Highway Deaths Down
DOC.TEXT: Highway fatalities dropped last year after three straight years of increases, from 47,087 to 45,454 and the nation's top highway safety officer credits tighter laws, advertising campaigns and greater public awareness. The death toll represented the lowest ever, in terms of miles traveled. ``Most of these regulations went in about two years ago but they really didn't take effect until last year,'' Jerry Ralph Curry, the head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said Tuesday. ``All of these things working together have dumped them down.'' Deaths involving passenger cars dropped from 25,808 to 24,929 in the United States last year as part of the overall decrease in highway fatalities, the national Transportation Safety Board reported. Highway fatalities account for 95 percent of all transportation deaths. Before all the figures were in, the safety administration in February estimated 1989 fatalities at 45,500 and said this figure was 2.2 deaths per 100 million miles traveled, the smallest death rate on record. The 1988 figure was 2.3 per 100 million miles and the 1980 rate was 3.3 per 100 million miles. ``This was not an accident,'' Curry said. ``We worked very hard along with the rest of the nation to make that happen.'' He said seat belt use is up. ``The leader of the nation is Hawaii, 78 percent belt use,'' he said. ``Puerto Rico is second with 70 percent. New York State, big as it is, is next with 60 percent. The national average seat belt use is 46 percent.'' A total of 35 states now have seat belt laws, he said. Curry also cited three million cars equipped with air bags now in use; an ad campaign featuring two talking crash dummies, and new state laws permitting administrative license suspensions for driving while drunk or drugged. He said Vermont, Connecticut, Maryland, Florida and California all passed such laws bringing the total number of states that have them to 29. ``The number of people killed in alcohol and drug-related accidents on the highway is still totally unacceptable,'' said Jim Kolstad, chairman of the NTSB.``Alcohol and drug abuse continues to be one of the greatest threats to transportation safety facing our nation.'' Aviation deaths were practically unchanged: 1,160 in 1988 and 1,158 in 1989. General aviation deaths dropped from 796 to 763 and fatalities involving airlines from 285 to 277. But those decreases were offset by a rise in air taxi deaths from 58 to 86 and commuter airline deaths from 21 to 32. Grade crossing accidents invlolving trains and highway vehicles accounted for 791 fatalities in 1989, up nearly 15 percent from the 689 the previous year. Rail fatalities increased from 563 to 601. The grand total of all transportation deaths decreased from 49,904 in 1988 to 48,243 last year, the NTSB said.

DOC.HEAD: Ginsberg-Glass Song Cycle Staged at Arts Festival
DOC.TEXT: ``Hydrogen Jukebox,'' 21 poems by ``beat'' poet Allen Ginsberg set to music by Philip Glass, was splendidly sung but difficult to understand in its staged premiere at the Spoleto Festival. It's presented as an ``acted'' song cycle, with much arm moving, walking and rolling around the stage by six splendid singers. Few words are understandable, far fewer than in most new operas in English. In an opera, when words aren't understood, the audience can get the gist of what's going on from the plot. But in Ginsberg's poems of free association, symbolism, fanciful happenings, inside allusions and non sequiturs abound, and one line of poetry often has no relation to the line before. The work desperately needs surtitles. We saw Monday night's performance, the third, in the Sottile Theater. We were able to realize there are anti-war poems, many references to India, nature, politics and industry, with appropriate back-wall projections. Glass' music was usually a melody, which the singers _ James Butler, Richard Fracker, Suzan Hanson, Thomas N. Potter, Linda Thompson and Darynn Zimmer _ sang over repetitive figures instead of chords. Each singer has a fine, distinctive voice, and they blended beautifully. Following the Spoleto Festival U.S.A., ``Hydrogen Jukebox'' will be performed at the Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy June 27 through July 15. A year from this fall, there are plans to tour ``Hydrogen Jukebox'' to 40 or 50 American cities. In great contrast was Mozart's ``The Marriage of Figaro'' from 1786, in the Dock Street Theater. Gian Carlo Menotti, artistic director of Spoleto Festival U.S.A., staged it. It became the hit of last year's festival and was repeated eight times this year, quickly selling out. The production is warm and friendly. Spiros Argiris conducted so briskly that some singers, especially Hilda Harris as Cherubino, had difficulty. Renee Fleming from Indiana, Pa., is probably the best Countess we've ever heard. Also fine were Erich Parce, Figaro; Young Ok Shin, Susanna, and Christopher Trakas, the Count. Menotti's grandson, Claudio, nearly 3, made his stage debut Saturday night as the son of the Count and Countess, with notable stage presence. Our biggest surprise at the festival was the sold-out ``Birth of an American Avant Garde'' concert at the College of Charleston. Host, composer John Kennedy, said that no piece on the program had been played more than a handful of times. The hit was William Russell's ``Four Dance Movements,'' three written in 1933 and one in 1990, and his 1936 ``Made in America,'' first performed in 1990. The concert, which included playing a suitcase, was at its most fun when Kennedy donned goggles and one glove and hammered a bottle to bits over a metal garbage can. Peter Garland was inspired by Indians and Johanna M. Beyer by a one-string instrument called a lion's roar, both at too much length. A 1971 James Tenney early minimalist piece completed the program. Old festival hands were saying there was the most experimentation ever this year. A sold-out chamber music concert at the Dock Street Theater, hosted in laid-back, knowledgeable, amusing style by Charles Wadsworth, sandwiched the premiere of Frazelle's ``String Trio'' between Bach and Vivaldi. The Memorial Day weekend streets of Charleston were crowded with people walking among 11 theaters, some going to concerts morning, afternoon and evening. Menotti said Tuesday that his greatest joy is introducing the arts to people who've never experienced them before.

DOC.HEAD: Government Orders Police Protection for Environmentalist
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with background on Mendes, CLARIFY position of Amancio, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The government has ordered special police protection for an Amazon-based rubber tapper who is leading the fight against the destruction of the rain forest. Police and farmers said they fear Osmarino Amancio, now in hiding, faces assassinated by landowners who oppose his environmentalist policies. There have been five attempts on Amancio's life this year. The former head of the rubber tappers union, Chico Mendes, was shot and killed on Dec. 22, 1988, outside his home in the Amazon town of Xapuri, near the Bolivian border. In Brazil, Mendes is revered as a man who died protecting the rights of peasants against powerful ranchers, who often hire gunmen to do their bidding in the jungle. U.S. producers are planning a movie based on Mendes' life. Landowners have cleared huge tracts of Amazon forest to provide grazing land for their cattle; cleared jungle land is initially fertile but quickly loses its nutrients. Poor peasants and rubber tappers, who make their living collecting rubber from the trees, oppose destruction of the forest. Amancio is one of the leading activists of the rubber tappers' union. The union is led by Julio Barbosa, who took over after Mendes' assassination. Mendes was the most prominent of almost 1,000 people _ most of them peasant farmers _ killed at the order of large landowners the past decade. According to Amnesty International, only two of the gunmen responsible for the crimes have been punished. ``Osmarino has suffered a number of death threats and police will now accompany him and also be posted at his home,'' Joao Martins, a federal police spokesman in Brasilia, said Tuesday. He said police were acting at the request of Justice Minister Bernardo Cabral. Rosa, a director of the National Council of Rubber Tappers in Rio Branco, 2,600 miles northwest of Rio, said: ``The protection is welcome but it is not enough. Landowners have gunmen who circulate freely in the region and they must be locked up.'' Rosa, who refused to be further identified, said Amancio may still refuse to emerge, even with police protection. ``The police were guarding Chico Mendes and that didn't prevent his death,'' she said. Amancio, 33, was based in the small town of Brasilea, 93 miles southwest of Rio Branco on Bolivia's border. ``If the government doesn't take serious action there will be a bloodbath,'' Rosa said. In a recent interview, Amancio vowed to continue his fight to protect the Amazon despite the threats on his life. ``I know my life is in danger,'' he said. ``But if we want to stay on the land and protect the rain forest, all of us must be prepared to run that risk.''

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Sentenced to 30 Years for Drug Conspiracy
DOC.TEXT: A reputed high-ranking member of the Medellin drug cartel, convicted in a seven-year conspiracy to import marijuana and cocaine into the United States, was sentenced Tuesday to 30 years in prison. The term was the maximum allowable under a Colombian extradition decree. Jose Abello Silva, extradited from Bogota in October and convicted May 19 on two drug conspiracy counts, also was ordered to pay $5 million in fines before he can be released. Rod Baker, head of the U.S. Probation office in Tulsa, said Abello would be eligible for parole in 10 years. ``For 10 years of your life, you were a major player in trafficking hundreds of thousands of pounds of marijuana and thousands of pounds of cocaine,'' U.S. District Judge Thomas Brett told Abello. ``Your smuggling network was large and sophisticated. The quantity of drugs imported into the United States by your organization has been responsible for immeasurable human suffering.'' In a 1989 decree allowing the extradition of accused drug smugglers, then Colombian President Virgilio Barcos declared that no Colombian national could be extradited unless the requesting state guaranteed it would not impose a prison sentence exceeding 30 years. U.S. Attorney Tony Graham sought consecutive life sentences and $8 million in fines for Abello. But Brett ordered a 30-year term for each count, to run concurrently, citing the Barcos decree. Graham, who said he may appeal the sentence, said he believed Brett could have imposed any term he wanted on Abello, ``as long as he is not incarcerated in excess of 30 years.'' Defense lawyer Richard Hayne said he was delighted Brett followed the decree. Abello stood at Brett's bench with his arms crossed during the hearing. Asked if he had any comment, Abello said, ``I am innocent.'' He also questioned whether his extradition to the United States was legal. He was convicted of conspiracy to import cocaine and marijuana into the United States and conspiracy to possess drugs with the intent to distribute. The conspiracy ran from July 1980 to July 1987 and included a transportation network from clandestine airstrips in northern Colombia through islands in the Bahamas. Abello was indicted in Tulsa because of a series of phone calls and money exchanges between parties in Oklahoma and Florida about a plan to import 500 kilograms of cocaine into the United States. The plan originated at a February 1987 meeting in Aruba at which Abello agreed to supply the cocaine. Prosecutors called 23 witnesses during the eight-week trial, many of them convicted drug smugglers who linked Abello to extensive drug trafficking. Abello testified that he was a legitimate cattle rancher, farmer and imported car salesman who walked away from the 1987 meeting in Aruba when cocaine was mentioned.

DOC.HEAD: Liner Arrives in Philadelphia Berth Two Days Late
DOC.TEXT: Moving slowly under its own power after being shoved off a sand bar, and minus 885 passengers it had brought from Jamaica, the luxury liner Regent Star docked in Philadelphia Tuesday evening. The ship, still carrying about 400 crew members, arrived at Penn's Landing on the Delaware River about 7 p.m. The 642-foot ship had been heading for Philadelphia's Pier 84 after a seven-day cruise from Jamaica when a fire early Sunday knocked out its steering and the ship ran aground in the Delaware Bay. It was stuck in 22 feet of water for nearly two days, leaving some passengers partying while others were frustrated, angry and even a bit afraid. On Monday night, the passengers were ferried to the Delaware shore. No one was hurt. ``I was scared,'' admitted Dorothy Klausmeyer of Baltimore after the liner struck the sandbar, couldn't get off and temporarily lost lights and power. ``The trip was wonderful, even running amok, it was wonderful,'' said Marjorie Ponder, Trenton, N.J., another passenger. ``Any traveler knows you can expect anything at any time.'' ``The crew did the best they could,'' agreed Lynn Harris of New York City, ``but once the Coast Guard took over everything seemed to happen faster.'' She said there were some passengers who talking about suing ``but, for me, the overall experience was interesting. I like adventure.'' Some passengers complained about the $15-a-minute charge to call worried relatives from the ship. The passengers were finally ferried to Lewes, Del., where 23 buses took them to their cars parked at airports and bus stations in the Philadelphia, Baltimore-Washington and New York City areas. Ferry terminal manager Gerald Hitchens said the passengers were ``quite understanding.'' ``I didn't see that many people upset. They understood the situation,'' he said. Ms. Harris said the end of the adventure was memorable. ``As the ferry pulled away from the ship, the entire staff and crew was on the deck waving goodbye to us, and the band playing `When the Saints Go Marching In.' It was a beautiful moment,'' she said. Mary Poniatowsky, Baltimore, said ``I had a beautiful time'' even though she is a teetotaler and didn't drink any of the free booze cruise officials offered. The Regent Star got off the sandbar with the help of high tides, several tugboats and power from the ship's own engines. Before the refloating, fuel was transferred to upper tanks. The Coast Guard had feared the ship's anchor could rupture the lower fuel tanks. Coast Guard Petty Officer David Oney said the liner will undergo further inspection by the Coast Guard and the National Transportation Safety Board at Philadelphia. A preliminary inspection Tuesday morning at Big Stone Beach in lower Delaware Bay found no serious damage, he said. ``Engineering controls were OK,'' Oney said. ``That was when approval was granted to bring the ship into Philadelphia.'' It might be months before a final report on the accident, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Probe Cauterizer Use in Operating Table Fire
DOC.TEXT: A surgical tool capable of releasing a spark was in use when fire and smoke engulfed a car accident victim on an operating table at UCLA Medical Center, the Fire Department said Tuesday. An autopsy was scheduled to determine if 26-year-old Angela Hernandez of Los Angeles died of the injuries for which she had just undergone surgery, or from the fire that started early Monday in the bedclothes covering her, said coroner's spokesman Scott Carrier. Among other things, doctors planned to check if she had inhaled smoke. The surgical tool, a penlike cauterizer used to stop bleeding from an incision, was present in the operating room along with pure oxygen, which raises the danger of fire, said Fire Department Inspector Ed Reed. ``In the presence of oxygen, even something like steel wool can catch fire pretty easily,'' Reed said. Fire Chief William Burmester of the arson squad said no official word on the fire's cause was expected until Wednesday. ``We're investigating a cauterizer as well as other tools that might have ignited the fabric,'' he said. ``We're not quite ready to make a final call yet.'' The accident grimly recalled an operating room death in October 1988 at nearby Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, where a 15-day-old boy was fatally burned when a cauterizer spark ignited a high concentration of oxygen in the room. UCLA Medical Center, at the University of California campus here, is owned by the university regents. Cornelius L. Hopper, a doctor who is vice president of health affairs for the state university system, noted that UCLA authorities, fire officials and state health regulators were all investigating. He said the regents would take no action until those probes are completed. No other injuries were reported, but the smoke closed down all 16 operating rooms for the day so they could be sterilized. The fire broke out about 5:30 a.m. in an underground level of the UCLA hospital. Surgeons had finished operating on Ms. Hernandez and were about to take her out of the room on a gurney when the sheets and blankets ignited, said Fire Department spokesman Pat Marke. Blinding smoke forced the medical team to leave the operating room and kept out university police. By the time firefighters arrived a few minutes later, the blaze had mostly burned itself out, officials said. Ms. Hernandez arrived at the medical center in critical condition late Sunday with heart and liver injuries sustained in the automobile accident in Santa Monica shortly before midnight, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Clown Victim Dies; Balloon Only Clue
DOC.TEXT: A balloon-carrying clown fatally shot a woman in the face and left few clues to the killing that has stunned this wealthy community, police said Tuesday. On Saturday morning, someone wearing a clown suit and mask, carrying foil balloons and a basket of red-and-white carnations, shot Marlene Warren when she opened the door of her home in the exclusive Aero Club neighborhood, police said. ``We're still out there going crazy, still plugging away,'' Palm Beach County sheriff's Lt. Lou Sessa said. Mrs. Warren, 40, was pronounced dead late Monday at Palms West Hospital in Loxahatchee, Palm Beach County sheriff's spokesman Bob Ferrell said. The only clue to the case so far is a balloon _ bearing a picture of Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs _ that store owners say is not commonly sold, authorities said. The Snow White balloon is not available at most stores, said Emilie Little, owner of Balloon Affairs. She said she would have to make out a special order if a customer requested it. Investigators continued Monday to interview people who knew Warren, who managed several rental apartments owned by her and her husband, Michael, 38. Michael Warren owns Bargain Motors in West Palm Beach and was at work at the time of the killing, police said. ``It's just a real shock for the whole community,'' said John Herring, who has served with Michael Warren on the community's Architectural Review Board.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Launch Scrubbed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with engineers still troubleshooting and additional details on problem. Picks up 10th graf pvs: `Earlier, the ...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CSB1, CSB2
DOC.TEXT: NASA scrubbed Columbia's launch Tuesday when an apparent leak in a hydrogen system was detected as workers were pumping a half-million gallons of propellant into the shuttle. The postponement came about six hours before the scheduled launch at 12:38 a.m. EDT Wednesday. No new date was set immediately, and engineers evaluated the problem through the night. The shuttle holds a $150 million observatory called Astro that will monitor unseen radiation and provide astronomers with unprecedented views of distant stars and galaxies. NASA spokeswoman Lisa Malone said Tuesday night that the leak appeared to be in the shuttle's main propulsion system or in the liquid hydrogen system's ground support equipment. ``The vehicle was never in an unsafe position at any time,'' she said. None of the seven astronauts were on board at the time. Malone said a new launch date would be set ``as soon as the problem has been identified and corrected.'' Engineers continued pumping hydrogen late Tuesday in an attempt to isolate the source of the leaking gas, Malone said. The leak could be anywhere in the maze of plumbing that carries the super-cold propellant into the spacecraft, she said. About 5 percent of the liquid hydrogen _ or nearly 20,000 gallons _ had been pumped into the external tank, officials said. Less than 25 percent of the liquid oxygen _ or 35,800 gallons _ had been loaded. It later was drained. The cylindrical tank contains two separate vessels, one for 143,351 gallons of liquid oxygen and the other for 385,265 gallons of liquid oxygen. The 528,616 gallons are pumped separately into the engines, where the two gases meet and burn to provide thrust for Columbia's three main rockets. Engineers in the launch control center at 5:15 p.m. noticed indications on their consoles that concentrations of hydrogen were building in the rear section of the shuttle. ``At that point, it didn't look good for launch,'' Malone said. The scrub was announced one hour and five minutes later. Earlier, the countdown had proceeded despite a problem with a loose connector on one of two communications units in the shuttle's middeck. The bad connector was unhooked and NASA planned to use the second unit for synchronizing data gathered and transmitted within Columbia and between the shuttle and ground stations. The nine- to 10-day flight is to be the first in five years devoted entirely to scientific research. Astro will probe radiation that is invisible from Earth and from the Hubble Space Telescope, deployed last month. ``We humans look at the universe in visible light,'' said Lennard Fisk, chief scientist for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. ``But the universe is, in fact, bright in many other kinds of radiation, and Astro will allow us to see the universe in ultraviolet light and in X-rays.'' The crew, commanded by Vance Brand, includes four astronomers who will operate Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes. An X-ray telescope will be managed from computer commands sent from Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md. Astro's four telescopes will make nearly 1,000 observations of up to 230 sources of ultraviolet and X-ray radiation while Columbia orbits 218 miles high. The targets will include Comet Austin, believed to be making its first trip through the solar system, and stars and galaxies, some as hot as 10 million degrees Fahrenheit. Astro's observing schedule has changed repeatedly over the years due to delays. The mission originally was scheduled for March 1986 and included Halley's Comet as a target, but the Challenger explosion changed that. A two-week delay this month because of repairs to the shuttle's cooling system resulted in further changes. Fewer observations are planned of Comet Austin, which is receding rapidly from the solar system. Jupiter and some stars are now too close to the sun to be seen by the instruments. But a quasar 10 billion light years from Earth is now in a better position than a month ago and will be Astro's faintest target, said Arthur Davidsen, principal investigator of Astro's Hopkins Ultraviolet Telescope. NASA expects the first observation to be made 15 hours into the mission, after the instruments are checked and calibrated. It is the first time since 1985 a shuttle is taking along components of Spacelab, although the pressurized module normally carried in the payload bay is being left behind. The astronomers will use Spacelab computers while working in the rear flight deck. Once the mission gets under way, it will mark some other firsts, too. It will be the first shuttle flight to offer ``Lessons from Space,'' tentatively scheduled for the fifth day of the mission. Forty-two middle school students at two NASA centers will question the astronauts through a two-way audio and video link. The exchange will be taped for distribution to schools nationwide. It also will be the first time direct radio communication is made between a U.S. and Soviet spacecraft. Columbia's astronauts plan to talk by ham radio to two cosmonauts aboard the Soviet space station Mir. Payload specialist Ron Parise, a licensed ham radio operator, also will contact amateur radio stations around the world. The other crew members are pilot Guy Gardner, mission specialists Mike Lounge, Robert Parker and Jeffrey Hoffman and payload specialist Samuel Durrance.

DOC.HEAD: Bok Announces Resignation After 20 Years as Harvard President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with later quotes from Bok. Picks up 4th graf pvs: `His presidency ...'
DOC.TEXT: Harvard University President Derek C. Bok announced his resignation Tuesday after presiding over two turbulent decades of sweeping changes at the nation's oldest and richest university. ``It is time for me to step down and allow a new president to provide fresh energy and continuity of leadership through the next decade,'' Bok said in a statement. Bok, 60, became the university's 25th president in 1971. He said he will step down at the end of the next school year and had no immediate long-term plans. ``There's no perfect time to leave a job like this, which I've loved,'' Bok said at the end of a hectic day after the announcement. ``But I've felt 20 years was the outside limit. I thought of leaving around the 350th (anniversary of Harvard) but the Harvard Corporation asked me to stay on for a couple of years. ``It's time for me to look for a new challenge.'' His presidency began amid student demonstrations against the Vietnam War. It comes to a close as women and minorities argue for greater representation at the school. Most recently, a black law professor drew publicity by taking an unpaid leave to pressure the law school into giving tenure to a woman from a minority group. In recent years, Bok also was the target of protesters seeking total divestment of university stock holdings in companies doing business in South Africa, and by clerical staff who formed a union after a 13-year fight. Through it all, the school has expanded in all directions. A core curriculum of basic studies was instituted, women gained equal access to the previously all-male college and the school became more accessible to part-time students by expanding the extension and summer schools. Also under his direction, the John F. Kennedy School of Government was developed into a major professional school, two art museums were added and athletic facilities were expanded. Gifts to the university rose from $50 million at the start of his presidency to more than $200 million this year. A new investment organization, Harvard Management Co., was created to manage the university's endowment. And the endowment rose from $1 billion in 1971 to approximately $5 billion, the nation's richest. Most of Bok's efforts at the 17,500-student school were low-key. He worked behind the scenes to maintain traditions at Harvard, which celebrated its 350th anniversary in 1986. But he was a ready defender of ideals. When then-U.S. Education Secretary William Bennett blasted Harvard's core curriculum of required courses such as moral reasoning as not rigorous enough, Bok shot back. ``Instead of pursuing these questions in an informed and sober manner, (Bennett) has followed his penchant for delivering highly publicized polemics against educational practices which he has not studied in detail,'' said Bok. Bok spoke out in 1982 about professors pursuing commercial profit in biogenetic research risking a loss of academic integrity. Bok, often ranked among America's most influential educators, drew wide praise as word of his resignation spread. ``He's absolutely one of the leading presidents ... not simply because it's Harvard, but he has provided outstanding leadership,'' said Robert Hochstein, of The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching. The university said a committee was being formed to find a successor for Bok, who had been the subject of wide speculation that he would step down. Bok, a Stanford University graduate, earned a law degree from Harvard in 1954. He joined the Harvard Law School faculty in 1958 and became dean of that school in 1968. He is the author of several books, including one on labor law with Watergate prosecutor Archibald Cox and three on higher education. He has served as chairman of the American Council on Education and the Association of American Universities and as a member of the board of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities.

DOC.HEAD: Commonwealth Party Condemns Bush Statehood Drive
DOC.TEXT: The governing pro-Commonwealth party unanimously passed a resolution on Tuesday condemning the ``repeated intervention'' of President Bush in favor of statehood for Puerto Rico. The 100-member general council of the Popular Democratic Party passed the measure, presented by Senate leader Miguel Hernandez Agosto, after an all-day meeting. Legislation before the U.S. Congress would allow Puerto Ricans to hold a referendum in 1991 on whether to remain a U.S. commonwealth with increased autonomy, become the 51st state or form an independent nation. The New Progressive Party has favored statehood for the commonwealth. The resolution said the Popular Democratic Party ``energetically repudiates any attempt by the government of the United States to manipulate Puerto Rican public opinion'' in the proposed plebiscite. ``The repeated intervention by President Bush as statehood's leading advocate in the plebiscite process represents a misuse of presidential power,'' it said. Answering previous charges of ``outside interference,'' Bush wrote Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon last Friday and said as president he had ``certain responsibilities for all the territory under the American flag.'' He said he had the right to favor statehood for this Caribbean island. Hernandez Colon, leader of the pro-commonwealth party, said Bush had a right to his personal opinion, but that he felt Bush was abusing his power as president. Earlier, he said Bush was treating Puerto Rico ``like a Baltic republic'' by sending two White House officials to the island to attend pro-statehood rallies and meet with statehood party leaders. Spain ceded Puerto Rico to the United States in 1890 at the end of the Spanish-American war. It became a U.S. commonwealth in 1952, an arrangement under which its 3.3 million residents are U.S. citizens and can be drafted but don't pay federal taxes and are ineligible to vote for president.

DOC.HEAD: One Dead Reported in Gas Well Explosion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with well re-igniting, capping experts called in; evacuation expanded to two-mile area; identification of dead man; one of injured released; other details.
DOC.TEXT: An explosion blasted a natural gas well Tuesday in southeastern Mississippi, killing at least one worker and critically burning four others, authorities said. A two-mile area around the well was evacuated, affecting about 145 people. Authorities initially evacuated only those within a half-mile, but expanded the plan after the fire went out by itself and then re-ignited, for fear that winds would scatter poisonous hydrogen sulfide gas. The gas is naturally associated with some gas fields. Experts at capping gas wells were to fly in Tuesday night. The explosion occurred at about 2 p.m., authorities said. The rig collapsed in the initial burst of what sounded like four successive explosions, said Alex Thomas, who lives within a half-mile of the rig. Others said there was another explosion later in the afternoon. Jim Maher, director of the Mississippi Emergency Management Agency in Jackson, said officials intended to keep the gas escaping from the well afire to burn off the poison. ``What they are going to do is bring a flame thrower-type device to keep the well burning,'' Maher said. Roads were closed leading to the well, which is about 75 miles southeast of Jackson, as was a five-mile stretch of U.S. Highway 11. ``Until we get a firm handle on this and somebody that can tell us with absolute certainty what is going on there, we will continue to take extreme precautions,'' said Mississippi Emergency Management Agency spokesman Dusty Perkins. Perkins said the rig was known as Travis No. 3 and was owned by R&H Oil and Gas Inc. of Tickfaw, La. City Clerk Debbie Logan identified the dead man as Dwayne Kennedy of Heidelberg. His age and exact job were unavailable. The four burn victims were in critical condition and would be moved to burn units in Greenville and in Mobile, Ala., said Lafe Jones, a spokesman for the South Central Regional Medical Center in Laurel. A fifth worker was treated for minor injuries and released.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Expresses New Confidence in Reaching Accord on Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Gorbachev confident of NATO accord. Pickup 4th pvs, `For Gorbachev...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos OTT1, OTT100
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev expressed confidence Tuesday on the eve of a superpower summit that he and President Bush will agree on a formula for permitting German unification without upsetting the balance of power in Europe. The Soviet president's comments came Tuesday evening in the Canadian capital, where he made a stopover en route to Washington for his second summit with Bush. Asked if he was optimistic about reaching agreement with the United States over Germany and its membership in NATO, Gorbachev replied, ``I am sure of that. And tell that to the American people.'' Gorbachev's remark to reporters during a walking tour of a downtown Ottawa mall marked a sharp turn from the gloomy assessments of Bush and his senior advisers in recent days and Gorbachev's own warning that U.S. insistence on a new, united Germany retaining West Germany's seat in NATO could stall the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Eastern Europe.
