KCBS Radio of San Francisco won in two categories _ overall excellence and spot news coverage _ for its reports on the earthquake. Ed Varagnaro is the station's news director. Other winners in the radio competition were: _Continuing coverage: WINZ, Miami; the Overtown riot and subsequent trial; Jeff Bray, news director. _Investigative reporting: WBBM, Chicago; airport security; Chris Berry, news and program director. _News series-documentary: WOAI, San Antonio; ``Separate and Unequal'' (education system in San Antonio); Jim Forsyth, news director. KGO-TV of San Francisco won the national award for television spot news coverage for its work on the earthquake. Milt Weiss is news director. Other winners in the TV competition were: _Overall excellence: KCNC-TV, Denver; Marv Rockford, news director. _Continuing coverage: KTUU-TV, Anchorage, Alaska; the Exxon Valdez oil spill; John Tracy, news director. _Investigative reporting: WCCO-TV, Minneapolis; problems with the 911 emergency phone system; John Culliton, news director. _News series-documentary: WGN-TV, Chicago; ``Laurie Dann: The Untold Story''; Paul Davis, news director.
DOC.HEAD: NOTES FROM EVERYWHERE
DOC.TEXT: New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, who's had some criticism for the news media, deplored the attacks on news people covering the aftermath of the Bensonhurst racial killing trial. He said reporters and photographers must be protected from verbal and physical assaults _ ``whether we like (them) or not.'' ... Tribune Co. plans an 18-hour-a-day cable TV channel offering news, sports and information beginning Jan. 1. It'll be called Chicagoland. ... Sportscaster Brent Musburger agrees with critics who say he talks too much and he over-hypes events he covers. ``It would be virtually impossible for someone who shares the responsibility for making an event a success to be a pure journalist,'' he says in an interview in the June 1 issue of Entertainment Weekly. ... Ted Turner's Cable News Network turns 10 years old on June 1. ``I have to kind of pinch myself to realize it's gone by so quickly,'' Turner said at an anniversary party at CNN Center in Atlanta. ``The next 10 won't be quite as exciting as the first 10, but stay tuned.''
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union enter this week's summit with renewed momentum toward clinching a treaty that for the first time would require each side to reduce the number of long-range nuclear weapons. While a treaty won't be ready for formal agreement when President Bush begins four days of meetings with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Thursday, the two men are expected to issue a joint statement this weekend declaring the main provisions of the pact to be settled. The details, on the other hand, could be months away. Bush and Gorbachev are expected to agree to drastically reduce their stockpiles of chemical weapons and to end production of those weapons. In addition, they are expected to call for ratification of two existing pacts limiting nuclear tests. U.S. and Soviet officials met during the weekend in an effort to settle arms control issues. The administration has said Bush also will press Gorbachev for a commitment to speed up NATO-Warsaw Pact negotiations to reduce tanks, troops and other conventional armaments in Europe. Progress in these talks has slowed recently.

He is, at 59, the oldest astronaut to ever fly in space. And that's too old, he says, to get back in line and wait _ hope _ for one more flight. As a result, Vance Brand expects the upcoming mission aboard shuttle Columbia to be his last journey into space. Brand will command the seven-man crew, four of whose members are astronomers and will operate a $150 million observatory called Astro. Liftoff is scheduled for 12:38 a.m. EDT Wednesday. ``I'll probably move on to a management job, a second career if you will, at this late date. But frankly, there isn't anything that beats flying in space,'' Brand said in a recent interview.

The leaf-devouring gypsy moth is coming, in numbers never before seen on the continent, scientists and federal officials say. ``You can almost take that to the bank,'' said Charles P. Schwalbe, a U.S. Department of Agriculture expert. In 1981, the last time the gypsy moth population exploded, the pest stripped the leaves from 12 million acres of trees and other plants in the Northeast. Gypsy moth populations rise and fall in cycles averaging about seven years. Now, scientists say, the region is due for another boom _ and a huge one.

As George Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev meet this week for summit talks that may shape the future, an 11-year-old girl from Aberdeen, Wash., is predicting the world will celebrate ``no more wars anywhere'' in just two decades. Sabrina ``Breezy'' Carter's vision of the future, which won a first prize, $4,000 scholarship in a nationwide essay contest of 16,000 youngsters, includes the election of a female U.S. president, a cure for the common cold and ray guns that will zap the dirt out of laundry. Miss Carter, a fifth-grader at McDermoth School at Aberdeen, will fly to Washington this week to read her essay and accept her prize in the ``Time Capsule Contest'' sponsored by Prodigy Services Co., a personal computer services firm based in White Plains, N.Y. The awards ceremony will take place at the Capital Children's Museum on Thursday, the first day of the Bush-Gorbachev summit. Breezy won first prize among elementary school pupils.

It's a con artist's dream. After years of learning to lock doors and install burglar alarms, Americans are being told it's their patriotic duty to open their homes to strangers. It's the U.S. Census 1990, and some swindlers are taking advantage: _An 80-year-old North Carolina woman was tied up and robbed by two men she thought were census workers. _People claiming to be census employees charged Houston residents $50 after helping them complete their forms. Census officials say such scams have to be expected. ``When you do something this massive, there's someone who will figure an angle to get money from it,'' said Noe Balli of the census' regional office in Dallas. He warned, ``Anybody who wants money, they're obviously not census employees.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release Thurs PMs, May 31 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Accordion Makers: Old Hands and New Folk
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A half-dozen accordions stand on Lawrence ``Shine'' Mouton's kitchen table, the result of hundreds of hours of work and decades of experience. ``My daddy was a musician _ Amadia Breaux. He composed `Jolie Blonde.' I tried to learn to play ... but didn't learn to play as well as he did,'' said Mouton, 63. ``I said if I couldn't play, I'd learn to make 'em.'' Mouton's name is now as well known among Cajun musicians as his stepfather's. His accordions are played by such performers as the popular ``Zydecajun'' musician Wayne Toups, and Jimmy Basile of Cajun Tradition, the Mamou group nominated for a Grammy award this year. As Cajun music and its spinoffs have become more popular, so has Mouton's craft. About 45 people now make the little German-style squeeze boxes, most of them in little backyard sheds. ``I figured I wasn't any dumber than the next fellow. I figured if he could make it, I could make it too,'' said John Elton Doucet, whose workshop is in his grocery store. ``The first one wasn't too, too good. But then the second one was good.'' Doucet makes six to 10 accordions a year. It's painstaking work. The flat metal reeds and the bellows are imported from Italy, but everything else is made by hand. Or at least adapted. For instance, many people make the big silver buttons on the left end of the accordion from chrome-plated chair glides. They snip off the little prongs, solder a wood screw onto the back and fill in the curve with lead. ``You drill a hole, and it's all threaded and ready to go,'' said Larry Miller, who makes accordions only for his family but makes and sells Cajun triangles, spoons set in wooden blocks so they're easy to use as a rhythm instrument and the over-the-shoulder style metal washboards used by Zydeco bands. The four wooden stops used to close off the four sets of accordion reeds are made from cabinetwork spindles. And tiny coiled screws inside the accordion were made to put tension on stereo tuning knobs. Some people paint their accordions, others varnish them to show off fine-grained woods. The long curved half-dowels which open or close the reeds often are covered with gold Mylar tape, which gives even more glitter than the once traditional gold paint and is a lot easier to apply. Miller said he began learning to play the accordion because of a lecture from Cajun music great Dewey Balfa, after an assembly at the school where Miller was principal. Miller told Balfa that his father had made triangles and played accordion, but none of his brothers or he had kept it up. ``He said, `If you're concerned about it dying in your family, it'll probably be your fault _ you were the one that broke the chain,''' recounted Miller. ``It hit me like a ton of bricks. Three days later, I went and bought an accordion and commenced to learning.'' About seven years later, he started thinking about making the instruments. He was influenced by stories he had heard about Mouton and a few other men who had loved the instrument so much that, after repairing and re-repairing German instruments made before World War II, they started making their own. Strictly speaking, the Cajun accordion is a melodeon or diatonic accordion _ a very different instrument from the big piano accordion popular shortly after the turn of the century. For one thing, the Cajun accordion is much smaller. It's about 11 inches high and six inches deep, and will squeeze down to 14 inches across. It weighs about eight pounds _ less than a third the weight of its big cousin. It's held on with a strap around the back of the left hand and a smaller strap for the right-hand thumb, and played like a hand-driven harmonica. Each of the 10 right-hand buttons gives two notes: one when the accordion is squeezed, the other when it's pulled out. The 28-pound piano accordion can't be held up without heavy padded shoulder straps. Its two-octave keyboard is twice as long as the Cajun accordion's little row of buttons; each key always plays the same note. Since it does have all 12 notes of the chromatic scale, it can play in any while the Cajun accordion is limited to four _ if a player is particularly adept _ and plays every note of the scale only in one. However, Cajun accordion makers say that their instrument can overpower the bigger one, because it has four sets of melody reeds. German accordions began showing up in Cajun country around the 1890s, and quickly upstaged the quieter fiddle as lead instrument. World War II stopped imports, and the factories were destroyed or converted to other uses. Factories resumed making accordions later, but the style popular in Louisiana _ four sets of reeds controlled by one set of buttons _ wasn't used much elsehwere. Mouton, Charlie Ortego and Sidney Brown and Marc Savoy are generally considered the pioneers of modern-day accordion building. Mouton began making accordions in 1961, opening up his father's old German-made Sterling accordion and using it as a reference. In 1970, heart trouble forced him to choose between a transfer and retirement from work as a civil engineer for Conoco. His hobby became his full-time job. ``Not to say a living. I don't make that much money making accordions, because the cost of reeds and bellows is so high,'' he said. Those two parts are ordered from Italy and cost hundreds of dollars. Reed makers don't give any discounts, Miller said, but he and about 25 other accordion makers recently began ordering bellows together. ``I remember when you could buy reeds for $5 a set,'' said Mouton. Now, the cheapest reeds are $90, and bellows start at $150 _ and those are for a brand scorned as vastly inferior to those made in Italy. Importing presents other problems. ``I ordered some reeds Oct. 19, 1989. They have my money. I still don't have the reeds,'' said Mouton. Mouton still works in a little backyard shed, though his heart problems have cut back to six or seven hours a day and about 20 accordions a year. A friend has begun cutting out the wooden parts for him to put together. Photographs of his father and his wife, Betty, stand on a shelf over his workbench. On the walls are a plaque naming Breaux to the Cajun Musicians Hall of Fame in 1984, musicians' signed promotion photographs, and several Wayne Toups posters, one of them inscribed, ``To Mr. Shine _ thanks for being a special friend.'' Mouton opens a corner cabinet. ``This is my daddy's old accordion. He bought it in 1918 for $7.50. I don't know what it would cost today. But I turned down $2,500 for it.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release Wed PMs, May 30, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Pia Zadora Returns to Her Musical Roots
LaserPhoto PN1 of May 26
DOC.TEXT: Pia Zadora, tired of fighting her image as a cinema sex tart, was ready to call it quits five years ago. Finally, she returned to her musical roots. The result was ``Pia and Phil,'' an album of nightclub standards backed by the London Philharmonic Orchestra. Critics, who had berated Zadora for everything from her movies to her marriage to multimillionaire Meshulam Riklis, suddenly remembered her musical background. ``It was really a big victory for me emotionally and otherwise. That was my last-ditch effort, my last bag of tricks. Thank God, it (singing) was something I had done all my life,'' Zadora said in a telephone interview from her Los Angeles home. In the background, her children _ Kady, 5, and Kristofer, 3 _ could be heard playing in the bathtub. Zadora, 34, said she took an 18-month break from touring so she could be with them. During that time, she recorded her new album, ``Pia Z.'' However, she won't perform any of the songs from that LP at her concerts with the Phoenix Symphony Orchestra on June 1-2 because the orchestra did not have enough time to learn the new music. She goes to Atlantic City, N.J., for a short stint following her Phoenix appearances. Zadora, a child of a violinist, was 6 when she appeared in the Broadway production of ``Midgie Purvis.'' After several other musicals, she attended the Juilliard School of Music in New York. Zadora jumped into films with ``Butterfly'' in 1981, earning a Golden Globe for best new actress. But in 1982, her career took a turn for the worse with the release of ``Lonely Lady,'' a critical and box-office flop. ``I must have been stupid,'' Zadora said. ``It was something that was offered to me. It was a Universal picture, and there were a couple of reasons I liked it. It was a serious role about a writer. But I had to live with it. I had to live with it when it was a `Movie of the Week' on television. The week it was on I went out of the country and wouldn't return my phone calls.'' Zadora also released a few dance-oriented, pop-rock albums that flopped in the United States in the early '80s. She scored a European hit with Jermaine Jackson on ``When the Rain Begins to Fall,'' but she refers to her early musical releases as novelty records. ``I really was in a tough position,'' she said. ``I got caught in one mousy project after another _ from `Lonely Lady' to all those silly records.'' But Zadora rebounded with ``Pia and Phil'' and then ``I Am What I Am.'' The albums followed the path paved by Linda Ronstadt in 1983 with her classics-filled ``What's New'' album. Zadora's orchestrally backed works included such tested songs as ``It Had to Be You'' and ``Smile.'' ``Pia Z,'' released in February, is more pop-oriented. It was produced by Grammy winner Narada Michael Walden, who has worked with Whitney Houston and Barbra Streisand. Zadora said she is apprehensive about returning to the screen or stage and feels her Golden Globe in ``Butterfly'' has been tarnished by critics who said her husband bought the trophy by wining and dining voters. Being married to a millionaire sometimes makes it hard for people to believe she is a legitimate artist, Zadora said. ``Certain people don't think I'm serious,'' she said. ``They say why should she bother to do it with all that wealth. Those people don't understand that it doesn't matter how much luxury or wealth you have, you still have to be productive.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wed PMs May 30
For Release PMs Monday June 4 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Golden Triangle Kingpin Little Affected by U.S. Indictment
DOC.TEXT: The heroin business has rarely been better for Chang Chi-Fu, alias Khun Sa, who seems more concerned about the rival Wa tribe than a U.S. government indictment. The United States has branded Chang the ``Prince of Death'' and the billion-dollar drug kingpin of the Golden Triangle. It has charged him with importing or trying to import more than 3,500 pounds of heroin into New York between September 1986 and February 1988, and has threatened to ``go after him if he can be located.'' Sources who were with Khun Sa when he learned of the indictment, announced March 15 in Washington, described the chain-smoking warlord as angry but not particularly worried. He has not, for example, made noticeable changes in his operations, and there is no indication the flow of heroin from his area of control in Burma has decreased. The United States did manage to arrest four members of his drug ring in Hong Kong on May 20. They are to be tried in New York on charges of smuggling 46 pounds of heroin into the United States on May 9. One of them, Sai Yeung Ng, was described as a brother-in-law of Khun Sa. A federal complaint filed in U.S. District Court in Brooklyn identified the others as Dun-Shun Yeung, Wirote Tankirdkit and Yu-Shing Lam. A warrant is out in Thailand for the arrest of Sze-Wah Yeung, another defendant in the case. The United States has been vague about its plans to seize Khun Sa, but has ruled out large-scale military action. Analysts note that the jungle and mountain terrain would make military operations difficult and costly. Thai officials say there has been no substantial pressure on them from Washington to move against Khun Sa. Burma is unlikely to cooperate, given Washington's denunciation of the military junta that seized power after brutally crushing a pro-democracy uprising in 1988. Washington stopped its anti-narcotics aid program to Rangoon in protest. Khun Sa now is engaged in one of the perennial conflicts of the Triangle, the rugged, largely lawless territory where the borders of Burma, Laos and Thailand converge. This time, Khun Sa's army is trying to stop the potentially powerful Wa tribe from muscling in on his territory. The Wa, one of Burma's multitude of ethnic minorities, broke away from the outlawed Burma Communist Party, which had emerged as a major narcotics producer and trafficker in the 1980s. Khun Sa has general control of areas near the Thai frontier, which allows opium transported from deeper inside Burma to be processed into heroin at border refineries. From these border refineries, the heroin is smuggled through Thailand to the United States, Australia, Western Europe and Asian points. According to official U.S. estimates, the Triangle's opium crop in the 1988-89 growing season amounted to 2,600 tons, about 85 percent of it from Burma. A similar amount is expected this year. Washington has focused on the drug deluge from Latin America and the so-called Golden Crescent of Pakistan and Afghanistan, which had supplied much of the heroin to U.S. addicts. At least 40 percent to 50 percent of heroin imported into the United States now originates in the Triangle, much of it bearing Khun Sa's imprint. Some knowledgeable observers speculate the U.S. indictment was not so much a prelude to direct action against Khun Sa as a message to Thailand and Burma. Melvyn Levitsky, the top State Department narcotics official, has criticized corruption in Thailand, which allows drugs to cross the country in vast quantities, and Burmese government connections with drug warlords. Khun Sa, believed to have been born in 1932, emerged as a narcotics trader in the 1960s. He claims to be a freedom fighter for Burma's Shan minority who must use narcotics to finance his rebellion. On several occasions, he has offered to sell the opium crop to the United States, and keep it off the illicit market. He has survived numerous battles and five years in prison. In 1982, he was driven out of his Thai stronghold, complete with swimming pool and plush quarters, and into Burma. The Thais have a $19,000 reward on his head, but his links with Thailand remain. He buys weapons on the Thai black market for his army of 4,000 to 10,000 men. His aides openly operate businesses in tungsten, jade and timber across northern Thailand, and he is known to have close ties to many provincial officials. Thai narcotics sources acknowledge privately that corruption among police, army and government officials facilitates the trafficking. Maj. Gen. Chavalit Yodmani, who heads the Office of the Narcotics Control Board, said the key to eradicating drugs in the Triangle is solving Burma's ethnic minority problems. ``Khun Sa is just one person,'' Chavalit said in an interview. ``You can indict twenty Khun Sas, but another one will simply spring up to take their place.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release Fri PMs, June 1 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: OK to Spend More _ As Long As You Get More
DOC.TEXT: The huge production costs and star salaries of the summer films have aroused fears that the film industry is headed down the same road as America's savings and loans. Don't worry, advise the makers of the $50 million ``Total Recall,'' which is set for release in 2,000 U.S. theaters tdoay. Says Arnold Schwarzenegger, whose salary was reportedly $10 million: ``As long as you can bring the money back, that's the key thing. In Hollywood, if someone would pay me $100 million in salary and they would get back $400 million, they would do it with pleasure. Wouldn't you? I would. ``The numbers don't matter. The only thing that matters is: Can you return this money twice or three times over? Sometimes studios make a movie for $5 million, then they put $10 million in for promotion and they lose it all, because it's a bad picture. This is how studios ... eventually ... go bankrupt.'' Adds director Paul Verhoeven: ``We made it pretty cheap by going to Mexico City. Shooting in Los Angeles, I'm sure that the movie would have cost $70 million or something like that. We started (the budget) at $43 million, and I think I went over 15 percent. So it's probably up to $50 million. I always go over 15 percent, even in Europe, where I made films for half a million. ``I always seem to go over a bit more than the producers want to give. But it's all on the screen. It's not something that fell in the water or disappeared into somebody's pocket. It's all there. ``I don't think you feel the (fiscal) responsibility as a director. You know that you can't make it for $5 million or even $40 million. The decision is economic. The producers must decide: Can we do this movie with all the special effects and by adding Arnold Schwarzenegger make our money back? If that possibility exists, they go for it. ``A company like Carolco makes a lot of pre-sales. With a name like Arnold's and my name, which is pretty well known in Europe, they can say, `Look what we have: the director of `Robocop' and Arnold Schwarzenegger, can we please sell this movie to you?' So they get a lot of money already from the pre-sales. Then they can say, `We can do it.''' ``Total Recall'' has been in the works for 10 years, originating in a short story by Phillip K. Dick, ``We Can Remember It for You Wholesale.'' Dino De Laurentiis developed the script, which intrigued Schwarzenegger in the mid-1980s. ``It was the best script I had read in years,'' he recalls. ``When I picked up the script the first time, I couldn't put it down. I read it all the way through, then I read it again. ... The whole business of memory being erased and another memory implanted was fascinating.'' Set in the year 2084, ``Total Recall'' depicts Schwarzenegger as an Earth laborer who enrolls for a memory-implant vacation and soon finds himself enmeshed in a civil war on Mars. De Laurentiis was unable to find a director for the film and sold the project to the enterprising Carolco, maker of the ``Rambo'' films. Schwarzenegger agreed to the choice of Verhoeven as director: ``He has the right mentality for it, the discipline, the know-how.'' The Martian world was created on the stages of Churubusco stdios in Mexico City with the designs of William Sandell. Included is the tawdry red-light district of Venusville with its glaring neon and an occasional touch of whimsy, such as a Jack-in-the-Box sign. Mexico City itself provided the locations for Earth 100 years from now. ``We used the Mexican style called `new brutalism' with all the concrete stuff, very threatening, with little windows, Aztec-style,'' said Dutch-born Verhoeven. ``There will be new things in the 2080s, but there will be things that you can compare with today. Especially when you come from Europe, where in every city you can see buildings that are four-, five-, 600-years old. So there is always a combination of the old and new. ``Generally I don't think the world changes that much. It will be a bit larger, the style will change a little bit. Buildings of Egypt 4,000 years ago are not much different from what you see today. People still need a roof if it's raining.''

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Saturday, June 9, the 160th day of 1990. There are 205 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: On June 9, 1954, in one of the most dramatic confrontations of the Senate-Army hearings, Army counsel Joseph N. Welch assailed Senator Joseph R. McCarthy for his attack on a member of Welch's law firm, Frederick G. Fisher. Said Welch: ``Have you no sense of decency, sir? At long last, have you left no sense of decency?'' On this date: In A.D. 68, the Roman Emperor Nero committed suicide. In 1784, John Carroll, who would become the first Roman Catholic bishop in the United States, was appointed supervisor of Catholic missions in the U.S. In 1860, the first dime novel _ titled ``Malaeska: The Indian Wife of the White Hunter'' _ was published. In 1870, author Charles Dickens died in Godshill, England. In 1892, composer-lyricist Cole Porter was born in Peru, Ind. In 1940, 50 years ago, Norway surrendered to the Nazis during World War II. In 1953, about 100 people died when a tornado struck Worcester, Mass. In 1969, the U.S. Senate confirmed Warren Burger to be the new chief justice of the United States, succeeding Earl Warren. In 1973, Secretariat became horse racing's first Triple Crown winner in 25 years by winning the Belmont Stakes in New York. In 1978, leaders of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints struck down a 148-year-old policy of excluding black men from the Mormon priesthood. In 1986, the Rogers Commission released its report on the Challenger disaster, criticizing NASA and rocket-builder Morton Thiokol for management problems leading to the explosion that claimed the lives of seven astronauts. Ten years ago: Comedian Richard Pryor suffered almost fatal third-degree burns at his San Fernando Valley, Calif., home when a mixture of ``free-base'' cocaine exploded. Five years ago: American educator Thomas Sutherland was kidnapped in Lebanon _ he remains in captivity. The Los Angeles Lakers won the NBA title with a 111-100 victory over the Boston Celtics. One year ago: China began making large-scale arrests in the wake of the crushed pro-democracy movement. The arrests coincided with the public reappearance of Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping, who was rumored to have been seriously ill. Today's Birthdays: Former World Bank president and former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara is 74. Baseball player Dave Parker is 39. Actor Michael J. Fox is 29. Thought for Today: ``Neither in the life of the individual nor in that of mankind is it desirable to know the future.'' _ Jakob Burckhardt, Swiss historian (1818-1897).

DOC.NOTE: For Release Wednesday PMs, May 30, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Summer TV Season No Longer Just Rerun Festival
DOC.TEXT: It's mid-August. You're too hot to go out. Grab a glass of something cool, park in front of the tube and consider the choices: A third repeat of ``I Married Dora.'' The second showing of that fabulous ``Manimal'' episode in which the lead character turns into a tiger. Or, wait, hold onto your sun visor, what about the fourth special encore presentation of that ``Moonlighting'' episode where Maddie sleeps with Mark Harmon? There's been a cure for the summertime rerun blues. It's called flipping the dial to a network where there are myriad first-run programs to chose from. And that means not flipping to ABC, CBS or NBC. It took the Big Three a couple of years to swallow this little pill. It went down only after Fox Broadcasting Co. stole significant numbers of viewers last year while the big boys over at the mondo-networks took their usual summer naps. The alternative Fox network, not asleep at the wheel, has taken to calling last year's coup ``The Summer of Opportunity.'' This year, they plan to maintain year-round original programming. Two new shows have been announced for the summer, as well as more fresh episodes and specials of shows such as ``Cops,'' ``America's Most Wanted'' and the critically acclaimed ``In Living Color.'' Cable networks such as Home Box Office like to take credit, too, for increasing their viewership by running original programming during the summer. ``The networks are definitely reacting to cable television,'' said HBO spokesman Richard Licata. ``Cable is definitely eroding their (ratings) shares.'' The sleeping giants have stirred, and this summer ABC, CBS and NBC are pumping more money into summer programming than ever before. But it's not a whole lot. And even though the Big Three are making a big deal out of their summer programming, with few exceptions, it's still pretty meager fare. ABC will show unseen episodes of the recently canceled ``Brewster Place,'' starring Oprah Winfrey, and ``Capital News,'' starring Lloyd Bridges. Its few new summer shows include ``New Attitude,'' about a beauty salon, and the game shows ``Super Jeopardy!'' and ``Monopoly.'' Rather than produce a large slate of fresh shows, ABC instead has spent ``between $10 and $20 million increasing episode orders of existing shows,'' said network spokesman Jim Brochu. Over at the No. 1 peacock network, which barely held on to its top-rated status during May sweeps, NBC programming gurus have some interesting ideas for summer. Entertainment President Brandon Tartikoff announced this week that repeats of ``Quantum Leap,'' one of his favorite shows, would be shown at 10 p.m. EDT for five consecutive nights beginning June 25. New programs include ``Singer and Sons'' starring Esther Rolle and ``The Seinfeld Chronicles'' starring comedian Jerry Seinfeld. ``Because there are so many choices, no longer can you just simply go away and not come back until the fall,'' said NBC spokeswoman Sue Binford. ``Putting that into practice is very, very tough. We're not going to get there completely this summer.'' At bottom-rated CBS, executives have little to say about the summer season. They're too busy trying to figure out their fall schedule and how to get out of last place. But the battered eye is the only broacast network to have an executive in charge of nothing but summer programs. So far, CBS has announced three new programs for the hot months to come. One is ``War Room,'' about White House speech writers. Another is ``Northern Exposure,'' about a New York doctor forced to work in Alaska to pay off his medical education. In ``Manhattan Nights,'' which still is in production, summer viewers will peek at the lives of residents in a fictional New York apartment building. ``By having original programming on in the summer, we're trying to attract viewers back to CBS,'' said Mike Eisenberg, network vice president of research. ``We're trying to reduce viewer erosion.'' It is a simple fact that less people watch television in the summer. According to Eisenberg, the number of prime time viewers in July 1989 was 18 percent less than in January of the same year. There are several reasons: The weather is nicer and people take vacations. Might it also be that summer TV was lousy to begin with? Don't run to the lodge without reservations just yet, but as the networks pay more attention to hot weather programming, could an August sweeps period be far behind?

Elsewhere in television ... A GOLDEN GIRL GOES `SHOPPING': Rue McClanahan, star of ``The Golden Girls,'' will launch a line of fashion and jewelry on the Home Shopping Club. McClanahan describes the clothes as ``body friendly'' and made from ``realistic fabrics'' that will ``look terrific on women of all shapes and sizes.'' Translation: double-knit muu muus.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wed PMs, May 30

DOC.SECOND: PM-Last Stand in Burma, Adv 30, 1st Ld - Writethru,0786
DOC.NOTE: For Release PMs Wednesday May 30 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: 41-Year-Old Insurgency May Be Down to Last Battles
DOC.NOTE: Eds: In b0169, moved in advance May 24, INSERTS 1 graf after 4th `Thailand, eager'' with results of weekend elections
DOC.TEXT: The diehard Karen rebels have been squeezed into shrinking frontier enclaves and may be down to the last battles of their 41-year-old fight for autonomy. It has been a long, hard march for one of Burma's many ethnic minorities, most of it backward. At the beginning, in the late 1940s, Karen troops swept through Burma's major cities and even penetrated to the outskirts of Rangoon, the capital. In the past two years, the army has overrun most of the Karen bases along the Thai border and sent 28,000 refugees fleeing across the frontier. Thailand, eager to exploit Burma's rich forests, has struck deals with the government at the expense of the rebels. Hundreds of fighters have died on both sides in fierce jungle combat, sometimes hand-to-hand. The opposition won the Burmese national elections last weekend, but it is not certain how that will affect the Karen war or when the military government will relinquish power. Among the last Karen strongholds is the border town of Manerplaw, capital of territory the Karen call Kawtoolei. Manerplaw, probably one of the world's most idyllic guerrilla bases, sits on the Moei River, at the foot of mist-streaked hills. Its neat wood-and-thatch buildings house 12 government departments of the Karen National Union, including foreign affairs, fisheries and mining. Karen leaders claim to command 10,000 troops and govern 1 million civilians. The Karen fighters and a dozen other rebellious ethnic minorities with which they are allied do not seek independence, but greater political and cultural autonomy. ``If you consider it historically, it is the worst situation we have faced, but it doesn't mean the end of the Karen revolution,'' said Ba Thein, general secretary of the Karen National Union. He said the Karen were switching to more classic-style guerrilla warfare and would have little trouble operating in areas of eastern Burma dominated by the Karen minority. A ``mobile headquarters'' would be organized if Manerplaw fell to the Burmese, he said in an interview. Ba Thein also expressed hope for internal political change in Burma. ``We are not alone,'' he said. ``All the people in Burma are struggling for freedom. We believe that, if democracy comes, all the ethnic minority problems with be solved.'' Burma's military, which brutally crushed a pro-democracy uprising in 1988, has shown remarkable tenacity. The loss of border bases has greatly reduced the Karen National Union's income from taxes levied on frontier smuggling, which was used to buy weapons. In contrast, the 200,000-member Burmese military has restocked its arsenal with funds from teak-logging concessions granted to Thai businessmen. Burmese control of the border is now in the interest of powerful Thais, and rebel officers say some Thai-Burmese military cooperation has occurred. ``The logging has been the death knell of the Karen,'' said a knowledgeable Western observer in Bangkok. He noted that earlier friendly and mutually advantageous ties between the Thais and Karen had helped sustain the insurgency. What some sympathetic Westerners and Thais have called the ``sellout of the Karen'' fits a historical pattern. Although the Karen have lived in what is now Burma at least as long as the Burmans, they have been suppressed and looked down upon as ``savages'' and ``wild cattle of the hills.'' The Karen fought bravely alongside the Allies in World War II, while a pro-Japanese government sat in Rangoon, but promises of some autonomy were broken when Burma gained independence from Britain in 1947. After the early successes of their insurgency, the tide turned against the Karen rebels and they were gradually forced into the border region. There has been incompetence and some corruption among the aging rebel leaders, who have not conducted a real guerrilla war, and disparities in power and education between the Christian leaders and their followers, most of whom are Buddhist or animist. In 1984, the government stepped up its campaign and three years later announced it would destroy the Karen National Union within two years. That has not happened, but two words often heard when the rebels discuss the future are ``dark'' and ``bleak.'' ``I am 63 and have fought all my life,'' Ba Thein said. ``My children have now joined the revolution. Perhaps the next generation will also have to struggle.''

DOC.HEAD: A ``Credit Crunch'' Explanation
DOC.TEXT: How can surveys show no credit crunch on a national scale when so many businesses complain about financing restrictions? It will be a year before enough hard data are available and analyzed to say whether or not a national credit crunch exists today, which means, of course, that the answer will be too late for practical purposes of policy. Meanwhile, anguished shrieks of pain can be heard from operators of startup companies, from those involved in any way with real estate or building, from companies with little collateral to offer, and from otherwise solid outfits. Have their complaints fallen into that no-man's land, that intellectual desert where economists debate, equivocate, qualify and toss questions from one hand to the other and never reach even a tentative conclusion? Some help in resolving the apparent contradiction _ between those who rely on economic statistics and see no credit crunch, and those small companies that complain of being squeezed almost to death _ can be found in phrasing. Most surveys, for example, make a distinction between a general credit crunch and regional ones. A key phrase in this distinction is ``national credit crunch.'' To many economists, anything regional doesn't qualify. Surveys also tend to look at business in general, whereas most complaints seem to come from small or medium-size businesses, which often use real estate as collateral. Some economists tend to think only in big-business terms. And, it has been argued, those companies that indeed are hurt, even when they represent only a small fraction of the whole, squeal so loudly there is a tendency to think the entire barnyard is in an uproar. One of the most cogent explanations offered is that of economist William K. MacReynolds, who makes a sharp distinction between a general credit crunch, which he says may not exist, and a specialized one, which he says does exist. MacReynolds' thesis, developed for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, is not a cop-out but an explanation. While stating that ``to date, there is no conclusive evidence that a general credit crunch exists,'' he provides this observation: ``However, there is a clear sense from published economic data, credit market behavior, new credit availability, bank examiner actions, bank reactions, and anecdotal evidence provided by bankers and small-business people in more than half the states in the country that a credit crunch is underway.'' In short, and without awaiting statistical conclusions, he declares there is indeed a problem out there. He observes that larger companies with access to various credit markets have suffered the least, even though many of them have had their credit ratings lowered. And, as everyone knows, the junk bond market has collapsed. Small-business credit providers, he says, are burdened by targeted bank examinations, especially since the spate of bank and thrift failures, and these examiners are especially critical of real estate collateral. Real estate is a primary source of collateral for small business. Bank examiners, says MacReynolds, are asking banks, even well-capitalized community banks, to get new appraisals and to write down the value of these loans. ``If banks do not seek new appraisals or adjust existing loans with new collateral, they are forced to write down the value of loans and report large losses,'' he explains, adding: ``And while bank examiners and government regulators would not claim they wish to discourage good loans, the pressure on banks is to withhold new loan approval. ``Even performing loans from long-standing bank customers, whose ability to repay debt goes unchallenged, can be classified as troubled because new appraisals have not been made.'' That situation is exacerbated, says MacReynolds, when small banks are taken over by larger ones. Then, he suggests, the small-business customer might almost automatically lose its credit, even with a good payment record. Conclusion: ``In a general slowdown, everyone's capital tends to erode, and asset values stop rising. ``Regulatory actions on top of a slowdown that discriminate against a class of borrowers regardless of their proven ability to repay loans make the situation worse to the point where a crunch is unavoidable.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release Friday AMs, June 1, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: OUT OF STEP: Turmoil in Dance World
Is Dance Alive and Well?: The Joffrey and Other Upsets
DOC.TEXT: Is dance in America alive and well? ``It's alive but not well,'' says Richard Philp, editor in chief of Dance magazine. ``No, it's isn't,'' says choreographer Agnes de Mille. ``It's suffering from malnutrition. There isn't any money.'' And that's a catastrophe, in her view, ``because the well-being of the arts is a direct thermometer of our country's spiritual and emotional well-being. ``The function of art in our lives I think is vital. It's next door to food. We have to have something.'' In recent years, dance companies throughout the United States, like other organizations in the arts community, have suffered from cuts in financing and reorganization. Some companies have virtually gone out of business. ``In general, what you're seeing is true throughout the arts: a decline in funding due to the economy, the mergers and acquisitions phenomenon and to a change in priority in some companies who now have an emphasis in the environment, education and social causes at the expense of the arts,'' said Betsy Hopkins, executive director of the fund-raising organization Corporate Fund for Dance. Hopkins said that, in general, the nation's 400 or so dance companies were healthy and not any worse off than other arts organizations. ``There's a heightened interest in dance in this country,'' she said. ``But dance companies just don't tend to have big endowments.'' The most recent upheaval in the world of dance has been at the Joffrey Ballet. Gerald Arpino, co-founder of the company with Robert Joffrey and artistic director since Joffrey's death in 1988, resigned May 1 and said the company _ on the eve of a Los Angeles season _ couldn't perform his or Joffrey's creations. Arpino later said the company could dance his works starting May 25. He resigned after the Joffrey's 55-member board voted to establish a nine-member operating committee, which would virtually eliminate his power and the board's power. Ten board members resigned immediately. The vote came after the board learned that the company, beside its $1 million deficit, owes $800,000 in payroll-withholding taxes. Negotiations continued and on May 23 an agreement was reached. Arpino, whose resignation was never accepted, continues as artistic director. He will license his and Joffrey's ballets to the company. An executive committee of 10 board members plus Arpino will run day-to-day operations. During May, board co-chairmen David Murdock in Los Angeles and Anthony Bliss in New York, vice chairman Frank Lynch, board president David Holbrook and executive director Penelope Curry resigned. Earlier in the month, Murdock, the millionaire who was instrumental in the Joffrey adopting Los Angeles as a second home in 1983, offered to lead a three-year drive to erase the Joffrey's deficit. Murdock's resignation may mean he rescinds that offer. Also, the Joffrey's contract with the Los Angeles Music Center expires June 30. Last November, the board defeated a proposal to name Bliss' wife, Sally, a former dancer who headed the young Joffrey II company, as artistic head of the company to whom Arpino and Curry would report. The Joffrey's July 17-29 engagement at the University of California at Berkeley has been canceled. However, four performances June 7-9 at the Spoleto Festival in Charleston, S.C., remain booked. American Ballet Theater's big upheaval came last year, when Mikhail Baryshnikov abruptly resigned as artistic director. Baryshnikov had brought in Jane Hermann from an administrative job at the Metropolitan Opera to become executive director of American Ballet Theater. She cut the season's budget to $18 million from $23 million and instituted cost-cutting measures intended to reduce a $1 million deficit. This led her to clash with and then remove Charles France, Baryshnikov's personal assistant. In support of France and citing artistic standards, Baryshnikov resigned in September from the company he had headed since 1980. The Dance Theater of Harlem danced a season at the Kennedy Center for Performing Arts in Washington in March. Having canceled its May season here, it laid off dancers, technical personnel and some administrative staff, saying $1.2 million could be saved. Cancellations in domestic and European tours had made the year's projected deficit $1.7 million. America's most renowned modern dance troupe, the Martha Graham Dance Company, also had to lay off dancers through February and March; there was no money to pay them. Dancers returned in April to prepare for appearances in the United States, Spain and Japan from May through August. Personality conflicts and power struggles may play a part but most observers agree the basic cause of turmoil in the dance world is lack of money. ``I think the problem comes right down from the presidency and the National Council on the Arts. They don't give enough money and they don't give it regularly enough. They're stingy,'' said Agnes de Mille. ``Dance cannot support itself, never did and never will. The fine arts aren't designed to pay for themselves. In the early days, Lucia Chase footed the bill for Ballet Theater. Lincoln Kirstein still foots the bill for the New York City Ballet. Rebecca Harkness helped what became the Joffrey Ballet. ``Dancers are very special. They have to be cared for very carefully and it's expensive. Now, they're getting reasonable salaries. Before, they starved.'' Money sources are drying up, while operational costs continue to soar. ``I don't know what the Dance Theater of Harlem is going to do,'' said Philp, the editor of Dance. ``The Joffrey's philosophy has been to present the best of 20th century dance, historical as well as contemporary. They may have to adapt.'' After the Dance Theater of Harlem's shutdown became known, it received nearly $150,000, a third each from Chase Manhattan Bank, the New York State Council for the Arts and individuals, so that its school could remain open. The Shubert Foundation made a $200,000 challenge grant to the company. A fund-raising event will be held this month. At Ballet Theater, works by experimental modern-dance choreographers and expensive new productions of Russian ballets often were mounted during Baryshnikov's tenure. Philp says of the latter, ``The dancers didn't have the maturity that's necessary to project the heart and soul of certain roles.'' In the future, American Ballet Theater apparently intends to emphasize Antony Tudor and Agnes de Mille dance-dramas and to develop stars who'll be box-office draws. A fund-raising 50th anniversary gala, with top ticket price at $1,250, was held in January. While de Mille praises the efforts of dance companies to pull themselves up by their own bootstraps, she believes the government should see the need for vigorous interest and help. ``I think our lives are terribly starved. We have enough electrical gadgets but our brains are empty. In large measure our spirits are empty. If they weren't, we wouldn't have so many snarling people on the streets. ``I think our government doesn't lead us,'' she said. ``I think they reflect what they think is the common will and they think the common will is for more soap operas and more crack. ``We were blessedly fortunate with those men in Philadelphia, the founding fathers. They were knowledgeable and they sat down and really deliberated and didn't have people telling them how many votes they're get here or there.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Friday AMs, June 1

DOC.SECOND: AM-AP Arts: Off Their Toes, Adv 01,1262
DOC.NOTE: For Release Friday AMs, June 1, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: OUT OF STEP: Turmoil in Dance World
A Summer Break at Dance Theatre of Harlem
With AM-AP Arts: American Dance, b0486
DOC.TEXT: The members of Dance Theatre of Harlem see themselves as different from those in other top-tier ballet companies, united on a mission to bring the fine arts to people too long out of their reach. But this summer the dancers have found themselves thrown apart, laid off for six months by a combination of bad luck and economic reality. Losing 15 of the minimum 40 weeks they're accustomed to working each year, the dancers worry about paying their rent, meeting other bills and keeping in shape. And they worry whether their company can come out of this in one piece. ``I'm very concerned that this interuption is so long that it's going to be hard to rebuild suddenly,'' said Virginia Johnson, a principal ballerina and the company's star who has been with the troupe for 21 years. ``I am very worried about the individual dancers and if the company as it was is going to be able to survive. ... Will they be able to leave what they found in the interim?'' Johnson considers herself lucky, having quickly lined up guest performances with the Garden State Ballet in Newark, N.J., and the Washington Ballet in Washington, D.C. She also plans to continue work on her college degree _ she took a leave of absence 20 years ago from studying history. The lithe, delicate dancer thinks about modeling, or maybe working as a receptionist. She takes dance classes: ``When you're a dancer and you're used to dancing eight hours a day, you just don't feel like the same person if you're not taking class.'' She insists, however, that she has not considered quitting the troupe. ``It's not just a job; it's not just a place that we go to dance. It's a place that we feel we make a contribution to solving some of the world's problems.'' Arthur Mitchell, a former principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, co-founded Dance Theatre of Harlem in 1969 as a commitment to the Harlem community after the assassination of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. From the start, the troupe challenged racial stereotypes and proved that blacks can dance classical ballet. The company prides itself on preserving American dance repertory, demonstrating a variety of styles and moods, from the classical ``Swan Lake'' to George Balanchine's neoclassical ``Allegro Brillante'' to Mitchell's modern ``Holberg Suite'' to the folk ballet ``John Henry.'' In 1988, the troupe captivated audiences in the Soviet Union with its magical retelling of John Taras' ``Firebird,'' set to the original Igor Stravinsky score. Now considered among the country's top professional ballet companies, Dance Theatre of Harlem's commitment to its mission remains as strong as ever. When not doing regular performances, the dancers conduct workshops for disadvantaged youths, introducing them to the arts and the discipline they require, and particularly to classical ballet. One such audience included members of rival Los Angeles street gangs. ``We're trying to be positive role models ... to all the youth in the United States,'' says Eddie J. Shellman, a principal dancer who joined the company in 1975 and plans to stay even after he stops dancing. ``We're very close. We're all related because we're all going for the same thing, which is a sense of pride, giving the best that we can give _ just raising the company's self-esteem, which happens at every performance,'' he said. Shellman is spending the layoff teaching ballet, working on a license to teach dance as a substitute in New York public schools and preparing for his wedding to fellow dancer Endalyn Taylor. He is living partly off his savings. Lowell Smith, a principal dancer who's been with the troupe for 13 years, is trying to break into acting, as he's always planned to do. He intends to dance full time again when the company resumes. But at 36, he's also realizing he may soon be seeking a more permanent alternative. Mitchell felt Dance Theatre of Harlem was somehow safer than other non-profit arts companies, partly because it earns a relatively high 50 percent of its budget. But the middle fell out of the company's scheduled European tour when an arts festival in Leeds, England, was canceled after its artistic director died, and its London booking was lost because the venue's regular occupant had a schedule change. Then an American sponsor had to cancel the company's dates in San Diego for financial reasons. Facing a potential $2 million deficit and a spring New York season that traditionally loses money, the only way the company could show fiscal responsibility was to curtail activities, Mitchell said. The company laid off about 80 full-time dancers, technicians and administrative members of a full- and part-time staff that totals 140, cutting the budget for the fiscal year that ends Sept. 30 to $5.3 million from $7.6 million. Special grants from Chase Manhattan Bank and the New York State Council on the Arts allowed the company's school to keep going. Performances were canceled from April, except for one fundraiser. The company plans to resume Oct. 1 _ provided the board sees the fiscal year end without red ink and sees a significant start toward $2 million in the bank. Mitchell is optimistic. But some dancers, especially younger ones, worry he won't be able to bring everyone back. Andre Levitt, 26, who joined the corps last year, reluctantly admits he's been auditioning for other dance troupes. ``I don't want to, but you have to be careful,'' he said. ``I'm too young to guest now for the rest of my career. I should be in a company, learning things.'' Meanwhile, he tries to make ends meet. On what he says is the bottom salary rung, Levitt normally earns $495 a week. Unemployment brings him $225 a week. A three-week guest appearance with a Virginia company brought him $500, total. ``It was really frustrating,'' Levitt said of the layoff. ``I guess I thought that with a bigger company like Dance Theatre of Harlem, that things like this just don't happen.'' Sophia Cannonier feels even more vulnerable. She's still a probationary apprentice, not yet under regular contract. Still a student and on a stipend, the layoff cost her half her check. But still a citizen of Bermuda, she has no work permit. And still a student, she has had to spend at least four hours a day in class and rehearsing for an open house, leaving little time to work even off the books. ``It keeps me busy. It keeps me in class,'' she says. ``It keeps my hopes and just my adrenaline going.'' Cannonier, 20, plans to go home and live with her parents this summer. She'll guest, like some other members of the company, with the Bermuda Civic Ballet. A former beauty queen, she plans to do some modeling. And, she says, she will return. ``I ultimately want to be in Dance Theatre of Harlem,'' Cannonier said. ``I love what they do, how they perform. And I want to be a part of that ... just the way they move, their rapport, their style.''

DOC.HEAD: OUT OF STEP: Turmoil in the Dance World
Dollars Go, But Don't Come Easily
With AM-AP Arts: American Dance, b0486
DOC.TEXT: In the world of tutus and toe shoes, red is particularly hot this season. Barely a week seems to pass without a mention of some dance company's financial woes. The problems aren't particularly new to non-profit organizations. ``Everybody's always been struggling,'' said Stephanie French, vice president for corporate contributions and cultural affairs at Philip Morris Companies Inc. ``But somehow it seems that they're more severe now. ``Giving budgets haven't gone up so much, but everybody's operating budget has. All the requests are for more money.'' Trouble comes to all sizes and all regions. At the Joffrey Ballet, which has homes on both coasts, long-simmering artistic vs. administrative conflicts were brought to a head this spring by a deficit growing toward $2 million. In a power struggle, artistic director Gerald Arpino resigned _ taking his works and those of the late Robert Joffrey, with whom he founded the company in 1956. Numerous board members, including French, also left. Arpino and the works have returned. The deficit didn't leave. At the Cleveland Ballet, fast growth helped cause an accumulation of red ink, particularly in the last five years, that is hard to wash out. American interest in dance blossomed in the 1960s and '70s, thanks largely to the Ford Foundation fostering ballet training and companies nationwide. Headline-grabbing defections of glamorous Soviet dancers such as Rudolf Nureyev and Mikhail Baryshnikov also helped. But now audience growth is leveling, while costs are not, and companies find themselves in an increasingly competitive fight for money. Douglas Sonntag, senior program specialist in the dance program of the National Endowment for the Arts, notes that many companies, of various sizes, are flourishing artistically and financially _ such as the New York City, Boston, Houston and Pacific Northwest ballets. If a dance company earns more than 30 percent to 40 percent of its income, that's really quite good, Sonntag says. But it isn't always enough. Dance Theater of Harlem has been earning 50 percent of its budget, says co-founder and artistic director Arthur Mitchell. But this year, emergencies unrelated to the company cost it three scheduled appearances, two in the middle of a European tour. That erased $1.2 million. Then an anticipated $150,000 in grants turned out to be $50,000. Seeing red, Mitchell, the executive director and the board took emergency evasive action. They called a six-month layoff, canceling the remaining European dates as well as the company's New York season that, though important for prestige, traditionally loses money. The 14-year-old Cleveland Ballet has been growing by leaps and bounds. Its budget for the fiscal year ended last June 30 was about $7 million, more than double that of five years before. Its deficit was $1.3 million. This year also is expected to close in the red. The Cleveland Ballet earns 65 percent of its income, spokeswoman Christine Patronik-Holder says. The rest is contributed. And, as is the case with many other dance companies, the Cleveland Ballet has no endowment. The company has found its niche in full-length, theatrical ballets that are expensive to mount, even though it makes most costumes and scenery in-house. But ticket sales have gone down, Patronik-Holder says. Rent for theater, studio and office space is $600,000 a year. Growing pains have been costly. In 1988, the Cleveland Ballet presented itself in Chicago, to good reviews and a $600,000 loss. Now, it performs only in Cleveland and its other home city of San Jose, Calif., unless assured of at least breaking even. Philip Morris' French believes the answer lies in arts companies finding a broader donor base, especially among individuals. But it's not a good time for donations. At the National Endowment for the Arts, the dance program budget has remained at about $9 million for several years, Sonntag says. About two-thirds of that goes to dance companies. Grants range from $10,000 to $400,000. But they have to be matched. In the private sector, where profits have been sagging, corporations that sponsor the arts are demanding more marketing for their money, he said. That poses problems for arts groups that can't afford to give disproportionate credit to any single source. Today, individuals, corporations and foundations with any money to give face a devastating array of causes that address fundamental social needs _ such as homelessness, AIDS and crack-addicted babies. ``They are hitting at a much more basic level of need in our society than cultural improvement,'' says Sonntag. ``We have to have homes before we have theaters.''

DOC.TEXT: In Turin, Italy, the Roman Catholic Church has six official exorcists to cast out demons. Magicians, seers, faith healers, mind readers, astrologers and others dabbling in the occult advertise regularly on television. Has Satan established a stronghold in the ancient city famous for its religious icons?

Real or imagined, the devil is tormenting this sober industrial city in northwestern Italy. Some believe a sinister presence lurks in the shadows along the city's broad, arcaded boulevards and haunts the medieval squares in the nearby mountain hamlets of the Piedmontese Alps. The city likes to be remembered as the former seat of the House of Savoy dynasty, the first capital of a unified Italy, the resting place of saints and religious relics, the home of the Fiat auto empire. It's also the home of the Shroud of Turin, which some believe was the cloth with which Joseph of Arimathea wrapped the body of Jesus Christ after his crucifixion. But Turin has a darker reputation as a haven for Satan and his disciples. There is no proof, of course. But what is certain is that the city has six official exorcists, an underground core of devil worshipers and thousands of people dealing in the occult. Specialists in the occult maintain that Turin forms part of two ``magic'' triangles representing good and evil. Along with Prague, Czechoslovakia, and Lyon, France, the city is reputedly a center of ``white magic,'' a positive force. Turin is also said to join London and San Francisco as a stronghold of ``black magic,'' which is considered harmful or diabolic. ``Turin has always been a place of great spiritual and magical ferment,'' says Giuditta Dembech, a journalist and author of the book ``Torino: Citta Magica'' (Turin: Magic City). ``It has some of the qualities of places like Mecca, Jerusalem and Lourdes.'' The city first attracted widespread notoriety as a devil's playground four years ago when Turin's archbishop at the time, Cardinal Anastasio Ballestrero, appointed six official exorcists. Exorcism, the process of casting out demons, is an accepted practice in the Catholic Church. Pope John Paul II has frequently stated that the devil is a pervasive reality in today's world. The naming of the six exorcists in Turin followed a directive from Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, prefect of the Vatican's Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, for churches to exercise greater control over exorcisms. ``Unfortunately some of our priests had gone a little too far and were performing exorcisms too hastily,'' says Canon Giuseppe Ruata, who heads Turin's pool of official exorcists. Two events in 1988 further contributed to the city's satanic image. First, the pope spoke of the devil during a visit to Turin, saying: ``From the history of salvation, we know that where there are saints there is also another person who presents himself not by his name but the name of others. He is called the prince of this world, the demon.'' Then, a month later, Turin hosted a weeklong conference on demonology that bitterly divided local politicians, churchmen and academics. Church officials deny Turin has a greater problem with the devil than any other cities, pointing out that Milan tops Italy with eight exorcists of its own. Milan has a population of 1.5 million, compared with Turin's 1 million. ``Turin has an image it doesn't deserve,'' Ruata, 74, said in an interview at the archdiocesan offices. ``I wouldn't make Turin out to be the capital of the demonic empire.'' Most agree, however, that Turin has an unusually high number of magicians, seers, faith healers, mind readers, astrologers and others dabbling in superstition and witchcraft. They advertise continuously on private television and radio. ``There are more than 100 of these types of agencies in Turin,'' Ruata says. ``They charge $400 as the initial fee for removing a spell. It's a huge form of trickery.''

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
TURIN, Italy: of trickery.''
DOC.TEXT: Ruata says he is approached every day by people who believe they are possessed by the demon. Nearly all, he says, are people with psychological problems or are superstitious. Actual demonic possession occurs in ``perhaps 2 or 3 percent'' of the cases, Ruata says. He says he has personally performed only one real exorcism. ``Real diabolical possession involves a great aversion for the sacred,'' he says. ``The possessed will spew out terrifying curses and speak foreign languages which they never learned. Sometimes levitation occurs. They rise up, then fall back like a sack of potatoes. It's horrible. Then the phenomenon goes away and they don't remember anything.'' While there are people in Turin who turn to the church to combat demons, there are others who pay devotion to Satan in secret, ritualistic ceremonies. Ruata says devil worshipers have robbed churches of hosts, the bread consecrated for the Eucharist, and other objects for use in ``black Masses.'' Gianluigi Marianini, a Turin television personality, political figure and demonologist, claims the city has 40,000 satanic followers. ``The ones I've known are everyday people,'' says Marianini, 71, stroking his white goatee. ``They don't give any outward sign of anything. They just have this dark corner of their lives. They are usually people who are frustrated with their lives and choose this parallel religion out of disillusionment.'' Dembech, the author, disputes the 40,000 figure. ``It's already hard enough to find 40,000 perfect Christians,'' she writes. ``The real Satanists in this city can be counted on one hand.'' Turin's devil worshipers have sometimes left behind signs of their activities. Last year, for example, a satanic cult was blamed for desecrating an ancient church in the suburb of Pianezza, plundering the tombs of clerics buried there centuries ago and using the bones for some macabre ritual. The bones were found scattered around the church and some tombstones were crushed. Marianini says several young girls found murdered in the countryside south of Turin in recent years have born signs of ritual sacrifice. ``The girls were killed by sword or dagger, their money and jewelry were untouched and there was no sexual assault,'' he says. Marianini says he's seen basement temples used for black Masses. They are equipped with a black marble altar, an upside-down crucifix, black candles and wooden balls ``which are said to contain pieces of human hearts,'' he says. During black Masses, according to eyewitness accounts, participants at times show up hooded and the ritual sometimes ends in sexual orgies. An example of the undeserved attention given the devil occurred in 1988 when the murders of a young Turin couple were blamed on a satanic ritual, drawing such lurid headlines in the normally staid local newspaper, La Stampa, as ``Fear of the Devil Killed Them.'' Last month, a court put an end to the hysteria, ruling they were victims of a cocaine ring. ``The Devil Acquitted,'' said La Stampa. The Rev. John Navone, an American theologian at the Pontifical Gregorian University in Rome, believes Satanism is no more prevalent in Turin or Italy than in other modern, industrial societies. ``What about Los Angeles or Miami or Seattle?'' he asks. ``I think there is probably more Satanism in the United States than Italy. The fact that it is a scandal in Italy is perhaps a sign of the society's health.''

DOC.TEXT: This is a love story, the story of a man and woman who overcame unusual handicaps to find happiness together, not the least of which was the attitudes of other people. Bill and Myra, both mentally and physically disabled, are helping put to rest some old stereotypes.

They were afraid of each other at first. Myra wanted to know why Bill wore braces on his For repeats of AP copy, the Service Desk can be reached at 212-621-1595 or 1596.

DOC.TEXT: Neither Bill nor Myra has matured much beyond the mentality of a young adult, Buchanan says. But together they have achieved what each wanted so badly for so long: independence and intimacy. ``At night, when I come home, he's sitting there,'' Myra says. ``There's somebody to talk to, somebody in the house.'' There's somebody to help figure out the microwave, turn off the television or share a funny story. ``There's someone to call `Hon' or `Sweetie,''' says Diane Barbee, residential director at the cooperative. As in any relationship, Bill and Myra have their problems. Through therapy, they have learned how to control the frustrations that quickly turn to anger. They've also learned how to turn to each other when faced with the sudden pain of an insult, perhaps issued by a mocking stranger in a passing car. But still they are sometimes unprepared. ``One time there were some people in a car and they said they were going to a party, did we want to come along,''' Myra says. ``So we did, but it wasn't good. They were religious people and they wanted things.'' That's where the Cooperative For Human Services staff comes in. Counselors such as Barbee and Buchanan are on hand to intervene when someone _ perhaps a peddler _ tries to capitalize on Bill and Myra's naivete. The staff is also there to explain the daily prejudices and bolster morale. They are part of a civil rights movement embodied by the proposed Americans With Disabilities Act which, if approved by Congress, would guarantee equal opportunities to the nation's more than 35 million adults with mental and physical handicaps. It would help people like Bill and Myra when they confront old stereotypes, such as the common assumption that parents with disabilities will necessarily bear similarly disabled children. Dr. Pasquale Accardo, co-author of ``When A Parent Is Mentally Retarded,'' says it depends on the individual whether retarded parents are able to give their children a well-rounded upbringing. But he says his studies indicate that less than one-third of their children are born retarded. ``People still have irrational fears,'' says Accardo, a professor at St. Louis University School of Medicine. Bill and Myra are helping educate the public. They are familiar fixtures in their hometown just outside Boston, meeting people while on their weekly trip to the supermarket, standing in line to catch a ``Batman'' matinee or having a hamburger at the Brigham's coffee shop. ``A lot of people look at someone like Myra and Bill and think it's nice they can do for themselves,'' Barbee says. ``But others think differently.'' Some people underestimate what Bill and Myra can do for themselves. They think they have to speak louder or gesture wildly. Some people don't understand that retarded adults are not exempt from the human range of emotions. Disabled people can be scary _ even to each other. Bill, much like Myra, had reservations when they first met in 1974 at a supervised workshop. After four decades of living in his parents' home, he wanted to prove he could live on his own. But he also harbored memories of a previous girlfriend who had whipped him across the face with a belt and threatened his one good eye with a lit cigarette. ``I wanted to know why she was in the hospital for all those years and she explained how she used to be really nervous and did damage to her mother and friends,'' he says. ``I just looked at her and thought, `Should I or shouldn't I?' '' he says. ``And then I said to myself, `I'm going to try it again.''' Soon they were sharing Cokes at a nearby Holiday Inn, listening together to the songs of Elvis Presley or taking the bus to spend sunny days at Salisbury Beach. Sometimes they would take drives with Myra's parents up to Vermont or Maine. They were growing closer, and soon they became lovers. ``When I was growing up I figured I would never move out on my own and always be a burden,'' Myra says, reaching for Bill's hand. ``I'd never know how to cook or sew. I'm dumb. I'm stupid. That's what I thought. Now I know some other things. And Billy does, too.''
