DOC.TEXT: It's the last wish of hundreds of terminally ill children to visit Walt Disney World or one of the other tourist attractions in central Florida. Now they can, thanks to the efforts of a death camp survivor and a lot of other individuals and corporations.

As a boy of 13 in a Nazi concentration camp, Henri Landwirth learned what it's like to wait fearfully for death at an early age. At 63, he believes he's been living the past 45 years on borrowed time. So feeling a need ``to give something back,'' he's now helping make dreams come true for terminally ill children. The slim, white-haired Landwirth, a survivor of the infamous death camp at Auschwitz, is the founder of a vacation village called Give Kids the World, a special retreat for children whose last wish is to visit Walt Disney World, Sea World or one of the many other tourist attractions in central Florida. Because of his efforts _ combined with the generosity of some major corporations and individuals _ hundreds of terminally ill boys and girls come here every year with their families. All it takes is for the sick child to ask a local group in his or her hometown. They spend a week at the complex, each family in one of the 32 villas at the year-old village. ``Seventy-five percent of the dying children want to see Mickey Mouse,'' Landwirth says, citing statistics compiled from visitors. ``Eighty percent of the families never left their home state and just as many will never travel again as a family. So this trip is a lifetime vacation. ``Families can do all the major theme parks or whatever they want. Each kid gets a gift every day. We have a big party, local restaurants provide food. The Disney and Sea World characters visit and entertain. We have volunteers working with the kids.'' The village is located in the rural countryside less than a mile from busy U.S. Highway 192 near Disney World. It has a playground, a pool designed for the handicapped, a fishing lake, a mock pirate ship and a large cafeteria-family center. ``We never turn anyone away, and we can accommodate a family on very short notice because the greatest enemy of these kids is time,'' says the soft-spoken Landwirth. Landwirth came to his role as benefactor through the determination he acquired as a youth to survive the Jewish Holocaust. He and his twin sister, Margot, were separated from their parents and sent off to separate concentration camps in German-occupied Poland in the early days of World War II. Their father, Max, was killed soon after his imprisonment. Their mother, Fanny, was among more than 1,000 female prisoners herded aboard a ship that was blown up at sea just weeks before the Nazis surrendered to the Allies. After five years of imprisonment, young Henri managed to escape and spent about a month hiding and wandering _ homeless, sick, hungry and scared. Finally, three days after the war ended, he was taken in by a family in a small Czechoslovakian village. After his recovery, Landwirth hitchhiked back to a small town in Poland where he had learned his sister was living after her repatriation. Together they returned to Belgium, where they were born, and he emigrated to this country in 1949. Soon after his arrival in New York, where he worked briefly as a diamond cutter, Landwirth was drafted by the U.S. Army during the Korean War. After his discharge, he went to hotel-management school under the GI Bill, got married and eventually got a job in a Miami Beach hotel as a bellboy. Hard work paid off in better jobs and soon he was manager of the Starlite Hotel in Cocoa Beach, at the time the nation's space program was gearing up in nearby Cape Canaveral. Landwirth became innkeeper to the nation's original crew of astronauts, the Mercury Seven. Virtually the entire space hierarchy and journalist corps moved into first one and then another hotel he operated during those early years. He became friends with astronauts John Glenn, Alan Shepard and Scott Carpenter and media personalities such as Walter Cronkite _ all of whom would later serve on the advisory board of Give Kids the World Foundation.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
KISSIMMEE, Fla.: World Foundation.
DOC.TEXT: ``We were like a family,'' says Landwirth, recalling the exciting, infant days of the space program. Glenn, now a U.S. senator from Ohio, went into partnership with Landwirth in the hotel business in the Orlando area in 1970, soon after Disney World began operating. The two were franchise holders for three large Holiday Inn motels for years. They still own one in Kissimmee, and are planning to build a new hotel at the Disney community of Lake Buena Vista. Landwirth and the astronauts also became founding members of the Mercury Seven Foundation, which provides annual scholarships for upper-level college students specializing in aerospace, science and engineering fields. Landwirth, who has a long history of philanthropy, first became interested in helping terminally ill children when as a hotel operator he provided free rooms for some of the kids and parents who were brought here on an occasional basis by volunteer groups around the country. ``I remember two kids died while waiting for arrangements to be made for a visit to Disney World,'' Landwirth says. ``It took so long to coordinate efforts for airline transportation, lodging, free tickets at the attractions, food and all of the other things. ``I decided something had to be done.'' Landwirth used a foundation he had created in his mother's name as financial backing for his idea to act as a clearinghouse to make all local arrangements for the last-wish trips. He first contacted Disney officials three years ago and they enthusiastically agreed to help. ``They were fantastic,'' he says. ``To this day, they've never said no to anything and they are our biggest supporters and contributors _ from money to services and people and all the special things that they do and do not publicize.'' After that, Sea World, Cypress Gardens and other attractions got into the picture on a permanent basis, along with Holiday Inn and some 40 other businesses and groups large and small. Area hotels continued to furnish accommodations until the village was built and dedicated last year. The $3.5 million in construction costs came from donations, with $1.7 million coming from Holiday Inns Corp. and its employees and $1.8 million in labor and materials from area businesses and the community, said Julia H. Wylam, director of development. Landwirth calculates the value of the goods, services, tickets, gifts and other items provided directly to the kids and their families last year at $3 million. There are some 150 wish-granting foundations around the world that identify the children, provide administrative and medical assistance and round-trip transportation for their visits here. Many of the kids write Landwirth and the village staff after their return home. ``You are a wonderful man,'' wrote teen-ager Amy Johnson from Phoenix, shortly before she died of leukemia. ``Children are supposed to be our future but kids like me don't have futures, we just have memories _ memories of our past. You're in my prayers for remembering us little people.'' Lisa and Jack McDonald of Lewiston, Maine, who brought their 5-year-old daughter, Kristin, to the village in March, wrote: ``Our visit to the Kids Village allowed us as parents to share our experiences, hopes and fears with other parents who are undergoing very similar actions and emotions in their respective lives.'' Landwirth now devotes most of his time to the village. ``This is my life now. I'm fulfilling a spiritual need,'' he says. ``I love this country. I love what's happened to me here. This is more rewarding than anything I have ever done.''

DOC.TEXT: In the 40 years since Arthur Miller first adapted Henrik Ibsen's ``Enemy of the People'' as a protest against McCarthyism, he has reverted back to the secondary theme of the century-old play, a warning about environmental pollution. Miller has moved the play from a 19th century Norwegian village to a turn-of-the-century health spa in Maine in a new staging for ``American Playhouse'' on PBS. It will have its premiere on Wednesday. ``It's really a prophetic play,'' says Miller, who is in Los Angeles to help with the taping of the play by KCET-TV. Jack O'Brien directs this version, which stars John Glover and George Grizzard as brothers who end up on opposite sides of an issue. Glover plays a doctor who discovers that a tannery's faulty waste disposal system is polluting the town's water supply and is causing an epidemic of health problems. When he makes this public, the townspeople, led by Grizzard, the mayor, turn on him for fear it will harm the town's reputation as a health spa. In 1950, when Miller adapted the play for Broadway, it spoke out against Sen. Joseph McCarthy's campaign against domestic communism. But the times have changed and the play is now seen as a cautionary tale about pollution. ``I saw the Ibsen play in London last year and realized why the ecology theme had such an impact,'' Miller says. ``But that wasn't why Ibsen wrote the play. Ecology was hardly important in Norway in the last century. It was the right of someone to speak the truth against the will of the majority.'' Ibsen wrote ``An Enemy of the People'' in 1881 after reading a newspaper account of a scientist who was vilified for reporting the pollution of a town's water supply. The tourist dollars theme also was used by Peter Benchley in ``Jaws.'' It told of a police chief who faced opposition from the mayor and townspeople when he tried to close a seaside resort's beaches because of attacks by a great white shark. ``One of the reasons I chose to adapt this play in 1950 was that Fredric March asked me to do it at the height of the McCarthy era,'' Miller says. ``In that same period I wrote `The Crucible,' which is a parable of the McCarthy era.'' Miller is also discussing an adaptation of ``The Crucible'' with executives of the Arts & Entertainment cable channel. O'Brien, artistic director of the Old Globe Theater in San Diego, says what Miller has done is give ``Enemy of the People'' an ``American spin.'' ``Bringing the play to America figures only obliquely in the story because Arthur has such respect for Ibsen,'' O'Brien says. ``Arthur has written the dialogue in quintessential American cadence. But the relevance of this play written so long ago is scary. ``I just did Anton Chekhov's `Uncle Vanya,' which was written in 1892. It has a huge speech about conservation and ecological disasters. You would absolutely believe that play was written today. The same thing with Arthur's adaptation. So why shouldn't we take advantage of it?'' O'Brien, at the Globe Theater since 1981, puts on 12 to 15 shows a year. ``Enemy of the People'' is the fifth play he's directed for ``The American Playhouse.''

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 1 b&w photo.)
DOC.TEXT: Playwright Peter Barnes recalls that about 10 years ago critics were complaining about the length of his plays. In frustration, he tried radio. He liked it. Barnes is not alone in writing regularly for both stage and radio. The list includes such names as Tom Stoppard, Arnold Wesker and Harold Pinter. Not only does radio offer exposure, it attracts big names. Barnes wrote for radio one of the late Laurence Olivier's last roles, ``No End To Dreaming.'' His radio work has enjoyed the luxury of talent such as Dame Peggy Ashcroft, Paul Scofield and Sir John Gielgud. With the notable exception of David Mamet, few major playwrights in the United States bother with radio drama. But several expatriate American writers have found a hospitable environment on the British airwaves. Craig Warner, a 25-year-old American based in London, has had three radio dramas produced by the British Broadcasting Corp. He says he has now written more radio plays than he ever heard broadcast when he was in his native Los Angeles. Warner's ``By Where the Old Shed Used To Be'' won a Giles Cooper award as one of the five best radio dramas of the past year. For many, the BBC and radio drama are synonymous. Besides serials and soap operas, the network produces an average of 500 radio plays a year. Two commercial stations _ Radio Clyde in Scotland and LBC Crown-FM in London _ also program radio drama. Finlay Welsh, drama producer at Radio Clyde, acknowledges that audiences and financial returns are small. However, he said in an interview, ``It's very important that an independent radio station not simply produce news and music programs but also make a definite and deliberate contribution to writing and acting.'' Radio drama's heyday dates back to Dylan Thomas's ``Under Milkwood,'' perhaps the best-known radio play ever. It lasted until the mid-1960s. Those were the days when the theater was under censorship. There was no alternative ``fringe'' theater to pick up the slack. ``The very important thing is to nurture writers,'' says John Tydeman, head of the BBC Radio drama department. ``Pinter still writes; Tom Stoppard is writing a pla for us. They can say things in a certain way on radio, and we are discovering new people all the time.'' Some are first surprised, then delighted, to find themselves writing for radio. Peter Barnes' series ``Barnes's People'' began on BBC Radio 3 in 1980. ``Radio was a ball because they just asked, I delivered, and they put it on,'' he says. Barnes notes that radio plays are made in three or four days, compared with the eight years it took for his award-winning 1985 play ``Red Noses'' to get produced at the Royal Shakespeare Company. Arnold Wesker, the noted British playwright of ``Roots'' and ``Chips with Everything,'' was commissioned to write his first radio play, ``Bluey,'' in 1984. It was about a judge on the verge of a nervous collapse. ``I got my education from radio, but I never really thought about writing for radio,'' he recalls. Wesker found he enjoyed the genre. ``I was using sound in a way that couldn't be used so effectively elsewhere _ the sound of wind and rain, the sound of building sites, the sound of words echoing through the judge's head which finally assemble and tell him what had led to his breakdown,'' Wesker says. A second radio play, ``Yardsale,'' was later performed as part of a double bill on stage. Wesker says he would write more if the money were better. Even the most successful radio dramas pay a fraction of the $35,000 to $50,000 or more that a hit play can generate for its writer. David Zane Mairowitz, an American writer based in France, says he's ``one of the few people in the world'' who can live off radio drama. His plays are produced first in Britain, then translated and sold on the Continent. Mairowitz, 47, says he was drawn to the imaginative demands of radio. ``A radio listener is someone who has to produce the images in his mind, in his head. Whoever's listening is responsible for 50 percent of the input of whatever he's listening to.'' Mairowitz, like Warner, also received a Giles Cooper award this year, for ``The Stalin Sonata,'' about a female pianist imprisoned during Stalin's 1937 purges. Sometimes radio is a steppingstone to the stage. Agatha Christie's long-running ``The Mousetrap'' began on radio as ``Three Blind Mice.'' Tom Stoppard wrote his 90-minute ``Artist Descending A Staircase'' for radio only to have it turn up last December on Broadway, where it flopped. Simon Gray, whose ``Quartermaine's Terms'' and ``The Common Pursuit'' have been hits off-Broadway, used radio as the medium to revise his London play ``Melon.'' ``I found myself changing a few scenes and suggested we should give it a whirl on radio,'' he says. Gray rewrote it for BBC Radio 3 under the title ``The Holy Terror,'' a name it will retain for its Broadway bow next January.

DOC.HEAD: Civic Forum Led Revolution, But Has Many Election Challengers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 1-2 and 17, A survey ... 12 percent., to UPDATE with later poll.
DOC.TEXT: It won the ``velvet revolution,'' runs the government and smiles on every village from its happy-face symbol, but Civic Forum has tough competition in the nation's first free elections since 1946. Polls show it leading, but with less than a quarter of the total vote. Civic Forum appears likely to lose to the Christian Democrats in Slovakia, the more rural and Roman Catholic of the two constituent republics. Campaigning began officially April 29, with rallies, posters on practically every available surface and endless spots on radio and television. Each of 23 parties fighting for seats in the federal parliament and the Czech and Slovak legislatures gets four hours of time. Czechoslovaks will vote Friday and Saturday. Few differences are evident among the parties. All reject the communist past, including the Communists. All favor a market economy and parliamentary democracy. Civic Forum's membership cuts across the political spectrum. It claims to be neither left nor right and emphasizes its well-known personalities, including President Vaclav Havel, experience, and authority as leader of the November revolution. In the din of conflicting election claims, muddied further by accusations of past connections between leading figures and the Communist secret police, polls show one in four voters undecided and have the the Communists running third. As elsewhere in Eastern Europe, the Communists are under fire from all the others, despite the party's new advocacy of democratic principles. Civic Forum's competition comes from a flock of new or remodeled parties, chief among them the Christian Democrats, buoyed by recent center-right victories in East Germany and Hungary. ``We shall win ... but I don`t know how big it will be,'' said Jana Ryslinkova, a mathematician who speaks for Civic Forum. ``I think it won't be less than 30 percent.'' Havel, Civic Forum's biggest asset with voters, is officially setting himself apart from organization he helped found, on grounds his office requires impartiality. The immensely popular president does help indirectly by participating in events organized by Civic Forum. He opened its indoor-outdoor exhibit on recent Czechoslovak history, which draws large crowds. Under a new proportional system, a party whose candidate list gets 5 percent of the vote nationally is guaranteed representation in Parliament. Up to six parties could qualify, forcing Civic Forum to make a power-sharing arrangement. Parties variously describe themselves as right, center or center-left, but the main distinctions involve economic control and social benefits. Leftist parties such as the Communists, Socialists and Social Democrats favor slower conversion to capitalism and some retention of benefits. The Christian Democrats reject any degree of socialism, empasizing their identification with ``Christian values and tradition.'' Some Civic Forum leaders want to retain elements of socialism. A survey released by the state polling organization May 20 said Civic Forum was supported by 26.9 percent of voters, while the Christian Democrats had 16.4 percent and the Communists and Greens 9.8 percent each. In Slovakia, Christian Democrats led Civic Forum's Slovakian arm by 29.1 percent to 13.1 percent. In November, Civic Forum seemed to be the country's only authentic political force. Its rallies attracted hundreds of thousands of people and persuaded Communist leaders to step aside peacefully. Since then, the government it dominates has improved Czechoslovakia's image abroad, negotiated a deal for withdrawal of Soviet military forces by June 1991 and erased myriad symbols of the old order. Radical overhaul of the economy must wait until after the election, however, in part because of divisions in the government over how fast to go. Ms. Ryslinkova, the Civic Forum spokeswoman, said the edge goes to Civic Forum over parties offering similar programs because ``what we have more than the other parties is the ... people able to lead.'' Hoping to overcome it is the Christian Democratic Alliance of the People's Party, formerly allied with the Communists, the Christian Democratic Party in in the Czech republic, and the Christian Democratic Movement in Slovakia. The alliance has joined forces with associations of would-be entrepreneurs and farmers and appeals to those with Christian values, said Miroslav Bartos, a People's Party candidate and one of the parliamentarians appointed in December to replace resigning Communist deputies. Communist spokesman Josef Hora said his party, which ruled from 1948 until last year, might get 10 percent to 12 percent of the vote. The party claims a membership of 900,000 in the population of 15.5 million. Hora complained that critics don't take the party's ``renewal'' seriously and still blame it for the repressions of the past.

DOC.HEAD: `DICK TRACY': Summer's No. 1 With a Bullet?
From Clues to Cues _ Dick Tracy Goes From Funnies to Film
DOC.TEXT: ``Dick Tracy'' the movie opens in nearly 2,000 theaters June 15 amid a media megablitz that rivals last summer's ``Batman.'' But will Warren Beatty's film about the square-jawed flatfoot with the yellow fedora match the $252 million domestic gross amassed by the caped crusader? Fingers crossed, Walt Disney Co. is tossing a huge premiere at Disney World in Florida with 3,000 journalists expected to attend. Following trailers that have appeared in 2,000 theaters since Christmas, TV commercials will be unleashed on the nation's networks. Merchandise, including Tracy's wrist-watch radio, will flood the market. But skeptics point to some negatives. The comic strip Dick Tracy, once featured in 500 newspapers, now appears in 150 and is little known by today's young, moviegoing audience. And what's worse, the young crowd hardly knows Beatty, 53, who has made only two films in nine years, the last being the quintessential bomb ``Ishtar.'' His other was the critically acclaimed ``Reds,'' in 1981. He co-starred with Diane Keaton and received an Academy Award for best director. Another problem is that although ``Dick Tracy'' co-star Madonna may be a megastar in pop music, her last few movies were megadisasters: ``Shanghai Surprise'' and ``Who's That Girl.'' However, Barrie Osborne, executive producer of ``Dick Tracy,'' takes an upbeat view. ``The picture should attract a wide audience, because it can be appreciated on different levels,'' he said in an interview. ``The younger audience can enjoy the prosthetic characters (Pruneface, Flattop, etc.), lots of action and beautiful color. And they certainly know Madonna. ``The older audience can appreciate the wit and the appearance of the film; much of it was derived from post-expressionist paintings _ a `Three Penny Opera'-Bertolt Brecht look. ... And Warren can bring that (older) audience as well.'' Disney plans to issue graphic novelizations _ spruced-up comic books _ of ``Dick Tracy'' to bring some sort of awareness to the movie and character. ``Dick Tracy'' was the creation of Chester Gould, who drew cartoons for Chicago papers. He began submitting comic strip ideas to Joseph Patterson, publisher of the New York Daily News. Gould finally clicked with ``Plainclothes Tracy,'' a hawk-nosed, straight-arrow detective who Patterson renamed Dick. The strip made its debut in the Detroit Mirror on Oct. 4, 1931, and the Daily News eight days later. The comic strip featured blood, bullets and a menacing menagerie of villains with memorable names. Flattop, Flyface, Measles, Mumbles and more have threatened the intrepid two-fisted Tracy for nearly 60 years. Tracy, his sweetheart Tess Trueheart and his grotesque enemies became American icons in the 1930s and '40s. Low-budget movies and serials and a short-run TV series helped fill the country's fascination with Gould's denizens of the underworld. ``Dick Tracy,'' according to Beatty, had its beginnings in 1977 when producers Art Linson and Floyd Mutrux bought film rights from the Tribune Syndicate. They made a deal with Paramount Pictures, which enlisted Universal Pictures to co-produce. Various packages were proposed, including projects with directors Steven Spielberg, John Landis, Richard Benjamin and Walter Hill, and stars Harrison Ford, Clint Eastwood, Richard Gere, Tom Selleck and Mel Gibson. Beatty became involved in 1983, but Paramount reportedly balked at his pay demands. Five years later, Michael Eisner and Jeff Katzenberg had moved from Paramount to Disney, and they revived ``Tracy'' with Beatty, adding certain fiscal restraints (``Ishtar'' cost $40 million). No one at Disney is saying how much ``Dick Tracy'' cost. Reports range from $23 million to $30 million, considerably less than other summer epics such as ``Total Recall,'' a reported $50 million; ``Die Hard 2,'' $60 million plus; and ``Days of Thunder,'' $55 million plus. ``It was a modestly budgeted film,'' insists executive producer Osborne, a veteran of such bloated budgets as ``Apocalypse Now'' and ``The Cotton Club,'' both made by Francis Coppola. ``It was all filmed on the back lot and on sets that were constructed. The film was made on budget _ within the contingency.'' The contingency, according to reports, was that Beatty would have to sacrifice part of his take for exceeding the budget. Osborne, 46, who began in films as a Directors Guild trainee, joined ``Dick Tracy'' in September 1988. He had not worked previously with Beatty, but he soon learned how the producer-director-star operated. ``Warren acts as a conductor,'' said Osborne. ``He is very collaborative, likes to get people together and listen to their ideas. Then he selects what he wants. ``The look of the film was his idea. He wanted to achieve the same quality of the Sunday comic strip. When there was a red, it was the same red throughout, the same green, etc. It took some convincing when (cinematographer) Vittorio Storaro and (production designer) Richard Sylbert came on board. ``The limited-color pallette was hard on (costume designer) Milena Canonero; she came in with cloth samples in 10 shades of blue, 10 shades of green. Warren told her he wanted one shade only. It was a tough challenge, but it helps the film. The production design of most films is anchored in reality. Because of the grotesque characters in `Dick Tracy,' we needed devices to tell the audience that it was not reality.'' A major attraction of ``Dick Tracy'' is the appearance of well-known stars in wild makeups, Osborne believes. They go unbilled, but their identities are an open secret: Al Pacino as mob boss Big Boy Caprice, Dustin Hoffman as Mumbles, James Caan as Ribs. Among those who are billed: Glenne Headly, Tess Trueheart; Mandy Patinkin, 88 Keys; Charles Durning, Police Chief Brandon; William Forsythe, Flattop; Dick Van Dyke, the district attorney; Paul Sorvino, Lips Manlis; Estelle Parsons, Mrs. Trueheart. Beatty considered several actresses for the role of the seductive moll, Breathless Mahoney, before deciding on his close friend Madonna, who argued that the role was similar to her own onstage persona. Beatty agreed, eschewing the usual readings and tests. Madonna's biggest challenge, she says in publicity material, was singing the five Stephen Sondheim songs: ``It was a great learning experience for me because when I first heard the music I panicked. `I can't sing these songs; they're too difficult,' I said. ``But Stephen was very helpful and generous and gave me a lot of encouragement. They are great songs. I wish I could write songs like that.'' Beatty's challenge, says Osborne, was directing the actor Warren Beatty: ``It is actually not impossible to direct yourself. Warren was able to watch a video playback after each scene, but mostly he relied on the reaction of people around the camera, like Richard (Sylbert) and Vittorio (Storaro).'' ``Dick Tracy'' was tested before audiences away from major film centers in large cities, and the reaction was ``great,'' said Osborne. Only a few cuts were made to tighten the film to its 100-minute running time. Then the labs started turning out the 200 70mm, six-sound-track prints that will play major theaters, and hundreds of 35mm, two-track versions that will appear in the rest of film houses in the United States and Canada. All that remains to be seen is whether or not Dick Tracy will go from funnies flatfoot to big screen scream.

DOC.HEAD: ``DICK TRACY'': Summer's No. 1 With a Bullet?
Batman & Brenda and Dick & Dagwood: Hollywood Loves Comix
With BC-AP Arts: Dick Tracy Movie, b0527
DOC.TEXT: The Warren Beatty-Madonna movie may be attracting a lot of hoopla, but Dick Tracy is no newcomer to the screen. Tracy purists may prefer ``Dick Tracy Meets Gruesome,'' circa 1947, in which the fabled flatfoot does battle with the great Boris Karlorff. Or maybe ``Dick Tracy vs. Cueball,'' a low-budget 1946 flick in which the detective takes on a bald smuggler. Then there are two other RKO features of the mid-1940s that starred Ralph Byrd or Morgan Conway as the steel-jawed, hawk-nosed sleuth. Or, see Dick Tracy as an FBI agent in ``Dick Tracy's G-Men,'' a 1939 yarn with Byrd chasing the evil Zarnoff. If you have the patience, you could watch four serials, dating from 1937 to 1941, with Byrd as Chester Gould's comic-strip hero. Beatty's rediscovery of Dick Tracy follows the pattern of recent Hollywood times: Filmmakers have been exploiting long-establish characters of comic strips and books, giving them a modern look for today's audiences. ``Batman'' is the biggest success story thus far. Created by Bob Kane in 1939, ``Batman'' flew onto the big screen with serials in 1943 and 1949. The sensation of the 1965-67 television series led to a 1966 feature, also starring Adam West and Burt Ward. Last year a hyped-up ``Batman,'' starring Jack Nicholson and Michael Keaton, proved a huge moneymaker. ``Superman'' dates back to 1940s serials, a 1951 quickie ``Superman and the Mole Men'' and the subsequent TV series starring George Reeves. Christopher Reeve took over the cape in the 1978 epic ``Superman.'' It was a huge hit, followed by three sequels with diminishing results. ``Little Orphan Annie'' first hit the screen in 1932 with Mitzi Green as the carrot-topped waif. Then _ gloryoskee _ ``Annie'' became a hit Broadway musical in the 1970s. Its success was repeated in a 1982 movie, directed by John Huston, of all people, and starring Albert Finney, Carol Burnett and Bernadette Peters. Not all comic heroes and heroines have done as well in recent years. ``Flash Gordon'' was an expensive failure in 1980, helping along the eventual collapse of Dino de Laurentiis' American enterprise. ``Popeye'' bombed in 1980 despite the best efforts of Robin Williams to imitate the one-eye spinach fancier. ``Brenda Starr,'' with Brooke Shields as the resourceful reporter, remains on the shelf after three years, partly because of legal tangles. ``Brenda Starr'' was made by New World Pictures, which has since gone out of business. There are disputes over New World's assets, and whether or not the movie will be released depends largely on how the disputes are resolved. But the film has appeared in some overseas countries. Motion pictures and comic strips were born at about the same time and almost immediately began their association. Hearst cartoonist Winsor McCay drew his ``Little Nemo'' for the screen in 1911 and followed with ``Gertie the Dinosaur'' in 1914. ``Krazy Kat,'' ``Bringing Up Father'' and ``The Katzenjammer Kids'' were other early movie cartoons. Comics also contributed characters for live action: ``Ella Cinders'' (Colleen Moore), 1922; ``Tillie the Toiler'' (Marion Davies), 1927; ``Skippy'' (Jackie Cooper), 1930; ``Harold Teen'' (Arthur Lake), 1934; and ``Joe Palooka'' (Stewart Erwin), 1934, and another version in 1946 with Joe Kirkwood, plus sequels. Serials, which Hollywood ground out from 1930 to 1950, were ideal for telling comic book stories. They included: ``Archie,'' ``Captain Marvel,'' ``Flash Gordon,'' ``Jungle Jim,'' ``Mandrake the Magician,'' ``Talespin Tommy,'' ``Brick Bradford'' and ``Terry and the Pirates.'' For 10 years starting in 1938, Arthur Lake and Penny Singleton annually appeared in two ``Blondie'' films, as sandwich-loving Dagwood Bumstead and his dizzy wife. After his Tarzan days were over, Johnny Weissmuller made 12 quickies as ``Jungle Jim'' from 1948 to 1955. After scoring as a musical on Broadway, ``L'il Abner'' came to the screen in 1959 with all its Dogpatch characters intact. ``Prince Valiant'' put Robert Wagner in a page-boy wig in 1954. Bill Mauldin's dogface soldiers Willie and Joe appeared in the 1951 ``Up Front'' and did a sequel, ``Back at the Front.'' Racier comics also have made it to the screen: ``Modesty Blaise'' (Monica Vitti), 1966; ``Barbarella'' (Jane Fonda) 1968; and the only X-rated cartoon movie, ``Fritz the Cat'' in 1971.

DOC.HEAD: ``DICK TRACY'': Summer's No. 1 With a Bullet?
Dick Tracy Merchandise Floods Stores, But Is Anybody Buying?
With BC-AP Arts: Dick Tracy Movie, b0527
DOC.TEXT: Would any hip teen be caught dead wearing a T-shirt plastered with the profile of a forgotten comic strip cop? Warren Beatty may still cause some female fans to swoon, but the star and director of ``Dick Tracy'' faces a far more difficult seduction in the youth-driven movie merchandise business. Young shoppers are starting to inspect goods decorated with the likeness of Madonna, who co-stars as Breathless Mahoney in ``Dick Tracy.'' But Beatty's title character has remained an elusive sale, some retailers and manufacturers say. And while the film itself continues to generate much anticipation, ``Dick Tracy'' wares are lagging behind retail products linked to ``The Simpsons,'' ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles'' and other TV shows and movies. ```Dick Tracy' will in no way come close to `Batman,''' said Nancy Overfield-Delmar, manager of special event and merchandise publicity for J.C. Penney. ``The movie may do very well in theaters. But there is no awareness in stores right now.'' John Green, president of ``Dick Tracy'' T-shirt licensee Village Mews, said Walt Disney Co. has been slow to promote the film, with little expenditures for billboards, television spots and posters. ``From a retailers point of view, that's not very good,'' Green said. ``The `Batman' hype was going a year before the movie came out. A lot of kids still don't know who Dick Tracy is.'' Marketing Evaluations, a research firm that studies the appeal of celebrities and fictional characters, found in a study last year that Dick Tracy ranked below average. His popularity was below Wonder Woman, Howdy Doody and Archie. Larry Carlat, the editor of Toy & Hobby World, believes young shoppers will be more interested in Barbie and Nintendo video games than Beatty and Madonna. But Playmates, a leading toy manufacturer, thinks ``Dick Tracy'' will outsell ``Batman.'' As movies, ``Batman'' and ``Dick Tracy'' share several common elements: Both are based on long-standing comic strips, both have been adapted into live-action films and both feature recognizable central characters. Yet the merchandising of the two films is wholly different. Jack Morrow, vice president of licensing for Applause Inc., makers of ``Dick Tracy'' dolls, figurines, mugs and key chains, said Warner Bros. positioned its ``Batman'' as a fad, not just a movie. The logo thus became a statement unto itself. ```Tracy' didn't have the same warm-up that `Batman' had, and I attribute that directly to fashion. That yellow and black design was cool. And `Tracy' doesn't have that,'' Morrow said. ``Dick Tracy'' merchandise, retailers and licensees say, will live or die on the film's performance. If the movie soars, so, too, will the products. If it bombs, then you can look for ``Dick Tracy'' products on the discount shelf. ```Willow' could have sold a lot of merchandise if the movie was good,'' said Gary Caplan, a licensing consultant. ```Howard the Duck' could have sold a lot of products, too, if the movie had played well.'' According to trade estimates, ``Batman'' merchandise so far has claimed retail sales of $650 million. A studio typically enjoys 10 percent of the wholesale revenues generated by the merchandise to which it holds the copyrights. In 1980, licensed products had retail sales of $9.9 billion. By 1989, that figure had surged to $64.6 billion. About $3 billion worth of merchandise inspired by movies and television programs was sold last year. Even if ``Dick Tracy'' produces wholesale receipts of $100 million, Disney will collect $10 million _ for doing essentially nothing but negotiating deals and approving artwork. And if kids wear T-shirts bearing the film's logo, Disney has walking billboards touting the movie. Among the estimated 100 merchandise licenses are yellow fedoras, wrist walkie-talkies, stretch satin evening wear (as worn by Madonna's Breathless Mahoney character), shower curtains, drapes, backpacks, jewelry and a variety of watches. There also will be three movie-related record albums. Will ``Dick Tracy'' be able to get his man at the cash register? So far, it looks like a tough case.

DOC.HEAD: Adv for Weekend Editions, June 2-3
AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Video View: Home Video News and Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Triumph of the Spirit'' (RCA-Columbia Home Video. VHS-Beta, $89.95. Rated R)
``Triumph of the Spirit'' is as subtle as a right to the jaw and, at times, just as powerful. At other times, it swings and misses. A Holocaust film that came out late last year, ``Triumph of the Spirit'' was nearly forgotten thanks to the near-simultaneous releases of the acclaimed ``Enemies: A Love Story'' and the Costa-Gavras drama ``Music Box.'' But ``Triumph'' couldn't be more different. While those films are about memory, with the Holocaust a nightmare lurking off-screen, ``Triumph,'' shot on location in Auschwitz, dares to show the unshowable. The film is based on the true story of Salamo Arouch, the middleweight boxing champion of the Balkan countries in 1938. After the Nazis occupied Greece, he and his family and friends were deported to Auschwitz. Arouch, used by the Nazis to box with other prisoners, survived and now lives in Israel with his wife, children and grandchildren. ``Triumph'' is relentless, deliberately hard to take, with no time for the soul-searching of ``Enemies'' or ``Music Box.'' ``They promised us a new life in Poland,'' Arouch (Willem Dafoe) recalls. As he speaks, Nazis are squeezing Greek Jews into cattle cars and shipping them off to their new life _ in Auschwitz. Blows, big and small, rain down. The Nazis take their valuables, shave their heads and make men and women wear the same drab uniforms. Prisoners are kicked, literally, out of bed each morning and drag themselves back at night, beaten down by a day of marching and lifting. Screaming matches break out over a pair of shoes. A woman breaks down and cries as she begs her friend for a few drops of broth. When Arouch steals a moment with his girlfriend, Allegra (Wendy Gazelle), he embraces her as if he were a starving man sniffing a loaf of warm bread. The Final Solution is never far away. Gas chambers. Hangings. Commanders coolly selecting the next round of victims. Arouch, however, is spared. He KO's a guard who pushed him down a hill and becomes a valuable commodity to the commanding officers, who bet on him in boxing matches with other prisoners. Arouch wins every fight. So ``Triumph'' becomes a story of ``triumphs,'' physical, moral and spiritual. Arouch is bloodied, but not defeated. ``All I have left is my love for Allegra,'' he says after the camp has been liberated and his family killed. Shoulders slumped, Arouch exits down a long and empty road, walking gingerly under an endless gray sky. If this video comes up short, don't blame Dafoe, excellent as a man who learns to duck punches in and out of the ring. Co-stars Robert Loggia, as Arouch's ailing father, and Edward James Olmos, the camp gypsy are both solid. But Dafoe has to keep a straight face with such lines as ``You still taste like apricots,'' and ``How can we do this to our brothers?'' The direction, by Robert Young (``Dominick and Eugene'') is unimaginative, and worse, the music soars and swells like the soundtrack of an old Bette Davis movie _ a symphony seeming to rise with every tear that falls. ``How many rounds?'' Arouch asks when offered the chance to fight. ``Rounds?'' the commander responds. ``No rounds. You fight until one can't get up.'' ``Triumph of the Spirit'' lasts a full 15. Give it a split decision.

PG-13 _ Special parental guidance strongly suggested for children under 13. Some material may be inappropriate for young children. R _ Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. X _ No one under 17 admitted. Some states may have higher age restrictions.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
In the Groove: Record Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Laredo'' (MCA) _ Steve Wariner
Steve Wariner's easygoing ``Laredo'' travels over some familiar country ground but comes up a winner on the strength of above-average songs and the singer's ability to convey that he clearly enjoys the material. Using three producers, Wariner shifts comfortably from mid-tempo ballads to ``lite'' swing, maintaining a pleasant groove that falters only when he indulges in the sappy sentimentality of ``I Wanna Go Back,'' a needless lament for the good ol' days. Wariner, a staple on the country charts, knows what makes a hit, and almost everything else on ``Laredo'' sounds groomed for the radio. ``Precious Thing,'' a bluesy love song, the tear-jerkers ``She's in Love'' and ``There for Awhile'' and the clever ``The Domino Theory'' appear likely candidates to receive airplay. The band is tight (the piano playing is superb throughout _ four keyboardists are credited), and the digital recording is clear and uncluttered but not cold. All in all, a safe, likable album. If you have to go down the middle of the road, Steve Wariner's not a bad guy to have along as a rider. _ By Marc Rice, Associated Press Writer.

``Dog City'' (Grudge) _ Crack The Sky
With ``Dog City,'' Crack The Sky is guilty of one of rock 'n' roll's deadly sins: wrapping politically charged messages in dull, plodding music. This band has a lot to say, but who can pay attention to the words when the music is putting them to sleep? And, despite the bombast here, who can stay awake through this set? This from a band that knows better. Never a household name, Crack The Sky does enjoy some cult status largely on the strength of its 1975 debut, which successfully mixed John Palumbo's delightfully bizarre songwriting with quirky, imaginative guitar-based rock. None of that here. Palumbo's lyrical sights are on the nation's social ills _ the homeless, drug abuse, violence _ but his words are lost in a mix of leaden, hard-rock cliches. Even if you agree with what he's saying, you may find yourself wanting to join the other side. Only on ``Mr. President,'' in which a children's choir makes a plea for the government to do something about the homeless, does the music break away from the muck. It's not nearly enough, though, to salvage this dog of an album. _ By Marc Rice, Associated Press Writer.

``Jump for Joy'' (Alligator Records) _ Koko Taylor
The Queen of the Blues meets the King of Gonzo. Talk about strange bedfellows. But in proving again that she's no pretender to the crown, Koko Taylor rips into Ted Nugent's ``Hey Baby'' as if it were one of her own. Maybe it's not so strange. After all, rock 'n' roll has its roots in the blues. Taylor's 12th album, ``Jump for Joy,'' is a strong follow to 1987's ``Live From Chicago _ An Audience With the Queen.'' If history repeats itself, Taylor could be up for her second Grammy award (her last three releases have been nominated). This is standard fare from Taylor, marked by tough, from-the-gut vocals and a solid band that boogies. Lonnie Brooks slides in for a duet and some six-string work on ``It's a Dirty Job.'' Taylor mixes five originals with five covers. The bulk of Taylor's blues are in the good-time vein. On ``Time Will Tell,'' however, she sings with raw emotion that makes her loss from the death a year ago of Richard ``Pops'' Taylor, her husband of 30 years, nearly palpable. _ By James Reindl, Associated Press Writer.

On Show: Museum and Gallery Shows and Exhibits
DOC.TEXT: The Museum of Fine Arts in Houston has opened its gallery of Far Eastern Art after a closing of more than two years because of space limitations. The gallery, which opened on May 12, includes more than 60 paintings, sculptures and ceramics from Japan, China and India. Recent acquisitions are a 6th century Japanese Haniwa Warrior of terra-cotta, and a pair of Japanese six-panel screens illustrating the ``Tale of Genji'' from the late 17th and early 18th century. Elsewhere, the Luman Reed Gallery will open at the New York Historical Society in New York City, presenting the 18th and 19th century art patron's entire collection of American and European paintings for the first time in more than 100 years. The gallery will open on Nov. 13. Here is a list of exhibits and shows at other galleries and museums in the United States:

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Star Watch: Parenthood, Hollywood Style
DOC.TEXT: Schooled since birth in the discipline of the theater, Amy Irving sought interviews to promote her new movie only days before delivering her second child. She already was the mother of one of the most famous _ and richest _ boys in the world, Max Spielberg, whose father is her former husband, film tycoon Steven Spielberg. Irving and Spielberg were divorced last year. Max now has a half-brother, Gabriel Davis Baretto, born May 4 to Amy and Bruno Baretto, director of her new film. Max also has another half-sibling, since Spielberg and Kate Capshaw became the parents of a daughter, Sasha, on May 14. But that's a different story. Like Spielberg-Capshaw, Baretto-Irving are not married. ``But we plan to be,'' declares Irving. Her new movie is a Paramount Pictures release, ``A Show of Force.'' Based on Anne Nelson's book ``Murder Under Two Flags,'' it delves into the political intrigue surrounding the murder of two young men in 1978 in Puerto Rico. The alleged coverup caused a government scandal that apparently still has reverberations. ``The script is very close to the facts of the case,'' Irving said. ``There was some license that we took in telling the story, and there were some demands that we do not use real names. There were rumors that the American government is trying not to expose this film too much because it does come down pretty heavily on them. ``The fact that the two boys were set up to look like Cuban-backed terrorists and then murdered in cold blood has been proven. How high up the influence goes and who was involved is still under investigation.'' The actress admitted her own ignorance of Puerto Rico before making the film _ ``I even asked what currency they used.'' Her stay there provided an education, and she concludes with understatement: ``I don't think that the situation there is one that America has helped.'' Like many of today's film heroines, Irving plays a television reporter. A widow with two children, her investigation ``puts her life in jeopardy, puts her family's life in jeopardy and makes her question her own vision of what America was; she seeks the truth and comes into her own strength in seeking the truth.'' Her role as Kate Ryan de Melendez is the mainstay of the plot, which also involves Andy Garcia as the prosecutor, Lou Diamond Phillips as an undercover agent and Robert Duvall as the television station manager. Also in the cast is Irving's mother, Priscilla Pointer. With an actress mother and a father who was a distinguished stage director, Amy Irving grew up in the theater. The late Jules Irving was artistic director of San Francisco's American Repertory Theater when Amy was born in Palo Alto, Calif., 37 years ago. She made her stage debut at 9 months in ``Rumplestiltskin,'' trained at her father's theater and later at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art. Over the years, Irving has divided her time between stage (``Amadeus,'' ``Heartbreak House'') and screen (``Carrie,'' ``Yentl,'' ``Crossing Delancey''). Daughter of one director and former wife of another, it seemed inevitable she would fall under the spell of her ``A Show of Force'' director. ``I met Bruno before the film,'' she related. ``He flew up from Brazil about a year ago March, and we talked about the film. I had seen his `Dona Flora and Her Two Husbands,' and he showed me other of his Brazilian films; he has made nine there. All of his films have a central character of a very strong woman, a woman who travels through some kind of journey in life. In each one, the performances were so impressive that I couldn't wait to be directed by him. ``We had a wonderful experience making the film, and afterward more happened. It turned out to be a grand experience in my life.'' After their marriage, she says, they plan to make their home here; she also has a house in New Mexico, and he will keep his base in Brazil. ```A Show of Force' is Bruno's first English-language film, and he plans to come to America and pursue his career here,'' Irving said. ``He got tired of people `reading' his films; all his films are subtitled (outside Brazil and Portugal). To be able to have people watch the faces as the story unfolds is something that he's wanted for a long time. ``We'll go to Brazil. We've spent some time there, and I'm learning Portuguese. His 13-year-old daughter lives with us, and our life is pretty international now. Max has already learned how to ask for a chocolate cookie in Portuguese.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
The Artists: Hardhat, Paint Brush and Nerve
DOC.TEXT: Grace Lai stumbled into her artistic passion. But she can't afford to stumble now. Lai spends much of her time 30 stories or more above the ground, sometimes near open walls and elevator shafts, just to get the right perspective for her paintings. Hardhat on head, she totes her studio on a handcart, painting watercolors of Chicago's changing skyline and the workers who change it. She's been working at the North State Street site of the American Medical Association's new headquarters for about two years, watching excavators, welders, steelworkers, cement workers, plumbers, electrical contractors, carpenters, tilesetters, pipefitters and more. ``No one has ever tried to document what they do,'' Lai says. ``This is something they can take home and show their wives and say, `Look, I really DO work.' '' Lai, 62, and her husband, Harry, operated Acme Studios at various Chicago locations for 25 years until his death in 1985. She then decided to return to school and try to support herself with her art. She sketched her first construction site in 1985. It was on her first day back in art school when her bus dropped her at the 42-story office tower at 190 N. LaSalle, the first Chicago building designed by the architect Philip Johnson. Transit schedules forced her to arrive two hours early for class at the American Academy of Art, and she filled the time sketching. Several weeks later, the chief site inspector noticed her, liked her work and made her the ``official'' artist for the construction site. The current building is the third site she's painted. Between Johnson's building and her current site, she climbed and painted the 50-story tower at 35 W. Wacker Drive that houses the Leo Burnett Co. advertising agency. Before she found her passion for painting construction sites, she used the only subject of which she could think. ``I used to just sketch people on the buses back and forth from visiting my father in the nursing home,'' she says. ``But it was a chancy thing. If people found out you were sketching them and didn't like it, you took your life in your hands. But most of them were delighted.'' Her original watercolors sell for $400 to $500. She has 8-by 10-inch prints made of each one and sells the prints to workers for $15 to $40. She sells enough to ``get by,'' she says. She leaves space around the construction scenes in many of her works, which she fills with portraits of individual workers or crews. The workers often pose briefly during their coffee breaks. ``When are you gonna do me, Gracie?'' one worker asks. ``Any time,'' she says. They agree on a painting and a time and part company, each expressing thanks. John Buck Co. and Miller-Klutznick-Davis-Gray Co., partners in the building, plan to show her works at the building's grand opening, tentatively scheduled in August. Lai will have 25 to 30 full-size watercolors ready, all showing different phases of construction. She hopes the show will bring recognition and a wider audience. It will be her first show outside the Pallet and Chisel, a group of Chicago artists with a studio in the downtown Loop who combine their efforts to promote local art. Her paintings now are available only at her in-home company, Advertising Art, and at the City of Chicago store in the Loop. ``Success for me would be being respected by fellow artists. This may end up affording me a living, but I don't want to turn out garbage,'' she says. ``Most importantly, I want to be an artist. It doesn't have to be in construction. I'd like to go into a paper mill or an atomic plant, things people hear about and never see. You have to be half-insane to do it, but my gosh, can you find anything more exciting?'' The excitement _ and potential danger _ of being hundreds of feet above the ground has never caused her any trouble, says Lai, who signs a release at each site. A contractor involved with each site has insured her under his company policy. ``My only problems are off the site. Last year, I spent four months on crutches because I was doing aerobics and I landed wrong. So aerobics can go. I'll walk,'' she said. However, the time on crutches was even helpful. ``After I came back, my painting changed entirely. I became a lot more thoughtful. I did whole scenes instead of just throwing things together. I think it was being away for so long; it made me realize what I was missing.'' Construction workers help her stay out of the way, she says. ``You kind of sense when things are starting to move, and usually somebody will come by and say, `Gracie, scat!''' She laughed again. Lai worked in December when she had to add alcohol to her paints to keep them from freezing and had to cut the fingers out of her gloves on her drawing hand to handle her pens and brushes. And she didn't quit when her friends told her she wouldn't finish art school, or when her classmates began placing bets on when she'd drop out. She graduated last year. Her tenacity has provided her with a living, experience and friendships. ``I know so many of my friends who say, `Nobody ever comes to see me.' You've got to out and meet the world.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Music Makers: Bo Knows the Business
DOC.TEXT: After 35 years, Bo Diddley wants his payday. It's nice to be called a legend. It was fun playing the White House. Induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame was flattering, and telling center fielder Bo Jackson that he didn't know diddley was a laugh. But now, Bo wants more. Bo wants cash. ``I feel like America owes me something more than just saying, `Oh, the great Bo Diddley,''' the 61-year-old artist said in a recent interview. ``Elvis Presley copied me, and I used to wouldn't say anything about it. When they found the white boy who could do what I was doing, then they shoved me back in the corner and he went on to Las Vegas, where all the money was. But Bo Diddley never got a chance to get involved,'' he says. ``I have no bitterness against Elvis or any other white entertainer that records black music, but I think there should be some recognition as to where he got the stuff from. Don't come up and steal my stuff and say you wrote it, because that's a lie.'' It's not just Elvis who rode the Bo Diddley beat to success. The trademark guitar sound that he's played during six decades anchors the Who's ``Magic Bus,'' Bruce Springsteen's ``She's the One,'' Buddy Holly's ``Not Fade Away,'' Johnny Otis' ``Willie and the Hand Jive,'' Elvis Costello's ``Lover's Walk'' and George Michaels' ``Faith.'' Diddley _ like other rhythm and blues artists in the late 1940s and '50s _ was paid a flat fee for his recordings and received no royalty payments on record sales. But over the years, he's found his music on records around the world, ``in places I ain't never heard of in my life.'' ``But where's the money?'' he says. ``The thing that hurts me so bad is that every time I come up with something it looks like somebody jumped on it, they make money with it and I can't get arrested with it. ``Everybody says, `Oh, you've got such a negative attitude.' Guys can always tell Bo: `You shouldn't be hollering about that. That's water under the bridge.' Yes, it's water under the bridge, but my kids were deprived of a lot of things because the water went under the bridge, and I'm not at all happy about that.'' Diddley has been entertaining almost from the day he was born Otha Ellis Bates on Dec. 30, 1928, in McComb, Miss. He was later adopted by his mother's cousin and took on the name Ellis McDaniel, which his wife calls him to this day. When he was 5, the family moved to Chicago, where he learned the violin at the Ebenezer Baptist Church. He learned the guitar at age 10. He entertained passers-by on street corners, taking inspiration from the rhythm and blues bands playing in local clubs. In his early teens, he played on Chicago's Maxwell Street and acquired his stage name, a moniker derived from a ``bo diddley'' _ a one-stringed guitar. For four years beginning in 1951, he played at the 708 Club on the South Side. In July 1955, he was signed to the Checker record label and his first single, ``Bo Diddley,'' was a success. He appeared on ``The Ed Sullivan Show''; shortly thereafter, radio disc jockey Alan Freed called his music ``rock 'n' roll.'' ``I was first to be called rock 'n' roll. Not Little Richard, not Elvis Presley, not Buddy Holly. None of them. I was the first one,'' Diddley says. He stood out on stage with his homemade square guitar, dark-rimmed glasses, black leather jacket and black hat with a diamond-shaped turquoise pinned to the front. ``I'm an entertainer. I'm a showman. I'm not a guitarist,'' says Diddley. ``When you're dealing with cats like myself you're dealing with a real entertainer, a person who knows what the stage is built for.'' It's not the same at home, where he's Ellis to his wife and ``Bo Pop'' to his grandchildren. He's also no rebel off stage, serving a stint in the 1970s as a sheriff in New Mexico. He considers himself patriotic. ``I'm here, baby. I'm a piece of this dirt or whatever it is. I didn't come from no Africa,'' he says. Sometimes, he can be found building a porch in Deboe, Fla., for his 70-by 24-foot trailer home, surrounded by rose bushes, fruit trees and grass. He says the home is so big it makes him feel like ``nobility,'' but he knows what it can connote to some people. ``It's comfortable. It doesn't bother me what people think because there's so many people that live in those trailers that got more money than Bo Diddley. I am a regular person,'' he says. He is still paying for a large home in Hawthorne, Fla., which he moved away from when a previous marriage ended. Someone, he says, should do a benefit for Bo Diddley to clear him of his $300,000 debt. ``At 55, I couldn't retire. I couldn't even think about it,'' he says. Meanwhile, he'll keep touring the country, playing here and there and mostly near his home in the same sort of venues where he's been displaying his act for parts of five decades. With all his business failings, one of Diddley's greatest achievements came last year when he was in the Nike sneaker commercial. ``The Nike commercial did more for me than anything done for me in the last 20 years. Everybody knows Bo Diddley now, just because I said, `You don't know Diddley.' That's all I said. I ain't done nothing else. I don't understand this part of it.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Books and Authors: Code of the West Lives in Medoff's Plays
DOC.TEXT: The tall stranger rode into town and stayed because he found what's left of the Code of the West was still alive in Las Cruces. He packed no gun. He had a typewriter. A recent Stanford University graduate school alumnus in 1966, Mark Medoff drove into Las Cruces in a black '62 Volkswagen beetle with no idea that he would become one of America's premier playwrights. Florida-born Medoff, just turned 50, is a Westerner now. He teaches screenwriting, playwriting, acting and directing at New Mexico State University and writes on his computer in the wood-paneled library of his Spanish colonial home. The author of the Tony-winning ``Children of a Lesser God'' and Obie-winning ``When You Comin' Back, Red Ryder?'' says many of his plays are about Old West values and the fall of the hero, as Medoff recalls from growing up in Miami Beach. ``I think we don't have heroes in this country particularly anymore,'' Medoff said during an interview at his home. ``We have demystified all our heroes. We don't have people we look up to.'' He's not particularly optimistic about what has replaced them. His new play, ``Stumps,'' is the second sequel to ``Red Ryder.'' In it, Vietnam amputee Stephen Ryder and a wheelchair-ridden comrade try to sell a screenplay to a pornography producer, a sociopath in clergyman's clothing, who brutalizes them and Ryder's Vietnamese wife, Lin. After two New Mexico productions, ``Stumps'' is ready for larger venues, and Medoff has started sending it out. The challenge of ``Stumps'' was to create an educated, articulate character without a conscience, the Rev. Calvin Rhodes, who'd be seen as human, not allegorical. ``I guess my greatest fear about Calvin Rhodes is that he's not simply an aberration but that he's a kind of character we may see proliferate around us in our lives,'' Medoff says. Ryder's luck has been lousy with sociopaths. In ``When You Comin' Back, Red Ryder?'', a gunman holds patrons of a desert diner hostage and wounds one. The play's roots were Westerns. ``The bad guys ride into town, they go into the saloon and they start tormenting the guy who drinks milk,'' he says. In the first sequel, ``The Heart Outright,'' we learn the gunman later was killed by state police. But the author has met such bad guys only in his head. ``I've always maintained that I have all the worst of my worst characters in me, and I think we all do.'' He recalls a happy childhood listening to the real Red Ryder on the radio, along with ``The Lone Ranger'' and ``Straight Arrow.'' ``My father's a doctor; my mother's a psychologist. My father was a superb pianist; my mother's a very fine painter. The house was always full of music and art and books, and it was a very nice upbringing ... a very civilized, congenial upbringing, and yet I think that in a way we in my generation all bridled against our very civility.'' ``The Wild One'' with Marlon Brando impressed him as a teen-ager. In that film, biker Brando half-terrorizes, half-mesmerizes a small-town diner. ``I was about 15 and looking at my upper-middle-class, Jewish, well-educated self, thinking, `God, I wish ... I had the guts and the wherewithal to put on black leather and get on a hog and go out and make trouble.'' Instead, the 6-foot-tall Medoff channeled his aggressions into sports, tore up a knee and had to quit football. He now has a passion for golf. He was also 15 when he started writing prose. With support from his parents _ but with their warning about the vagaries of literary life _ he studied creative writing at the University of Miami. One of his stories was published by Random House in ``Prize College Stories'' of 1963. He got his master's degree at Stanford and accepted a position, at first reluctantly, at New Mexico State. It worried him that it was an agricultural school ``with cows right on campus,'' but he soon found it a more diverse barnyard: The first people he met were involved in the Las Cruces Community Theater. One was actor Bill Frankfather who suggested Medoff write a play and they'd put it on. ``So I did, and they did and that was the beginning.'' Frankfather played Rhodes in the New Mexico Repertory Theatre production of ``Stumps'' this winter in Santa Fe and Albuquerque. The nurturing and support from campus and community and the spirit of the Old West keep Medoff in New Mexico. He likes his plays to succeed in New York, but he prefers to stay here. ``I have an affinity for the Old West, and I think there's still a residual civility here. ... There's just something about the warmth of the people.'' He met his wife, Stephanie, in one of his literature courses. They have three children: Debra, 22; Rachel, 15; and Jessica, 11. Parenthood changed Medoff as a writer. ``The world is so much with us, and the world is so full of violence and seems to be so much fuller today than it was yesterday of a lack of conscience that, for my children, I know I'm trying to write material that brings people face to face with that lack of conscience in hopes of fostering change,'' he said. When a brother of one of Medoff's students was murdered several years ago, Medoff created ``The Homage That Follows,'' which was to have been his statement on sociopaths. But he became sympathetic to the killer. ``Even though what he did was unforgivable. It became clear he was not without conscience.'' So ``Stumps'' was summoned up from the depths of his anger.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Nashville Sound: Lorrie Morgan's Year of Tragedy and Triumph
DOC.TEXT: Keith Whitley and Lorrie Morgan seemed the perfect pair when they married. They were both singers with blossoming careers. When she was away from home singing in concert, he always sent flowers or called to ease the separation. He planned to adopt her 8-year-old daughter by a previous marriage. Morgan was the precocious child of a Grand Ole Opry star and was so beautiful and talented she had been voted runnerup in the Miss Nashville Pageant. Some people called them ``Mr. and Mrs. Country Music.'' Then Whitley died last May of an accidental alcohol overdose. Morgan became a widow at age 29, losing her husband just as her career took off. She recently talked about the past year, a year ``filled with a lot of highs and lows,'' in an interview in the conference room at RCA Records, a room named in memory of her husband. ``I finally have something I've waited for all my life _ the success of this career,'' she said. ``But I also lost part of my life that I had lived for and that was a fairy tale marriage with Keith. It was every woman's dream _ to have a fairy tale marriage. ``If I had to take my choice, I'd rather have him than anything. But it's not my decision to make.'' Morgan's album, ``Leave the Light On,'' was certified gold in May for sales of a half million, placing it ahead of dozens of others, including Dolly Parton's highly promoted ``White Limozeen.'' Morgan's ``Five Minutes'' was a No. 1 country music single in April. ``Dear Me'' was another hit single last summer _ just weeks after Whitley died. At a time she should be exhilarated because of career achievement, Morgan finds herself searching to explain her frame of mind in a year of tragedy and triumph. ``I don't know that I'm bitter,'' she said. ``You know that old saying, `God never puts anything on you that you and he can't handle.' There's a reason for all this. I'll probably never know the reason until I go up to heaven and ask.'' ```Confused' is probably a better word as to why it happened, the way it happened, when it happened.'' The night after her husband was buried, she sang on the Opry as a tribute to him. ``It was real difficult,'' she recalled. ``It was difficult just to breathe, to open my eyes. It was something I felt I had to do to get on with life. It would have been very easy to sit home and mope and cry and stay shut up in a room. But I needed to be around friends, not closed in.'' Within two weeks, she was back on the road traveling to concerts. She used her late husband's bus. ``It was an eerie feeling. I could picture him coming out of the back any minute.'' Five months after Whitley's death, she tearfully accepted his award on network TV for single record of the year from the Country Music Association for his ``I'm No Stranger to the Rain.'' This year, it may be her own award she accepts. Her ``Leave the Light On'' has been in the top 10 of the country music charts. She will have performed live before an estimated 1.2 million people by year's end as part of a lengthy concert tour with country superstars Alabama and the hottest country act in four years, Clint Black. Two duets she recorded with Whitley before he died will be released soon by RCA. Morgan now is reaping the rewards of a singing career that began when she performed on the Opry at age 13. At just 14, she was singing on the road with her father, Opry star George Morgan. At 16, she had her own band and was a touring act. ``I've paid a lot of dues, learned a lot, seen people come and go, what to do and what not to do. I think I'm ready for the success I'm having. I guess this is the big final test when you have your exams,'' Morgan said. ``I'm not sure I can point to the one thing for my success, but a lot of years has helped.'' Whitley, 33, has remained in the public eye because of the continued release of his songs. ``He's going to be one of the greats,'' Morgan said. ``There may be someone come around who will have more success than Keith did, but there never will be another better singer. Never.''
