DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: The Lincoln Center Council, which represents the center's 11 artistic organizations, has announced its support for the beleaguered National Endowment of the Arts. The 25-year-old NEA came under attack last year from Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., when it gave support to an exhibit of works by the late photographer Robert Mapplethorpe. The show last June at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington was canceled after some called it obscene, resulting in a move by Congress to limit federal funds to the arts. The NEA distributes money yearly allocated to it by Congress to large and small arts organizations and to artists. Last year, restrictions were written into the endowment's appropriations bill barring it from supporting artwork considered obscene. Lincoln Center has begun placing inserts in programs for its Great Performers concerts asking supporters of ``a thriving and culturally diverse'' arts community to write to their congressional representatives in support of the NEA. The Lincoln Center council is made up of all the New York arts center's organizations, including the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic and New York City Ballet.

Pop star Patti LaBelle will lead a celebrity-filled brunch to benefit the Black Health Research Foundation. Other hosts of the brunch, to be held June 9 at B. Smith's, include actress-singer Melba Moore, Clarice Taylor of ``The Cosby Show'' and Harry Carson of the New York Giants. LaBelle is the first national spokesperson and honorary chairman of the board for the foundation, which is the first national voluntary health organization to address the issues of premature death and disability in blacks.

``Serious Fun!'' at Lincoln Center returns for a fourth season of 16 performances at Alice Tully Hall from July 13 through Aug. 2. This free-wheeling, eclectic festival has become a mainstay of the performance world, and once again will present an array of the most insightful, inventive, outrageous and controversial of today's artists. ``Serious Fun!'' will include ``Manson Family: Helter Five-0,'' a full-length multi-media opera fusing the Charles Manson story as handled by Det. Steve McGarrett from TV's ``Hawaii Five-0.''

The Tony Award-winning ``Jerome Robbins' Broadway'' will end its run at the Imperial Theater on Sept. 1. The musical began previews on Jan. 9, 1989, and opened Feb. 26, 1989. It will have played 55 previews and 634 performances at the time of closing. Featuring 62 dancer-singers, ``Jerome Robbins' Broadway'' will begin its national tour in Boston on Oct. 2. There are future plans for a European production that would begin in Berlin or Paris in mid-1992 and tour throughout Europe. Winner of the 1989 Drama Desk and Outer Critics Circle Awards as best musical, ``Jerome Robbins' Broadway'' also on six Tonys. The musical's 10 numbers were selected from more than 20 Broadway productions that Robbins either conceived, choreographed or directed, including ``On the Town,'' ``The King and I,'' ``West Side Story'' and ``A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum.''

David L. Wolper, Jack Haley Jr. and Steven Spielberg will produce ``A Celebration of Tradition,'' a lavish extravaganza that will highlight the rededication of the historic Warner Bros. Studios in Burbank, Calif. The June 2 spectacle will be filled with hundreds of singers and dancers, atmospheric sets, lavish musical numbers, comedy bits and a stars who have been associated with Warner Bros. motion pictures. The Warner brothers opened their first movie theater in 1903. It wasn't until 1922 that they opened their first West Coast studio on Sunset Boulevard in Hollywood. In 1929, the brothers bought First National Pictures' large studio in Burbank, and invested heavily to make it the finest such facility in the world. Warner Bros. Studios in Burbank became the home base for some of the most important stars and filmmakers in the business. In the spring of 1972, Columbia Pictures and Warner Bros. joined forces and the facility was renamed the Burbank Studios, by which it has been known since.

Cashiers shouted ``Passports!'' at crowds of testy shoppers on the first day of new rules that barred non-Muscovites from the capital's besieged stores. Tempers flared over the rules Monday, which were intended to curb a wave of panic-buying that started after the government announced Thursday it was raising prices as part of a gradual transition to a market economy. Shouting matches erupted between cashiers and shoppers who did not know about the rules. Long lines moved slowly as the internal passports were scrutinized for the stamp that proved residency.

Gasoline prices climbed and currency devaluation slowed as part of the latest in a series of wage-price control pacts. Salinas signed a new Economic Growth and Stability Pact with business, labor and farm leaders of his Institutional Revolutionary Party at a ceremony in the presidential residence Sunday night. ``This is a renewed effort to fight inflation and consolidate the conditions of growth that Mexicans demand and deserve,'' Salinas said.

The European Community's executive body proposed a tit-for-tat measure that could allow EC companies to copy semiconductor designs of U.S. chip makers. Monday's proposal by the EC Commission, which must be approved by the community's 12 member nations, would drop protection of chip designs from non-EC countries that do not legally protect designs made within the EC. Unlike other non-EC countries such as Austria, Japan and Sweden, which recognize and protect designs of chips made in the community, the United States protects only its own chip designs.

President Bush is being asked by 170 House Democrats to step into the worsening savings and loan crisis more and request additional funds from Congress to investigate and prosecute fraud in the industry. The Democrats, led by Rep. Charles E. Schumer of New York, sent a letter Friday to Bush saying the $50 million appropriated to the Justice Department to investigate and prosecute S&L fraud isn't enough to handle the backlog of thousands of potential criminal cases. An additional $100 million is needed, said the Democrats, including some lawmakers who last week accused the Justice Department of dragging its feet on prosecuting thrift fraud.

Ministers of the West's 24 leading industrial countries could be in for heated discussions this week as they seek to overcome sharp differences blocking a new international trade pact, officials said. The Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development's annual two-day ministerial meeting beginning Wednesday represents one of the last opportunities for the countries to resolve sticking points on trade in agriculture and textiles, senior officials of the group said at a briefing Monday. Trade has come to the foreground because only six months remain to conclude the Uruguay round of the 98-nation General Agreement on Tariff and Trade (GATT) talks, scheduled to end in Brussels in December. Negotiations began in 1986 with the objective of liberalizing trade in goods and services.

Voters in the tax-revolt state are being asked to double gasoline taxes to keep highway traffic moving. Proposition 111 on the June 5 ballot would double the 9-cents-a-gallon tax on fuel over five years to finance the largest transportation investment in state history. The $18.5 billion raised would pay for new highway and railway construction aimed at thwarting freeway gridlock. A companion ballot measure sponsored by Gov. George Deukmejian would authorize a $1 billion bond issue just for rail transit construction. Environmentalists are pressing a similar but more generous measure that would provide $1.99 billion.

Saudi Aramco, the kingdom's giant oil-producing company, said Monday its output in 1989 fell 1 percent to an average of 4.86 million barrels a day. The summary of the report, released through the official Saudi Press Agency by the Petroleum and Mineral Resources Ministry, stressed that despite the slight decline the company ``maintained its position as the largest oil producing company in the world.''

A regulatory clampdown on risky real estate lending contributed to a 10 percent decline in first-quarter housing construction, F.W. Dodge said. The construction information division of McGraw-Hill said starts on new houses, condominiums and apartments totaled 275,738 units in the first three months of the year, down from 307,080 units in the same period of 1989.

Canada's Varity Corp., a major farm equipment makers, wants to move headquarters across the border to attract U.S. investors, but a Canadian official said Monday his government would sue to block a move. Varity is considering moving its headquarters from Toronto to Buffalo to make its stock more attractive to U.S. investors, said a company spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Canadian government imposes a 15 percent withholding tax on dividends, the spokesman said.

The dollar was mostly lower in exceptionally quiet European trading Monday, affected by the Memorial Day holiday in the United States and a bank holiday in Britain. The dollar's biggest decline was against the yen, where it fell below 150 yen for the first time in nearly three months. Gold rose in Zurich but was not traded in London or Hong Kong, which also was closed for a holiday.

DOC.HEAD: EC Consumer Prices Up By 0.9 Percent In April
DOC.TEXT: Inflation in the 12-nation European Community jumped 0.9 percent during April, boosted by sharply higher consumer prices in Britain, Portugal and Greece, the EC's statistical agency Eurostat reported Tuesday. The increase was faster than a 0.5 percent rise in March and up from a 0.8 percent increase a year earlier. Eurostat said the consumer price index for the EC as a whole rose 5.4 percent in the 12 months to April, higher than a 4.7 percent increase in the United States and a 2.4 percent rise in Japan during the same period. Eurostat said a 3.0 percent surge in Britain accounted for a large part of the EC-wide increase. Britain's April figure was pushed up by the introduction of the community charge on adults, or so-called poll tax, rises in excise duties on alcohol, tobacco, and gasoline, as well as increases in public utilities, rents, and in seasonal food costs. The 3 percent April increase in Britain was the highest since April 1980, when the consumer price index rose 3.4 percent, Eurostat said. Eurostat said a 1.7 percent jump in Greece and a 1.2 percent increase in Portugal also drove up the inflation rate for the Community as a whole. In the year to April, Greece had the highest EC inflation, at 17.9 percent. Portugal had price increases of 12.9 percent, Britain 9.4 percent, Spain 7.0 percent, Italy 6.2 percent, Ireland 4.2 percent, Luxembourg 3.6 percent, Belgium and France 3.2 percent, Denmark 2.4 percent, West Germany 2.3 percent, and the Netherlands 2.1 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Mexicana Buying 30 Airbus Planes
DOC.TEXT: Mexicana de Aviacion has agreed to buy 30 Airbus A320-200 jets for $1.1 billion. Mexicana and Airbus Industrie, a European consortium, signed a letter of intention Monday in the presence of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari at the Presidential Palace. Airbus also signed a technical agreement with the airline that calls for construction of a maintenance base in Guadalajara, 360 miles northwest of the capital. Airbus will begin delivering the new passenger jets next year, and the two parties will negotiate for possible purchase of another 20 planes, according to a statement by the airline. The A320-200 seats from 130 to 179 passengers. Among the 30 new planes being purchased, 16 are considered sold and another 14 are being purchased on option, depending on need, the statement said. Mexicana hopes to nearly double its fleet from 48 planes to 82 by the end of the decade, Mexicana President Carlos Abedrop Davia said. Abedrop said the company has gone through a major restructuring to improve service. ``Now we are beginning the second important task: updating our fleet.'' Mexicana's present fleet is comprised of 42 Boeing 727-200's and six DC-10s. The airline has said it plans to sell some of its older planes. Mexicana previously announced that it plans to expand domestic and foreign routes next year. Mexicana presently flies to the United States and Latin America. Formerly government owned, Mexicana was sold to private investors last September as part of the government's privatization plan. Airbus Industrie is owned by partners in West Germany, France, Britain and Spain.

DOC.HEAD: Tektronix Announces Layoffs, Restructuring
DOC.TEXT: Tektronix Inc. announced Tuesday it will lay off about 1,300 employees as part of a restructuring designed to offset the electronics manufacturer's financial problems. Under the restructuring, the 44-year-old company said it plans to sell or close some of its test and measurement operations and non-television communications businesses. The layoffs will reduce the company's employment to about 13,000 by August, Tektronix said in a statement. ``These steps are part of a broad effort to place Tek on a solid financial footing for the long term,'' said Robert Lundeen, chairman and chief executive officer. The restructuring and layoffs will result in a one-time charge of about $70 million in the fourth quarter ended May 26, the company said. Tektronix has suffered net losses or only marginal profits in recent quarters on flat or declining sales. In the quarter ended in March, the loss was a record $24.5 million. The company's annual sales are about $1.4 billion. Longtime President David P. Friedley resigned in April at the board's request, and Lundeen assumed the title of chief executive officer. The company declined to specify which businesses will be sold, but said the process would begin immediately. Tektronix also said it is exploring the possibility of partnerships to enhance the market position and performance of its Visual Systems television equipment unit. Tektronix also said it has ended discussions with Sony Corp. concerning the possible sale of the company's Grass Valley Group subsidiary.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Food Price Increases Lead to Welfare Cuts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 9th graf, `New York ...,' to include situation in Illinois. PICKS UP in 10th graf, `Congress has ...'
DOC.TEXT: Recent sharp increases in the prices of food staples have led several states to cut food allotments or drop people from welfare rolls. The cost of milk, orange juice, cereal, eggs and infant formula has risen 8 percent in the first half of this fiscal year, four times the rate predicted by the Federal Food and Nutrition Service, The New York Times reported today. The price increases have stretched the $2.1 billion that the federal Women, Infants and Children program spends on 4.5 million new and expectant mothers. As a result, the states, which administer the program, have had to either reduce the food allotment, reduce the number of participants or both. Federal officials said they did not know how many people had been affected by the cuts, the Times said. F. Phillip Shanholtzer, spokesman for the Food and Nutrition Service, said the inflation has ``outstripped everyone's predictions.'' Officials blamed the price increases, such as a 13.3 percent rise in the cost of orange juice and 5.9 percent for cereals, on natural effects such as the drought of 1988 and the December freeze in Florida. Texas and Missouri are not accepting new cases. Both states said children who show no signs of clinical malnutrition will be cut from the program. New York will try to cut its caseload by 20,000 to 360,000, while Connecticut no longer allows use of federal funds to buy orange juice, suggesting instead that mothers buy apple or pineapple juice, which cost less. Illinois officials, however, say their state is an exception to the national problem and will not have to cut any of its 162,000 recipients, according to the Chicago Tribune, which also reported on Friday on cuts in the WIC program. Congress has proposed a $150 million increase in the program for next year. That money was meant to strengthen the program, but now officials hope it will be enough to stay even. The WIC program provides poor families with food vouchers. It is open to pregnant women, those who have just given birth, and children. It serves 1 million women, 1.4 million infants and 2.1 million other children under age 5, or about one-third of all babies born in the United States. During the 1980s, when other welfare programs were cut, WIC was spared because federal studies said it saved lives, reduced infant mortality and prevented illness, thereby sparing future expense to Medicaid.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Sharply Higher
DOC.TEXT: Share prices were sharply higher Tuesday on London's Stock Exchange in light trading. Most of the buying in morning trading was confined to stock-index futures. The market had a late afternoon surge, stimulated by higher prices on Wall Street. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index finished up 30 points, or 1.3 percent, at 2,295.6, its session high. Volume was 330 million shares, compared with 386 million shares Friday. The market was closed Monday, a bank holiday in Britain.

DOC.HEAD: Cadbury Schweppes To Buy Perrier's Non-Cola Soft Drinks Business
DOC.TEXT: Cadbury Schweppes PLC, the British beverages and sweets manufacturer, agreed Tuesday to buy most of the non-cola soft drinks business of Source Perrier of France for 125 million pounds, or $211 million. The purchase includes the noncarbonated fruit drinks Oasis and Bali, the fruit drink concentrate Atoll and the bottling rights for Gini, a carbonated lemon drink, Cadbury Schweppes said. Cadbury Schweppes said 1989 sales of the businesses being acquired was 91.3 million pounds, or $154 million. The acquisition includes two manufacturing plants near Paris and one in Marseilles, Cadbury Schweppes said. The company is not buying a couple other brands and Perrier's bottling rights to Pepsi-Cola products. The deal is conditional on clearance by the French authorities. Cadbury Schweppes said the acquisition is being made by the purchase of shares in Compagnie d'Exploitation de Boissons Refraichissantes, a wholly owned subsidiary of Source Perrier. Perrier executives have said that the company wants to concentrate on its flagship bottled water interests because it expects that market to expand dramatically in coming years. Earlier this year, Perrier withdrew its mineral water from shelves worldwide after some samples of the water were discovered to contain traces of benzene, a naturally occurring chemical said to be cancer inducing. Source Perrier since has reintroduced the mineral water, after carrying out checks and repairs to prevent benzene from entering the finished product.

DOC.HEAD: $12 Billion Development Bank for Eastern Europe Created
DOC.TEXT: Officials from 40 nations on Tuesday signed a treaty creating a $12 billion development bank to finance Eastern Europe's conversion to a market economy. The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development will be a ``catalyst between the capital and know-how of the West and the businesses of the East,'' French President Francois Mitterrand said at a signing ceremony. Mitterand proposed creating the bank last November as Communist regimes crumbled across Eastern Europe. He said the 42 founding nations would not reduce their individual support to Third World countries. The bank is expected to become operation in April 1991. The 12 European Community nations hold a controlling 51 percent interest in the bank, although the United States is the single biggest shareholder with 10 percent interest. Eastern European countries will hold 13.5 percent interest. Under the bank's statutes, two-thirds of the founding members must ratify the treaty before the bank can start lending money to countries in Eastern Europe that have embraced democratic principles. The bank will allocate at least 60 percent of its loans to the private sector in Eastern Europe and the rest to public projects. The five-month negotiations to create the bank were punctuated by disputes over the Soviet Union's membership and the choices for a venue and president. Early in the talks, the United States raised objections to accepting the Soviet Union as a full member. The dispute was resolved by allowing the Soviets to join, but limiting borrowing for three years to the amount of capital they contribute. The Netherlands led a rebellion by six other small Western European countries against plans to locate the bank's headquarters in London under the presidency of Jacques Attali of France, one of Mitterrand's top aides. Dutch officials, saying the big European powers were too dominant in multinational instituions, lobbied in vain to have the bank based in Amsterdam or to have former Dutch Finance Minister Onno Rudding picked as president. In Paris last month, Attali was elected 32-8 over Rudding. The bank's two institutional members, the European Commission and the European Investment Bank, abstained. London received 23 votes as the venue for the bank's headquarters, while Amsterdam and Copenhagen got five votes each. The Dutch kept their finance minister at home Tuesday and sent a low-level delegation to the signing ceremony instead.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Official Urges Push in Key Trade Negotiations
DOC.TEXT: A top U.S. trade official on Tuesday appealed to other rich nations to give a push to trade talks stalled by a dispute between the United States and European nations over government payments to farmers. ``A window of opportunity is now,'' U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said a day before the opening of high-level discussions by trade and finance chiefs of two dozen industrialized nations. ``The possibilities are profound,'' she said. ``It just is going to take the political will to do it.'' The officials are attending the annual meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. They were expected to focus on the Uruguay Round talks, an ambitious effort to revamp the world trading system. The negotiations, which involve about 100 nations, are designed to reduce barriers to trade in agriculture, textiles and other manufactured goods, and in services such as banking and investment. The bargaining began in Uruguay in 1986 and is due to end in December. But a fight between the United States and the 12-nation European Community over agricultural subsidies has raised concern the talks could end in failure. The United States wants the EC, also known as the Common Market, to end import barriers and domestic and export farm subsidies that distort trade. U.S. officials estimate that ending the costly subsidies could boost U.S. farm exports by $11 billion annually. The Common Market give its farmers subsidies through guaranteed prices for many crops. It also assists exporters so more expensive European farm products can compete with lower prices on the world market. The community argues it has begun trimming farm aid but contends it cannot scrap the program entirely. In 1988, European leaders adopted a plan limiting the maximum annual amount of expenditure on price guarantees over five years. U.S. officials have said the measures were not enough to fix what they deem a fundamentally flawed system. ``Agriculture is a key to the success of the round so that the Europeans are going to have to decide whether they want a successful round,'' Mrs. Hills said. She said about $1 trillion worth of commerce was not covered by international rules. Without regulations, countries can use a variety of tactics _ some considered unfair by trading partners _ to sell their goods or protect them from competitors. Mrs. Hills said that ``if we don't get a deal in agriculture, we're not going to build the rules we need in these areas where there are no rules at all.'' ``It's just time that we do have rules, for without rules we are a lawless international trading community,'' she said. The flow of textiles, for instance, is controlled by a network of tariffs and quotas, not by the multinational trading system. The Uruguay Round talks are held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. GATT is a forum and an agreement for promoting freer trade. Officials want to move talks along so lower-level negotiators can reach preliminary agreement in at least some of 15 areas under discussion at a July 23 session in Geneva, Switzerland. OECD members are: Australia, Austria, Belgium, Britain, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, the United States and West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Court Agrees To Hear Case on Interstate Business
With AM-Scotus-Business, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court agreed Monday to decide whether state laws that interfere unconstitutionally with interstate businesses also may violate federal civil rights law. At issue in the Nebraska case is whether states can be forced to pay lawyer fees and other legal expenses for businesses that challenge a state's discriminatory taxes. The case stems from an Ohio trucker's challenge of a Nebraska truck tax. Mark Dennis, the owner of Dennis Trucking in Royalton, Ohio, sued the Nebraska Department of Motor Vehicles in 1984 over taxes imposed on truckers from states that imposed certain types of taxes on Nebraska-based trucking businesses. The taxes, which are no longer in effect, were imposed on trucks from Arizona, Arkansas, Idaho, Nevada, New York, Ohio, Oregon, Pennsylvania and Wyoming. Nebraska courts ruled that the state tax interfered impermissibly with interstate commerce. State officials were barred from collecting the taxes, but the courts refused to treat Dennis' suit as a civil rights case, which would have entitled him to recoup lawyers fees and other expenses. The case is Dennis vs. Higgins, 89-1555.

DOC.HEAD: Interest Rates Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities were mixed in Tuesday's auction. The Treasury Department sold $8.4 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.80 percent, up from 7.74 percent last week. Another $8.4 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.74 percent, down from 7.79 percent last week. The rate on three-month bills was the highest since April 30 when they sold for 7.91 percent. It was the lowest for six-month bills since they averaged 7.68 percent on May 14. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 8.07 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,802.80 and 8.17 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,608.70 In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, slipped to 8.22 percent last week, down from 8.24 percent the previous week.

Prices surged higher in light trading on Wall Street today as technology stocks rebounded from Friday's sharp losses and took the rest of the market along for the ride. Five minutes before the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was up 48.62 to 2,869.54.

DOC.HEAD: EC, Japan Agree To Improve Trade and Other Ties
DOC.TEXT: The European Community and Japan agreed Tuesday to improve trade ties and Japan hinted it soon would give more money to the developing democracies in Eastern Europe. EC estimates show that the 12-nation alliance's trade deficit with Japan grew 5.9 percent in the first nine months of 1989 from the same period a year earlier to reach $23.2 billion. Frans Andriessen, EC commissioner for foreign affairs, said the two sides would form a panel to review bilateral trade that would discuss current problems and try to reach a ``breakthrough'' in the trade imbalance. Japanese foreign minister Taro Nakayama also told journalists Japan was ``directing its assistance to all'' developing democracies in Eastern Europe and said Western aid program to these nations were ``very important.'' The European Commission coordinates aid from 24 industrialized nations, including Japan, for Poland and Hungary. The aid is likely to be extended to five other East and Central European nations at a meeting in July. Andriessen said Japan had a ``firm determination to continue helping the newly developing democracies.'' Kabun Muto, the Japanese minister of international trade and industry, said Japan would try to help Europeans invest in sectors ``welcomed in Japanese markets.'' He did not specify the areas, but said the action would help reduce the trade imbalance.

DOC.HEAD: Dukakis May Seek Sale of Tobacco Investments
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Michael Dukakis may try to make Massachusetts the first state in the nation to divest its stock in tobacco companies, a spokeswoman said Tuesday. ``Right now we're taking a serious look at it,'' Dukakis aide Mari Sullivan said. Dukakis last week asked aides to determine whether he can order the state to divest through an executive order or if the legislature needs to pass a bill, according to a report in Tuesday's Boston Globe. Anti-smoking activists say Massachusetts would be the first state to take such action. Activists have mounted a nationwide effort to push states, universities and hospitals to divest of tobacco holdings. But tobacco industry officials have said they foresee little trouble for their stock, although they do not completely dismiss the efforts. Harvard University last week announced a policy against using any of its nearly $5 billion endowment fund to invest in tobacco companies. The City University of New York has a similar policy. Massachusetts holds $31 million in tobacco stocks as part of a $2.9 billion pension fund managed by Pension Reserves Investments Management. About $24.6 million is invested in Philip Morris Co. Other holdings include U.S. Tobacco, Lowes Corps. and American Brands Inc. In addition, the state treasurer's office has invested millions of dollars in tobacco stocks as part of a retirement fund for teachers and state employees. As of April 30, the investment in tobacco stocks totaled $26.9 million. The anti-tobacco drive had its genesis in a May memo in which Secretary of Human Service Philip Johnston and public health commissioner David Mulligan argued against the investments on health grounds.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Plans To Speed Privatization
DOC.TEXT: East Germany plans to speed privatization of its industry as the nation lays foundations for a switch to capitalism, its economics minister said Tuesday. Economics Minister Gerhard Pohl said only 180 of about 8,000 state-owned industries have been converted into publicly held companies so far. ``If things continue like this, it will take five years'' to reach total privatization, Pohl told reporters in Bonn after meeting with West German Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann. Pohl said the East German parliament is to approve a legal framework by October to quicken the process. He said ``incentives'' were planned for potential investors in now state-owned enterprises, but he did not elaborate. West Germany has been pressuring East Germany to quicken privatization as a source of revenue for economic reconstruction. The two German states are to become a single economic entity as of July 2. West Germany will provide massive financial backing to start the possibly painful transformation of East Germany's centrally planned economy into one based on free-market principles. For its part, East Germany has pledged to start selling off state-owned property to produce its own contributions for economic reconstruction. There are fears privatization could result in eliminating many ailing businesses unable to withstand competition. Pohl and Haussmann discussed plans to build a layer of small and medium-sized companies to form the backbone of the newly restructured East German economy. Pohl said his government plans legislation to increase fivefold the number of trainee positions available in industry starting in September. He said it is too soon to say how many people will lose their jobs as uncompetitive industrial companies go out of business in the economic merger. Pohl said about 1 million people will have to be retrained under the new order.

DOC.HEAD: Brady Sees More Competition for International Aid
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said Tuesday that debt-strapped Third World countries must reform their economies quickly to compete with emerging Eastern European democracies for investors. ``The incentive for the developing countries to move ahead vigorously with reform efforts has taken on additional urgency since the emergence of Eastern Europe,'' Brady said. ``In the aggressive worldwide competition for foreign investment, countries which fail to create an attractive investment environment run a real risk of lost opportunities and falling behind,'' he said. Brady said the competition was for not only investment capital put up by commercial banks and other private interests but also for support from governments such as the United States. ``We are committed to providing maximum possible support for market-oriented reforms in both regions (of Eastern Europe and Latin America),'' Brady said. ``But let's face it, the world is short of capital and governments are shorter still.'' Brady said the Bush administration was channeling its aid both on a country-by-country basis and through multinational lending organizations such as the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. Brady's remarks were made in a speech to the American Chamber of Commerce in London. A text of the comments was released in Washington. Brady praised the progress made under his 15-month-old debt initiative in which commercial banks are provided incentives to forgive a portion of the $1.3 trillion debt being carried by Third World countries. So far, six nations _ Mexico, Venezuela, Costa Rica, Morocco, the Philippines and Chile _ have reached debt-reduction agreements using guidelines of the Brady plan. Brady said the commercial bank debt of the six nations accounts for nearly half the debt of the 16 largest debtor countries and that negotiations are underway to reach debt agreements with several other countries. The crumbling of communist domination in Eastern Europe has grabbed the headlines, but Brady said revolutionary change has also been underway in Latin America. ``Democratic elections in many Latin American nations have produced a new generation of leaders committed to market-based economic reforms,'' he said. Brady addressed business leaders in London before traveling to Paris for a ceremony establishing the new European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, aimed at providing assistance for Eastern Europe. He also was leading the U.S. delegation to the annual meeting of the 24-nation Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development.

Prices surged higher in light trading on Wall Street today as technology stocks rebounded from Friday's sharp losses and helped propel the Dow Jones industrial average to another closing high. The industrials gained 49.57 to close at 2,870.49, surpassing the index's previous high of 2,856.26, set just last Wednesday. Technology issues had pulled the market sharply lower on Friday after Adobe Systems, a computer software company, said its earnings for the second quarter and full fiscal year were likely to fall short of analysts' estimates. But the high-tech stocks did an about-face today, in part because of a Barron's article that said International Business Machines was on an upward course after several laggard years. IBM was among the big gainers today. Rising bond prices, which often help support the stock market by easing concerns about interest rates, did so again today. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond was up about $4 for each $1,000 in face value by late afternoon. Analysts said the stock market sentiment appeared positive despite Friday's 35-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average. They said early signs of weakness brought buyers back into the market. Some computer-program buying was reported today, and prices surged higher late in the session as investors who had been on the sidelines jumped in to avoid being left out of the rally. Analysts noted, however, that with a light volume, it remained to be seen if the gains would hold up.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: hold up.
DOC.TEXT: Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by a margin of about 11 to 4 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 1,107 up, 427 down and 454 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 137.41 million shares, against 120.25 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index rose 2.86 to 196.57. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose 2.72 to 362.56.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower; Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Renewed domestic buying after the long U.S. holiday weekend helped the dollar stage a partial recovery from an earlier foreign selloff, but it still ended lower against most major currencies Tuesday. Gold prices were mixed. Foreign exchange dealers said trading in the dollar was uneventful and interest probably would not perk up before the release Friday of U.S. unemployment data for May. Speculation about possible developments at the summit that begins Thursday between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev kept some currency dealers on the sidelines. ``It was generally a quiet day today with the dollar climbing back from its overnight selloff,'' said Marc Chandler, currency analyst at MMS International in Chicago. ``U.S. dealers took advantage of the dip in the dollar to re-establish long positions.'' The dollar weakened in European trading. Markets in the United States and Britain were closed Monday for a holiday. ``I think the market's taking stock after the holidays,'' said Andrew Elliott, international foreign exchange salesman at Chase Manhattan Bank in London. The dollar's trading day began in Tokyo where the currency closed at 150.70 Japanese yen, up from 149.45 yen late Monday. Later, in London, it rose to 150.95 yen. The dollar continued its rebound in New York, rising to 151.22 yen from 149.40 yen late Friday. Selected late dollar rates in New York, compared with Friday's late quotes, included: 1.6740 West German marks, down from 1.68235; 1.4105 Swiss francs, down from 1.4235; 5.6380 French francs, down from 5.6615; 1,229.50 Italian lire, down from 1,235.50; and 1.17945 Canadian dollar, down from 1.1830. The dollar weakened against the British pound. Sterling strengthened to $1.6945 in New York from late Friday's $1.6905. In London, the pound rose to $1.6953 from Friday's $1.6930. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Monday's late levels, included: 1.6710 West German marks, down from 1.6790; 1.4080 Swiss francs, down from 1.4215; 5.6280 French francs, down from 5.6565; 1.8810 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8910; 1,228.25 Italian lire, down from 1,233.50; and 1.1815 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1828. Gold prices ended with minor losses in domestic trading after posting scattered gains overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, a troy ounce of gold for current delivery shed 80 cents to close at $367.40. Republic National Bank quoted a bid of $366.90 for a troy ounce of gold bullion, 60 cents lower than Friday. In London, gold rose to a late bid of $367.60 a troy ounce from $367.45 late Friday. Monday was a holiday in Britain. In Zurich, gold was unchanged from Monday at a closing bid of $367.50. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 56 cents to close at a bid of $369.48. Silver prices finished lower. Silver for current delivery fell to $5.138 a troy ounce on New York's Comex from $5.215 Friday. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid of $5.17 a troy ounce from $5.23 late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Rebound, Send Blue Chips To New High
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Prices surged higher on Wall Street Tuesday and the Dow Jones industrial average reached another new closing high as technology issues recovered from Friday's losses and took the rest of the stock market along for the ride. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials jumped 49.57 to 2,870.49, surpassing the blue chip barometer's previous closing high of 2,856.26, set just last Wednesday. Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by a margin of about 11 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,107 up, 434 down and 462 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to a relatively light 137.41 million shares, up from 120.25 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 167.06 million shares. Technology issues, which pulled the market sharply lower on Friday, reversed course Tuesday after a Barron's article said International Business Machines was on an upward course after several laggard years. Investors snapped up IBM, bidding the stock up 3{ to 119}. Friday's decline had been triggered by an announcement by the computer software manufacturer Adobe Systems that its earnings for the second quarter and full fiscal year were likely to fall short of analysts' estimates. But Adobe was a winner Tuesday, gaining 2| to close at 37~ in over-the-counter trading. Other high-tech gainers included Digital Equipment, up 2\ to 94}, and Tandy, which gained 1{ to 35{. Both stocks were traded on the NYSE. On the over-the-counter market, Apple Computer rose 1 to 41 and Intel was up 1[ to 48|. Rising bond prices, which often help support the stock market by easing concerns about interest rates, did so again Tuesday. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond was up about $4 for each $1,000 in face value by late afternoon. Analysts were cautiously upbeat about Tuesday's gains, noting that the advance came on relatively light volume. But they said the market showed signs of strength in its ability to shake off Friday's 35-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average. ``After the Adobe decline on Friday, you'd think it would temper the enthusiasm, but it certainly has not,'' said Michael Metz, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Co. ``It shows a very resilient market, with with underinvested participants looking for entry points,'' Metz said. Some computer-program buying was reported Tuesday, and prices surged higher late in the session as bargain hunters and investors who had been on the sidelines jumped in to avoid being left behind. The most actively traded issue on the NYSE was Varity, which rose [ to 3[. Other Big Board gainers included Time Warner, which soared 3] to 109 after another Barron's article called the stock undervalued. Wal-Mart rose 2] to 57{, Disney rose 2[ to 119}, and Bristol Myers Squibb was up 1[ to 61~. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market gained $45.179 billion, or 1.33 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks advanced 2.86 to 196.57. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 7.68 to 421.31, and S&P's 500-stock composite index gained 6.07 to 360.65. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market picked up 3.82 to 457.51. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 362.56, up 2.72.

DOC.HEAD: Dow Jones Average Jumps Nearly 50 Points to New High
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices surged Tuesday in light trading as technology issues rebounded from Friday's sharp losses and helped propel the Dow Jones industrial average to another closing high. The Dow finished up 49.57 at 2,870.49, surpassing the widely watched index's previous record close of 2,856.26, set last Wednesday. Broader market indicators also jumped higher and nearly three stocks rose in price for every one that fell on the New York Stock Exchange. Technology stocks pulled the market sharply lower Friday after Adobe Systems, a computer software company, said its earnings were likely to fall short of analysts' estimates. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 35 points on Friday. But high-tech stocks did an about-face Tuesday. Analysts said the rebound stemmed partly from an article in Barron's magazine that said International Business Machines Corp. was on an upward course after several laggard years. IBM, a key component of the Dow industrial average, was among the big gainers Tuesday. Declining interest rates in the bond market also helped support stocks by easing concerns about higher interest rates. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell to 8.62 percent from 8.66 percent Friday. Tuesday's climb occurred in relatively light trading volume. NYSE volume totaled 137.41 million shares, compared with 120.25 million on Friday ahead of the three-day Memorial Day weekend.

DOC.HEAD: Copper Futures Drop in Reaction to Labor Accord
DOC.TEXT: Copper futures prices plunged Tuesday on New York's Commodity Exchange as traders reacted to a labor accord reached last week between Kennecott Corp. and its workers. On other markets, grain and soybean futures were mostly lower, livestock and pork futures were higher, energy futures gained and precious metals futures dropped. Last week's agreement between Kennecott and the United Steelworkers union, which represents the mining company's workers, proved to be a drag on copper futures. Copper settled 2.10 cents to 4.10 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in May at $1.1585 a pound. There had been been fears that a dispute over wages and benefits could result in strikes in the copper industry, said Jim Steel, an analyst with Refco Inc. in New York. The union settlement reduced the possibility of supply disruptions had a contract agreement failed to materialize before the June 30 expiration of the previous contract, Steel said. The agreement makes it more likely that the other copper producers will reach accords with their unions, he said. Grain and soybean futures were mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybean prices fell sharply as professional selling set in during late trading. The demand for soybeans and soybean products has been negligible, said analyst Joel Karlin of Research Department Inc. ``What demand there has been is being supplied by sales in South America,'' Karlin said. He said soybean futures also were pressured by continued wet weather in the Midwest that has delayed corn planting. Forecasts have called for more rain later this week. Karlin said traders are concerned that the longer corn planting is delayed, the more likely the acreage given over to soybeans will increase. Corn takes longer than soybeans to mature. The weather outlook offered some support to corn futures, as did scattered export business, Karlin said. Wheat prices gained on ideas among traders that wheat had been oversold in recent sessions, analysts said. Wheat was 4{ cents to 6 cents higher with July at $3.35 a bushel; corn was 1\ cents lower to 2 cents higher with July at $2.84\ a bushel; oats were 7 cents to 8\ cents lower with July at $1.46\ cents a bushel; soybeans were 8 cents to 14} cents lower with July at $6.06 a bushel. Thestrength of meat futures sent livestock and pork prices higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Frozen pork belly futures closed up the 200 point limit in the wake of the U.S. Agriculture Department's monthly cold storage report, released Friday, which showed light movement of pork bellies into cold storage. Hog futures were higher, gaining support from bellies and higher cash prices. Cattle futures were boosted by spillover buying from the pork pits. Live cattle were .10 cent lower to .55 cent higher with June at 74.07 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .20 cent higher with August at 83.90 cents a pound; hogs were .43 cent to 1.30 cents higher with June at 67.25 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .70 cent to 2 cents higher with July at 67.85 cents a pound. Energy futures were higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange after rallying from a steep selloff in earlier trading. Analysts attributed the early selloff to an oversupply of crude oil. However, unleaded gasoline led a comeback on revived buying interest by major oil companies in the U.S. Gulf Coast region and the firming of the European gasoline market, said Jim Ritterbusch, an analyst with PaineWebber Inc. in Chicago. West Texas Intermediate crude oil was 6 cents to 28 cents higher with July at $17.98 a barrel; heating oil was .32 cent to .58 cent higher with June at 50.24 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .85 cent to 2.38 cents higher with the June contract at 65.79 cents a gallon. Precious metals futures were lower on the Comex, with followthrough selling of silver futures from Friday's weak close pulling gold lower. Gold was 80 cents to $1.10 lower with June at $367.40 a troy ounce. Silver was 7.7 cents to 8.5 cents lower with May at $5.138 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Airlines, Lufthansa, Nissho Iwai Acquire Stake in Air Express Company
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf pvs, DHL International... to DELETE incorrect reference to DHL Corp. and clarify.
DOC.TEXT: DHL International Ltd. said Tuesday that Japan Airlines, Lufthansa and the Japanese trading company Nissho Iwai will acquire a minority stake in the air express service company. Japan Airlines and Lufthansa each will get a 5 percent stake in DHL with an option to buy up to 25 percent within 18 months. Nissho Iwai will acquire a 2.5 percent interest with an option for up to 7.5 percent. The company said negotiations were under way for selling a small stake in DHL Corp., based in Redwood City, Calif., but no agreement had been reached. Patrick Lupo, chief executive of DHL Worldwide Express in Brussels, said the deal would allow DHL to expand air, hub and gateway operations. ``This alliance will enable us to keep pace with market growth in Europe and Asia,'' he said. DHL said that its network carried over 50 million international shipments last year. The network has over 24,000 employees worldwide and operates 1,350 service centers in 184 countries. DHL said 1990 revenue will top $1.8 billion. DHL International Ltd., part of the DHL Worldwide Express Network, operates in all areas of the world outside the United States. DHL Corp., another unit of the DHL Worldwide Express Network, operates the business in the United States and its territories.

DOC.HEAD: Jovanovich Resigns as Chairman at HBJ, Succeeded by Herrington
Laserphoto planned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf pvs, Wall Street ... to UPDATE with closing stock price. Picks up 12th graf pvs, William Jovanovich ...
DOC.TEXT: Chairman William Jovanovich resigned Tuesday from textbook publisher Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., three years after orchestrating a recapitalization that kept the company independent but left it heavily in debt. ``Forty-three years is enough,'' the 70-year-old Jovanovich said in stepping down from his last major corporate assignment at the company he joined as a textbook salesman and editor in 1947. He had been disengaging himself from the company over the past two years, stepping down earlier as president and chief executive. Jovanovich will be succeeded as chairman by former U.S. energy secretary John S. Herrington, 51, who has been on the board of directors for a year. His son, Peter Jovanovich, 41, was named president and chief executive late last year and was named Tuesday as chairman of the executive committee, another post the elder Jovanovich is leaving. Analysts said they expect no major shifts in direction for the company, which is grappling with how to handle a debt burden that is expected to become a more serious problem over the next few years as cash dividends come due. ``I don't see where this makes a whole lot of difference,'' said Andrew Herenstein, who follows the company for the investment firm Delaware Bay Co. in New York. ``There still has to be some kind of restructuring.'' Wall Street also shrugged off the change. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Harcourt finished unchanged at $3.12{ a share. William Jovanovich joined Harcourt Brace & Co. as a book salesman and editor in 1947 and built it into one of the nation's leading publishers of textbooks as well a premier medical and professional publisher. When he became president and chief executive in 1954, the company had annual sales of $8 million and employed 125 people. Last year, it posted revenue of $1.3 billion and employed 6,000 people. Although he owned less than 2 percent of the company's stock, Jovanovich exercised unusually strong control over the company. It added his name to its own in 1970 when Jovanovich added chairman to his list of titles. He was seen within the industry as a maverick, moving the company to Orlando, Fla., from New York in 1983 and shunning the usual trade associations. ``Forty-three years is enough, especially since I now can devote my time to editing books and writing them,'' he said in announcing his resignation. But Jovanovich leaves the company with $1.6 billion in debt incurred in a 1987 recapitalization undertaken to avoid a takeover bid from British publisher Robert Maxwell. Many analysts say the company generates enough cash to meet its interest obligations over the next two years. But they warn that trouble could develop in 1992 when cash payments start coming due on preferred stock and debt which now are issuing additional securities as dividends. In an effort to pare its debt, Harcourt sold its theme park business to Anheuser-Busch Cos. for $1.1 billion last year. But the price disappointed some analysts. That sale helped the company post a profit of $72.1 million, or 17 cents a shsre, in 1989 on revenue of $1.34 billion, compared with a loss of $53.4 million, or $2.03 a share, on revenue of $1.27 billion a year earlier. More recently, HBJ was reported to have been in talks on selling more assets to Thomson Corp., the Canadian publisher. The company never confirmed who it was talking with, but announced May 9 that it had terminated talks on selling assets and public debt to a third party. In addition to its publishing operations, Harcourt has interests in the insurance business, which accounted for one-third of its 1989 revenue. Herrington, 51, has served as a member of the Harcourt board since May 1989, and has served on its executive and finance committees. He served as energy secretary in the Reagan administration from February 1985 to January 1989 and was assistant secretary of the Navy from 1981 to 1983. Herrington called Jovanovich ``an American publishing legend, a pioneer in educational technology and an industry giant who built the best independent publishing house in America.'' In a telephone interview, Herrington said he became a candidate for the job after the elder Jovanovich asked him to run for it. ``I think it's going to be a team effort between Peter and I,'' he said, adding he brings management experience honed in overseeing the sprawling Energy Department to the job. ``We are looking at all options. We are interested in keeping this company viable, independent and American,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Close Higher
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices rose Tuesday, led by a strong jump in unleaded gasoline due to what analysts said were internal market factors and concerns about future gas supplies. The June contract for wholesale unleaded gasoline rose 2.38 cents to 65.79 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange, on top of Friday's 0.18 cent increase. The July contract increased 1.96 cents to 62.96 cents a gallon. John Hill, a vice president at Merrill Lynch Energy Futures, said the increase was prompted partly by continued buying among major oil companies in the Gulf Coast market. He also said there was concern that some refineries taken off line for routine maintenance would not return to full production as fast as originally expected. ``Gasoline output's just a little behind where we thought it would be,'' he said. ``(The refineries) are coming back on, but they're coming back on a little more slowly than we anticipated.'' Among other refined products traded on the Merc, the June contract for home heating oil rose 0.58 cent a gallon to 50.24 cents, after dropping 0.15 cent on Friday. Later months showed slightly smaller increases. Bob Baker, senior energy analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said the price rose on the coattails of the increase in unleaded gasoline. The July contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, rose 18 cents to $17.98 a 42-gallon barrel on the Mercantile Exchange following a 3-cent drop Friday. Later contract months showed small increases. Analysts said the price was bouncing back after declines last week that were spurred by renewed concerns of a worldwide oil glut. Natural gas prices declined. The July contract fell to $1.585 per 1,000 cubic feet from $1.592 Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Shareholder Sues Software Company After Stock-Price Plunge
DOC.TEXT: A stockholder of Adobe Systems Inc. has sued the computer software company and its top officers over a 30 percent plunge in its stock price, claiming fraud and stock manipulation, it was disclosed Tuesday. The U.S. District Court suit was filed Friday after the price of Adobe's stock, which is traded over the counter, dropped by $15.25 a share to $35.25 in reaction to the previous day's report by the company that second-quarter earnings would be 27 to 35 cents a share, far below previous projections. Adobe closed at $37.875 a share Tuesday in continued heavy selling. Stockholder Donald A. Wells Jr. said in the suit that Adobe's top officers knew in March that the company's stock price was inflated but issued a series of misleadingly optimistic statements to the public. Wells cited a May 2 statement by John E. Warnock, Adobe's chairman and president, that the company would continue to demonstrate solid rates of growth and had maintained its leadership position in its industry. Adobe's software is used to control computer printers. Warnock also stated that sales to Apple Computer Inc., Adobe's leading customer, had not slowed, despite knowing that Apple planned to use a competitor's product in its future laser printers and that sales to Apple would plummet, Wells charges. The suit said Warnock and four other officers sold 316,000 shares of Adobe stock between March 6 and last Thursday, at prices they knew were inflated. Meanwhile, Wells and other members of the public relied on the alleged misstatements by the company in buying the stock, the suit said. Wells, who said he and his retirement plan owned 500 shares of Adobe, seeks to sue on behalf of all who bought company stock during the period. No specific amount of damages is claimed, but the suit says the stock's aggregate value dropped by more than $300 million during Friday's selloff. Adobe, based in Mountain View, issued a statement Tuesday saying it was ``not unusual for companies having announced a drop in their income, as we did, to receive one or more similar complaints.'' ``We also believe the lawsuit is completely without merit and we intend to vigorously contest the action,'' the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Say Public Wants Safer Food After Chernobyl
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet health official said Tuesday that consumers in his country are demanding safer food after the accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power station. ``In the last few years there has been a lot of discussion as to the information given to people as to what they eat, drink and breathe, and it has produced a lot of interest and activity in ecology,'' Alexander Kondrusev, vice minister of health, said at a conference. ``People do not want to eat the contaminated foods and they express it forcefully,'' he said. Kondrusev and Victor Tutelyan, an official with the Soviet Academy of Medical Scientists, spoke at the opening of the International Conference on Food Safety at Michigan State University. Tutelyan said some meat, milk and potatoes from a 6,200-square-mile area near Chernobyl are still contaminated with radiation. He said 4 million people live in the area. ``It will be a long time before it will be possible to obtain milk that meets current safety standards and is acceptable for use,'' he said. High radiation levels began showing up in Soviet milk two or three days after the April 26, 1986, explosion at the nuclear power station in Chernobyl, about 80 miles north of Kiev. Two jet-like emissions of radioactive material spewed into the air, followed for 10 days by a cloud of radioactive gases, Tutelyan said. He said Soviet officials attempted to protect the public by moving cattle into barns so that they would not graze in pastures contaminated by the fallout. Some citizens rejected the government's countermeasures. Nearly 30 people, mostly elderly farmers, insisted on leaving their milk cows outdoors to graze on contaminated grass. Tutelyan said the farmers, who were 70 or older, decided not to worry about developing cancer in 20 years. Meat contaminated with radiation was buried in a 20-mile zone around Chernobyl, but Tutelyan said new technology has been developed to decontaminate meat. He also said milk can be made into butter because the radioactive contaminants are concentrated in the water portion of the milk and can be separated. In 1986, 20 percent to 30 percent of milk, meat, greens and fruits produced near Chernobyl had to be discarded, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Names American Express Exec To Run Brokerage Unit
DOC.TEXT: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., continuing a major overhaul, on Tuesday named an executive from parent American Express Co. to run the troubled firm's retail brokerage and asset management units. The move is the latest step by American Express to reshape the nation's second-largest securities firm, which has stumbled badly following a huge expansion in the 1980s. Shearson is expected in coming days to announce a reorganization that could split its investment banking business from its retail brokerage network, possibly including the resurrection of the venerable Lehman Brothers name. In what analysts called a precursor to the division, Shearsonsaid Tuesday that Jonathan S. Linen would become president and chief executive of the firm's retail brokerage and assest management businesses starting next week. Linen, 46, currently is president and chief executive of American Express' direct marketing and travelers checks group, which includes investment products, life insurance, merchandising and publishing businesses. Linen was described as a close associate of American Express Chairman James D. Robinson III, who has led the restructuring at Shearson. Shearson also said that Hardwick Simmons, a respected industry figure who had run the firm's brokerage division, had resigned. Simmons, former head of the Securities Industry Association, the industry's main trade group, could not immediately be reached for comment. American Express in recent months has infused more than $1 billion in capital into Shearson and is buying all of the brokerage's remaining common stock. American Express now holds 61 percent of Shearson. Robinson earlier this year installed Howard L. Clark Jr., then American Express' chief financial officer, as Shearson's chairman and chief executive after ousting Peter A. Cohen, a Wall Street whiz who led Shearson's growth. The firm expanded in the last decade during a period of great deal making activity and unprecedented profits. Shearson in 1984 took over the respected Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. investment bank in 1984. Shearson lost an industry record $915 million in the first quarter, partly because of expenses to pay for a restructuring tht included about 2,000 layoffs. Most Wall Street firms have been forced to cut back because of an industry slowdown since the 1987 stock market crash. Linen has no direct experience in the securities business, but is viewed as an effective trouble-shooter during 21 years at American Express. He will be responsible for running Shearson's retail network of about 10,000 brokers, second in number only to Merrill Lynch & Co. Shearson's retail network had about $180 billion of assets held in private accounts at the end of the first quarter and about $93 billion under management for pension funds, corporations and institutional clients. Analysts said they did not necessarily believe Linen's lack of experience on Wall Street would be a handicap. They said his first task would be to renew confidence at the firm among its retail brokers. Linen's marketing background also could help in assessing what financial products the firm is selling and their cost, they said. ``The primary focus right now is to get Shearson straightened out,'' said Lawrence Eckenfelder, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in San Francisco. ``Some people say why bring in another person from the outside. On the other hand the guys that had been running it hadn't been doing a very good job.'' Linen came to Shearson in 1969 as assistant to the chairman, who was then Clark's father, Howard Clark Sr. He held various positions, including president of the U.S. travel services division from 1980 to 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Brokerage Unit Files for Chapter 11
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. on Tuesday joined its parent company and filed for bankruptcy court protection, saying it hoped to come back as an operating entity on Wall Street. Drexel said the filing under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy law was a step to enable the firm to emerge from court protection alive, but it did not specify what kind of business it would operate. As part of the plan, Drexel named John F. Sorte as chief executive. He succeeded Frederick H. Joseph, who led the firm through its rapid rise in the 1980s under the growth of junk bonds pioneered by Michael Milken. Sorte, 42, who will take over Drexel's day-to-day operations, was co-head of the firm's corporate finance department and a member of its executive committee. Joseph will remain as president of the firm's parent, Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., which sought bankruptcy protection Feb. 13. Previously, it had been expected the Drexel would simply liquidate all of its operations even though most of its subsidiaries were never covered by the parent's bankruptcy filing. In Tuesday's filing, made in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, Drexel said ``it is anticipated that a viable reorganized entity will emerge.'' Drexel said 14 other smaller subsidiaries of the parent company also filed for bankruptcy protection. The company said the filing would allow the units ``to utilize and realize the full value of their respective assets.'' The filing allows all of Drexel's operations to reorganize under court protection, a move that would have been difficult had only the parent been in bankruptcy proceedings. It also freezes outstanding litigation against any of the subsidiaries. Federal guidelines generally prohibit investment firms that do business with the public from seeking bankruptcy protection. But Drexel officials said the firm was able to make the filing because it no longer had any client accounts. A revived Drexel would not be expected to deal with the public but could seek to manage its existing stock and junk bond holdings and advise clients, including companies that issued junk bonds under Drexel's auspices. Drexel said in a statement that it now has 500 employees, down from 5,400 when the parent filed for bankruptcy and more than 10,000 at its peak in the mid-1980s. In a court filing earlier this month, Drexel said it had total assets of $3.26 billion and liabilities of $2.8 billion as of April 30. That was down from $54 billion at the time of the parent's bankruptcy filing. Drexel said Tuesday it has sold off 87.4 percent of its securities portfolio. Spokesman Steven Anreder said the firm still holds about $1 billion in securities, mostly hard-to-sell junk bonds that have been battered by a downturn in that market since last fall. Drexel made millions in the 1980s in large part because of its prowess issuing risky high-yield bonds used by expansion-minded companies and for hostile takeovers. But the firm last year pleaded guilty to six felonies and agreed to pay $650 million to settle widespread securities law vioilations following a lengthy government investigation. Milken admitted to six felonies and agreed to pay $600 million in penalties last month.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Years Later, Reader Wins Contest for Predicting Prices, Trends
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT that late editor was Forbes, not Forbes Jr.
DOC.TEXT: A Forbes magazine reader won $10,000 for predictions made in 1980 on such things as the cost of a Big Mac, the prime rate and the number of pro football teams at the end of the decade, the magazine said Tuesday. Jack Rankin Jr. of Round Hill, Va., out-predicted 660 readers who entered the contest announced in the Oct. 27, 1980, issue of Forbes, the magazine said. The magazine's late editor, Malcolm Forbes, wrote in his Fact & Comment column that he would give $10,000 to the reader who most accurately forecast 35 items 10 years in the future. ``If you're so smart, here's $10,000,'' Forbes wrote. ``All you have to do between now and this year's end is to send me your estimates of what the numbers will be for these 35 items at the end of the decade _ Dec. 31, 1989.'' Forbes magazine established a point system for grading the entries, each receiving zero to 10 points per item based on nearness to the actual figure. Rankin, 59, had one perfect score, for his exact estimate of the number of pro football teams _ unchanged from 1979 at 28 _ and earned points in 22 of the other categories, Forbes said. Rankin, a communications support group manager for Honeywell Federal Systems in McLean, Va., also was close to the mark for the price of a Big Mac _ he forecast $1.60, while Forbes said it was $1.79 at the end of last year. But in some categories, Rankin was way off. He forecast the Dow Jones industrial average would be 1,150; it was 2,753 on Dec. 31. He said the price of a barrel of Saudi crude oil would be $59; it was $18.40. Other categories included the number of computers in the United States (52.4 million, up from 300,000), the number of shopping malls (more than 34,000 from 19,200), the price of an ounce of gold ($399 from $525), the national debt ($3 trillion from $845 billion) and the number of lawyers (725,574 from 464,851). Malcolm Steve Forbes Jr., editor-in-chief of the magazine, announced another contest for the next decade in the magazine's June 11 issue. The winner this time will receive $100,000. His advice to entrants: Don't assume today's trends will continue.

DOC.HEAD: Group Seeks to Represent Eastern Pilots in Bargaining
DOC.TEXT: A recently formed pilots association at Eastern Airlines moved Tuesday for an election that it hopes will make it the pilots' bargaining agent, replacing the union that struck the carrier last year. The Eastern Pilots Association said it represents 93 percent of the airline's 1,775 flying pilots while the Air Line Pilots Association, the current bargaining agent, represents less than 5 percent. Thomas Cooper, chairman of the EPA steering committee, said ALPA has lost touch with Eastern's working pilots after leading them off the job in sympathy with striking Machinists last year. ``Our organization better represents the real interests of the men and women who are flying Eastern's planes every day,'' Cooper said in a statement. ``The fairest way for the pilots of Eastern to determine the destiny of their own careers and the future of Eastern is to have an election.'' The EPA is seeking immediate action on its application for an election to the National Mediation Board in Washington. ALPA called off its walkout late last year but most of its members remain without jobs. Eastern is flying with pilots who crossed picket lines and with non-union pilots who were hired during the strike. ALPA's membership includes an estimated 1,200 to 1,400 Eastern pilots who are not working. ``Under the Railway Labor Act, ALPA is the legal bargaining agent for all Eastern pilots, and the actions taken today by the EPA do not in any way affect that representation,'' ALPA spokesman Lou Baldwin said in a statement. The airline had no comment, an Eastern spokesman said. Meanwhile, Eastern said Tuesday it will offer special discount fares during June ranging from $49 to $99 each way for youngsters 12 to 21 and people 62 and older. The mileage-based fares are $49 one way for flights up to 300 miles; $69 for 301-1,200 miles; and $99 for trips over 1,200 miles. Rates are $10 more each way during peak travel times. Eastern said the fares are available in all domestic markets and good for travel beginning May 30. Travel must be completed by June 27. No advance purchase is necessary and all tickets are fully refundable. A three-day minimum stay is required.

DOC.HEAD: Controversial Plant Lights Homes with Nuclear Power for First Time
DOC.TEXT: The long-delayed Seabrook plant lit up homes with nuclear power for the first time Tuesday night as operators began gearing up toward full operation, officials said. The plant was operating at 15 percent capacity and producing about 75 megawatts of electricity, enough to supply 65,000 homes, when it was connected to the New England power grid just after 8 p.m., officials said. The hookup occurred as part of a series of tests to ready the plant for full operation by mid-summer, spokesman Ron Sher said. ``By making this initial connection ... we're now on our way toward making a major contribution to New England's long-term energy supplies,'' Edward Brown, president of plant operator New Hampshire Yankee, said in the news release. Sher said the plant would produce electricity into the early morning hours and then be disconnected from the power grid so equipment can be tested. Operators will connect and disconnect the generator from the grid repeatedly during the next several weeks of testing. At full power, Seabrook will generate 1,150 megawatts, enough to supply 1 million homes, New Hampshire Yankee has said. The plant first produced electricity during tests in November 1985, before it received an operating license, but that was non-nuclear power generated by the system's heater and pumps. The $6.5 billion plant was licensed in March after years of delays. Opponents who claim the plant is unsafe and that the surrounding area cannot be evacuated in an emergency have fought the reactor in the courts, through the regulatory process and in mass demonstrations since construction began in 1976. The long delays and rising costs _ the original cost was projected at less than $1 billion _ forced its lead owner, Public Service Co. of New Hampshire, into bankruptcy court in January 1988. Public Service is in the process of being taken over by Northeast Utilities of Connecticut.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Eases, Stocks Gain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei, dollar, comments
DOC.TEXT: The dollar moved lower against the yen Wednesday morning, reversing its opening gains, while stocks recovered from early losses to post moderate gains. The dollar closed the morning session at 150.55 yen, down from Tuesday's close of 150.70 yen. After opening stronger at 151.05 yen, the U.S. currency ranged between 151.38 yen and 150.55 yen. The yen's movements against the dollar continued to dominate stock trading, with stocks opening lower in line with the currency's early weakness and then advancing as the yen recovered. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average rose 157.55 points, or 0.48 percent, ending the morning session at 32,975.22. The Nikkei index lost 373.94 points on Tuesday. A trader with Nomura Securities Co. said the yen's early weakness against the dollar discouraged market players and sent the index plunging more than 350 points before rebounding at midmorning. Buying of technology issues that are expected to benefit from a weaker yen helped the market recover, said the dealer, who spoke on condition of anonymity. In currency dealings, the dollar strengthened to 151.60 yen in Sydney market earlier Wednesday and then was pushed down to around 150.50 yen in Tokyo on profit-taking, said Masato Hayashi, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. The dollar rose earlier because ``market players were mainly selling the yen to buy back the (West German) mark that had been oversold against the yen,'' he said. Dollar-yen dealing was relatively inactive ahead of the announcement of May U.S. unemployment figures on Friday, he said. ``Currently, there is little yen-buying incentive here,'' Hayashi said. The benchmark No.119 10-year Japanese government bond fell to 88.02 points from Tuesday's close of 88.51. That boosted the yield to 6.965 percent from 6.865 percent.
